Title: Interview with Steve Paxton
Abstract: June Johnston interviews Steve Paxton about the origins and nature of Contact Improvisation, discussing its evolution from 1961 and the importance of physical and interpersonal contact.
Text: Interview with Steve Paxton by June Johnston June Johnston: Steve, could you tell me what happened in the instant of innovation when you suddenly discovered you had something? Steve Paxton: (laughs) No, I couldn't. That instant began for me probably in 1961 and is still continuing. It's simply part of the process of exploration that dance work has been for me. There was not an instant. There were many, many years of classes, compiling of material from different movement forms. There was a time when several of us in v ermont who were working on this form decided to name it. I was actively looking for a name for an '.it' that we· obviously were all involved with. June: Could you say what that 'it' was? Steve: Well, Contact Improvisation was chosen as a name because it expresses it well. It's a strange name, I think, but it it hasn't seemed to have hampered it at all because it is accurate. It is definitely a physical art and you deal with the other person physically but there's also all the other aspects of person that are contacting each other. Volume 4 1979 CQICI Sourcebook 1

Title: A SHORT HISTORY
Abstract: This article provides a brief history of Contact Improvisation, tracing its origins from Steve Paxton's work in 1972 to the formation of ReUnion and the establishment of Contact Quarterly.
Text: A SHORT HISTORY During a Grand Union residency at Oberlin College in January 1972, Steve Paxton made a work for 11 men in which they threw, caught, flung, collided and fell among one another continuously for l 0 minutes. Then they stood for a few minutes. The dance was called 'Magnesium'. That spring, while teaching at Bennington College, Steve met with two studentsLeon Felder and Nita Little-who had been stimulated by a similar curiosity with the physical forces that effect motion, experimenting with lifting, falling and exchanging weight with mutual support. In June 1972, with funding from Change, Inc., Steve gathered about 15 "of the best athletes that I had run into in the course of a year or two of teaching," both men and women, to explore the principles and potential of communication first evident in 'Magnesium'. The first week was spent in rehearsal. The 2nd week was a public showing of the working process, 5 hours daily, at the Weber Gallery in NYC. This event was called Contact Improvisation. Among the participants were Laura Chapmen, Steve Christiansen (video), Barbara Dilley, Leon Felder, Mary Fulkerson, Danny Lepkoff, Nita Little, Alice Lusterman, Curt Siddall, Nancy Stark Smith, Nancy Topf and David Woodberry. Inspired by this event, the work continued. A tour in early 1973 brought Steve Paxton, Curt Siddall, Nancy Stark Smith, Nita Little and Karen Radler to the West Coast, performing and leading workshops in Contact Improvisation under the name, 'You Come, We'll Show You What We Do'. The ambience of the work in performance continued to be informal: no music, special lighting or costume, audiences in the round, duets and trios interspersed with solo dancing. In June 1973, Steve brought a group to Europe for the first time to perform Contact at L' Attico Gallery in Rome. By 1974, Nita, Curt and Nancy were in the San Francisco Bay Area teaching the form to others, creating more dance-mates and developing a context for the work's expansion. Joined by Steve Paxton, in 1975 they formed ReUnion, the first formal Contact Improvisation company, meeting once a year to tour the West Coast with performances and classes. The continuing dialogue concerning Contact's development soon included hundreds of other individuals and groups. The Contact Newsletter (now Contact Quarterly) was initiated by ReUnion in 1975, edited and produced by Nancy Stark Smith, to foster communication among the geographically dispersed teachers, performers and practitioners of Contact. Inspired by the work, the work continues. ~ Lisa Nelson & Nancy Stark Smith 2 CQ/CI Sourcebook Susan Milani and Alan Gardner Volume 5 1979-80

Title: NOTES AFTER TEACHING SECOND CLASS IN MISSOULA MONT ANA
Abstract: Danny Lepkoff reflects on teaching Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of the spirit within the form and the need to create a space for free play and exploration.
Text: DANNY LEPKOFF: Volume 1 1975-76 NOTES AFTER TEACHING SECOND CLASS IN MISSOULA MONT ANA After teaching I walked home and sat and talked with Janet I realized today that I am not interested in the form of Contact Improvisation but in the spirit the form contains this spirit is a real thing and with out the spirit Contact turns into something like Judo the spirit is a living work process that is not necessarily confined to Contact Improvisation but is a way of playing of attaining the freedom to play with yourself and others with a tree or a pole. I want to drum up this spirit. In teaching Contact I feel two things: 1. That I know and understand the form but in order to convey the spirit through the form I must find a something to teach which is not outside to myself but is me 2. I've come here to Missoula and I feel that the form "Contact" is pretty much com man knowledge or thought to be by .._, alot of people and there are lots of expectations to what it is "Get out the mats do a round robin" So I think in order to teach the spirit of contact I cannot teach Contact. I want to create a situation in which free play FREE PLAY can happen Where a certain concentration is going with a certain practice and nothing happens until something is happening I want to create a situation where 1 nothing happens (an exhausted state) AND 2 (when you dont know whats gonna happen is happening) SO TEACH A CLASS IN WHICH YOU REACH A STATE WHERE NOTHING IS HAPPENING BUT POSSIBILITIES ARE OPEN THATS ALL YOU HAVE TO DO ------SURPRISES -VOICE WORK --SHOUT A WORD TO EACH OTHER---GO OUT AND TAKE A WALK AROUND THE ROOM-----Volume 1 1975-76 CQICI Sourcebook 3

Title: DARTINGTON MARCH:
Abstract: Steve Paxton discusses the connection between Mary Fulkerson's Anatomical Release work and Contact Improvisation, noting the ease with which Fulkerson's students assimilate Contact due to her focus on anatomical awareness and efficient movement patterns.
Text: DARTINGTON MARCH: Images. Spent time with Mary Fulkerson, teaching and taking classes. Several of our number [contacters] have studied with Mary, and she has spent time in Contact, though she prefers her own work as a basis from which to teach. However, the continuing juxtaposition of her Anatomical Release work and Contact has provoked a headful of thought; her students in England and those from Rochester, N.Y. take to Contact with remarkable ease compared to other groups in the U.S. This ease of assimilation is of interest. While the students are lying down, crawling, walking or running, Mary Fulkerson speaks ritually, encouraging greater sensitivity to alignment and efficient patterns in the body. The manner of presentation tends to by-pass the though~ of the listener. The listener is preoccupied with moving or relaxing at the time, and the ritualization has a lulling effect, soothing in tone and timing. The images she provides are simplified anatomical 'cartoons' of functioning anatomy as opposed to intellectual or visual anatomy. These images describe .sensations their location in the body and possible directions in which they might move. The students then assimilate material directly from their own sensations, culled from releasing unnecessary tension, work, strain. Mary Fulkerson finds a rare balance of authority and humility which gives fundamental weight to her voice without usurping the motivation of the student and avoiding their rebellion or fascination. Nor does her voice question the integrity of the sensations unique to each student. Their confidence in the process gathers momentum with the growth of awareness of the functional anatomy, and soon, non-anatomical images can be simply physicalized. Earlier in the process however, before these channels become clear, an illogical image would more likely provoke bewilderment, scorn, or intellectual interest, than movement. The parallel is with the Contact 'stand': The mind of the listener is encouraged to become a receiving instrument. Fulkerson's images further provide guidance to sensations which improve function. The stand in Contact isused to remove the habitual masking of the forces-that-be by relaxing the listener into states of mind where time, gravity, mass and inertia are apparent, where balance is seen as subtle movement, and social expectations in partnering can be dropped; it is possible to talk directly to the body~ and for the listener to listen directly with the body. Each person can hone and direct real physical sensations into their own most direct & efficient dance. As Mary Fulkerson is currently presenting her work at Dartingtim College (Devon, England) it is used as a first step providing the student with a map into private anatomical sensations and improvements. Great care has been given to the anatomical propriety of the images, because in this work, the idea each person's mind holds of their body is seen as crucial to the awareness each develops. Beyond Mary Fulkerson's work there is a question for the student at Dartington. What to do with the vocabulary they have sensed and the improvements they find in their use of the body? Many possibilities exist, and one path, that of Contact, seems quite compatible; moving from the interior of one's functioning anatomy, to functioning with another. I hope in the coming years more of us have an opportunity to sample this connection. STEVE PAXTON 4 CQ/CI Sourcebook Volume 1 1975-76

Title: CHRISTIE SVANE
Abstract: Christie Svane reflects on Contact Improvisation as a surrender to surfaces and attention to the actual, contrasting it with the Western dance preoccupation with leaps and the notion of escape from Earth's hold.
Text: Nijinsky, rockets, platform shoes, Notre Dame, top-hats, the World Trade towers, every spire, every pedestal, the pre-occupation of Western dance with leaps, the whole notion of Heaven. Amidst mania for escape, (when did it begin?) from Earth's hold on us, Contact Improvisation springs up and spreads love of the fall. Instead of the rebellion of blast-offs, there is a surrender of surfaces. The lust for the "impossible," a moon-landing, a test-tube child, we replace with attention to the actual. "Find out what the body does; not what you can make it do." The crusade to capture a There is abandoned, leaving us here, to fall, and roll and fly. Christie Svane

Title: EDITOR LETTER
Abstract: Nancy Stark Smith introduces the Contact Quarterly, explaining its voluntary nature, the collaborative spirit of Free Association, and the shared experiential knowledge of Contact Improvisation that unites its contributors.
Text: Welcome. Yes; you're in the right place. The Contact Newsletter has moved on to become the Contact Quarterly a publication put out voluntarily by Free Association four times a year (seasonally). Free Association isn't an official name for those of us behind the Quarterly, but a term that catches the spirit of our collaboration. Our personnel shifts with each issue depending on (1) which coast is hosting the production, and (2) the availability and interest of local contacters for work on the production. Our common center is a working and experiential knowledge of Contact Improvisation. So far, everyone who has 'freely associated' on any of the Newsletter/Quarterly publications has had some experience with this new, now almost five-year-old, dance-movement-meditation-art-sport-event-piece. On that basic ground we 'stand', and from that stand we swing out into our overlapping worlds to collect material and enthusiasm to channel back through the center and out as far as it travels. Arriving safely and with news. Contact is interface. And though there are only certain faces you've seen before, there are many more where they came from. Parallel transparencies. Two people inventing electricity within days of each other on opposite sides of the globe. Coincidence? Yes, Co-Incidence. And in a likewise but less dramatic manner, we find more of each other every day. Contact Improvisation has the unique quality of being believed whether admired, respected, scorned, berated, inflated or ignored. Yes real time. Yes real bodies. Yes real people. This particular credibility allows Contact Improvisation and those involved in it, to run tangent to many worlds relating deeply in to those worlds without either becoming distracted or dilute. In fact, the communication which we continue to develop among ourselves and articulate in our dancing serves us well outside our immediate numbers. It is what creates our access to the unfamiliar faces, the rapidly surfacing and the as-yet unsurfaced numbers of people who are working with the material of their lives in just such a direct manner as we attempt in our teaching, performing and writing of Contact Improvisation. We 'stand' together at the ring of a watering hole; our weight brings the water up, our bodies, the weight down. So, that's where we come from. And here is where we are.

Title: EDITOR'S REPORT I High Moon 11th Hour Reflections
Abstract: Nancy Stark Smith reflects on the process of creating the Contact Quarterly, using imagery of the water hole and the moon to describe the collaborative effort and the articulation of new directions in Contact Improvisation.
Text: The image I had for the last issue (Winter 1976) was the water hole. The place where we collect to drink. A circle where everyone who comes fits in. All those cows bent to the water, the lines of their backs, helped me re-invent the wheel. At the watering hole we stood in order to bring our weight down; our weight brought the water up. We came full circle. This time we started again with nothing. New moon. We collected ourselves. As the last light left, we arranged ourselves in a blind configuration; (blackout on stage, the lights come up and the performers arc all in place). We started. Then the crescent moon we seemed to use the light as it grew, filling in the implied circle. Journal entry, March 24: "   Musing new directions, transition at its most spread out point, as entropy of possibilities peaks." The moon, a new image to fill, and we, in as much detail as possible, articulate the filling. Learning the ropes means knowing how far they can take you; how much weight they can hold. One day, the arc of the rope's swing is predictable and suddenly short. There is another side; the side just outside your reach. But is your reach the rope's, or, if you can find a vehicle with a larger range should you ride it. "Limits are what any of us are inside of," Charles Olson said in a talk that was recorded. In ReUnion's Contact classes we often talk during the warm up. Not necessarily to suggest specific activities, exercises or structures, but to create an environment, to supply images that may call out a particular awareness. We talk to the body as it experiences sensation. We say, "You know that place when you stretch, the place where the muscle has eased out to its limit, that place on the edge of stress, on the edge of pain." We say, "Work there, spend some time there, on this side of the edge." "The edge is home," Lee Breuer said during a radio interview in Washington, D.C. in 1975. But it seems the edge is moveable that by sensing the limit, respecting it, you encourage it to open. A push comes to a shove. But if you go only as far as you are welcome, you are invited back. What has this got to do with the Contact Quarterly. Not sure, only that I sat down to present the image I was having for this process. How we stand. How we stand still, and keep moving. Palm Sunday. Full Moon. Lunar Eclipse.

Title: CONTACT IMPROVISATION A STATEMENT OF APPRECIATION
Abstract: Danny Lepkoff expresses his appreciation for Contact Improvisation as a way for people to interact on a purely physical level, fostering healthy interaction through focus on physical sensations and embracing the forces of gravity and momentum.
Text: Contact Improvisation is a way for people to come together and interact on a purely physical level. Fostering a healthy interaction is the important concern. In coming to a dance one must be ready to engage in a constant effort to focus on the physical sensations of weighted movement, balance and stillness. It is not the issue to identify through any conscious thought process what the sensations are; you need not know "what physical sensations you are experiencing," you must know how to focus with constant effort. It is. the strength and purity of this effort which will foster a healthy interaction in dancing with another. The simplicity of the form Contact Improvisation is a gift. Its value is that it Is A Way for you and I to dance together. To befriend the forces of gravity and momentum is to dance with a sense of humor and constant humility, is to discover one's being self, is to discover true communion. The essence of this dancing is the concentration and focus one brings as a dancer, it is only through this constant effort that our dancing will continue to be. Four laws of ecology: "(1) everything is connected to everything else; (2) everything must go somewhere; (3) nature knows best; and (4) there is no such thing as a free lunch." Barry Commoner in The Closing Circle, A. Knopf, New York, 1971, p. 18. '-· I. . ·--1~

Title: A LOOK BACK AND A LOOK FORWARD
Abstract: Danny Lepkoff reflects on the profound impact of Contact Improvisation on his life, emphasizing the importance of communion, responsibility, and the shift from student to teacher, while envisioning Contact's growth as a social function for communal reinforcement and healthier daily interactions.
Text: The work I have done in Contact Improvisation has, needless to say, had a powerful eff~ct in my life. In the late spring of 1972 Steve told me of a piece he wanted to do in N.Y.C., and I went down there to rehearse and perform a dance called Contact Improvisation. The work that was done for that performance and subsequent gatherings for intense periods of dancing was larger and affected more levels of my being than I was aware of at the time. Most forceably I was struck by the simple yet overwhelming experience of communion with another person achieved through the dancing, and the freedom as well as discipline found within that communi~n. I remember feeling literally transported to another world when dancing, a world in which I was able to become a stronger self than I lived with day to day. I don't think, in that first performance, anyone fully realized the power of the forces brought into play among us. Many injuries, pulled, sore, and knotted muscles were the physical result of irresponsibility in the face of those forces. I became impressed with a sense of responsibility to myself and those I was dancing with to create a healthy interaction. The work done during that concert became not something I could forget. The realm of Contact Improvisation I realized was not "dance" but living, the forces at play between two people dancing are those forces which exist day to day, the strong self I had experienced was nothing but myself. I was left with the ever present challenge to realize my strong self in day to day living as well as the responsibility of achieving a healthy and true communion with those people I meet day to day. I suppose this task is universal for all living beings, however I have received a lot of strength and focused energy specifically from the work I have done with Contact Improvisation. I realize now that in order to continue this work I must be involved in the process of transmission. lt'seems that with understanding and experience of the forces at play in Contact Improvisation, receiving becomes transmitting, student becomes teacher, dancing becomes giving. It seems very natural, and I do not hesitate to think that any one who has had enough experience with Contact will feel this shift of role. It is no wonder there are now many teachers of Contact Improvisation. The dancing is just beginning to expand on a social level, into our society. What will be the direction of this expansion? Contact was created in the context of the dance art world. This is a good place, however the traditions of possession and ownership among artists are unhealthy for Contact Improvisation. My dream is that Contact will grow to become a social function. Periodically people living in the same area will gather for a day or week of dancing, for the sole function of communally reinforcing and acknowledging the strong self inside each person in the face of those one lives with. Walking down the street and greeting someone, buying groceries in a store, and all the daily interactions of people will be on a truer more realistic footing, and a general climate of health may be achieved. This may seem far fetched but I feel the beginning is at hand and in view of this direction it is obvious that we need to: continue dancing and deepening our experience and familiarity with the forces at play in Contact Improvisation keep lines of communication open, i.e. this newsletter, and cooperatively give and share the experiences and information gleaned from dancing and teaching. The class I tried to start in Bennington this summer did not work out. I am trying again this fall to get some people together to dance. I think I will be picking apples this fall. The seasons are changing here, color on the trees and colder nights and shorter days, new feelings emerge and don't fit comfortably yet. Hope to see some of you again, maybe hit the west coast again this year. Hello to All

Title: Bodies in Contact , cont'd.
Abstract: This article describes Contact Improvisation as an expression of sensitivity, involving two bodies in contact, communicating through impulses, weight, and momentum, and emphasizing yielding to the present moment and organic transitions.
Text: As a performer I have often been approached . by members of the audience who are in wonder about the phenomenon of Contact Improvisation. A 170-pound man is dancing with a 120-pound woman, rolling up and down her back and over her shoulders, or being carried by her. Is it a skill of gymnastic trickery? Not at all. Contact Improvisation is an expression of sensitivity in both the physical and emotional realms. It demands, above all, the ability to yield to the present moment. On a descriptive level, Contact Improvisation . is a new movement form, improvisational in nat.ure, involving two bodies in contact. Impulses, weight and momentum are communicated through a point of physical contact that continually rolls across and around the bodies of the dancers. Take two human bodies standing face to face. Each one has a center of gravity within the body somewhere in the vicinity of the navel, the exact location depending on the proportions of the individual. If they lean towards each other and support each other simultaneously, they then create a weight/mass system that ttas a center of gravity in space somewhere between their na~els. Like boleroes, fluid and eccentrically weighted, the dancing bodies swing, bounce, roll, swim and fly through and with the the common center of gravity. As the participants move, this center moves. The original format for conducting contact sessions is a "round robin." As the participants· circle around the space a dynamic environment is created; in response to this environment, the dancers allow certain beginnings to occur. In· tention and forcefulness have nothing to do with all of this: The dance is ever changing, never the same. A series of events takes place as uninterrupted, pure transition from a beginning to an end. Working with Contact Improvisation is discovering how it feels to let this transition take place organically. In each individual duet it becomes apparent when an ending needs to happen. The dancers are obligated by the form to let these endings occur. Like any discipline, Contact Improvisation requires serious work to gain proficiency. As in learning a new language, the movement and concepts feel awkward at first, but with practice one is able to find a personal range of expression. Participation is not limited to "dancers," but rather to anyone who wants to develop new skills in movement. The technique is most influenced by the disciplines of aikido, hatha and pranayama yoga and gymnastics, all of which teach us tt1at energy is conserved if the body knows how to flow along

Title: SEEN FROM THE OUTSIDE
Abstract: Ernst von Glasersfeld reflects on Contact Improvisation from an observer's perspective, suggesting that it involves not two but four entities: the two selves of the dancers, each striving to maintain contact while being both subject and object of the other's actions.
Text: In ordinary, every-day situations, to make contact there have to be two. That seems a commonplace and we simply take it for granted. Watching Contact Improvisation, however, is a strange experience at first. The making, keeping, and stretching of contact, there, does not easily fit the accustomed conceptual schema. It takes quite a while to discover the reason: Its contacts involve not two but four. In the world of our experience, what we call our "self" is no more and no less than what we experience of ourselves. In terms of our senses, our "self" is composed of what we perceive of ourselves, visually and tactually for the most part, plus what we internally sense about the states of , our muscles and organs. This "self" is necessarily very different from what we are in the experiential world of another person who, visually and tactually, experiences us from a wholly different point of view. In Contact Improvisation, therefore, there are two selves, each striving to maintain contact with another person. Both are constantly the acting subject of their own actions, and at the same time they are the object of the other's actions. And since the possibilities of making and maintaining contact are nearly always many, the coordination of motion of the one dancer that perceives the other and the other that perceives the one, is threatened at every moment. There is a perpetual struggle to neutralize inherent discrepancies and to preserve a reciprocally invariant relationship of contact. Seen from the outside, this becomes a powerful and at times shattering allegory of the precariousness of any harmony in human relations. If this is not too idiosyncratic an interpretation, it must raise the question: Will Contact Improvisation really remain a moment-to-moment improvisation or will it gradually develop regularities, fixed sequences, and rules? Contact of two independent agents can be maintained only to the extent to which one can foresee the motions of the other. (That goes for ALL relationships, and that is why we always need some rules and conventions). To IMPROVE in the art of Contact Improvisation (or in the art of relating to others)

Title: TEACHING CONTACT IMPROVISATION
Abstract: This article discusses the role of the teacher in Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of sharing one's attitude and trusting in both oneself and the students. It highlights the teacher's responsibility to guide students towards their own inner understanding of the dance, seeing knowledge as limitless and fostering a sense of security.
Text: In assuming the role of teacher you do not simply share your objective body of knowledge, you share your basic attitude towards the work towards the world You are in a position ofresponsibility: Responsibility for trusting in yourself in your students to give instruction and then to fallow to teach and then to dance You guide the student to the 'teacher in himself' You share your knowledge of the dance by addressing yourself to that part of the student that already knows If you hold on to your knowledge then you will feel insecure as a teacher You must see your knowledge as limitless, this is what it is. Title: CONTACT IMPROVISATION / A DEFINITION
Abstract: This article defines Contact Improvisation as a duet movement form where two people move together in contact, maintaining a spontaneous physical dialogue through shared weight and momentum. It emphasizes releasing muscular tension and embracing natural movement possibilities like rolling, falling, and being upside down, leading to free duet dancing and the expression of one's essential energy.
Text: Contact Improvisation is a duet movement form. Two people move together, in contact, maintaining a spontaneous physical dialogue through the kinesthetic sensual signals of shared weight and common or counterpoised momentum. The body, in order to open to the sensations of momentum, weight, and balance, must learn to release excess muscular tension and abandon a certain amount of willful volition to .the natural flow of movement at hand. Skills such as rolling, falling, and being upside down are explored:, guiding the body to an awareness of its own natural movement possibilities. Simple and direct duet exercises allow couples to explore and focus on specific relationships which come up in free improvisation i.e. supporting or taking someone's body weight, giving your own weight, jumping on someone, rolling off of someone. Once certain simple exercises and sensations are introduced the realm of organic body movement becomes very accessible to the body, and a great deal of one's essential energy can be expressed. It becomes important to develop a state of alertness, the senses so poised, that one may work in an energetic state of physical disorientation with safety, trusting one's basic survival instincts. All the work leads to free duet dancing: together with a partner one freely explores movement possibilities, an experiment, a time to ·play, a time to dance togetherness, a time to be and speak through your body. Contact Improvisation deals fundamentally with organic body movement. Organic body movement is motion manifest in activity directly dealing with the physical forces of the environment, gravity being the major influence, ~ovemc:nt in which the body and senses are engaged in the effort of survival.· Sports and games develop the body's organic movement possibilities to a peak. "Contact" has been called an art-sport. Contact Improvisation speaks for the belief that the realm of organic body movement is limitless and rich in the possibilities for expression of one's self, one's being. ••••••••••a

Title: THE POLITICS OF CONTACT
Abstract: This article summarizes a discussion from FOCUS 8/77 about the politics of Contact Improvisation, focusing on the power relationships within the dance and its connection to broader societal issues. It explores the needs fulfilled by contact improvisation, the potential for it to break down power imbalances, and the relationship between the contact community and the larger society, including questions of accessibility and elitism.
Text: On Saturday afternoon August 20, 1977, some thirty participants and teachers of FOCUS 8/77 gathered to talk about the Politics of Contact. The issue was as much one of defining the question or concern as it was coming up with an answer. The discussion began with a minimal definition of politics: awareness of and concern for the power relationships in a given interaction or situation, particularly those relationships which are unacknowledged. or assumed and unquestioned. From this beginning the discussion was wide-ranging, spirited and largely unstructured. Going back over a ta pc-recording of the seminar a month later, I have selected out and arranged (without regard to original sequence) representative and provocative comments to share with the larger contact community. To my knowledge this discussion was the first attempt to look at our work from this perspective and clearly it is only one small step, but an important one. In retrospect, I saw our talk centering around two issues.· The first was seldom defined as a focus but kept surfacing in people's comments: what kind of needs are filled by contact improvisation'? Consuelo: I was interested in figuring out why it's come down that because of privilege like the $125 privilege and the class background privilege, why it is that this environment has developed around contact; but I don't see that contact itself is this white cultural kind of   John: I'm not sure I agree with that, for one thing it's demonstrating the needs   contact like anything else is fulfilling certain needs. Eleva: That's what I was going to say earlier, perhaps it's the white middle class that needs to get in touch with their bodies. Tom: What I see it gets down to is am I willing to go into the world receptively and attentively to what's happening around me and to be in touch with my needs in a particular situation and other people's needs. I really think it is something about the reason we're here is because we need to be here, else we wouldn't be here, to learn whatever we're getting from this, and I see it very much in spiritual terms   this group of people is here to get what we're getting and I think a lot of people don't need it or are doing it in another form. Elizabeth: The same kinds of things that happen in contact are things that I think have happened to other kinds of people in other situations, like in work situations where men do heavy physical work together and might have to use their bodies in the same kind of cooperation and same kind of sensitivity to each other   but different than a dance situation   which comes with a different kind of awareness. Broni: Its purpose is different too. Mark: This may relate to why this kind of event is strictly one ethnic group or one social class. I'm concerned in society all over the country how it seems there's a great gap between this kind of situation of workshops and focusing on a specific kind of dance and what I would call the masses   their desire to move and to socialize and be part of something which is being generally exploited. For those people who are not coming to studio spaces and being part of something, the whole word dance means to them Friday night and swallowing a six pack of beer and going to a bar or disco; I think it's exploitative and I really feel there's a gap between that space and this space and it's really tough to breach. jerry: Contact has a lot in common with folk art and we are a folk   we invent it as we go along, we make it out of what we've got and the fact that what we've got is a college education, and money, and attractive healthy bodies, and good teeth, you know, is different from having a bunch of mahogany trees and a couple of rocks   Contact improvisation has roots in dance, it was found by dancers, and it has gone away from being a dance thing; it is a movement form. There are people here who are not primarily dancers and the form is reaching out toward those people the way some people seem to think we should be reaching out toward different classes of society or different ethnic groups. Mark: I feel that there are some aspects of this kind of dance that are slightly different than any kind of particular outlet that supplies the needs for any particular ethnic group. I really feel that there are some aspects of contact that are evolutionary .. I can't think, unless somebody can fill the space, of other kinds of dance in the past which have been this free with sharing and this much touch and connections .. I think this kind of dance is more significant in specific kinds of problems, like sexual politics, for example, men dancing with men   and even in the sense that it doesn't rely upon other forms like music goes right to an essence or centering   This form of dance crosses a few more bridges than others have. Consuelo: You mean in the sense that it is kind of like a future vision of how people can relate to each other in terms of sensitivity and activity? Jon: In terms of sexual politics we're still dealing with one on one, two people getting together, and contact gives you metaphors for expanding that to three or four or ten or twenty or whatever and that should be explored too. · Keriac: Watching a ballet that gets into these boy.girl things, I don't get much metaphor for my life from those; whereas I really find the material in contact, the interpersenal stuff that's happening in contact, is a really useful sophisticated metaphor for what I'm experiencing. · Consuelo: Right now I feel really committed to art for change. It's really not enough to do a contact performance for me, it really isn't. I feel like I want to know more what's going to come out and deliver a message; and I don't mean just whatever message is there but I mean pretty specific messages. Kris: There's something about pure energy that gets exchanged between people, we become something of everything we are around, and when I see a performance I become those performers; and it means a lot to me and it's the strongest and most pure learning experience I have and it's devoid of content. It's not statements. Consuelo: Well, that sounds like a pretty powerful statement. I see that most of these needs in relation to contact have to do with the desire to break down the uneven power of the various roles that people assume in relating to one another, be it male to male, dancer to nondancer, or performer to audience. Contact improvisation as a political process can thus be seen as a means for bringing people together in a way that prevents or at least discourages the assumption of roles and inequalities of power which roles so often establish. There seemed to be agreement that, on an immediate personal level, contact achieved this aim if the integrity of the physical form was respected. The second issue of the discussion seemed to center around the kind of relationship the contact community and the contact form is establishing with the larger society. Does and will this relationship maintain the same freedom from inequalities in power and thus allow all people access to the vital (role-less?) movement relationships which are contact improvisation? Karen: The way to deal with it is to work on both levels one is on the normal ground level of literally dealing, believing that change takes place and revolution takes place within my own body first and then at the same time being aware of where my body is: is it in the studio, in Cat's Paw, and that door is closed unless I have $125, and then what do I do about that; and I think there are two different issues and both are necessary. Brent: But we made this experience available for ourselves   at least I did. Karen: Because it is within your program in life to be able to do that. We're talking about a whole part of the world where it isn't part of the program it's not there   so is art going to be something we're talking about, an eclectic thing that stays where it is, or can this particular art form go out because it doesn't have to have all that professional dilettantism that other forms have. Can it just be a way of reaching people on another basis? Laurie: Not right now. john: This is a white middle class trip and other people out of that might not necessarily want to have it. Laurie: And they might and they can't because they can't afford to. John: That's not true. Laurie: If one person wants to and can't   John: There have been set up free situations for people to study this and it is only taken by white upper class people. ' Ernie: Sometimes it becomes a real trip that we are laying on them because we don't have the sensitivity to know what they need. Mark: What is the balance between being crusaders for contact and making it an available form for those that are interested? John: It is a manifestation I think in many ways of class differences and therefore class problems that we should deal with; solutions are tough. Evelyn: Most of the arts are a social   I mean there's a certain class of people that do them. For a long time they were a very elitest thing. Ernie: But is it elitist? That word really blows my mind cause it's a power term. It assumes that if we develop a dance form, it is automatically elitist. It's a dance form!   something that came out of our culture. Our culture may be elitist in a lot of ways money and social structures generally, but that doesn't mean the dance form is elitist. Laurie: But it reflects the society. Karen: I am forever grateful in one way, in an aesthetic sense, and in other ways, for things that have come out of formalized, in a sense elitist, art forms and I value them. Then I hear what we're saying on the other side. Now is there room for both ways to be? Keriac: If you are thinking of contact as a folk art and experiencing it, it is quite a different setup than if you are thinking of it as a performing art or a spectator thing. Like Karen was talking about, how can we have both of these things, that they both enrich our lives? I think that it is facetious to say that it is a folk art so that we can all rest our minds about that, you know, that we don't have to be concerned about   that we're clean; this is a folk art, it's ok. One can use contact lots of other ways the relative morality, the rightness or wrongness or whether it fits into your value system should be examined. Ernie: If you take something like contact   and you can make it into where you're more sensitive to life in general, the balances and flux of life in general, then it becomes evolutionary; but if you take it and it becomes another package, then that's what it is, another package. Some questions arc asked. concerns expressed and a dialogue begins. I hope the excerpts above may have provoked thoughts in you and that you will share them with others. It is part of the dance. I hope that l have not distorted too much the meaning of what people said by taking comments out of context or order. And in reading, please realize the text above is in some sense my interpretation, my reflection, my recreation of what took place. You had to be there. . . · ------fl-----BYRON BROWN is one of the founding members of Mangrove and a member of the Bay Area Contact Coalition who sponsored Focus: 8/77. He lives and teaches contact in San Francisco, California.

Title: IN THE COURSE OF TEACHING
Abstract: This article reflects on the experience of teaching Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of accepting limits, encouraging students to stretch beyond them, and recognizing the element of risk involved. It highlights the significance of 'listening' as a force behind transition, the need for attention to wander, and the balance between observance and verbalization in teaching.
Text: Accept your limits. I ask that students allow themselves the permission to realize their limitations. I also encourage the sudden stretch beyond limitation. To see within this language the existence of a subtle yet expansive definition of the word 'risk'. "Isn't that very risky?" asked a student looking up at a friend pivoting in the valley between neck and shoulder of her partner. I believe this work and other explorations compatible with Contact always involve the element of risk, whether we are rolling along air-born arcs or standing still. As flow does not mean slow, receptivity needn't be measured by passivity. 'Listening' is one of my favorite words in describing the force behind transition. Attention needs to wander to stay interested. In the teacher, your partner, yourself. Re-circulate. Hearing Robert Creely opinionate that the full human attention is there for forty minutes. The concern for rhythm and balance of class time. Developing trust in the quiet of before and afterimages. The forms of students moving, trucks on the freeway, the teacher's words measured and heard by breath, inter-relate and create a whole entity. The class assists a teacher in locating his or her placement between the skills of observance and verbalization. Besides the basic sense of too much or not enough (alternately, I've been told by students how there is excessive technical input or a frustration due to a casual and modest directive), we learn to use the word if it fits. Of course there is still much more to say. In one of his first introductory classes, asking: "ls the contact point the tension between trust and responsibility?" In agreement yes, Danny, there seems to be many levels of lifting experience. Dancing well with new students is the most advanced part of my learning. ______ , ,.. _____ _ ALAN PT ASHEK writes from San Francisco where he lives and teaches. Studying Contact Improvisation since 1974, he is a member of freefall company. a Bay Area based performing and teaching ensemble. "It is very tempting for a teacher to feel he is in possession of an understanding, that this is his ware which he sells and peddles; yet a good teacher peddles confusion rather than ease, guiding students through a gentle order of questions, witness to their discomfort and fumblings. There are many ways a teacher can teach, but I think the soun:e of this ability is a simple compassion I sense teaching as a movement or passage on the level of heart" Danny Lepkoff

Title: REMEMBERING FORGETTING
Abstract: This article explores the teaching and learning process in Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of remembering the beginning and sharing the first steps of an idea or experience. It draws parallels between learning to walk and learning contact improvisation, highlighting the body as the teacher and the need for basic experiences to build upon. The article also suggests that teaching should reflect the learning process, mirroring the breathing rhythm of information, exploration, pause, and inspiration, and reminding teachers and learners to 'remember to forget it'.
Text: It's easy after teaching awhile to forget the beginning, to forget how to share the first steps of an idea or experience. Remember learning how to walk? It was a logical organic progression. The body was the teacher. It knew just how to prepare for the next step-it wriggled and squirmed to get ready to roll, rolled to get ready to creep, creeping became crawling, crawling prepared for sitting, squatting to standing to falling to standing to stepping to falling to walking. Watch babies. They have much to teach about how to teach and learn. In teaching/learning contact improvisation, what are the first steps? What are the basic experiences needed for the next step and the next? Perhaps it would be helpful to remember, to retrace, the first year of contact improvisation. What is the last thing you learned? Can you remember learning it? How did it happen? Teaching should reflect the learning process. And learning mirrors the breathing rhythm. INformation EXploration Pause !Nspiration. "Oh I get it," said the small child, "First you think it. Then you see it. Then you fo~get it. Then it happens."• That's a good lesson plan. Title: THE SMALL DANCE
Abstract: This article discusses the concept of the 'small dance' in Contact Improvisation workshops, where individuals focus on minute movements and relaxation while standing. It explores the awareness of the skeleton holding the body upright even when mentally relaxed, and the interplay between ordering oneself to relax and continuing to stand.
Text: EUZABETI-1: At the very beginning of a Contact Improvisation workshop, teachers often talk about the 'small dance'. Why do _YOU start with the 'small dance'? STEVE: Well, first of all, it's a fairly easy perception: all you have to do is stand up and then relax-you know-and at a certain point you realize that you've relaxed everything that you can relax but you're still standing and in that standing is quite a lot of minute movement: .. the skeleton holding you upright even though you 're mentally relaxing. Now in that very fact of you ordering yourself to relax and yet continuing to stand-

Title: TEACHER TEACHING
Abstract: This article explores the role of a teacher in Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of facilitating self-discovery and empowering learners to find their own way within the form. It discusses the teacher's responsibility to pass on valuable information and create an environment where learners can develop their own skills and motivation.
Text: What becomes a teacher that becomes a teacher? The function of a teacher is to help the learner learn. preparing the learner to find out themselves. skill/ tact equals visibility/ invisibility e~uals tact I skill having become experienced is a debt to the forces-that-be that we must constantly acknowledge. We are privileged to pass on the sensitizing information, relaxing infonnation, strengthening information, information of the forces-that-be. Is it true? that: the learner learns to be partly the self & partly the teacher thus the implantation continues through the generations so the skill for our arts is the model of no model thus leaving the motivation in the student, in the way we would want to retain power over ·our. lives while at the same time retaining the option to release control· the dancing does the teaching. the teacher points to that. teacher is the manager for a long concert (all the classes, end to end) which teacher sees with eyes-that-can-see and so shows the others how-to-see so gradually the learners learn to see and the special position of teacher can be shared. teacher becomes special learner, using the energy granted by the class to learn ever more intensely. Does the class seek purity? If so, special learner will receive pure energy and pure intensity. this is the power of the special learner. The power granted by the learners is only equal to the power developed by the teacher in the learners. Does the teacher poach the motivation· of the class? Does the teacher teach the poaching of personal power? Then the special learner will receive impure energy colored with power play and gland games. quality to quality, receiving what is given. a volley ·ball of Karma. MATERIALS: physical sensations, patient discipline. Activity preserving the integrity of . the sensations of the forces. materials strengthening the ability to stay oriented. Communicating these to the body as directly, gently, simply, humbly as can be. Endeavor to grow strength organically. As taught, so one tends to teach. Could the teacher enjoy a class. taught by their 'I student's student? beyond the brief moment of transmission is a long, a potentially life-long association. Our Karma will be clear & irrevokable, not only bad or good. Consider: sitting & rocking one day and examining the chain forged moment to moment, over the years. Memory of the forces-that-were, ourselves among them. oo Steve Paxton This article is reprinted from Summer 1976 issue of Contact Newsletter (Vol I No. 51. STEVE PAXTON is an inveterate Contactor and is interested in improvisation.

Title: IN PRAISE OF BADDANCING
Abstract: This article explores the value of discomfort and imperfection in Contact Improvisation, suggesting that the "bad dancing" on the edge of the circle can be a rich source of learning and growth. It emphasizes the importance of embracing the fear of opening and finding companionship in the ever-present indications of what is possible.
Text: I learn from knowing I am uncomfortable, and going ahead; and the going ahead being the letting-go-ahead. So the discomfort is to be appreciated. It is an environment from which springs an opening. Contact embraces this fear of itself. this seminal verge. We are concerned with where the dancing originates. At times it appears to me that the important thing is not the dancing in the center of the circle. but the experience on the edge of the circle, the often disquieting dance on the verge. This view, which might be seen as antithetical to the work. is also necessarily part of its premise. The invitation to feel the dread of opening is an inherent part of the total occurrence. Dances in which both bodies ride a shared wave of truly unleashed rise and falling are rare. Yet the dances which abound halting, starting repeatedly, responding to impulses a fraction of a second too slow to flow, doubting one's perceptions are rich with valuable information, honest manifestation of fluctuation between positive and negative response. We fear surrender. make our homes in the almost, and venture into readiness only when we must. The discomfort at the verge serves by intensifying the contrast: the darks get darker, the lights lighter, and the picture gets easier to see. I value this work not only for the rare glimpses of in-touch, in-time, in-tune. but for the companionship of the ever-present indications of what is possible. The form itself, if one exists beyond the instances of attempts to experience it. is none other than the existence of the possibility of a dance in which wills. instincts. and verges merge. Emergency, emerge, merge. It amounts to having to believe in a possibility which one may never have . experienced. All this to say I am devoted to something which I rarely feel, the possibility of which I never leave. We extend to ourselves an invitation which we rarely accept. but the extension of it is what matters. Living for so long on the verge of that acceptance, I figure it's time to call it home. o0 Christina Svane CHRISTl:\A SVA'.\:E :s a dancer·poet·teacher·video artist living in New York City.

Title: CONTINENTAL DMDE a gravity warm up
Abstract: This article presents a gravity warm-up exercise, guiding the reader through a series of weight shifts and arm movements to explore balance and connection to the earth's forces. It encourages awareness of the body's delicate balancing act and the flow of energy through the bones.
Text: Stand In Colorado facing North. Align your skeleton along the forces of gravity, sending your weight evenly down through your bones back to the earth. Remember the center of the earth, tis density. Empty of idea. full of sensation, feel the small dance, the delicate Inner balancing act of a 2-legged creature; falling gently cin and off center, weaving about your axis. Feel the rise of the earth's strength back through your bones. supporting your stand Let your arms float up from your sides, parallel to the earth" s curved surface; legs equally weighted. Gradually fill your right leg with more weight, letting the left grow empty. Meanwhile softly reach ·eastward with your right arm; stay within a comfortable balance. When yo'1 re near the edge of that balance, extend your arm a bit further, so you can reach the Atlantic Ocean Dip your fingertips In Gradually bring your weight back ovP.r tnto the left leg from the right20%, 50%, 70%; reaching, without stretching, the left arm out towards the Western shore, dipping your fingers Into the Pacific. Back through center to the East. dip, through to the West, dip. Each time send less of your weight out to either side, leaving most of It centered and running down through your bones, until you are just barely rocking; balanced tn the middle of the Divide. Nancy Stark Smith

Title: A DEFINITION..
Abstract: This article defines Contact Improvisation as a duet art-sport that has gained international recognition and been adopted by dance companies and organizations. It emphasizes the importance of physical touch, mutual support, and awareness of physical laws such as gravity and momentum.
Text: Contact Improvisation is a duet art-sport currently receiving international attention by those institutions concerned with new departures in the forms of dance. Dena Davida, Carol Harwood photo: Marc-Andre Gagne In the years since the inception of Contact Improvisation, in 1972, it has been adopted as performance mode by some 10 dance companies across the U.S., and used as a teaching technique by those grass roots dance organizations, institutions and individuals concerned with investigation of d'ance improvisation ephemera before the concerns of art aesthetics arise. It is an activity related to familiar duet forms such as the embrace, wrestling, martial arts, and the jitterbug, encompassing the range of movement from stillness to highly athletic. The exigencies of the form dictate a mode of movement which is relaxed, constantly aware and prepared, and on-flowing. As a basic focus, the dancers remain in physical touch, mutually supportive and innovative, meditating upon the physical laws relating to their masses: gravity, momentum, inertia and friction. They do not strive to achieve results but rather, to meet the constantly changing physical reality with appropriate placement and energy. ~ Steve Paxton

Title: John Faichney
Abstract: This article discusses the adaptation of the performance piece MOMENTING for European performances, focusing on the concept of 'MUTATIS MUTANDIS' and making necessary changes based on the situation. It highlights the importance of falling and release in maintaining momentum and organic development of variation.
Text: In looking forward to the European performances of MOMENTING, it was readily apparent that the piece could not be restaged intact each time. After toying with some of the formal manipulations that might be imposed upon it, I finally chose to let the piece be adapted to the situation as I found it. In the context of formalism, the 'piece' became a piece about 'MUTATIS MUTANDIS': about 'making the necessary changes'; e.g., on the level of multiple performance. photo: Lance Segusa   the resolution for myself of what constitutes the real? actual? performance problem: to fall. So that the maintenance of a uniform momentum does not become exhausting, I have found it necessary to subordinate that occurrence to the rule of weight, imprisoned by gravity: that, as long as I can fall, the RELEASE will give me the energy to rise again, but THE SENSE OF WHAT WILL PROVIDE THE RELEASE IS THE KEY TO THE ORGANIC DEVELOPMENT OF VARIATION. Title: Three Poems for the Contact Quarterly
Abstract: This article presents three short poems exploring themes related to Contact Improvisation, including delicacy, balance, and renewal.
Text: 1. I want to go where everybody wears Lots of lace or little bits of lace, where Lace grows on trees for easy picking, For a long while, and take you with. 2. It's the delicacy of the grip that does the Gripping, leaning out over counterbalancing The weights with wing of gravity, relaxed Holding so close to letting go you'll Know for sure as signals cross the junction Twixt the tetrachords, hum the whole quartet Of double systole, double diastole. 3. Restore new life to old sponges! Marie-Marie sponge rejuvenator ! So simple a child could do it! Jerry Zientara

Title: JUNIOR! HOW JUMP CAN YOU FAR? 1 1 Child's cry overbedrtl in a playground.
Abstract: This article explores the relationship between verbal and body languages in Contact Improvisation, highlighting the importance of attention, focus, and shared understanding. It discusses the evolution of a language within the form and the challenges of communicating its principles to diverse audiences.
Text: By arranging and rebalancing our scrutiny and our relaxation of focus in our daily routine we find ways to our appropriate redemptions. The constant prayer that leads the pilgrim, Saint Therese's "little way", the yogi's systems of breathing, and the mover's attention to the body as it washes, waits for the bus, cleans out the catbox or ties a shoelace are among ways we focus our being towards whatever unexpectable or hoped-for visionary experience waits gracefully for us. Verbal languages and body languages both present regions of articulation, regions of common understanding, and regions of the unknown. By looking at "what we know" we approach the fascinating places of "the unknown". Historically, Contact Improvisation began with everything unknown and in the recent handful of years, a body of knowledge, perhaps a grammar of words and motions, has been evolving. We know we belong to the same tribe because we understand each other; we share a context. flexibility active bounce round robin circle breath play partner attention gravity momentum pathways floor honest dialogue wave trust weight float stillness skeleton mood glide interfacing contact rise skin center (This example is a random selection from lists of "words related to Contact improvisation" made during a writing seminar led by Nancy Stark Smith in Seattle, January 1979.) By now, hundreds and hundreds of people have had some exposure to the form and its language, through classes, workshops, performances, reviews, magazines, and photographs. People from all walks of life have attempted to describe, analyze, teach Contact in terms of their own vocabularies, which range from the scientifically spare to the wildly rhapsodic. Meeting changes and development within the practice of the form and colliding, assimilating, and crossing with words from other contexts, the language of Contact Improvisation attempts to stay clear, direct, and as immediate as the movement itself. The very obvious and the very subtle are always present in any utterance, pose, or figuration. Understanding the shapes and shades of meaning and of momentum is as easy and as dif ficult as understanding music or the weather. Embodying a concept may or may not use words before, during, and/ or after; when we seek discourse, the universe of words enters the picture. While a woman rolls in a wavelike motion across the floor, another woman waves to her, waving her hand. (Homonym phenomenon.) During "the stand", a condition of vertical rest, in which the skeleton is balanced so the muscles don't have to work to hold the body up, small adjustments and rebalancings were noted to go on involuntarily. When the accumulating jiggles and twitches were seen to be a continuity, there had to be something to call it, and it is "the small dance". This happened in the old days. Also in the old days, so many experimental movements were attempted that they were. given numbers. These days the only one that is called by its number is "the 58". "58" is a vault pivoting off the partner's thighs, around hip-to-hip, rolling over an arc across the partner's back, finally rolling off into the air or someplace else. Influx and innovation occur in oi.tr lingo through borrowings like aikido rolls, t' ai chi stepping; forward rolls; from physics and metaphysics we adapt and adopt referent points like counterbalance, chakra, yoga asanas, field .energies, ma.gnetism. Innovative word-invention can produce terms immediately understandable, for example, Simone Forti's use of "artsport" soon swept the Contact village and one feels again how perfect a word it is coming upon the ungainly "sportart" in a newspaper clipping. Other terms like "blotto dance" never quite caught on. "Finger ouija" may or may not be current. Obviously Contact's language functions among practitioners-only groups, and in mixed groups which include non-contactors. In the former case, assumptions are frequently taken for granted, based on common experience. Just as you can tell at once if your partner is really in kinetic dialogue with you, when verbal conversation flows the words are subsidiary to the moment, suppor-tive of the meaning. In the case of the latter, often contactors find ourselves making wild analogies with rock-climbing or talus-running (which we may not have done a whole lot of ourselves), trying to clarify concepts without having to demonstrate at cocktails just what a 58 is. When we are faced with a reporter, our mother, a dance teacher, a baseball fan, or a child who sees us doing it in the park, what words do we call up? At the best of these moments the principles that live within our process emerge momentarily, and some of the phrases stay around. Repeating definitions, describing the same moment several times, feeding our words and gestures into the common experience keeps refining and redefining and refinding the same· old gravity and change. ~~~~If~~ R41ke ~~~~~cf~~~ fJ_, ~ {,. ~ ~~~~·~~+~ '$f. <#-~ !.~~t. {f ~1 !:. ~~ ~ "R~ ~~~c{~~ &~'4cQ~© ~~~f?~ ~~~t4&r~~tr ~ 'tc ~~ ~~~~(j~.f ~~~~~'f§~l-7 #MQf 9m.ff ~1111 (Where two frames of reference cross, forming four corners, linear transmissions fan out towards new forms in old formats, and variant conditions, as "from visceral to visual", verbal to ideogrammatic .) Sometimes after a duet we have no words because the experience was its own verb, its own noun. Art in teaching, healing, presentation relies upon articulation of the parts, knowing the anatomy, the syntax. As we come to know the form we learn its languages, and we change and it changes and we keep finding the known.and the unknown, like the subtle and the obvious, in every gesture and utterance. Title: CENTER OF GRAVITY
Abstract: This article explores the concept of center of gravity in the context of dance, explaining its physical definition and discussing how it changes when the body changes shape. It emphasizes the importance of understanding center of gravity for movement and balance.
Text: "Center of gravity" seems to have a lot of meanings for dancers. If you look the term up in a physics book, you find about half a page; they seem to think that it's so simple as not to be worth discussing a lot. But the concept is pretty deep when you think about it and use it to look at movement. Here I will be talking about center of gravity in the same physical sense that a physicist would use the term. I will leave aside meanings such as "center from which you move" or "spiritual center," and try to show the richness of the simply physical interpretation. However, I am emphatically not saying that dance is "nothing but physics" more about that later. First I will explain and define the center of gravity for a rigid body, and then talk about the more interesting cases when the body changes shape and the center of gravity changes. Title: WHERE YOU GOIN' WITH THAT GUN I Setting Our Sights
Abstract: This editorial discusses the direction and focus of Contact Improvisation (CI) and Contact Quarterly (CQ). It explores the balance between sensation and achievement in CI, and how choices and priorities shape the practice. The editorial also considers the role of CQ as a 'vehicle for moving ideas'.

Though it is th irection must nevertheless be osen in order to proceed. For a long time it appearedthat Contact Improvisation ore concerned with sensat n than achievement and . Yet there is a li ollection of expe ences one coul is the poi of Con eels backed up against the running the still figures into a blur of movetowards the finish line. With baton in matches stride so the passage of baton from y are going somewhere. rnal movement sensations: the rhythm of earth.
