That we, like the joggers, therefore feel free to choose any direction for our practice ysical interaction that doesn't intentionally injure you or ow broad an activity can be before it has no parameters at all and call life, or in this case, human experience. When, in 1977, Steve ied, "Just the pleasure of using your body is, I think, maybe the main an unplanned and spontaneous way, where you're free to invent and they're free to invent and you're e other-that's a very pleasant social form." However, it was by first establishing priorities that Contact was able to provide its particular kind of pleasure. Contact can be seen as a means for communicating through physical contact. Dialogue proceeds, using the exchange of weight between partners to tune them to the physical forces that effect their motion and to tune them to each other. At the outset of Contact Improvisation, a choice was made to minimize the social content of the contact and to work, initially, with the physical elements involved in the exchange. Stated or by example implied, this choice along with others brought depth to the practice of Contact by limiting its scope. By narrowing the focus of the activity, subtle information was made visible: the experience of gravity; the "small dance" of the skeleton balancing erect; the flow of weight through the body as it rolls across the floor; the exchange of weight between partners during lifting, throwing and catching; the sensation of sharing a dynamic center of balance with another mover. It has been 8 years since the decision to work with these specific physical elements. In this time, practice has revealed many principles that, serving as anchors, allowed the scope of partner exchange to widen. The practice of CI continues to suggest ways in which its principles and skills can be applied. Following these suggestions leads to fascinating work in dance, theatre, therapy and education. As the concern with physical contact and weight exchange becomes less of a focus in their work, many Contactors wonder whether they are still doing "Contact Improvisation". Others continue their studies regardless, not caring one way or the other what it is called. Contact, as an evolving system, tends to attract the forces that work to open what is fixed, change what is static. Ever since its formation as the Contact Newsletter in 1975, Contact Quarterly has reflected this eagerness to find relevance in a broad range of sources. In considering the direction of our interests, as editors we ask ourselves, 'What does shooting guns have to do with Contact Improvisation?' In shooting, one tests the accuracy with which a message of energy (power) can be delivered to a distant point (moving or still). As a 'vehicle for moving ideas', Contact Quarterly shares that aim. Nancy Stark Smith Volume 5 1979-80 CQ/CI Sourcebook

Title: Editor Note
Abstract: This editorial reflects on the experience of falling in Contact Improvisation and life. It explores the concept of a 'blind spot' during a fall, and how staying awake and aware can transform falling into a dynamic balance and a state of grace.
Text: "There is a bit of insanity in dancing that does everybody a great deal of good." Edward Denby Letters Editor Note When I first started falling by choice, I noticed a blind spot. Somewhere after the beginning and before the end of the fall, there was darkness. And then the floor. Luckily, there were mats at first. Soon I learned that the end of the fall was the beginning of another move, usually a roll. That gave me somewhere to go. So I rolled. At the end of that roll was another roll, and at the end of that, another. Then, I noticed another blind spot. Somewhere after the beginning and before the end of the roll, there was darkness. In that darkness, however, I noticed a body moving, a body that knew just where to go. The blind spot in the fall is the moment when the fall and the faller lose synch. The faller falls asleep and her body falls without guidance to the floor. Truly lost in space. Ever fall asleep at the wheel? You 're so tired your eyelids stick together each time you blink ·until they pop wide open as you realize you've just been driving 60 mph on the highway with your eyes closed, for how long? The same sensation occurs while falling. You wake up shortly before reaching the floor, just in time to hastily steer yourself to safety. Adrenalin makes your hair stand up. The more I fell, the more familiar the sensation of dropping through space became, the less disoriented I was during the fall. Staying awake from the first moment of balance-loss, I found that falling was in itself a dynamic balance. One in which the forces at play-gravity, momentum and mass-were all operating in their natural order and if my mind was with me I could gently guide that fall toward a smooth landing. Confidence came with experience and soon enjoyment took the place of fear and disorientation. In the course of a Contact Improvisation duet, I found myself taking every possible option to fall. I would slip out unexpectedly from under my partner just to take the ride: head first, feet first, horizontally, diagonally; falling became irresistible. It has become clear; there is no where we can stay put. Even standing, we execute a continuous fall. The expression, 'fall from grace,' becomes an impossible statement when falling is itself experienced as a state of grace. This is not to say that disorientation, confusion and dis-ease have no place in the geometry of balance. They, in fact, stimulate the balancing mechanism. Stimulate us to ask questions: what is dis-ease, what does healthy mean, how do we recognize and maintain it? How can we stay awake during the fall; this is the healing issue. Nancy Stark Smith Fall 1979

Title: CONTACT & HEALING
Abstract: This letter discusses the connection between Contact Improvisation and healing, emphasizing the integration of body, mind, and soul. It suggests that Contact encourages looseness, openness, and responsiveness, leading to change on emotional, mental, and spiritual levels, and promotes a healthy cross-linking of all levels towards wholeness.
Text: CONTACT & HEALING Just saw the Winter '79 issue of CQ and it looks really good! I see that the next issue is on healing   a very important topic on many levels   If anything comes out of the discussion it will be an awareness of the connectedness of all things, and an affirmation of Contact as a connector. If I may ramble on a bit longer and share some insights and a viewpoint   It seems the pop'lllar notion of 'health' today is a state of 'not being sick'. Healthy, however, means 'to be whole'' and is linked to the words "holy" and "beauty" (the Greek word for health is "koilo" meaning beautiful). An unhealthy person is damaged, not whole. A holy person is a whole being. So, the meaning of health expands beyond the physical aspect. Being healthy involves the dynamic integration of body, mind and soul in a process of creative self-expression   we are healthy to the degree that we are manifesting our possibilities. Our culture seems to be overly rational and intellectual-separating mind and body. I know, for example, that most architects live in their heads and experience with their eyes. They're very tight and far from spontant0us (if I may generalize that grossly). Contact Improvisation encourages integration within the self. 50 CQICI Sourcebook Volume 5 1979-80 It asks for looseness, openness and responsiveness   as well as .a sensitivity to one's own needs and those of others   making one like moldable clay-impressionable, sensitive, tangible   pulled, thrown, melted, solidified, broken and pulled togetherso much physical activity that one cannot help but change on the emotional, mental, and spiritual levels as well. With this awareness we can encourage a healthy cross-linking of all the levels   toward a wholeness of b.eing   The environment surrounding us can be a 'stage for life'   supporting 'wholeness'. A healthy environment nurtures healthy people; healthy people build healthy environmen ts. With this spirit, Namaste! Ross Chapin Mpls, Minnesota

Title: MORE INFORMATION
Abstract: This letter explores the similarities between Contact Improvisation and psychological therapies, such as Gestalt therapy, Jungian therapy, and group dynamics. It questions whether psychological consciousness should be brought to Contact classes and how it might change the process.
Text: Dear Contact Quarterly, Coming from a background of psychology and movement therapy, I am intrigued by the similarities between what I have experienced in Contact Improvisation and my experience in psychological therapies. The following is a brief synopsis of the psychological theories I have looked at in this way. Gestalt Therapy-focuses on "being in the now." By paying attention to our inner needs in each moment, we relinquish the avoidances in our lives and commit ourselves to confronting, and living in the present. Jungian Approach to Therapybased on Carl Jung's belief in the existence of the feminine and masculine in each of us regardless of our gender. The essence of the work in Jungian therapy is to balance out, and come to a resolution of the imbalanced or conflicted opposites within us. Various theories of Group Dynamics-predictable behavior patterns inherent in the development of a group which evolve out of the unfolding of contact and intimacy amongst the members of a group. Theme of rejection-a common denominator to most therapies. Based on denial of a human being's primary need for love and acceptance, usually going back to one's early relationship with parents. The building of trusting and honest relationships is a key factor in any mode of therapy to help counteract feelings of unworthiness, and the fear of rejection. Some thoughts: I am wondering if more attention should be paid to Volume 5 1979-80 Contact Improvisation as a healing art by bringing psychological consciousness to Contact classes, jams, and workshops? And if so, how do we do this? (Also, has it been, or is it presently being done by anyone?) Will doing this change Contact Improvisation from an educational to a psychological process, and if so, do we want to do this? So, to sum up, can (and how can) an exploration of psychological theories and techniques shed some light on to the psychological framework within Contact Improvisation in order to open up greater potentiality for the teaching and dancing experience of Contact Improvisation? Would love to have an exchange of ideas on this by contacters who have experience and expertise within the field of psychology. Toward growth and wholeness, Deborah Goldberg Greenfield, Mass.

Title: A DEFINITION Round Up
Abstract: This article provides a definition of Contact Improvisation, describing it as a movement system based on communication between two moving bodies and their relationship to physical laws.
Text: CONTACT IMPROVISATION is an evolving system of movement based on the communication between two moving bodies and their combined relationship to the physical laws that govern their motion-gravity, momentum, inertia. The body, in order to open to these sensations, must learn to release excess muscular tension and abandon a certain quality of willfulness to experience the natural flow of movement. Practice includes rolling, falling, being upside down, supporting and giving weight to a partner. Alertness is developed in order to work in an energetic state of physical disorientation, trusting in one's basic survival instincts. It is a free play with balance, self-correcting the wrong moves and reinforcing the right ones, bringing forth a physical/emotional truth about a shared moment of movement that leaves the participants informed, centered, and enlivened.

Title: Round Up
Abstract: This short piece discusses the concept of falling in Contact Improvisation, both alone and together, and how the blending of weight between partners creates a shared center of gravity.
Text: In Contact Improvisation we fall alone and together. By blending the weight of two bodies through a shifting point of physical contact a shared center of gravity is established. Around tbis center partners ride weight along common paths of momentum. Releasing, folding and activating weigbt flow through the joints, opens and softens participants to each other and the floor. fo this softened and receptive state we ,1re able to adapt quickly and quietly to tbe most charged of falling encounters.

Title: A DEFINITION
Abstract: This article defines Contact Improvisation as a movement form involving two bodies in contact, where impulses, weight, and momentum are communicated through a point of physical contact.
Text: CONTACT IMPROVISATION is a movement form, improvisational by nature, involving two bodies in contact. Impulses, weight and momentum are communicated through a point of physical contact that continually rolls across and around the bodies of the dancers   Like bolos, fluid and eccentrically weighted, the dancing bodies swing, bounce, roll, and fly through and with a common center.

Title: The Educational Value of Contact Improvisation for the College Student
Abstract: Daniel Lepkoff argues for the inclusion of Contact Improvisation in college dance and theater programs, citing its value in developing physical skills, presence, trust, and challenging traditional sexual roles.
Text: This statement was submitted to tbe Educational Policies Committee of Hampshire College, Amherst, Mass. on November 29, 1979. Contact improvisation is a movement technique. Though much younger than ballet or modern dance, it proves to be as rich and dee~. It ei_nbodies a progression of physical skills which can be used to train the beginner as well as challenge the virtuoso. Students of contact improvisation acquire access to a large realm of movement very quickly and begm to make significant changes in their movement patterns, strength, and sensitivity within three or four classes. This makes the technique particularly desirable for the theater student and non-dancer. The skills acquired in contact improvisation are by no means limited to the form itself. A deep understanding of weight, movement flow, and use of strength greatly aid anybody who desires to study ballet, modern dance, or other physical disciplines. The extensive exposure to the physical and mental states involved in improvising and discovering movement can help choreographers in their attempts to gather material for their set work. Contact improvisation directly strengthens one's presence. Just as one can become aware of the eyes seeing, the ears hearing, and the skin feeling, one can become aware of the mind sensing. Through practice of this dance form one becomes able to experience and observe the state of one's nervous system particularly when in an intimate physical relationship with another. This spawns an element of control over one's perceptual reality. This control and ability to focus is training in developing power. Personal power and strength of presence is essential in any performing situation as well as in daily life. Contact improvisation nurtures a basic physical trust between two people and among a group. The form demands a care and consideration of one's partner and towards this end seeks to develop sensitivity and confidence. This trust and the freedom which ensues kindles a rich and fertile environment for working creatively with another person. Knowledge and experience of this environment aids in any situation where people are working together, actors on stage doing a scene, or dancers performing a piece. The working relationships which develop in this form cross the boundaries created by sexual roles; men dance with men, women with women, and men with women alike. I do not know of anv artistic discipline in which non-~exual, deep, and honest physical contact is explored with_ total equality relative to sex. In this form women lift men as often as men lift women. Women learn to exercise a kind of strength which often has never been encouraged, likewise men learn to allow themselves a soft, responsive, and non-competitive posture. It is a revelation to both partners that a one hundred and eighty pound man can be easily & completely supported by a one hundred pound woman. Again, the trust derived from freeing the traditional sexual roles creates a more comfortable and fluid atmosphere among any group of artists seeking to work together. Contact improvisation seems to be of particular value for the college age person. College students find themselves in an intense period of transition. They are coming to grips with the image and reality of themselves as adults. Thev are intently exploring the psychological politics of sexual relationships. This form offers them a grounded, simple, and clear opportunity to interact deeply and honestly with each other. It seems to serve as a reference point or forum for experiencing oneself in relationship with others in an unthreatening environment and without the need to formulate consciouslv or to talk about what is going on. The strongest evidence for the emotional supportive value of this work is the very real attraction students have for this form. They want to experiment and expand. This form gives them the opportunity to go ahead. In and of itself contact improvisation has become a significant movement within the dance world, recognized bv audiences and critics as a fascinating and evocative performance experience. Many up and coming dancers and actors are using the skills they've acquired through practice of this form to advance themselves in their artistic work. Considering its value as a supportive discipline for the actor studying theater or the dancer studying traditional techniques, as well as its presence as a new and viable dance form, I feel no hesitation in recommending to any college or university that contact improvisation be a permanent part of the curriculum of any program in dance or theater. ~

Title: AIKIDOINFORMATION IN DEED
Abstract: Steve Paxton discusses the value of Aikido, a Japanese martial art, for those involved in Contact Improvisation, highlighting its emphasis on non-polar interaction and efficient body mechanics.
Text: reprinted from Contact Newsletter, Vol I No 5, Summer 1976 ] ack Wada (Sensei) Aikido instructor at [the University of California at Santa Cruz] gave a demonstration during the Contact Improvisation workshop 19 April [1976]. Aikido is a ] apanese Martial Art developed early this century by M. Uyeshiba, then a master of the extant martial arts. Aikido has valuable information for those who have eyes to see. Wadasensei did much to make the forces visible; spirals and curves to meet the pro-forma aggression of his 3 ukis, the energy of easy blending, guiding, leading and directing attack energy to its own neutered completion. Most valuable to me was Wada-sensei's unvarying unromanticized unstressed concentration. Seeing him react was information in deed. The martial arts are the arts of war. They have each been forged in the heat of life or death, and have matured through a lineage of survivors. Aikido is of particular interest due to breadth of vision of the situation of war. It does not stress the vs. but the non-polar 'we'. The intense realization which death brings to activity has graced the martial arts including Aikido with efficiency. This elegance of means is based on profound (because essential) information of body mechanics, training procedures, and physical possibilities. Here is infor· mation embodied in a seamless flow. The concentration which cannot bend. The accommodating winning maneuver. Contact Improvisation is not a martial art. It is perhaps an art sport if it is defined by the context in which it currently operates. The means of teaching are not those of life or death confrontation but life to life confrontation. The teaching philosophy is that of mildness, supposing that learning can be joyous, that the danger of finding is a pleasure in depth. Con• tact as a means has produced a community of particular information, an 'it' against which other things can be assessed, by which 'it' 'itself' can be gauged in living manifestation. It is time to question: What is the result? Is the fire hot enough to forge the solid concentration? ls mildness means enough to calm the seeker and show the teacher and the student a calm balanced center, to obliterate a hierarchical I (invitation to war, Atlas vs. Heracles) and to expose the We of us and the forces? Or is it a cheap thrill, placator, builder of influence for those with the sweets, waste of time spent in orgy of sensation? Compassionate teachers? Balanced teachers? Concentrating teachers? What will it be? The current generation is the test animal. Contact will always be reflected in our karma. Contact is serene. We think we know: the forces in play. 'It' /us are on the line. Things are always life or death. ~

Title: THE BUSINESS OF CONTACT TOURING
Abstract: A conversation between Peter Ryan, Dena Davida, Ellen Nayduch, and Roger Neece discussing the practical and ethical considerations of organizing and promoting Contact Improvisation workshops and performances, including financial arrangements, competition, and community impact.
Text: Ellen: We're discussing the business of Contact-How to be a business manager or how not to be. What are the primary ingredients in putting on a performance? We came up with: a mailing list, space (size and location), scheduling, organizing. Are you doing it for a friend or, as Dena called it, are you taking a cut? What kind of expectations did you have as the organizer? Were they shared by the performer? Peter: I think that as a promoter you have to maintain your integrity. The fact is that we are part of the Contact community that stretches from coast to coast. There are times when people are bringing in someone they know only from reputation. There is a danger that you may get in over your head. You have to be able to say, "no" even though you want the workshop to happen, "I'm sorry, I can't guarantee this amount of money or this number of students." You must be clear as to what you can generate and let the artist make the decision. Dena: Concerning integrity, there have been inklings and rumblings of competition for markets, like "don't touch Oregon, it's mine." The Bay Area Contact Network in San Francisco, initiated bv Alan Ptashek and others [see CQ Vol IV No 3/4] is a model we can think about in the future to help us cooperate instead of compete. Isn't that the philosophy of our dance form? Ellen: In terms of competition among producers, the four of us mentioned that we hadn't been "doing it" lately, so someone else is obviously "doing it" instead. Dena: The first year that I sponsored people, I did it "as a gift", to help myself learn and to support contact in my community. I've grown to understand that it is important to take a percentage so that you don't feel that your energy is exploited. Roger: I've always thought that management is just as much of an art as the dancing. Ellen: On the East Coast Tour in 1978, it was suggested that the managers and the performers all take an equal cut. In this instance we were seen as equal partners. Roger: In actual fact, this arrange·· ment never happened. Dena: In Montr(al, we've never offered a guaranteed fee to the performer because we are not producers and have no money to back the performance. On the other hand, I've worked for the Muse"e des beaux-arts de Montr~al which can produce the performance and take the risk of losing money. Ellen: What we're talking about is two styles, one where you are the manager and have all the responsibility and another where you broker the services of an institution. Clearly if you can broker these services it takes the risk, time, and frustration out of your hands to some degree. If you're going on your own, the failure or success is all yours. The expectation of a good performance can be crushed totally when no one shows up and there is no money to pay anybody, including yourself. a conversation between Peter Ryan, Dena Davida, Ellen Nayduch and Roger Neece at Current Exchange 1979 Peter: Dena's letter in the Contact Quarterly last year requested that people not take it for granted that if they gCJ on tour they're going to be able to get sponsors in each city. Again, if you are planning a tour, please be sensitive and respect the people who live there; they rely on their community for their livelihood. So, if you come in as a high profile performer you are going to milk the market. If you are on the road a lot or want to be on the road a lot, consider the fact that we are a limited market. You are placing a great burden upon your promotor to go beyond his/her neighborhood and dance community to generate that extra revenue for you. Roger: The easiest way to organize something is to affiliate yourself with a local dance studio that does modern or experimental work. You can use their mailing list, studio, facilities, etc. to piggyback with your own personal resources instead of taking on all the organizing yourself. A financial guideline: if you co-sponsor with someone (and they provide the postage and mailing, box office and publicity) the standard split is 50150. One situation or avenue that has been very successful in New York City is affiliation with galleries. The Paula Cooper Gallery has hosted three sets of performances, and the Holly Solomon Gallery sponsored one. In some cases they guarantee the performers a small fee, but usually they furnish only the space. Donations are requested. Peter: Vancouver is not a visual arts center, and galleries have not been a good alternative here. ._, Dena: In Montr~al, we've worked in three settings: Studio Catpoto, universities, local studios. Luckily we have always had our"own work space and, given enough time, we can free it up for a week. We usually get it for a bargain price since we are the major renters, say 100 dollars for the week (and free classes for our landlords). Concordia University recently hired Andrew Harwood to teach, and Universit€ de Qufbec hired me-and paid us on guest teacher salaries. Occasionally Studio Nouvelle Aire has co-sponsored someone with us. Peter: If you can do it, get an institution to back you. Look for the museums, the community colleges, libraries, churches, public buildings with downtown plazas, art councils. Roger: It is also important to know your local area and what can and can't be done there. It's one thing to organize a workshop for ten people with a teacher who is your friend; it's another thing to plan a series of workshops, two or three performances and guarantee a fee of $500. You have to know beforehand what you're going to be able to handle. Dena: Getting very practical, I think about all the expenses. There's the airfare, fee for the space, poster design and printing, office supplies, postage, telephone, housing and food (in Montreal we usually bed and board the artist with us). Sometimes there are additional costs such as video, lighting equipment, tech personnel. Ellen: Listening to Dena's list of expenses and how they are or are not paid for, I would describe this process as "grass roots". If one looks at the actual costs to produce a concert, it can be quite expensive. It seems that in the Contact community we are relying much more on volunteer human resources, than financial resources. Dena: I find we're designing a new business context. I've also been involved with the National Endowment for the Arts touring program, and I see that contacters are working on a totally different basis (day to day survival, maybe?) Peter: In the winter of 1978, I sponsored Beth Goren and Danny Lepkoff. The workshops were each a week long and the fee was $ 50. There were 10 to 15 people per workshop so there was a healthy amount of money. The costs were not that great because airfare was not included. Ellen: So out of this gross income of $500 how much money did you make and how much time did you put in? Peter: I put in a lot of time, I did a lot of groundwork and I haven't even thought about the percentage. I had a separate bank account for all money I made as a sponsor and did not break it down for each individual project, but I probably made about$ 75 for each, about 20%. Ellen: One question that comes up in terms of percentages is the amount you take as the manager. I've also taken from 10 to 20 percent, depending on my experience at the time. Dena: The workshop classes have been the real money-making part of each residency. The performances have brought in a minor amount in every case. Ellen: Production costs are usually high compared to performance revenue. Whereas in a workshop, the overhead is low, the fees are high for the participants, and you're paying only one or two teachers. Dena: The cost is infinitely greater for five people. It's much easier to do a successful duet tour. Roger: One of the biggest problems has been finding a suitable space (large enough and with resilient floors), and then having to pay $ 5 or $10 an hour for many hours of classes. Peter: Sometimes it's difficult to negotiate a reasonable fee for a week of classes. In Vancouver, I've rented the Western Front and made arrangements to cover the cost of the space. I included that in the fee for the workshops. We don't work on a percentage basis either. Dena: In Montreal, we've always offered a flat rate for space, not by the hour or by a percentage. Ellen: Another thing you might consider, especially if you are in a learning phase, is bartering. Maybe you want to take the workshops for free in exchange for your services. Be clear from the beginning with yourself and the performer that that's all you want out of it. I think you'll find the amount of time it takes to produce a residency is much greater than you ever think it is. Dena: At Catpoto, we four (now six) help each other plan residencies, though one person takes the major responsibility (we alternate). We have a video person, and we all translate into French, in exchange for taking the classes. Ellen: Keep a clear, accurate record of expenses and make out a projected budget of income and expenses. And contracts. I highly recommend contracts even if you are promoting a friend. It's good business to make out a contract signed by both parties stating the exact requirements. It's not something you write up when the person arrives, it's something you agree on beforehand. Roger: Before you begin, it's also a good idea to talk with your local dance studios and find out what their experience has been in sponsoring other artists. You may get some idea of how receptive the non-contact community might be. Dena: Know your community and find out the schedule of other arts organizations (even a psychology convention could conflict). Don't overlap with other important events. Ellen: Time is another consideration. You need to accommodate both day and evening workers. Planning during college vacations is not a good idea. But no matter what schedule you make, someone is going to be unavailable or disappointed. Also, think about the location of the space. If transportation is not good or the locaheard of him. People were totally going on my say-so that this was going to be a good class. Peter: Essentially, the issue you are raising is that of selling the person. Some people do not have to be sold, their names are already commodities. Dena: Montreal is different because the commodity in the workshops I have sponsored has been Contact Improvisation itself, not the reputation of the teacher. The large T'ai Chi community and those interested in dance improvisation always come. Roger: Boston and New York City that's of vital interest to a lot of people in general, so with that in mind I put out information to the dance community, to doctors, to the athletic community, and to special interest groups. It's also a good idea to contact people in neighboring cities so you don't have to generate the whole market from your one area. You can collaborate in terms of a series of workshops or one big wor:kshop for several cities. Ellen: It also cuts transportation costs for teachers. Dena: In one case a "special interest" group saved us from a disaster when "' ~ ..c u 0 0 ..c 0. tion is not safe, people who might be interested in the work may not come. A high profile place attracts more students/audiences. How much do people in your area know contact and the particular person you are sponsoring? When Steve Paxton came to Boston there was a real interest not only from Contact people but from people who were interested in dance in general. Whereas, when Andrew Harwood came, although I knew he was a great teacher, no one had ever are much different. The Contact community is very small relative to the dance community. So for the sponsor it's really a matter of reaching out to the public and selling the teacher. Peter: You have to go beyond the Contact people to those not regularly engaged. For example, when Beth Goren came, she did a workshop called "Balancing the Body/Mind". Now Andrew Harwood and Mangrove \vere following on each other's tails. What we thought of, with Mangrove in town for only three days, was to have them teach a men's class and tap the gay and "masculinist" communitv. The Gav Rights Association beca~e an enth~siastic co-sponsor. Those were the largest workshops we've ever had. We've relied mainlv on word-of-mouth among the dancer~. other fringe artists, psychologists, and friends of friends of friends. Limited postering !n certain cafes   Peter: ~\y experience is that word-ofmouth is not sufficient. In most urban areas there is a glut of posters. So if you're going to compete with what else is goi

Title: Beyond the Rambling Rolling Rut
Abstract: This article presents a collection of scores designed to encourage range and skill with creative process while involved in contact improvisation. It emphasizes tapping into intuition and embracing a wide variety of dimensions in movement.
Text: Beyond the Rambling Rolling Rut by Kris Wheeler The following is a collection of scores designed to encourage range and skill with creative process while involved in contact improvisation. Creative process is the essence of improvisational artistry. It taps the intuition and is therefore able to embrace great quantities of information, and to perceive simultanegusly patterns and relationships of many dimensions-rhythm, poetry, design, imagery   Dancers, especially those with no other movement training than contact improvisation, seem to limit their movement material and restrict their contact dance to a narrow range of possibilities. Rather than shut out the reception of info~ation we can allow our intuition to absorb and play with choices of a wide variety of dimensions. When first becoming aware of and expanding the range of our moment to moment choices, we can find ourselves intellectually deciding the · future. This interferes with the intuitive choice process. Let it be a phase to pass through and emerge with more awareness and greater participation with the totality of the moment. The Content of the Dance, the Emerging Elements Two people beginning in physical contact, dance. (Later they can begin out of contact.) When either one notices an emerging idea, it is announced and both explore it as the source of their dance. It needn't take longer than one minute to announce an idea and it can be anything from the specific to the abstract, (e.g. slow, in and out of contact, balancing, bubbling, I support as you fly, "Rock a bye Baby," spinning   ). The dance should be at least a five minute exploration of the idea. If the other dancer doesn't understand what was said, or doesn't see how it fits, that person says, "I don't get it" and the dance continues until another idea is announced. This is to keep from trying to recreate what is already in the past. and the circle can announce what is perceived as the movement idea to be used as a source. Each time a new dancer joins a new idea is announced. (It is interesting to hear the circle's observation of your movement.) With time, more depth and subtlety will develop in observation and vocabu• lary-at about this stage dancers are quick to perceive the potential of their movement material and the announcement will be superfluous. Stillness: to Clear the Space and Frame the Dance, or Beginning and Ending First work with short solos-1 to 3 seconds in length! Clearly establish both the beginning and the ending. Ask for feedback from observers about their perceptions of exactly when ~d with which part of the body the dance began and ended. Two people work together, starting out of contact, finding their own individual beginning, spending some time in physical contact and then finding their own individual ending with whatever seems appropriate. It is important to recognize and stay committed to the ending moment. Eventually the dancers become more perceptive of each other and their interface so that the dance seems to determine the beginning and ending. The Line The part of the dance between the beginning and the ending can be thought of as the line. The line represents the flow of the dance; anything from the sometimes local develop• ment of an idea to a series of chaotic and random events. Some improvisational lines work and some don't (and some work for some people and not for others). The point is to be aware of the line, or the flow of the dance, in order to more fully participate in it. In a round robin, both the dancers In groups of 3, two dance and one watches. A short dance at first, 2 to S minutes with clear beginning and ending. Eventually work toward much longer dances that hold together as a whole. After each dance spend some time with feedback and discussion. How did it hang together? Did it end too soon, chopping off the line? Did it ramble and not utilize the opportunities?   Uniqueness of each Dancer After dancers have grown more sensitive to their partner, their sensitivity can be interwoven with their own unique creative process: Two dancers start individually-simultaneous solos, time to gain a sense of their own dance; at some point they come into contact and work with maintaining their own individual line as well as creating the duet. Eventually they leave physical contact to find an individual ending. ~

Title: DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS IN CONTACT
Abstract: Keriac discusses their experiences teaching Contact Improvisation to diverse groups, including seniors, the blind, therapists, and communes. They highlight the therapeutic and community-building aspects of Contact, emphasizing its potential as a folk art.
Text: DIFFERENT DIRECTIONS IN CONTACT by Keriac Until I wrote this article, I hadn't realized how many different directions I've gone with Contact in the past year. All of these experiences are united by one personal goal: I'd like to contribute to the development of Contact as a folk art, a meaningful art activity which ordinary people do for pure enjoyment in the normal course of their lives. I wantto be a dance teacher/performer within a community of people who may have chosen not to dance full-time, but still retain a sense of the dancer in themselves. I've been reaching out to people who might not otherwise think of getting into Contact dancing, even if they should have heard of it. I've been contacting: with Seniors   I did a Contact workshop with SAGE, a senior citizens group in Oakland, California. When I arrived I was pleasantly surprised to find all the senior citizens and social workers lying on the floor of a plushly carpeted living room, each with their head on someone else's belly, laughing hysterically. Naturally, I immediately joined the fun. As I led the group through contact exercises, I noticed a nervousness in myself. I feared being out of touch with the stamina and flexibility of older bodies and the degree of risk appropriate to older people. The possibility of injuries floated up into my mind. However, this group responded to the same exercises that I use in my regular classes with only slight modification, and I soon felt at ease. I stayed primarily with exercises that did not take the participant very far off center, but by the end of the session, we had even gotten into weight taking, and the only person who had dropped out was an 83 year old woman who had recently broken her ankle. As the two hour session was coming to an end, I found myself doing active-passive duets (I was the active one) with one person after another. Everyone around me began claiming, "I'm next!" "I'm next!" It was fun. Every single person danced a duet with me, even the woman with the broken ankle. These older men and women let me balance them in the air on my hip or back without clutching or showing any signs of fear. They melted into the floor and took my weight with just the right amount of active-passive involvement. I was amazed-we were really doing contact! At our final hug, everyone was incredibly high, including myself-despite my sweaty exhaustion. As I left, I overheard them saying that they wished the experience had been videotaped so that I could be shown at an upcoming Senior's conference in the Midwest. Gray power is powerful! with the Blind   I also taught a series of classes at the Lighthouse for the Blind this last year. There were six students, some were senior citizens. Within this particular group of blind people, there were multiple handicaps. Some were mentally retarded or psychologically disoriented, some had excessively tense, rigid bodies, one was obese, one had a fractured collar bone from a recent fall, others had arthritis, diabetes and other conditions which made them short of breath or easily dizzied. I altered my class goals, deciding to use contact as a movement therapy tool rather than as an end in itself. We spent about an hour on warm-up and relaxation, then spent the last hour on contact exercises. Since I couldn't just say "Do it like this" and then visually demonstrate the activity, I was forced to describe many sensations that I experience in Contact with precise language. This was a major challenge for me and I learned a lot about Contact in the process. Using Contact experiences to improve the student's real-life functioning increased my awareness of how really beneficial and healing Contact is. I feel incredibly enriched by the luxury of my present Contactor's lifestyle which includes so much touching, trusting, and ease of movement. Since classes at the Lighthouse have come to an end, one of the visually disabled students (without other impairments) is now attending my regular class where he is much in demand as a Contact partner among the other students. ~

Title: with Therapists
Abstract: Keriac discusses teaching workshops for therapists and the insights gained about Contact as a therapeutic tool. They explore the parallels between physical dynamics in Contact and psychological dynamics in relationships, highlighting the concepts of assertion, manipulation, and the "rescuer-victim-persecutor" triangle.
Text: with Therapists   Teaching workshops for therapists with my sister, Ilene Dillon,-who is a therapist with a private practice in Marin County, has also increased my vocabulary and awareness of Contact as a therapeutic tool. Ilene immediately recognizes principles of assertion at work in the dynamics of Contact interplay. Her theories on manipulation are amply illustrated in what makes a Contact duet work or not work. It seems that the same laws which are operating on a physical level in Contact activities are also operating on a psychological level in relationships. Vocabulary used to describe emotional realities has a very strong impact when one senses that it is also true on a literal level when one dances Contact, and vice versa. Bruce Dodson, a member of the "Issues in Radical Therapy" newspaper collective, and I co-led a Contact session at the Radical Psychiatry Summer Institute at Fort Mason this year. Here the language and emphasis differed slightly from Ilene's, but it seemed that Contact also fit in well with the Radical Psychiatry point of view. I found it easy to communicate the notion of giving body surface to case a falling person's descent (rather than grab them to try to keep them from harm) to people who were already familiar with the concepts of the "rescuer-victim-persecutor" triangle (when a person tries to 'help' someone by 'taking care' of them, they create a victim who will later resent"-persecute] them for it.) In other words, the person with the problem should have control of solving it. My communal family and I attended the Summer Institute together. We have started using Radical Psychiatry techniques in our emotional sharing meetings and our personal lives. It has helped us achieve more intimacy as a group, and a better clarity in resolving conflicts. It feels good to sense the harmony between the principles used in my family and emotional life and in my dancing.

Title: with Communes
Abstract: Keriac discusses leading Contact sessions for communes, highlighting the diverse reactions and the potential for breaking down physical barriers. They also mention starting a Contact class primarily attended by members of communes.
Text: with Communes   The Communal Grapevine, (a network of communes in the S.F. East Bay) invited me to lead a Contact session at their monthly potluck gathering. Over 40 communal houses belong to the network. It seemed like all 40 of the households were in attendance. The very large living room of the host commune was filled to the brim with people ready to experience their first Contact session, and beyond their heads I could see many others pouring in the front door. This was a greatly diverse group, ranging from early teens to seniors, and encompassing a wide variety of lifestyles. For some, it was clear that Contact teetered on the edge of what was sane and/or respectable behavior. But an "I'll try anything once" attitude prevailed. About a quarter of the group was still dancing two hours later after hungrier companions drifted off to sample the temptations of the pot luck. By then we were involved in pretty athletic movement and the decrease in density gave us room to move safely. At the end, the diners and dancers re-grouped and discussed values of interdependent, cooperative, trusting, and responsible interaction held in common by Contact Improvisation and communal living. Several communal houses invited me to come to their regular house meetings to lead their family in an evening of Contact sharing. I accepted. For some houses, this meant the first breaking of an unspoken taboo against physical contact among the house members, and caused a mixture of anticipatory excitement and apprehension. So far I have not heard of any resulting orgies fulfilling anybody's worst (or best?) fears after indulging in the communal contact sessions I have led. Some of the communards in the East Bay wanted more Contact than a one-shot family meeting. At the time, no one was teaching Contact in the East Bay, so I started a class which was held at Berkeley Moving Arts and then later at the Dwight House commune. It was attended primarily by members of three communes although publicity eventually opened it up to others as well. (Historical note: I began teaching Contact more than two years ago in much the same series of events. First, just a weekly sharing session with my communal family in our living room. Then my family began bringing their friends, the friends brought their friends, and soon I was putting up posters and teaching four classes a week in the Walkabout studio in San Francisco.)

Title: in Community performances
Abstract: Keriac discusses their experiences with community performances, including a street performance project called "Public Works" and demonstrations at a public library and Jewish Community Center. They highlight the use of props and the enthusiastic response from audiences.
Text: in Community performances   This summer, a small loose group of contactors calling ourselves "Public Works" met informally on Sundays in Golden Gate Park and performed outdoors for the crowds lined up waiting to get into the King Tut exhibition. I initiated this project, modeling the structure on a street performance group of which I was a member five years ago. "Public Works" differed from the earlier group in that we used props rather than white face to provoke curiosity and we did Contact Improvisation rather than theater. Wearing construction worker hats and bright orange T-shirts, and surrounded by our props, which included road crew pylons and flags, plus two sawhorses stenciled with the "Public Works" logo over the bright orange stripes, we evoked the image of workers doing street repair. The dancing started with high energy jumps and lifts, and the contact duet movement was amplified with hand-held road crew flags. This was the most effective way we found to attract attention and gather an audience. "Public Works" participants agreed it was an interesting experiment. We plan to revise and recycle it after the rainy season is over. This fall, I've continued my exploration of Contact as a performance form with the advanced students in my regular classes. ] oe Dowling, Robin Snyder and I recently gave a Contact demonstration and performance at the Noe Valley Public Library. Conditions were difficult: a cold, linoleum covered concrete floor in a small room with low ceilings. A party with a live band was going on in the room above us, and our space was the only access route to the building bathrooms. However, we had a capacity crowd of enthusiastic people who joined us in an hour of Contact experiences, watched our Contact performance, and then eagerly participated in the question and answer period. The physical limitations • had not prevented us from turning people onto Contact. This fall, Charles Campbell and I also did a Contact performance and demo at the Jewish Community Center, which included a lively question and answer period. People in the Bay Area are beginning to notice the term "Contact Improvisation" and are eager to find out what it's all about. 'Bo

Title: Q &A
Abstract: Steve Paxton answers the question "What is Contact Improvisation?" by discussing its origins as a study of communication through touch, contrasting it with the isolation often found in Modern Dance, and addressing the potential for misunderstanding the form through a purely technical approach.
Text: Q &A by Steve Paxton "What is Contact Improvisation?" That the question is asked reveals either that the term is investigated by people with no opportunity to see performances or jams by contactors; no recourse to social dancing, a friendly wrestling match; or, as in my case, too much exposure to the above. When, in 1972, a group of dancers began work on Contact Improvisation, it was a study of the way communication was possible through touch. My own background was mostly the Modern Dance, which may be seen as a study by individuals in physical isolation, usually within a group. In classes of this sort one maintains a sphere of isolation from other students to avoid belaboring them with battements. Crossing the floor, it is customary to move serially, enabling the instructor to see each student as they pass. From this background the communication possible through touching was, and still is, a profound experience. Likewise the movement which resulted from contact improvising-a non-rationalized, intuitive movement leading to unforeseen phrasing, positions and gambits-was a relief from years of willful technical applications. Although improvisation has long been a sophisticated approach to music and, more recently, to drama in the U.S., in my background it didn't exist. Although there were many references to improvisation as an impor.tant factor in the development of modern dance (Isadora Duncan and Rudolf Laban,) by the time I came to study, Modern Dance seemed in a period of codification. From the many 'mainline' modern dancers with whom I studied, I can recall only classes full of rote exercises. This state of affairs is so contrary to the spirit of Duncan or the ideas of Laban that one might suppose Modern Dance had been born and died during the first half of the 20th Century. Yet the term 'Modern Dance' holds promise of renewal: it seems less useful to limit ~

Title: LETTER FROM STEVE PAXTON TO THE CRITICS in England
Abstract: Steve Paxton writes a letter to critics in England, discussing the potential for misunderstanding Contact Improvisation. He emphasizes that it is not a form of set movement phrases but an approach to movement driven by reflex and intuition, warning against a purely technical approach that can hinder the dancer's evolution.
Text: LETTER FROM STEVE PAXTON TO THE CRITICS in England Totnes, Devon March '80 the phrase to a particular period than to presume that the name, phoenix-like, can rise from the ashes and become again applicable. In this interpretation it becomes an umbrella for avant-garde efforts of any sort, which is more or less the situation I encountered. From this perspective, basing movement upon intimate communication (rather than aesthetic dictates) was appealing. It spoke to my body, which had been in isolatiori for many years. Having found the phenomena, the next step was to select ingredients in preparation for the extremes of movement the communication could produce. Aikido, gymnastic and meditation techniques were included, and material gleaned from the contact improvisation itself. It was here, I think, in the effort to create a technical approach to insure greater safety, that misunderstanding of the form was born. Many folk who are drawn to Contact Improvisation to explore their physicality, will begin the practice willfully, trying to 'understand' and move intellectually (as is their habit) instead of exploring willingly. For some of these students, the techniques suggested by the teacher become doctrine. They 'know' what Contact Improvisation is because they remember the words and perform the techniques. I believe there is no form of dance for which this approach will liberate the dancer. Certainly not Contact Improvisation which is not a form of set movement phrases but an approach to movement in which the student moves from the motivations of reflex and intuition. There is a contradiction in a technical approach to improvisation. While one is aiming for a freedom from rationalized movement, one is still studying movement from the example and words of a teacher. Ideally, each student would move at their own rate, developing physical skills appropriate to their own improvisational explorations.
