Title: JUDSON/CONT ACT RELAY A Legacy of Ambiguity
Abstract: This article reflects on the Judson Dance Theater Reconstructions and the early days of Contact Improvisation, highlighting the resistance to solidification and the importance of ambiguity in keeping the art form alive.
Text: Seven days after the Judson Dance Theater Reconstructions at St. Mark's Church and the event seems a thing of the past. More so, even, than the original events done in the '60s. It was a little bit like seeing an old family photo of an event that is indelibly etched in your memory, but when viewed directly seems very far away. The event is more clearly gone, but even so, the memory remains current. Maybe that's because a memory, as it's carried through time, can change, and adapt to the new time. Though memories tend to slip away when they're no longer relevant, fixing them extinguishes their fire much sooner. I'd never been to Judson, and I was glad to see the 17 reconstructed works, but I was not nearly as filled with the spirit of Judson in the '60s as I had anticipated. I feel the spirit of those times best in the sense of humor, support, and challenge that I've witnessed between artists whose friendships were forged in that period-the permission to undermine one another, in fact the hope that if one got too comfortable, someone would pull the rug out from under you and set you spinning again. And so it is ten years since the first public performances of Contact Improvisation. People are talking now of producing historical Contact Improvisation events, writing books about Contact, and this issue of Contact Quarterly is Cl's 10th anniversary issue. At least one baton that seems to have been passed from the Judson world of the '60s to Contact in the '70s is a resistance to being solidified-the sense that to stay in one place too long is to freeze there. But whether you stay or go further, a "place" has inevitably been cleared by your passing, and that point of reference exists. Every day more trails are blazed to, from, through and around that place, with other landmarks forming along the way; and so it becomes increasingly difficult and in fact pointless to fix its outer limits. There does seem, however, to be a center-a downtown, as it were-to this sprawling Contact metropolis. But that center isn't exactly on the map. It's more implied than stated, suggested by the overlapping spheres of experience that the work produces. The activity of Contact itself is remarkably straightforward and recognizable, but the experience of it is relative. An atmosphere of curiosity has made the work a currency of exchange rather than a place to go-awkward for those who had expected to someday arrive somewhere. The way is the going itself; we remember what we are left with, but not always where we left from. One night at the Vermont Movement Workshop in Putney a few summers ago, about 50 people gathered for a discussion about Contact. No particular subject was slated. So, we started from scratch and asked, What is this thing called Contact Improvisation that people are so hot to do?, What is it? Some people said it was about communication, a code of sorts; others said it was about sharing weight, getting a rigorous workout, acquiring new skills, and others said it was about developing sensitivity. And the list went on. After the discussion, on our way back to our rooms, a few of us were walking past a cabin where some of the students were living and I heard through an open window as we walked past, "They know what it is, but they just won't tell. That Steve Paxton has passed on a legacy of ambiguity that keeps everyone from saying what it is, but they know." I laughed when I heard her, but I've thought about what she said a lot since then. And I think she's right. Not only did Steve offer a dance, but a built-in way of keeping it alive. Thanks, Steve, for that one. Nancy Stark Smith April 25, 1982

Title: Contact Improvisation views Round Up
Abstract: This article presents a brief description of Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of sensitivity, conditioning, and training to avoid disorientation.
Text: CONT ACT IMPROVISATION may be described as spontaneous mutual investigation of the energy and inertia paths created when two people engage actively-dancing freely, with their sensitivity to guide and safeguard them. Parts of the body may come to support weight which are unused to this, and several weeks of conditioning are essential to strengthen and communicate to the muscles what new stresses they may expect. We are working on the premise that the way to communicate with the body is gentle direct active exercise daily, for a suitable period prior to energetic workout. Certain part's of the body require special attention in communication, limbering, and strengthening: the neck, shoulders, thigh, pelvis, knee, ankle. Disorientation can be avoided by careful training of the peripheral vision, easy tumbling, and investigation of maneuvers which tend to confuse. Steve Paxton, 1972 Carol Harwood, Gurney Bolster

Title: SIX YEARS AGO reprinted from Contact Newsletter No. 2
Abstract: This article, reprinted from 1975, discusses the early days of teaching Contact Improvisation, emphasizing the importance of communication, generosity, and responsibility in passing the form along to others.
Text: [C.Q. Vol I No 2] Stinson Beach, California, 1975. I began a fall series of classes ("Contact Improvisation-The Art of Controlled Abandon") September 1st [1975] at Cat's Paw Palace in Berkeley, meeting twice a week for 21h hours in the evenings. Only now are things really starting to click, ideas and relationships popping into perspective. Contact Improvisation is an awareness, internal, and of the immediate environment/situation, but that's only half the story-rapport and communication follow. Hence this letter and the newsletter it is contained in. But there's more to it than just communication, with only that it's boring. It's the giving behind it that catches people's interest, the generosity that allows them to give too. That's the form "give weight", "take weight"; sharing is it. We have been throwing back and forth in the "core group" talk of people who wish to teach contact before we feel they are ready, and what to do about the situation. Obviously communication is the first answer and this newsletter the first solution. But in the future, to take a serious responsibility for the Form (Contact), to see that it is passed along to others well, we need to be more generous of ourselves, in terms of time and involvement so that our students can·be fully immersed in contact for a good solid period of time and realize the responsibility before being carried away with the desire to teach. Possessiveness with the form only causes people to go off and do it themselves or "teach" their friends. I also feel the need for developing some kind of cross-pollination between the major groups in this area (Bay Area). Some students just can't get enough, so if one person isn't teaching or not frequently enough we can refer over to another class. We need to provide enough "Contact" situations for people who are really hungry, to be immersed in it for a good amount of time. I have finally accepted the idea that the only way to be accountable for the form is not to be possessive of it and try to control it but to be generous and open, with the form, showing a sense of unity between us core people, rather than having/ showing. A lot of this has come out of long discussions with Nita [Little], and Nancy [Stark Smith] in the last month. Also I have talked it over extensively with Margaret Fish~r, and tonight I had a long talk with Byron Brown who I invited over for dinner. . Concerning my class it has been going well. I've been learning at least as much as my students, and that's a lot. The beginners were really beginners, and the form has a lot of material to work with. The class over the last two months has been 95% women and not as consistent attendancewise as I would like. I feel that familiarity and friendship/committment amongst the group is a very important factor. I guess that's the way it is here in the city. The biggest challenge has been working with people who aren't very aware to begin with of how they feel or how a duet feels to them, the challenge is to get them to feel something and to talk about it. For the most part sessions are energizing and time goes very fast for all involved. I look forward to more sharing and work and accept· ance among the core contactors. Sincerely Love, Curt (Siddall)

Title: pQUl\CS ANO CO a discussio
Abstract: This article presents a discussion between Keriac and Mark Pritchard about the values and political implications of Contact Improvisation, including its relationship to the white counterculture, its emphasis on equality and self-responsibility, and its potential as a folk art form.
Text: Values KERIAC: Someone at the seminar on politics in FOCUS '78 in Berkeley, my first Contact Intensive, postulated that perhaps Contact is what we white liberals need to make ourselves whole: it balances us. Other cultures have not deprived themselves of touch and the rest that Contact provides, so they don't need it as much; they need other things. MARK: In what ways does Contact fit in with tbe values and needs of the white counterculture? K: Contact is concerned with intuition, aesthetics, physi· cality, "being present in the flow." That's definitely "counter" to the mainstream culture's emphasis on rationality, intellect, status, and achievement. I'm a third generation Contactor: I learned about Contact not from the originators, but from their students. I keep thinking of questions I'd like to ask the originators, because I'd like to know if some of the political implications that I see in Contact are just my own projections, or were the values of my teachers, or actually came from the originators themselves and were consciously intended to be a part of the work. For instance: why was this form named Contact Improvisation and not Steve Paxton Tech· nique? In the entire modern dance world, every new approach except Contact is based on a cult of personality: Graham technique, Cunningham technique, Hawkins technique, etc. The Contact originators probably proceeded into this name very naturally, without even think· ing about it. But to me, that name is revolutionary-it reflects a whole new value system in dance. M: What was this value system? K: A notion of equality among people working together, without stars. I understand that Paxton was a teacher at Bennington at the time he began exploring Contact, and that his co-workers were mostly students. And yet, if two people try to do Contact while maintaining the typical student-teacher relationship, I think those two wouldn't end up doing much Contact at all. Both the name and the form itself assume that Contact is a collective creation that is bigger than individuals. There is a letting go of ego, and a letting go of traditional role expectations, that is unprecedented in dance. Effort-Shape work is another approach to dance that is not called by the originator's name. But Effort-Shape is based on an amazingly thorough and rigorous analysis of movement by Rudolph Laban. Laban's contribution was essentially intellectual, and the dancers who made use of his theories contributed the physical application that is now referred to as "Effort-Shape". Contact is essentially a physical manifestation. Have you ever struggled to define Contact? Every time someone asks me "What is Contact Improvisation?" my mind goes blank, even though I have carefully read and studied many written definitions of CI trying to prepare for this inevitable occasion. I invariably end up demonstrating physically. I think the best definition of Contact is "that which happens when you do Contact." We can extrapolate theories from Contact, but what we have been given is a physical legacy. l remember that Laban's theories had a similar impact on my dance work as Contact has had. It was a joyful release from the mind-set: "the correct way to study dance is to memorize and duplicate the movements of a famous dancer." This method does give you the advantage of learning someone else's lifetime of bodily insights, but whose body? Laban's work outlined the basic principles of dance design much as the Bauhaus has outlined the principles of visual and three-dimensional design for visual artists. It gives the dancer a choice of the whole universe of dance material, not just the iota that one famous person has dedicated his or her life to. That way, each person can choose the iota that best suits his or her own temperament, which is likely to produce a much more deeply felt commitment to their work. The result of freeing dancers from the master-apprentice model will be a lot more diversitv and creativity in dance. Contact also frees dance from 'the master-apprentice model. A maxim I picked up from my Contact teachers: "The dance (Contact) is the teacher." M: In what other specific ways does Contact reflect a new value system? K: Well, take the notion of taking responsibility for yourself, which is a big lesson to be learned in Contact. In Transactional Analysis there is a concept called "the rescue triangle", containing the roles of the victim, the prosecutor and the rescuer. According to this schema, when a person tries to "help" someone else by "taking care of her'', they create a victim who will later resent and persecute them for it. The way to avoid this dynamic is by not doing more than 50 percent of the work. To do more is "taking over" someone else's problem, and laying a subtle power tnp. In a Contact duet, you only do 50 percent of the work: you 're simply responsible for yourself. You are empathetic with your partner, in some situations you even extend help to your partner, but you do so in a way that doesn't take over the duet or solve what is basically your partner's problem. Giving body surface to ease your partner's fall, rather than grabbing your partner to "save him" is a prime example. In a Contact duet, each partner takes assertive actions, but each does so in a way that leaves choices open to the partner. When you jump on a contact dancer, she may roll out from under you; she may choose not to take your weight in the way you predicted, and that's part of the dance. Contact makes an important political statement about relationships-about what is my responsibility, my territory, my decision making power; and what is yours. n with Keriac and Mark Pritchard San Francisco, Summer 1979 Folk Art & State Art K: I have a pet theory I'd like to throw out, based on Curt Sach's book World History of the Dance: Art can be divided into "Folk Art" and "State Art". When ballet began, it went like this: all through Europe there was folk dancing; each village had its own dance. Dance had a real function in the ordinary lives of ordinary people; it was for weddings, funerals, religious festivals. It was for marking passages in individual lives and for coalescing a community spirit. It was inherently participatory. Political power in Europe was scattered in fiefdoms among many nobles. Then one of those nobles became more powerful than his neighbors, took over the lands around him and became king of that land. The King brought the disenfranchised nobles to his court, and absorbed their power. At court, the nobles didn't have anything useful to do; society life took over-dances, parties, social events. For entertainment, peasants were brought in from the country to demonstrate their dances. The nobles watched, the peasants danced. The nobles applauded the highest jumps, the fanciest turns, the flashiest costumes. Technique and showmanship became the content of the dance; Dance became a performance art. When the dancing was over, the peasants were given a good meal and sent back to resume their work on the land. One or two peasants, the ones who had been the most amusing to the audience, were asked to remain at court. These few spent their days refining their technique, giving performances and teaching dance (it became fashionable for nobles to learn the peasant dances.) The art of the King's dancers gave the King power over others, in the same way that the King's stable of fine horses added to his status and power over others. As long as their ballet continued to awe the audience, the dancers did not work at crafts or till the soil; they ate at the King's table. They were professional dancers. I have told this story as though "State Art" only arose in Europe, but I believe it has happened all over the world. "State Art" is characterized by an emphasis on technique which is mastered by a dedicated few, who then are watched by an audience. It is inherently elitist-a few talented people are given the resources necessary to support their artistic growth on a full-time basis; their achievements are then used to enhance and increase the status and power of the aristocratic patron who has the wealth to pay the bill. It is characterized by competition between artists and between patrons, by separation of performer from audience, by its emphasis on style rather than spirit. "Folk Art" is characterized by its accessibility to all people-the steps are simple, the spirit in which you do it is more important than virtuosity. It is non-professionalyou kick your heels in the village festival, and then go back to your survival support~ng work t?e next day. It is participatory-it's your weddmg, your life happenmg through the dance. You do not dance because you have to, you do not dance for someone else's pleasure, according to someone else's standards. You dance by your own choice, for your own satisfaction and because it co~nects you with others. There is no applause, the reward ts the dancing itself. Contact as Folk Art K: I see Contact as a folk art, with folk art values inherent in the work. Its basis is kinesthetic, rather than visual. The dance unfolds from giving primary attention to the bodily sensations of the dancer rather th:in from atte~ding to how it will look to the vi~wer. I~ ts a cooperative, connecting-to-others form. While dancmg Cont~c~, y_ou exist in the present, from moment to moment-it ts literally your life in the act of living. The context chosen for Contact activities at its onset reflected folk art values: no stage lights, no costumes, no proscenium stage, "performers" would grunt, groan, talk casually to each other, talk to the audience, quit dancing abruptly. Conta.ct "performances" frequently seen:ed like. a commumty gathering in witness of an event m the lives of the performers rather than an entertainment for the audience. The weh-established phenomenon of the Contact Jam is unique among modern dance activities: the jam is n~t a class to learn better technique, not a performance to impress . . others, it is dancing for its own sake, and a way to socialize with your community. M: That may be the way Contact was performed and practiced at the beg~nning, bu_t th~t doesn't seem too descriptive of what is happening right now. [Note date of interview-Eds.] K: True. Contact performance groups are showing a trend toward incorporating "State Art" values into the work. Take Mangrove as an example. They s~ill perform. most of the time with simple lights, no proscemum stage, mformal atmosphere. These are all anti-elitist elements. H~wever, Mangrove has steadily increased the!r use of the~tncal elements blended into the contact, which makes this essentially participatory form more "performance. orie~ted". Now they are blending choreographed material wit~ contact as well, and also including modern dance techmque and "theater courses as part of their workshop classes. M: What political implications does this have? K: Bringing folk art values int~ a perform~nce situation and making it work is a revolut10nary act, m my book. It not only re-defines what is possible to be performed, but also fundamentally alters our perceptions of interpersonal and power relationships. Are we (as audie~ce member~) stand-ins for our aristocratic predecessors, mtent on bemg entertained; are we stand-ins for our peasant predecessors, witnessing a community ritual; o~ is this new perfo~mance mode actually building a new societal structure which does not presume class division? Traditions M: There are now individuals and groups doing Contact who not only perform for money but who are supported by grants. K: Right. They're doing a form which is anathema to "State Art" values, yet they're plugging in to state support. Revolutions are not necessarily what will earn a living. My intuition is that Mangrove and _other grou~s like them will have to make some concess10ns to traditional values in order to survive professionally. If you try to make your living as a performing group, there is pressure to fit into the traditional _mold. The pressure. does not only come from the outside, but al.so f!o~ within. As performers, we naturally w~nt to ~amtam ht~h standards and communicate effectively wtth our audience. Our internalized sense of what is "good quality performance" is largely based on the previous model availabl~ to us-"State Art". This model has also shaped the audience's expectations to such an extent th~t the public may not be able to perceive your work at all if you do not conform to tl}e assumptions and values expected. M: It seems as if there is a set of considerations, in traditional art, that people think validate their dance, such as working with a teacher, preferably a well-~nown one, or an established choreographer, or an established ~ompany. Also: working on specifically choreographed pieces. Doing performances that resemble traditional ones. Going on tour. Doing publicity. Applying for grants. K: All those things validate your dance. But what di:> they validate? Your technical competence, not your creative skill. My technique was always lousy, and I w~s more interested in creative work. I wanted to create first, then develop my technique to get under it. But th_e oppos

Title: by Steve Paxton
Abstract: Steve Paxton reflects on the principles and techniques of Contact Improvisation, particularly the act of falling and adapting to variables of distance, position, and direction. He emphasizes the importance of timing, preparation, and trust in the body and the earth, as well as the role of muscle memory and open-mindedness in navigating physical interactions.
Text: I am examining the passage from up to down. I look at the range of the passage, from the small dance of standing, to the linked falls of walking, to swoops and dives from high points on other bodies. With experience, the act of falling has come to include an ability to adapt my body to the variables of distance, position, and direction and to intuit which part of my body will take the first moment of impact. The first part of my body that touches the ground I can use as a lever. By extending to that part, I can unify limbs and torso to prepare a sequence through which to smoothly transmit the energy of the fall, and my weight, into the floor. Within the brief freedom of the fall, my body can convert a sudden accident into a controlled descent. The result of so many changes in spatial and kinesthetic orientation in a short time has caused me to perceive space as spherical. The sphere is an accumulated image gathered from several senses-vision being one. As if quickly looking in all directions gives me an image of what it might be like to have a visual surface all over my body, instead of skin. The skin is the best source for the image, because it works in all directions at once. If we could turn the skin off, we would appreciate it much more. But the skin works most of the time on automatic pilot. The conscious mind is alerted if unusual stimulation appears on the surface of the body, but, I don't notice the touch of my clothes or my weight in a chair most of the time. In Contact Improvisation, however, I find I am hanging by my skin. And relying on its information to protect me, to warn me, to feed back to me the data to which I am responding. We are looking at material from 1972, training for the first performance of Contact Improvisation, at the John Weber Gallery. It was a hot New York City day, but everyone seemed game. What can be learned by catching a hurtling body? The importance of timing. That there is such a thing as a correct preparation. That understanding the technique with the mind is different than understanding with the body. That momentum can be extended and used once the initial impact is absorbed or deflected. Or that the seemingly impossible juxtaposition of a small woman catching a large man has possibilities-most of them leading to the floor. But that is reasonable. Trying to stop or hold too much weight is dangerous. The idea is to discover what is simplest to do. In a state of trust of the body and the earth, we believed we could learn to handle the forces involved in physical interactions between two people who permit each other the freedom to improvise. The first instant of any fall is crucial. At that point a roll may be prepared. If the preparation isn't made at the first moment, falling takes place without guidance from the faller. What can a body do to be safe? Commitment to something which isn't happening is a barrier between me and my body's circumstance. Memory of past judgements tells me that prejudging is not secure. And memory cannot function consciously because at these speeds I can't think my way to safety. If thinking is too slow, is an open state of mind useful? Seems to be. I remember deciding to learn falling skills, which have become muscle memories. I figured my chances of survival were greater with these skills than without-an assessment of things to come. In this way, prejudgement and memory do play a part in what is happening now. Although adults and children fall at the same velocity, adults are more liable to injure themselves because their mass is greater in proportion to structural strength. It is possible to develop responses to deal with this safely. Slides, rolls or full surface landings, which spread the impact of landing over as much of the muscle area as possible, are useful in Contact Improvisation as they are in the martial arts of Japan. I am concerned with the possibilities of guiding the momentum of the fall away from collision with the floor or partner. A body could endure for decades. I don't want to injure joints. On the other hand, shouldn't focus on doom. Can't exclude fear. Efficient falls tend to turn into slides or rolls, transforming vertical momentum into horizontal travel. I may find a last minute leverage from my partner to enable me to land upon my feet. My fall might be guided so it spirals around the body of my partner. Thus, a fall starting on the downward path can be guided into a circle orbiting my partner, and finally, its momentum used to aid in regaining a high perch. Contractive energy or tensions overpower the sensing of subtle movement, and so gravity is masked. Relaxed is almost right; but, flaccid is wrong. In exploring the small dance of skeletal alignment while standing, I am sensing subtle falls of parts of the skeleton. One thing is clear. I have little memory, muscular or mental, of what I've danced. The specific movements my body executes when I improvise do not register consciously, and I can't reconstitute them. I feel transparent in the action. Causing it only a little, and holding no residuals. ~

Title: by Randy Warshaw
Abstract: Randy Warshaw discusses the evolution of Contact Improvisation techniques, emphasizing the importance of physical safety and sensory education for students. He reflects on the balance between teaching specific skills and fostering personal exchange and improvisation in the dance form.
Text: As the sixties gave birth to new ideas, the techniques of the seventies evolved to provide tools for applying and teaching those discoveries. When Steve Paxton invited that first group of people to perform contact improvisation in 1972, he had no technique for showing them what they would be doing, or how they would do it safely; but he did have a group of gifted athletes, people with strong physical backgrounds, that could do potentially dangerous movement with minimal risk of injury. Starting with that solid physical base, they developed a movement form that was at once both spectacular and imaginative. As contact began to be taught, physical surity could not be assumed. Over the last decade, a comprehensive technique has evolved whereby students can very gently be introduced to the range of physical states encountered in the dancing. Moments from the dancing can be extracted and introduced to students in a controlled and structured setting. Because of this, it has been possible to teach people of greatly varying physical abilities complex physical maneuvers. The capacity to teach skills and develop physical range and confidence has made contact improvisation highly accessible and attractive. It's provided the necessary and important function of laying a solid foundation for full and open improvising. In contact improvisation, the senses need to be educated. Disorientation must become an acceptable sensation. A released body, supported in length, can be developed. Trust, patiently nurtured through confidence and familiarity, prepares the way for diversity. Through trust, awkward, uncomfortable moments of vulnerability and powerful moments of virtuosity become equally rich. When I began teaching contact, I wanted to pass on to others the simplicity and accessibility of the form. As teaching material, I chose those skills which I had been taught and felt confident and competent in. I found it possible to teach others to do them also. I got a lot of satisfaction in seeing my students develop abilities to soften, to roll, to give and take weight in diverse situations. But after several years of teaching this way, I began to feel limited. I felt that in teaching skills I was operating within a very finite field of experience. Though I was approaching what I considered to be the heart of the dancing, I wasn't quite there. Who was it that said there were 87 million permutations in contact? Well, I felt up against those permutations. It might take a very long time to find and teach all those permutations, but all I would be teaching was permutations. It wasn't quite the dancing. " It became burdensome to stay at least one step ahead of my students, each week coming up with new things to do. They were all learning lots of physical possibilities, types of physical moments, but.week to week I felt weighted by the task of finding new combinations for them to experience, weighted by the dependency that kind of teaching fostered . . Developing skills is a necessary part of teaching and le~rnmg contact. But there's a danger in making these skills overly precious. It's important to remember that skills are meant to introduce types of experiences that may be encountered in the dancing. What is found in that experience is the important thing. It's important that students notice their growing acceptance of disorientation, their a~areness of the body's ability to organize and take care of Itself, ~he trust and confidence they gain in themselves and their partners to stay with a moment, and meet the needs of each changing moment. Too often, though, stud~nts focus exclusively on mastery of maneuvers, challengmg themselves with more and more complex maneuvers as ~heir confidence increases. Mastery of maneuvers can be important in gaining confidence, but I think it's more important to take that confidence into the dancing than to take the maneuvers. It's the orientation towards a higher and higher refinement that runs the risk of distracting students from the opportunities for a more pers?nal exchange with their partner. The subtleties of any given moment can so easily be buried beneath the execution of that next move. When people like Steve Paxton, Lisa Nelson, Daniel Lepk?ff, and Nancy Stark Smith were performing and teachmg regularly, there seemed to consistently be new, good dancers emerging through contact. A couple of years ago a lot of g~od teaching and performing of contact dropped off (here m North America). Perhaps this was due to the fact that many of the early pioneers of contact had fo_und a fullness and maturity in their dancing that they wished to apply to other areas of interest. It seems natural to_ me t~at eight or so years of attention to any one thing will begm to call forth derivatives. Maybe, as contact had established itself fairly solidly at that point, a new freedom existed wherein they could let go of its nurturing. Also, as contact was just beginning to catch on in Europe, there was the need for teaching and performing there. In the absence of these dancers, I thought two things happened. First, many people who had been doing contact for awhile mistook these people's change for a change in contact imp

Title: STILL MOVING
Abstract: This article discusses the dance culture of Lower Manhattan, focusing on Danspace at St. Mark's Church and the CONTACT AT 10th & 2nd festival. It explores the relationship between performers and audiences in Contact Improvisation, emphasizing communication, cooperation, and the importance of understanding the premises of the form.
Text: This ,1rticie, ".'itil! .\fovi11g," by Steve Paxton, in,rngurates CQ's new colullln of the Sell/le 11c1me. \Vi th this column, we hope to encourage writings that cllidress tbe current tbi11king, perception and practice of Co11tc1ct Improvisation. Call it shop talk. Call it a conference-call, a sounding board. We 're calling it Still Moving. Please participate by sending your writings as well as your responses to what you read here, to us at CQ, P.O. Box 603, Nortbampton, MA 01061. STILL MOVING by Steve Paxton Cynthia Hedstrom is leaving Danspace (at St. Mark's Church, NYC). She has directed its use for three years and created a center in which the dance culture of Lower Manhattan moved and thrived. The space is one of the desirable venues for dances born in loft studios. The proportions are larger than the usual studio, but intimate enough to convey the sort of non-theatrical detail frequently laced through new dance work. The floor is hard and fast. The audience sits on carpeted steps under a balcony on three sides of the room. The upper area serves for lights and video/photo documentation. High above the floor, the ceiling vault is a great curve which caps the air lightly and elegantly. Susan Milani and Alan Gardner photos by Steve Paxton Carol Mullins does the lighting and Dan Froot coordinates other elements: sound, slides, films and sets. This team handled the many details, changes, complications of CONTACT AT 10th & 2nd with care and efficiency. It is something of a test to produce new works and improvisations because much remains unknown, untested or mutable right down to the wire. A tight, light, responsive system is invaluable for breaking new ground. However fine and airy the space itself may be, it is this team which made the house comfortable for the several dozen choreographers and performers who gathered there for 7 productions June 10, 11, 12 & 16, 17, 18, 19, 1983. The performers and choreographers had a great deal to pull together themselves. They arrived from England, California, Canada, the US, and from around Manhattan, with their concepts, improvisations and dancing bodies. They arranged themselves into the general format of Contact Improvisation or Choreographed/semi-set works with minimal ado. As (traffic) director of these events, I am eternally grateful for their grace under fire. • Contact Improvisation has been a performance form since its inception. Audiences and critics have challenged the appropriateness of this decision, and I think it true that the audienceperformer relationship may serve the performer here as much or more than the audience, certainly for those observers who require more explicit signalllng of intent in their audit. Their expectation is a rather fruitless approach to Contact Improvisation. It is, after all, improvisational. Intent and manifestation amount to the same thing. Further, any contact duet is a manifestation of a fraction of the possibilities of the form, so, audiences seeing a performance for the first time must be content with the specifics of that dance, if not the general idea. Much that is excellent in Contact Improvisation is the result of omissions-avoiding injury, for instance, yet allowing moments of instability while playing with powerful physical forces. Omit jarring the body, miscommunication, physical confusion, willful accomplishment. These omissions are about survival. Survival may be taken for granted by audiences. The performer of CI is not so phlegmatic. The notion that CI performance is 'ungenerous', as audiences have observed, results from CI performers paying close attention to life and limb. If the audience feels neglected due to lack of eye contact, for instance, they might consider that in CI training peripheral, non-focussed vision is employed. This is very awkward socially (try it at a party) but creates a state of mind in which vision is not paramount, for once, in the sensory spectrum of the performer. Mass is therefore more clearly sensed, as is positioning and change. Audiences of televised sports are accustomed to seeing athletes preparing for their tasks, and watching them work (play). These performers are primed to make unusual efforts and we watch the results of their play knowing what they are attempting to do, and, with some, we understand how they hope to do it-an empathy born of knowing the rules of the situation. I believe knowing the premises of CI creates a similar empathy, but the spectator must become used to the idea that a Form which is proposing to deal with improvisation formally, rather than being goal-oriented or aesthetically based, requires some other sort of empathy-perhaps that of the naturalist on a ramble. It is the mi.turalist who organizes the view into forms. The river will not speak of gravity n·or surface tension nor subsurface currents. These are attributes for the naturalist to infer. The birds signal their intent to the other birds. The naturalist is eavesdropping. Birds just bird. The naturalist must bird along. In short, theatrical forms rely mostly on contrast and conflict. CI depends on communication and cooperation. Sports rely on conflicting goals and 'plays'. CI has no point-system and the maneuvers are relatively unpredictable. Fred Holland & Ishmael Houston-Jones, June 1983 Dance has visual aesthetics, Cl has accepted a much more 'general look'. It just happens. Its subsurface currents must be inferred. I suppose we are asking audiences to look in unusual ways, but what of that? Every medium requires a shift of focus, every culture. Even every day. I would like an audience of Sherlock Holmeses who would discern the interpersonal currents, understand the dialogue, and maintain a stance of no blame, even in the face of the guilty performer who could not fulfill his own idea1s in performance. I gather from what I have written that I do not see the audience-performer relationship as one where the performer has a duty to the audience. I see it as a relationship where they have a relationship with each other, and if the audience may have expectations of the performer, well, so may the performer have expectations of the audience. You no doubt get the drift. "It matters what you give an audience to do" (Christie Svane). "Art criticism is for artists as ornithology is for the birds" (Barnett Newman). • Two works from CONT ACT AT 10th & 2nd, one of the semi-set variety, the second improvisational, remain especially vivid in my memory. Fred Holland and Ishmael Houston-} ones performed a gritty duet which segued seamlessly from contact to conflict to contest; through emotional areas into clear physical spaces; to sense-altering moments when the two bodies seemed to drag or claw through space; to events of high play, and casual conversation. Nothing settled as the dance progressed. It was one fevered long transition. It spoke of men, Blacks; they were at war at play at art at odds at one. The space was used darkly. A sound score of soulful mechanical grating and chugging added emphatic menace to some moments. The same sound, more frequent toward the end of the work, became a wash of rather loud pulsations, but were merely background noise when I perceived two men working in a factory. The throb of sound was hypnotic, and I had a feeling of falling back and forth through time, from the present moment of contact to several apparent references in their/our past: scrapings from old newsreels, late night TV wars, items in smoky bars. On the Saturday night of the second weekend, 5 folk who teach or perform contact in Lower Manhattan did an amazing thing which I have not heard brought up for discussion, though if there is orthodoxy in improvisation, this performance was a challengegauntlet down from the git-go. Looking the length of the space, I saw the lights come up on an Indianfile of performers facing right. The leader whirled and slapped the second across the face, which turned the second around to face the third; 2 slapped 3, 3 slapped 4, 4 slapped 5, who spun completely around and returned the com

Title: CONTACT AS THERAPY
Abstract: Irina Harris and Rita Ossi discuss their collaboration using Contact Improvisation as a therapeutic tool in Italy. They describe a workshop they co-led, exploring how movement and physical interaction can help individuals understand and address psychological issues. They advocate for the use of Contact as a form of body therapy, particularly in cultures that tend to neglect the body.
Text: In July of 1980, Rita Ossi participated in a contact workshop with me in Venice, Italy, for rehabilitation therapists and others interested in Contact as a therapeutic matrix, and thus began a fruitful collaboration which continues to enrich our respective fields of interest. Rita was then doing psychotherapy for a public health service, helping long-term patients become autonomous and reintegrated into the society. What most preoccupied her about these patients was the sense of expropriation that their bodies had suffered, the lack of care for themselves physically, and their fear or inability to adequately relate to others. She found that only by direct means and experience-body work-was it possible to improve their self-concept. As Rita continued to study Contact with me in Rome, she found the concepts of Contact Improvisation startlingly powerful (even if some she had previously encountered in Reich, Lowen, Perls, and Feldenkrais): establish contact with yourself and others, turn yourself upside down, feel weight and energy, perceive and occupy space, give and receive weight (physically and psychologically!), understand where the fears knot up inside. Each of us from her own starting point was convinced of the therapeutic value of contact. So last summer in Treviso, we held a workshop together. Most participants said that their primary reason for wanting to experiment with Contact was to widen their movement experience. Little by little as we worked, we noted that everyone found the work psychically therapeutic also. The workshop begins. After a brief introduction, I start some Contact exercises: with the floor, with various body parts, with space, weight, with another's body (with and not against). It is for them both an exploration and a discovery, a putting into focus, a union and a clash with their own sensations and postural habits. We go on to balances, somersaults and other upside down movements, feeling weight and energy, trying active and passive roles. There are moments when people seem confused because they are feeling new sensations, coordinations never before explored, relationships up to this point barely recognized; and there are other magic moments in which the movement flows as dance and everyone perceives the fusion of mind and body. When someone in the group encounters an apparently insurmountable difficulty, we stop. I try diversi:: physical approaches. Rita mentions the symbolic significance the movement might express, the psychological valence of that individual or group difficulty. She tries not to be categorical but proposes various hypotheses, interpretations which each can then investigate for himself. She gives some examples: not being able to give one's own weight or take another's may mean lack of confidence, fearfulness, mistrustfulness of others, rigidity in relationships; holding the head and neck stiff perhaps means wanting to control everything rationally; holding the legs, especially in couple work, could mean fear of sexual invasion, etc   Memories of old traumas arise, consciousness of habits (postural and psychic) taken on at particular times in one's life, fears that have never been overcome. When, on the last day, we put together sound and movement-roaringthere is a moment of panic. Broken, held sounds come out and they suddenly realize that these sounds open a new realm of the body. Eagerly and at length they work on the impasse. At the end of every day, Rita and I discussed the work accomplished, in what manner each participant had shown us something of himself. We examined our impressions of their personalities, their problems. The following day I proposed exercises relating to what had emerged, integrating this work into the general development of the workshop. And so the workshop was guided by psychological as well as physical considerations. The therapeutic effect was confirmed by the participants themselves in our final discussion when they talked of their sense of well being and physical pleasure, and also of awareness, each at his own level, of "dark areas", of the lack of acceptance of parts of their bodies, and of the possibility of accepting those parts and better integrating them. Rita and I had decided not to comment specifically but generally, to allow the experience itself to bring eventual insights. Rita has been able to verify, even in other situations, that the discovery of certain personality disturbances, if it happens in the body, with its own reactions and sensations, is more quickly recognized and can provoke more radical changes than an analytic psychotherapy based exclusively on words which often mask, color, and dilute significance and change. Certainly Contact is a dance form, full of life and expression, but we maintain that it can be used also as an efficient psychotherapy, or better, as "body therapy". Both in Italy and America where present physical fads tend towards negation of the body rather than self-discovery, we would like to see Contact better known and used. f! I would be very interested to know if and what anyone else is doing with the therapeutic aspects of Contact work. Irina Harris, 516 Nordhoff Dr., Leonia, NJ 07605.

Title: RANDOM NOTES from the Breitenbush jam
Abstract: Terrie Yaffe shares stream-of-consciousness reflections from the Breitenbush jam, touching on themes of ownership, disorientation, and the power of dance in relation to personal and political experiences.
Text: Time's up. Now words must reach the paper. Highlights. It's history-no fancy anybody's moving around like they owned the world. We owned the clock on the wall; we owned the gold in our teeth. The sun in the morning, the hot steam in the air, the hot sweat on our backs-we owned it. We owned the day before and the day after. We owned the color green and the color orange and all the blues and the color black. If my language offends you, forgive me. This is an ex-marxist speaking in tongues. Anybody home? It's good to get turned around, to get turned upside down because maybe for a little while you don't remember where you are ie. disorientation. I never counted who cares how many so many dances all different dances. I remember my black eye but not how I got it only that it felt (how should I say it)-earned. Not a day went by that I didn't refer to a poem I'd been working on. No matter how many times I tried to rewrite it, the beginning few lines always came up the same: Dance/ a million laughs for El Salvador/ for god's sake/ Someone dance. I'd started it many weeks before when someone I know was dying fast :ind was waiting on what? I a miracle. And really I had never thought much about miracles since, well, hebrew school in N.J. The light burning on Hannukkah was a miracle when one day's worth of oil in a burning lamp lasted an entire 8 days because someone with a fast horse and a few extra days to spare took a chance suspended his imagination and against all odds traveled to retrieve more oil. Before the jam, the poem had seemed vague and simple and incomplete. Five days later, without changing even one word it seemed to take root as a poem for the first time. Before the jam, my words seemed to belittle the very serious political and social aspects of the war in El Salvador but as I began to let go of the poem much in the same way as I began to let go in my dancing the actual meaning of the poetry became more clear. Dance/ a million laughs for El Salvador/ for god's sake/ Someone dance The current trend bespeaks the mood/ Bread and more bread/ and more bread Noone is alarmed at nature/ Midwives slap each grave image Sweat and muscle culminate beyond what waits A broomhandle blooms/ and winks

Title: STILL MOVING RESPONSE TO "CONT ACT AS THERAPY"
Abstract: Byron Brown and Carol Swann respond to Irina Harris and Rita Ossi's article "Contact as Therapy," sharing their experiences integrating contact dance into psychology studies and dance therapy. They explore the concept of boundaries in body therapy, particularly with drug addicts, and pose questions about how contact dance can support psychotherapeutic processes.
Text: Dear CQ, After I read the article by Irina Harris and Rita Ossi, "Contact as Therapy," in the last CQ [CQ IX 3, Fall 1984], I felt encouraged to write to you. This year I'm finishing my studies in psychology in Heidelberg and for 2'h years I've been doing contact improvisation and dance therapy. My interest is to integrate contact dance into my studies. Experiences you can have in this kind of dance, like flow of energy, weight exchange, the falling, trusting, flying,   will extend both your physical range of possibilities and your personal growth as well. At the moment I'm working on the conceptualization of boundaries/limitations in body therapy with drug addicts. First I'd like to introduce a little bit of the psychological thinking, which is very much based on Gestalt therapy, before I come to my questions about how contact dance might support a psychotherapeutic process. · From the psychological point of view, ego-boundaries are seen as constitutive [sic] for the ego, as a place where the identity of one's self manifests. Boundaries are the points of contact. It is like a membrane which allows a certain interaction between an organism and the environment, a point of contact where energy passes through constantly. Exploring your boundaries, your points of contact, you experience yourself, your ego, in relationship to the other. The ego is existent through the contact point and defines the boundary between the personal and the unpersonal space. Contact at the boundary creates a sense of independence and isolation, and at the same time it is contact and a possibility to share. This dualistic character of the contact at the boundary is necessary for the development and stabilization of what is called identity. Because of its importance for personal growth, you have to care about the very complex concept of boundaries in the psychological field. Sometimes you have to support people to build up (ego-) boundaries, sometimes you have to support them to become less rigid and more flexible at their boundaries or to rediscover the functions of contact, so that they can develop more ego-strength, autonomy and responsibility, etc. At this point, I'd like to find out how contact dance might support this psychotherapeutic work. In contact improvisation, the point of contact is a basic principle, first of all on a physical level, and for me, it always has to do with exploring and experiencing boundanes and limitations. The body 1s the pnmarv boundary between inner world and o~ter world ·and a manifestation, a personal system of what I am. I'd like to look at contact dance for a while in these terms and I'd appreciate very much, if anyone would like to respond to my following questions or share their experience in another way with me. I hope my GermanEnglish is understandable. Thanks a lot to Bob Rease and Robin Feld, who encouraged me during the August Summer Intensive in Heidelberg to come out with my interest. e What kind of boundaries do you experience doing contact dance? How do they manifest? • What kind of boundary-experiences do you have in relationship/interaction (in a duo, trio,   group)? -physical level -emotional level @ How do you experience contact at the boundary in terms of: -in between space (Zwischenraume) -surface-contact (Oberflachenkontakt) -full weight exchange (Gewichtsaustausch) What kinds of experiences do you have dealing with boundaries in terms of: -respecting boundaries/limitations -breaking through boundaries/ " -protecting with boundaries/ " -going beyond boundaries/ " What kind of support   and   What kind of demands   do vou need (from the teacher, from the group or environment), to have boundary-experiences?   to be able to extend boundaries? • Other associations, thoughts, fantasies on this theme Best wishes, Gila Albers Kuhlhof 24 4450 Lingen/ Ems 1 W-Germany
