Title: RESPONSE TO "DEALING WITH THE HEAT"
Abstract: Kris Wheeler responds to Nancy Stark Smith's editorial note "Dealing with the Heat," discussing the value of friction and conflict in Contact Improvisation and relating it to a model of creative processes.
Text: Dear Nancy, I appreciated your Editor Note last issue, "Dealing with the Heat," {CQ IX 3, Fall 1984], because I too, have begun to see value in the friction of opposition. I have felt my tendency to harmon_ize conflict in so many aspects of my life, from social interaction to simply how I reside in my own tissue. And lately, I have been exploring in both my personal life and my dancing the parts of myself that I had dismissed by omitting 'no's, by resolving differences rather than feeling the heat of the friction. I perceive that there is so much ~o be gained in this exploration and thmk that it applies to much of what I have experienced with Contact Improvisation. To engage in conflict one must be willing to draw upon the passionate charge that emanates from one's "guts'', tapping the heart of the matter. I am only beginning to appreciate the value of this juice. I have avoided it out of fear of sounding unreasonable or being too ego bound. Now I see it as a beautiful force that can orient me toward knowing-viscerally-my sense of purpose. I see the basic aesthetic of Contact as one of merging with natural forces, going with the flow, and experiencing union with both our partner and a process of engaging the physical laws of nature. Asserting control, saying n_o to this_ union, or establishing a distinct self m the dance is generally not done. As we continue to explore the mysterious beauties of the original aesthetic, I'm curious about how Contact will change if we bring more of ourselves to the dance, if our relationships include difference and separation as well as union, personal passion as well as the impersonal play of weight and balance. I see the orientation in Contact Improvisation toward harmony and process as an important voice on a leading edge of our culture, evidence of something more spontaneous and essential in dance and relationships than the superficial and goal oriented nature of much of our world. And I see the incorporation of conflict and passions as an important passage if Contact is going to continue to be a valuable social force. In order to discuss this point and to offer a perspective on Contact Improvisation in relation to our culture I'd like to share some of the work o'f Charley Johnston, M.D. He is a psychiatrist with a recently completed book, The Creative Imperative, about a model of all creative processes, from artistic endeavors to the process of developing a relationship, to developmental shifts over a lifetime, to cultural change and the creation of civilization . . . He sees similar structural shifts through all of ~hes_e processes as they grow. Although 1t will be unfortunately oversimplified, I'll describe the gist of this model in order to offer a point of view on Contact Improvisation's relationship to our current culture and on Contact's own development. . The basic pattern Dr.Johnston ~es m all creative process, all of life, is from formlessness/essence/mystery into form/manifestation/materialization and then into an integration process that eventually embraces both the structure and the essence. In other words, ~rom oneness into twoness, from unity ~nto separatwn, from what is archetypically fei:male mto archetypically male, from universal and spiritual into material and intellectual; and then into inte~ratio~. He _divides these three stages mto five which I'll call: 1) Pre-stage, 2) Early Stage, 3) Middle Stage, 4) Late Stage, 5) Integration. I'll describe each stage with exampl~s o~ developments in an art project, a ltfenme, and culture. It is important to note that each shift into the next stage reflects a transformation into an entirely different paradigm or system of values. And each transformation is a quantum leap into a larger capacity for experiencing aliveness, for being able to handle and even enjoy existing amongst unknowns. Pre-stage This is a gestalting time, a time of unity, before one is particularly aware of a cr.eative direction beginning to differen t1ate from this womb of possibility. In a lifetime, it is prenatal experience and early infancy, when the child bonds with parent. Culturally, it is the time when life is ordered by connection with nature-a powerful and mysterious ~orce. One lived within the unity of tnbe which was inseparable from nature and her cycles. CQ/CI Sourcebook 101 Early Stage . The early stage is the time df inspiration, the spontaneous possibility of essence taking form, the first notion of direction in creating a work of art. It is childhood, a time of fantasy. It is the time when cultures moved from tribal nature to the sophistication we associate with the early Greeks, the Aztecs, and Ancient Zimbawe. Basically, life is still experienced as a mysterious force of which we are in awe and by which we are totally influenced. Many of the special beauties of Contact Improvisation are reflections of this stage. We dance with spontaneity and participate in an often magical process that is larger than ourselves individually. Culturally, this is a spiritual time. Zen emerged from a culture at this stage. Not until the next stage do we become more personal, more passionate. Middle Stage As the first shapings of inspiration take enough form, they begin to challenge their source, their essence, for attention and belief. Here, distinction Integration The next stage, integration, is reflected by the leading edge of our culture. The essence of this stage is most apparent to me as I think of those people who, as they age, become sagelike. They come to gradually encompass all of the stages-they appreciate the mystery of life as well as the passions while maintaining facility with the intellectual and material aspects. With a work of art, this is when the work is complete and the artist becomes separate from it. Even though you may have created it, it will be quite a while before it is understood. Now it becomes a distinct entity with the capacity to teach even you who created it. I see Contact Improvisation as an aspect of Western Culture's movement into integration. I think it emerged as a counterswing from the materialistic direction of our culture. It has served me well in this regard. It has given me a taste of community while all I had known was transience. It has taught me about shedding of ego to enjoy the dance beyond my control; there truly is something to be trusted as alive without willful effort to make it happen. These are rather foreign notions to the goal oriented lifestyle of America in the twentieth century. But what about the twenty-first century? Ultimately, integration is more than a counterswing. Contact rather successsfully synthesized the mysterious, the more unformed and core aspects of the early stage with the articulate, discerning, and mechanical aspects of the late stage. But in this time of overstated glory for the intellect, I see much more value in engaging the heat of difference than for ideological articulation. In the same way that revitalizing the teachings of ancient prophets has been so meaningful to expand our capacity for living sanely in these seemingly insane times, I think we have much to gain in reclaiming the personal juice that is a powerful part of the uniqueness of each of us. I am excited to experience the potential embodiment of the charge of passions in myself and in connection with Contact Improvisation as it grows with me and with all of us. What will these changes be? Thanks Nancy, for all of your work with the Quarterly and sharing your growing edge. Sincerely, Kris Wheeler Seattle, WA Sept. 21, 1984 drawing by Christina Svane becornes very important. But not for empirical insight-that comes in the late stage. Instead, attention goes to distinguishing right from wrong, good from bad. As a work of art moves into more formedness, the original source acts as a sort of quality control continually questioning the integrity of the emerging form. At the same time, the urge to form must continuallly forge ahead or it will be swallowed by doubt. In a lifetime, it is the time of adolescence. In the polarization of forces arises a personal and even moral charge, a strength to know your position and stand up for it. (Sound familiar?) In Western Culture, the middle stage began at the birth of monotheism and continued through the middle ages. A result of that time was the creation of polarized social roles, e.g.: aristocracy and peasantry, male and female differentiation, and Christians and heretics. If we create a context in our Contact Improvisation gatherings that encourages people to engage in polarized relationships, then I'd say that the development of Contact as a whole is moving from the early stage into the middle stage. In my recent past, I have felt that emotional tension was a problem in a Contact class or Jam. It is useful to me to see the value of this stage rather than worry about conflicts shattering the unified foundation we have built. Actually, participation in this realm can create a capacity to meet one another in more ways. Late Stage In creating a work of art, the late stage is the time when attention goes to detailing the form and polishing the surface, now that the original source has taken satisfactory shape. In a lifetime, it is early adulthood when one is more oriented toward establishing oneself materialistically in culture. With the age of reason and into the industrial revolution, Western Culture shifted into the late stage. The forces of nature no longer appeared as a threat as we separated ourselves and focused on our capacity to control our environment. We have developed elaborate structures both materially and intellectually. We live in a culture that is in the midst of this stage. Aspects of Con· tact certainly reflect it: we have a highly articulate language for addressing the skills of Contact-a surprisinglly mechanical language of weights and levers, when actually the essence of Contact is union with natural forces and diminishing our effort to control. 102 CQ;CJ Sourcebook

Title: SOLO DANCING
Abstract: Steve Paxton's "Solo Dancing" explores the interconnectedness of dancers with the floor and each other in Contact Improvisation, emphasizing mutual freedom, reliance, and a state of present-moment awareness.
Text: by Steve Paxton reprinted from Contact Quarterly, Volume II no. 3, Spring 1977. Solo dancing does not exist: the dancer dances with the floor: add another dancer and you have a quartet: each dancer with the other and each with the floor. In the United States recently a form of dancing has arisen which treats each dancer as a surface to be played upon as is the floor. Named CONT ACT IMPROVISATION, it resembles wrestling, the jitterbug, fucking, tumbling and juggling; yet none of these quite describes the other; and none quite describes this dancing. The physical part is best pictured in terms of spectrums of potentials: two people freely improvising movement using the floor and each other as surface rely on gravity as a constant; inertia into momentum as a variable; adamant (the floor) to yielding (skin-muscle-bone-total mass) as surface features; and the variables of Program from the 1973 Contact performances at L' Attico Gallery in Rome, Italy. give and take, ruled not by set roles for each dancer but by the understanding that each may change from give to take at any time. This brings us to the non-physical part of this dancing; the state of being or mind permitting mutual freedom, with mutual reliance. The mind is kept empty of preconceptions and memories; it is in the present moments only, meditating on the potentials and on the easiest paths in the energy construct which are available to both dancers: it is a state of abandon; trust in the self and in each other must be total. The ability to help each other and one's self must be ever ready: through constant movement one pursues mutual ease in constant mutual change. The dancer's weight is only his tq give; not to possess. The final factor here considered is time. The division of time into minutes and seconds perhaps clouds the view of time-as-flow: but in this dancing where units of time are defined by the velocities of independent and semi-indepen• dent masses involved in movement of and upon the two bodies, time moves as quickly as the dancers move: given a state of constant falling, the glands react as in those falls wherein time apparently stands still, and the dancers shift from our pedestrian concepts into a time sense allowing some controls in the endless chain of accidents they have provoked: that is the improvisation in which they make contact. 1:!

Title: BACK IN TIME
Abstract: Nancy Stark Smith reflects on an experience of "doing" her partner's movements in Contact Improvisation, leading to a realization of the limitations in her own movement vocabulary and the potential for exploring new aspects of time and personality in dance.
Text: Seven years ago, while doing a Contact Improvisation duet, I was stopped short by a movement I made that wasn't mine. "Hey Lisa," I called to her from across the studio, "I just did your movement." "Let's see," she said, as I rewound my sensations and ' tried to do it again. Recognizing her idiosyncratic timing, she laughed and suggested I keep "doing her." My partner was willing, so we continued as I tried to put myself in Lisa's skin, in her nervous system, and dance. Instead of my usual moderated flow, I jerked and flinched, turning abruptly, plummeting halfway to the floor and stopping, pulling my arms back like a chicken and making tiny darting birdlike movements at unexpected moments. "Whoa," I said, wanting to stop, "this is too weird." What made me stop was the eery sensation of being in someone else's body and in their time. My choices, reactions, directions and timings were totallly foreign to me, but at the same time very familiar. I learned them from dancing with Lisa. There are many ways to learn someone's dance. In this case, I learned it through the skin. Dancing in physical contact with a partner is a lot like putting your ear to a wall and having a conversation with someone on the other side of it. Like the sounds in the next room, your movements and your partner's are amplified by the contact, and very little goes unregistered, even if unconsciously. In Contact, skin to skin, weight to weight, you're moved by your partner's movements and in this way able to feel their reflexes, the rush and pause of their time, first hand. In Alexander Neascu's article in this issue, he talks of a new kind of time called 'internal time' recently identified by postmodern physicists. I think it might be this kind of time-one that moves according to its own intrinsic logic and phrasing, not according to the standard clock-time divisions-that is communicated during Contact Improvisation. In "doing Lisa" I was further struck by the fact that although these were all movements I could physically do, they were not ones I would ordinarily choose. I had been under the assumption that in improvising I was calling on any and every movement I could possibly make, but now I realized I was in fact doing a very limited and consistent range of movements, textures and timings. That I was, in fact, always "doing myself." I found this a rather humbling and revealing discovery. Volume 11 1986 Looking back from here, the oddest part to me is how disappointed I was to realize I was only "doing myself" when I danced-as if I should have been able to do more. What more was there to do, one might ask. Well, Contact Improvisation for one thing. Obviously one can only do Contact, or anything else for that matter, in one's own way, but I was so busy looking at Contact Improvisation, I didn't notice myself doing it. I was too busy subjecting myself to "the forces"-of gravity, momentum, inertia, etc.-to notice what kind of subject I was. And I was taken aback to even consider it. Within the study of Contact, the experience of "flow" was soon recognized and highlighted in our dancing. It became one of my favorite practices and I proceeded to "do flow" for many years-challenging it, testing it: Could we flow through this pass? Could we squeak through that one, and keep going? I used to have a partner that I called the Flow Machine. His considerable mass streamed through the channels of movement, sometimes like a rushing brook, sometimes like molten lava, but always ongoing. I would get euphoric and giddy as the end of the phrase never arrived-always there was a new curve, and we'd bank off the edge of that one, going on and on. There is great pleasure in this. And it is in large measure through establishing and maintaining Volume 11 1986 photo: Bill Arnold a mutual flow that the trust is formed between partners which supports further risk-taking, as from this baseline one can quickly sense changes in the flow as they occur-changes in direction, modulations in timing-and be ready to adapt to them. The kinetic pleasures and soothing rhythms of time-in-flow can be hypnotic and often go unchallenged in Contact. Why rock the boat now that we've finally gotten it steadied? As I've said, I've always loved "doing flow" and still do, but the time came when I began to wonder what else was possible. What other kinds of time could be played out in the dancing, and where might that take us? What I'm finding is that it is there, in the departures from the established time frame, that new aspects of the dancers' personalities emerge and new risks are taken. Taking the lid off the flow container, time can move in new ways, reflecting not only the dancers' mutuality but their singularity, in time, and in space. Challenging any established order is a risk, and can come with a fair amount of disorientation and awkwardness. But Contact trains us so well in spatial disorientation-with all its whirling about, off-center and falling~surely our practice can welcome a little confusion in time as well. Nancy Stark Smith CQ/CI Sourcebook 105

Title: ALL IN GOOD TIME
Abstract: The author reflects on teaching Contact Improvisation and the challenge of transitioning students from clock time to an internal sense of expanded time, emphasizing the importance of relaxation and absorption in the moment.
Text: For the last month I've been going down to Wesleyan University on Fridays to teach two l '12 hour classes in Contact Improvisation. Though I've been liking the students a great deal, I've been grumbling a lot during the week about the classes being too short. But now the grumbling is bothering me more than the shortness of the classes, so it's time to look into the whole ordeal. The whole ordeal is about time, not enough of it, or more specifically, not enough of a certain kind of it. When I teach beginning Contact Improvisation, there are a few principles I come back to over and over-some for safety reasons, others for flavor. Some have to do with expanding one's orientation to space-experiencing space as spherical, dealing with disorientation, being able to fall, roll, and ride momentum, alone and in physical contact with another mover. I suppose this could be called spatial conditioning. Then there's time conditioning, which I'm just beginning to take particular notice of. A lot of the meditations on physical sensation (e.g. Paxton's "small dance") that have always been a part of Contact training are actually as much about inducing an experience of expanded time as they are about the physical sensations they point up. This sense of expanded time is a subjective state, one where time feels mutable and there are slippages-where a 45 minute dance can feel like 5 minutes, while a 2 second fall can feel luxuriously long. It is a relaxed state, one where time seems to have been released from its inexorable unit-to-unit march and allowed to roam in an open field with wide horizons and no fences, a time whose divisions and textures vary according to the moods and perceptions of the people moving through it. As with spatial training, this new temporal experience may be puzzling at first. All too often you lose your place in the dancing, but you find out through experience that if you just hang on a few seconds longer (those seconds feel like hours!) your place will come floating up under you like 106 CQICI Sourcebook a pair of lost footprints. You come to trust and in fact look forward to those gaps because in them you 're as vulnerable and available as you can be, and from there come new perceptions and some of the more surprising and refreshing movement material. But how do we get there from here? Especially when we 're coming in to the studio from Chemistry or Shakespeare or Ballet or a 65 mile drive. The transition from clock time to internal time can begin during the personal warmup-a period of time often given at the beginning of class to relax and "arrive," to get ready physically and mentally to dance with others. It deepens during the periods of extended duet improvising. Absorption in the moment expands the feeling of time and you come out of it enlivened no matter where you've been. It's this state of absorption and enlivening that I aim for in my own dancing and teaching. I spent the first few weeks at Wesleyan searching in vain for a quick passage, a trap door into this state. But how could I hope to transmit the spaciousness, mutability, and mystery of time when I myself was rushing to get in as much dancing, skills, improvising, sensitizing, etc. as possible in the 'short' time available? Exhausted from my struggle with time, I gave up and found that simply by relaxing I created more time. It felt like practicing Aikido, where one redirects an opposing force by first blending with it, not resisting it. Meanwhile, of course, as I was internally wrestling with all this, the students were rolling, giggling, getting dizzy, getting strong, confused, inspired, thinking it was silly, feeling it was profound and in general doing Contact Improvisation. As has often been said, the dancing teaches itself, if the teacher can only get out of the way long enough to let everyone dance   P.S. After all this, I still think an hour and a half is too short for a Conta

Title: TEACHING EXCHANGE
Abstract: This article documents a teaching exchange focused on Contact Improvisation, exploring topics such as using centrifugal force, staying flexible in the air, and exercises to stimulate movement. It also discusses the value of teaching principles versus specific movements and includes experiments on accumulating energy and force during stillness.
Text: SATURDAY begins with spontaneous warming up and dancing. The teaching exchange started with a discussion of areas where people wanted to work-personal experiments, ideas, difficulties, etc. We soon became involved in the subject of being in the air. . The initial question was how to use the force which takes you away from center (centrifugal force) to meet your partner again, and transfer that force into weight exchange? Here is an excerpt from the ensuing discussion: Nancy: Maybe there's another way to approach from the air that asks the other person to join your force-how do you join it, how do you read it so that you can work with it? To me it has to do with reading the movement before it gets to you so you can join with it. So coming through the air from different places, poses different problems to solve in terms of forces, momentum. Suzanne: How to stay flexible and open, to be able to read that movement when it comes with so mu-ch forc;e? Nancy: How to keep dancing in the air? People sometimes throw themselves in the air, and then lose their sensitivity while their partner just works with them. They are trying to hold themselves together in the air and that makes it heavy. They are not really there, they just want to get llld CQ/C/ Sourcebook down. Karen: The place where you are being supported is a little bit small, it's not like the floor   Mark: What about big men, I'm not used to relaxing in that position. Nancy: A lot of it has to do with if you're willing and ready to fall frum any height, because if you 're completely dependent on your partner or passive, you're in a funny position anyway. Karen: It takes time when you're up there to get used to that, too, and to try to fall, in different directions. Nancy: Also, when you're lifting someone who is big, to feel that it's okay to let them go, that you can start and follow through somehow without feeling that you have to hold them up there-otherwise you don't even stlut, cause you think it's too much. Moniek: One step before this   what kind of easy exercises can stimulate this process-like rolling-for people who don't have much experience? Nancy: Falling is good, because falling is moving through the air with gravity, and if people get comfortable with falling, on the other side of the fall is something that comes up. Falling gives you a force in an upward direction. It also makes you unafraid to go down. The down goes up and the up goes down, so if you can get the down part   Jaap: I'm interested in the problems of big men dancing with small women. When I'm going up I often feel the support collapses. Elinor: It's usually the men that don't want to give their weight to the women. They think they are too heavy. Nancy: Sometimes I find with heavier people who are afraid to give their weight, that they don't give their center. The center is off to the side so I can't get under it to support it and then they think, "Yeah, see? Well they can't support me" and so   they just keep the problem going. There are some men who are really quite large, and they give their center and the weight stays alive and even if it's a lot of weight you really can work with it a little bit. And they feel secure and you feel secure, which leads to less tension and thus more 'levity.' There's an exercise I do sometimes, it's a climbing exercise and if it goes slow enough you can feel and find your skeletal support. There's no momentum involved and it's not particularly light, it's quite heavy. But in the heaviness you find where the weight can be supported and how it feels. Then later when there's a little momentum it's lighter and you know where the places are, where you can go to support the weight (or be supported well). Mark: Even if I go up, it's already become a habit that I don't stay very long, so I never hang out there. Jaap: I'm finding out that it's not the point to stay very long, it's not the point that you're going up, the point is that you're moving and you happen to be up. Mark: But I'm talking about a technical level, as far as knowing what that is, to be suspended in the air. I know much less about it than you guys. Nancy: Maybe something to do is just hang out up there for one extra second. Again, it's like working with any --'* Volume 11 1986 limit-because it's a rhythm, up and down, up and down .. so you're just stretching or,opening the limit a little bit instead of 'how can I really stay so long' but just two more seconds and see what happens. Jaap: But there's one point-like when I'm dancing with Jaana for example, she's small, and when she's on me I have a lot of places for support, and when I'm on her she is really so small!! Nancy: People who are good supports really know how to use the movement continually for support as well as surfaces. There's really very little that the person up there has to do because there's so much riding the movement that's happening-with the little shifts to get around the shoulders, etc. Sometimes I really feel juggled by people. It's not 'cause they're strong but it's all the little stuff that they're doing. I want to learn to do that more. (To Karen) You work with a man about your size so you 're quite equal in your weight support, which is a great opportunity, because sometimes women don't lift small women either for very long, because they're not used to having someone up there very long. In the afternoon we had the actual teaching exchange. The mats were out and first Karen had us practicing Aikido breakfalls. Then Nancy led us in some light disorientation practice and we went on to jumping on people who were posts, approaching from the air and reaching your partner while still in that light state. During this session one question came up which seems essential to Contact teaching: When working on skills, does teaching specific movements or exercises have the same result as teaching a principle and improvising within that principle? How can you teach people to improvise if not by letting them find their own forms and ways to do things? Later on, Mark led a class which encompassed focussed duets as well as a dynamic group dance with brief and changing encounters. Focus: dancing with different people while still maintaining awareness of your original partner's center, then coming back to dancing with the original partner with an awareness of the group. Suzanne led an experiment which was about accumulating energy and force during a common stillness in the dance, while still in physical contact   until the accumulated force releases into movement through space. Later, watching "Magnesium" and "Chute" videos evokes a sense of history. Post-dinner networking discussion brings us to the publication of a European Newsletter and the setting up of a European Jam.

Title: DISCUSSION ABOUT NETWORKING
Abstract: This article discusses the reasons for networking in the Contact Improvisation community, including sharing information about classes, workshops, and performances, organizing jams, and exchanging ideas about teaching and research. It also covers organizational agreements for a European Newsletter.
Text: What is the reason for networking? Needs, desires could be divided in: • To keep informed about the places where Contact is being developed: classes, workshops, performances, addresses, dates. • To know possibilities to meet and to dance with other Contact dancers. Includes: knowing places and dates where and when Contact is going on; organizing Jams in Europe. Mark Tompkins reported about the experiences with the first European Jam in summer 1982 in the countryside of Southern France, organized by L'Atelier Contact. Important points were the necessity of good space and sleeping accomodations; costs (admission fee to cover space and organization, then there's room and board, and travel cost at the individual's expense!). Suzanne, Jean and Joanna offered to set up a Jam near Paris around the 1st of May. • To exchange about teaching and research in Contact. Possibilities: To invite another teacher to your studio. To continue with this Conference once a year. Important considerations: Who will organize the next one? The necessity of good housing. Costs as mentioned above plus possibly the fee for inviting a special teacher (the presence, guidance and knowledge of Nancy was very inspiring and supporting). The length of this conference was generally considered too short. To deal with these aspects brought up the idea of starting a Newsletter. We should be clear about its aims: If it should be to inform each other in a central way; or if it should be a way of sharing experiences and exchanging ways of working. We ~ecided to choose for the way to inform each other, and to leave the sharing of the work to the Contact Quarterly. Organizational agreements: • Type your own letter (one page) with information about your teaching and up-coming events in your area. • Each time there should be a coordinator. • Two issues a year to coordinate with CQ deadline so it can be a part of the magazine. • Send money to the next coordinator if you'd like to receive a copy (or else it cannot be made and sent). We finished the conference realizing the NETWORK IS A FACT! -tt [More news from this Newsletter and deadline information for the next one can be found in the CQ Newsletter in this issue./

Title: RECOGNIZING DANCE
Abstract: This article explores the internal experience of dancing, focusing on the connection between mind and body, awareness of space and other dancers, and the balance of forces within the moving body. It describes the feeling of being centered and steady amidst movement, and the importance of recognizing and accepting the truth of a situation to achieve control.
Text: I am in a form. A form of discipline. Focused outwards and inwards. Making connections, which make me to dance. I'm a mover alright. Eventually I'm moving the walls and the space between the walls. Me, as a centering organ, as a source of strength. (One powerful enough command and I would fly up, straight to the ceiling.) What I really do is hard to explain. I'm the centre of the space around me alright, and also of everything else, moving in that space. And it sometimes feels like it's me who makes it to move. I know of course, it's me who's moving, but something inside my skull stays steady, in one place, never shoving out of place   however much I'm going upside down, through whatever angles. In fact, the more angles I'm making, the more steady th is one part of me becomes. And the more steady this observing part of me is, the better I can make the world around me move. It's an interesting discovery. My body no longer distracted, because my organs no longer protest against every leap I make. There is an adjustment which makes it possible for my mind to follow the body, and for my body to follow the mind. Moving around I'm getting closer. Moving around I'm opening up. Getting aware of other people in the same space. Getting aware of other bodies (like mine, but different) moving around (but telling a different tale). Getting aware I'm actually moving in space which is shared by all the other bodies in the very same time. And by sharing this space, I'm sharing a conception. I'm sharing a movement, with every echo of it rolling between the walls of the space, wherein my body is responding, like a boat on the water. Effecting and being effected: my mind, with images. Mildly changing, disturbing changing, or however. My body, in the space. And some of the bodies around me, dancing. With the same mild flow or strangeness or confusion. However these waves in this stretch of time flow. And however much a mind is willing to allow changes to happen. My steady me is observing this. This part of me is the only part which doesn't let go. It's the part which must lay hidden in layers there are in my brains. It's a part which comes out on those moments/in those movements, when everything else is swimming in the stream. Comprehension. Understanding. Not the detail. Not the current. Not the face that expresses and reveals, but a sort of silent memo. A sentence like: "I was still, no movement at all." Which is nothing more than recognizing a situation and accepting the absolute truth of it. Which means that on that moment, there is a balance of forces, focused on the moving body. And the observation of such is the key of control. Then my steady part falls back inside its hidingplace and there are only all of my senses left, sprawling in the dance. Dancing with other bodies, all in the same room. Space, time separating. An improvisation about survival. Going around somebody's back, falling down, head first towards the floor, rolling, jumping up. Waiting, out of balance. Being out of balance all the time. That's the essence of this dance form. Trying to cope with that which moves around you. Trying to grasp a shift of weight. Feeling the floor move away and around. Focusing eyes, sensing ears, balancing feet, flexing spine. Finding a way to the end of that rope. Landing on hands and feet. Feeling the ground getting to rest, while sitting. Waiting for echos to finally fade. Walls becoming walls and bodies becoming personal objects. A sense of distance restored once more

Title: TAKING NO FOR AN ANSWER
Abstract: This article explores the concept of improvisation and the importance of embracing the "Gap," a momentary suspension of reference point that allows for unexpected and original material to emerge. It discusses the ability to wait and not follow the first impulse, comparing it to breaking a habit, and highlights the role of learning, unconscious pulls, and conscious choices in improvisation.
Text: Today is my birthday and I'm sitting in my car, parked, with the engine running, outside our building, watching the shadow of the building rise on a high pile of snow as the sun goes down behind the building. Maybe sitting here facing this blank page is the closest I'll be able to get in writing to the feeling of improvising. Because how can you describe something that isn't there yet? I want to be able to write from inside the movements of an improvisation and tell from there how things look, how they feel, how they're going. But I keep finding myself back here walking the line, on the page, trying to make pens pirouette, words walk and ideas bounce and split open, like dancing can do. I'm impressed and informed by all the efforts evident in this issue of people putting a finger on what isn't there. It's like talking about a hole. In this issue, we're trying to say what shapes the hole from within. In the early '70s, when I was first getting immersed in the world of practicing and performing dance improvisation, I spent a lot of time watching the Grand Union• perform. For hours, I would see material surface on shaky ground, get nourished, worked, referred to, developed, and I'd see it begin to strengthen, come into its own, and become the ground for what would happen next. I saw material be given life or death (which in itself could become the next material), and I learned that there was, in practice, no inherent hierarchy of material. Every move had equal potential to unify, clarify, destroy, or transform what was going on. It was not just the material itself but how and when it was delivered that gave it depth and power. Where you are when you don't know where you are is one of the most precious spots offered by improvisation. It is a place from which more directions are possible than anywhere else. I call this place the Gap. The more I im• A Dance Theater improvisation group including Yvonne Rainer, David Gordon, Steve Paxton, Trisha Brown, Barbara (Lloyd) Dilley, Nancy (Green) Lewis, and Douglas Dunn. Volume 12 1987 Volume 12 1987 provise, the more I'm convinced that it is through the medium of these gaps-this momentary suspension of reference point-that comes the unexpected and much sought after 'original' material. It's 'original' because its origin is in the current moment and because it comes from outside our usual frame of reference. When Katie Duck teaches improvisation, as she has many times as a guest teacher at the Theaterschool in Amsterdam, she often tells people not to use their first impulse, but instead to wait for maybe the second or third before taking action. This ability to wait and not follow the impulse is a lot like learning how to break a habit. Holding the moment open a few seconds longer widens the gap where the old behavior/idea/movement/thought/ feeling would have gone. And maybe you have nothing to put in its stead. So you put in nothing. On January 28th, it was a year since I stopped smoking (and, coincidentally, a year since the space shuttle Challenger exploded). I never stopped before and the change feels enormous. Every time I want a cigarette and don't have one I'm creating a gap. Moments that once were easily and automatically filled, have become uneasily and consciously unfilled. By leaving them unfilled, I'm not only breaking a 'momentum of being', a pattern of behavior, but I'm bringing attention and charge to a moment that would have passed without remark. One of the things that improvising and stopping smoking have in common is that they both require an appetite for learning. Both have the capacity to take you to new ground. Both are about unconscious pulls and conscious choices, about reckoning with habitual perspectives and behaviors. Being in a gap is iike being in a fall before you touch bottom. You're suspended-in time as well as space-and you don't really know how long it'll take to get 'back'. And then, when you do finally get back, no one even noticed you were gone. Nancy Stark Smith

Title: THE AWARENESS OF CHANGE
Abstract: This article explores the importance of awareness in Contact Improvisation, focusing on the "Ready State" and the process of deepening inner space to enhance outer expression. It discusses the stages of getting into the body, deepening quality, tuning sensitivity, and moving into exchange with a partner, emphasizing the need to be present and comfortable with change.
Text: by Chris Mathias The state or space created in the workshop setting decreases the stimuli of the outside world so that the internal impulses of our dancing can be felt, seen and acted upon. Once the outer arrangement has less of an influence, then the inner space becomes fuller, more alive and its range of possibilities become wider. The awareness of change in the inner space becomes vivid so that when the outer space of our world increases its influence, we do not lose the ground we have gained from the inner world. These statements were gleaned from a month's worth of writings, thoughts and discussions I participated in at Naropa Institute Summer 1986. However vague and general, they seem to apply to the state of mind we reach when awareness is brought to our dancing. During the course of the four weeks of Contact Improvisation classes taught by Nancy Stark Smith, we talked a lot about the "Ready State," never actually defining it, but nevertheless knowing when it had occurred. There never seemed to be a standard way of preparing the body to dance, but one ingredient was always required. Awareness of body sensation, movement and body/mind states. Once in the "Ready State," every part of our being participates actively. When not ready, some part of us hangs back, watches, refusing to participate, creating a rift within our own dancing and between us and our partner. 114 CQ/CI Sourcebook It seems that awareness implies action, and if this is true, then in the "Ready State" of Contact Improvisation we must actively know our sensations, movement and mind states. To know actively, or to bring awareness to dancing allows expression; the exchange of one body of knowledge with anoth· er. In my ignorance, I seemed to think that the "Ready State" was something to be achieved. A way of doing this was to identify the stages one might go through to reach the "Ready Stire." They came as follows: 1. Getting into the body-requires a shifting of mind into bodily terms, i.e., sensation, imagery and movement quality. 2. Body time-now in the body, the action is of deepening quality. 3. Body Sensitivity---,body sensation and states of mind become finely tuned. The sensitivity to and awareness of body sensation and body minds is increased. 4. Body Expression and Exchangemoving out of inner sensation and into exchange with a partner. The body becomes the mode from which I relate. Although these stages offered some insight into the process, they also told me something about my ambition to achieve something that I thought was necessary. The "Ready State" requires only to be where you are, not where you think you should be. This slight shift means bringing an awareness to the changes happening in our dancing; changing and guiding the changes as well, so that the dancing becomes an exchange between the inner and outer impulses. This awareness is full bodied, the mind responds to the body and the body responds to the mind. It is a way of being with change. Being comfortable with frustration, ambiguity and basically not knowing what comes next. A way of being which begins without expectations of what will come, freeing you to be with whatever is occurring. In looking back at the time spent at Naropa, I see that we seemed to create a space for ourselves that aimed for freedom from distraction. We cleared and prepared ourselves to dance in the most honest way we knew how. The discipline of Contact Improvisation requires this clarity of body, mind and spirit, so that the person can deepen within the form and of equal importance, enjoy their dancing.{::{

Title: TEACH I NG SCORE 1 PUPPET-PUPPETEER:
Abstract: This article describes a teaching score called "Puppet-Puppeteer," where one dancer acts as the puppeteer and the other as the puppet. The puppeteer initiates movement with a light touch, leading the puppet's upper body, while the puppet follows through but does not initiate. The quality of movement can range from light and feathery to heavy and nurturing, eventually bringing the puppet to the floor.
Text: Jonathan Smith I started the class off with unstructured solo warm up, asking for people to soften, and to move without working at it, and then continue in this mode into a slow duet warm up dance with the same qualities. The material that I presented was what I call the puppet-puppeteer motif. I developed this style of movement out of an image from a Robin Feld class working with manipulations. She was dressed in black and was moving a colorfully dressed person. I asked people to start off with a light touch, suggesting working the puppet by the upper body from behind, using the puppet's upper arms, or by pulling and leading from in front. The puppeteer does all the initiation; the puppet can follow through but not initiate. For example, the puppeteer can move the puppet's arm up and the puppet's arm can then slowly float down like a feather. Then the quality can get heavier, the puppeteer can bring the puppet into his or her center, taking more weight, nurturing and caring for the puppet; finally bringing the puppet to the floor, rocking it and putting it to sleep. I used this motif in a section of a dance that I created and performed in New York, June 1985, called "The River of Cause (because because because because because)."

Title: NOTES ON THE 1986 BREIT~NBUSH CONTACT JAM AND TEACHER'S CONFERENCE
Abstract: This article reflects on the 1986 Breitenbush Contact Jam and Teacher's Conference, highlighting the dialogue between doing and contemplation, the immediacy of sharing discoveries, and the strong sense of community. It emphasizes the experience of Contact Improvisation as a vehicle for personal expression and development, and as an influence in the structure of society.
Text: by Kurt Koegel The jam/conference was a dialogue between doing and contemplation, playing freely and then defining what seemed to be happening. It was a spacious time where together we sculpted our shifting understandings of the work. One of the joys of this process of inquiry was its immediacy-the being able to move from a stimulating discussion straight into dancing-or coming upon a discovery dancing   and having the context, right there, to immediately share it with someone, or the group   so to articulate the elusive find .. . In this setting the work was given range, depth, and focus-we experienced it as a vehicle of personal expression and development and as an influence in the structure of today's society. And the conference was about COMMUNITY. Other than finding out about the broad and concentrated research that is happening, I recall the connectedness and power I experienced'there. I've been in many group situations and worked on many projects, but I've never felt such a strong, nurturing, and inspiring sense of community. There were no leaders or followersrather we were all leaders and followers

Title: THIS COMMUNITY IS EXPLORING ITSELF. i:l
Abstract: This short piece reflects on the sense of community and exploration within a contact improvisation conference, highlighting the lack of traditional leadership roles and the emphasis on shared learning and expression.

Title: TEACHING SCORE 2 TRIO CONTACT POINT: Sharon Tomsky
Abstract: This article presents a trio contact improvisation score where one person acts as the "point of contact" between two others, facilitating communication and shared weight.
Text: A trio score. Three people in contact. One in the middle-touching both of the outside people. The 2 outside people are not touching each otherbut they are dancing together. (Looking at each other is useful.) The person in the middle is the "point of contact" between them. The communicator the sender of messages; transferring information back and forth-simultane'sly receivin.g & sen~ing information, about the contact-weight, pressure, etc. The place in the middle seems to be a real different place for people to dance from. Goin~ into a place ~f no-mi~d perhaps. Or no ego. Learning ab~ut wha~ the pornt of c~ntact 1s .. outs~de people learning about communicatin.g. Bein~ clear. R~lating. Stay1.ng with the other person. Listening. Sensing. Paying attention to the point of contact. (I learned this exercise from john LeFan.) {From the 7 986 Breitenbush jam & Teacher's Conference notebook]

Title: FREELANCING WITH CONTACT
Abstract: Paul Langland reflects on his introduction to contact improvisation and its impact on his artistic development, comparing it to sculpture and highlighting its emphasis on process and democratic interaction.
Text: This piece was written in 1979. We discovered it in our files and found the issues in it still very much alive. We talked with Paul about it and be agreed. He also noted that shortly after this period, performances of improvisation in New York City seemed to disappear for several years. [Eds.] I suspect there are many people presently involved in moving art forms who, except for exposure to contact improvisation, would not have entered the field. My experience is a case in point. As an art major in college, I enjoyed creating large sculptural environments for the body. The weight and awkwardness of the materials, plywood, two-by-fours, and other construction hardware, turned building a piece into a physical work-out. Sculpting was an arranging dance, using the whole body. During this time (1973), Curt Siddall, Nita Little, Steve Paxton, Nancy Stark Smith, and someone whom I remember well except for her name [Karen Radler] came to perform and teach contact on the west coast for the first time. I danced some and watched a lot. The idea of people presenting natural movement as a performance was a pleasant jolt to me. The democratic give and take between partners was appealing. Improvising dance, creating while performing was, for me, a revelation. And my personality was more comfortable with the social circumstances of dancing than the solitude of sculpture. My first dancing was suffused with comparisons between sculpture and contact. It was as if the four-by-eight plywood sheets I had been building with developed power steering, and could even lift me off the ground. photo© 1978 Leslie Cerier The three-dimensional experience of sculpture became four-dimensional, the fourth dimension being the time of the dance. I was no longer the manipulator. For every impulse of mine, there was another independent nervous system deciding what was happening as well. I saw that contact is very purely about process. In terms of sculpture, that meant showing how fascinating it is to make a piece, rather than showing a finished piece. Through performing, I like letting others in on the creating side of the work, the side most interesting to me. Since that time, I've performed in many different situations; contact, other improvised structures, and set pieces. In watching dance or performing it, I'm drawn to dancing which doesn't impose a style on the people who dance. This may partly be a hangover from art training which encourages students to find an individual vision from the start of training. I'm glad this idea has a lot of credence in the dance world now. Improvisation is one way of working individualistically either in a group or solo. A problem is that improvisation and performance are sometimes friends. We all know of our on nights and our off nights. Those who perform improvisation have decided that the pluses outweigh the minuses. The pluses are that the dancers are presenting a raw slice of life, uncut, uncooked. The audience's position is elevated because they are allowed to get in on the whole story as it happens for the first time. They aren't watching something which has been edited in rehearsal. Improvisation is risky and often rewarding for the performers. It is a way for performers to move on with work, not to stick with an image or sequence "What did you think of what you saw, asked Miss Stein . .. Only that Picassos were rather awful and the others were not. Sure, she said, as Pablo once remarked, when you make a thing, it is so complicated making it that it is bound to be ugly, but those that do it after you they don't have to worry about making it and they can make it pretty, and so everybody can like it when the others make it." Gertrude Stein which must be repeated several times. The formal qualities of contact make it a focused and grounded improvisational technique. There is a basic agreement between performers which provides a continual springboard into the dance. A performer of contact has a lot of freedom. I'm sitting here writing about how good a performance improvisation makes, and resisting tooth and nail the detractions. However, there are some. There is no overall structure to control the impact of the performance. It's like having several small dances linked together. Dull repetition can be a problem. When this happens, it's like watching the same rehearsed dance several times in one piece. This is one of the main limitations in previous dance work which many of us are trying to avoid by investigating improvisation. An ideal piece has few seams showing. There are a lot of ways to approach this, but they mostly have to do with pre-planning. It's difficult to achieve in an improvised performance. There also are some beautiful possibilities in pre-setting a piece; it can have long sections of synchronized movement, it can be a story, it can have special timing, or it can deal with the personae and not the personality of the performer. The search for these qualities is improvised but their presentation is, for the most part, set. Safety is important in contact. This results in contact being playful, game-like, and positive. There is a utopian communal quality to contacta great experience but not the whole picture. This one-keyed quality can be limiting for an audience, and make performing frustrating. There is little room to explore subjects like discord, tragedy, or events which are fantastic or grotesque. Sometimes I want to entertain/be entertained with these rich images. Sometimes I want the purity and abstraction of contact. When I perform contact, I like to feel that we, the performers, are sharing the performance with the audience. Among the most satisfying performances in this respect was a series done at the Paula Cooper Gallery in New York City [1978). We performed in the afternoon for three days, three hours per day. The audience was free to come and go. Those who stayed wanted to be there. As the performance progressed, the size and closeness of the audience increased. Neither the audience nor the piece was set. There was a cumulative effect from performing for a long time for three days in a row. Our dancing became very sure, and many audience members returned two or three times to watch. By the end of the third day we all felt like good friends. We felt like the home team. In the last year, I've been doing contact wearing different costumes. The costumes put a context into the dancing. Nina Martin and I did costumed contact as part of a living sculpture exhibit at the Susan Caldwell Gallery. Every half-hour or so, we changed clothes. We danced in pajamas, swimming suits, winter clothes, formal attire, and disco polyester. The costumes interest me because they provide a lasting image, however weird, of what the dancing is about. A subliminal story unfolded with each change. (Paul and Nina went to the prom all dressed up. They felt good and started rolling on top of each other. Nina's hat got squashed, so she _,. threw it away while climbing on Paul's back. They both fell into the buffet table, pensively. When the music started, Paul rolled up Nina's body and she supported him upside down with his jacket wrapped around his head.) Someone else may be having other daydreams as they watch. Our only plan was to do contact after putting on the different clothes, not to inject the movement itself with any plot or meaning. The dancing did feel very different each time we changed, mostly because the physical sensations of each outfit were so different. Winter clothes to swimming suits was a big change. As at the Paula Cooper Gallery, the audience could come and go. We felt very connected to the audience that stayed with us. Long performances are satisfying. We had a long time to allow the dancing to grow and change. Where we got the stamina tq do a three hour duet, I don't know. Solo space is something I want to see and do more of. It's a way for individual eccentricities to come out. Voice work, props, or other movement forms are possible without being filtered through that great equalizer, the contact duet. Contact ideas have been used as parts of different dance performances very successfully. Often I think of contact as a technique, or resource, rather than the thing to be performed. Here are just a few of the ways I liked contact being incorporated. In Simone Forti's Planet,.Terry O'Reilly and David Taylor did a low, slow, slithering contact duet with intermittent pauses based on reptilian movement while other animal-inspired dancing was happening at the same time. In Meredith Monk/Ping Chong's Chacon, Eli Pollock did a contact solo as the basis for his role as a drunken or crazy villager. Mary Overlie's The Figure has a section of "spatial contact"; dancing mostly without touching, but reacting to external sensing, and developing a flow with a partner(s). Last year, at the Contact Quarterly benefit in New York City, about twenty different contact pieces were shown. The variety was tremendous. There was a lot of experimenting and potential. Contact is democratic. Performers have equal opportunities in performance which, for me, is one of its great attractions. This equality shows in performance. The round robin form, and the freedom to start and stop dancing when you want is politically healthy for us humans. All contactors have a decision-making role as they dance, becoming their own directors. I have performed frequently in companies with directors, especially with Meredith Monk. What the director/company situation offers is greater specificity and depth of vision. The work process in The House (Meredith's company) is interesting. She frequently sketches out what to work on. We improvise and then set the most suitable material during rehearsal. Then work is further edited, or expanded and arranged with the other material in the piece. There are often sections of structured improvisation. In creating and performing, each performer has some responsibility as author, director, and actor. My thoughts on performance are open ended. Performing contact is rewarding, and there is an audience for it. It's reminiscent of a sports event minus the competition; the focus is on the moment to moment interplay of individuals rather than the outcome. A set piece offers other possibilities, both as performer and viewer. The two don't exclude each other. I hope the' multiplicity of performing possibilities continues to thrive and cross-fertilize. 1:: drawing: Margit Weichert

Title: [Statement written by Steve Paxton, ca. 1977]
Abstract: Steve Paxton addresses the question of whether Contact Improvisation is a performance art, emphasizing its improvisational nature, the mutual understanding between participants, and the focus on the performers' choices and reactions.
Text: There is currently some controversy in Canada: is CONTACT IMPROVISATION a performance art? Contact Improvisation is determined by two people at once, who both improvise freely, trying not to impede the work of the other. Spectators watch a physical conversation which may range from stillness to high athleticism. The reasons for the change in scale of movement or any other changes can be analyzed from emotional, physical or psychological levels. ?r many levels at once. The spectator 1s watching real people pressed by events and time. It is improvisation. Neither participant is totally in or out of control. The spectator does not look through the performers to a mind and its aesthetics. One looks squarely at the performers and their choices, reactions, and instincts, to what happens between them. What is revealed is mutual understanding, a basic system, a mode of communication. Touch. The fast and subtle skin processing masses, vectors, emotions, giving the muscles the information to correctly move the bones, so the duet can fall through the time and space of demonstration, neither partner hurt, hampered, subjected, objectified. Is it performance art? Performance has several levels of meaning. So does art. No one is defining their terms. They seem to mean, "I didn't enjoy the way it went," or, "If Tharp is, this ain't. " No matter. Go to it, Canadian Critics. Get it on conceptually. Or you could take a way out devised by those who perform Contact Improvisation   they call it an art-sport. Steve Paxton

Title: CALIFORNIA HARBIN HOT SPRINGS CONTACT JAM
Abstract: Andrew Clibanoff recounts his experience at the California Harbin Hot Springs Contact Jam, describing his initial unfamiliarity and eventual integration into the community through shared experiences and movement.
Text: The first CALIFORNIA HARBIN HOT SPRINGS CONTACT JAM was real good. I hod a nice time. A lot of people come from where /live-the Bay Area-but some from Chico, one from Boulder and a few from other West Coast towns. Being a newcomer to the contact community, I felt unfamiliar with what a jam was supposed to be. You know, I hod read some earlier issues of CQ, taken a couple classes from N. S. Smith at Wesleyan U., even did some Cl in NYC at PS122. But, going away for a long weekend with complete strangers to bathe in hot pools and dance didn't exactly make me feel at home, or at ease. What was the purpose of a jam, besides a reunion for those who hod already been practicing the form for awhile? I could tell there were some of us who were new to this kind of situation and didn't know precisely what was going on. This initial awkward time reminded me of my first high school dance. About everyone agreed that music and dance should be present (but separate some of the time) during the weekend. A lot of us, including myself, were interested in not setting particular times for dancing and drumming or even bedtime. Someone remarked that the time might be felt organically. At first, not a lot of time was spent collectively breathing or arriving. "Plunging in" is what seemed to be the desire of many. Maybe the hot springs pools provided the springboard for this desire. I couldn't join the flow, though, because plunging in is a fear of mine. I needed to toke time to sit and think and tune into myself for what I wanted from this jam. We were in a completely new world at Harbin, a rustic 7000 mile woodland, mountainous tree-lined areas volleying and rising oil around our enclosed dance shelter. A small brook ran by with clear water from the Napa Valley (wine country here in California). But with oil that beautiful natural environs, it was still troubling to me not knowing the jam boundaries. What were the rules of the game, as they soy? I sow possibilities in group sex, a homosexual and heterosexual couples' scene, raucous contact, soft-eye dancing, rolling and breathing. All this stuff I felt Friday night or so. Then, on Saturday morning, things opened up. Some of the senior members of the group taught half-hour mini-courses in Contoctesque basics and new discoveries. I went up to the pools in the afternoon. It wosn 't so bod there. It was softer and quieter than in the dance shelter. Hazy and lazy, strong and light, mole and female, folks were just chatting and healing. Four of us novice con· tocters huddled our arms together in the pool and floated around like a spinning wheel. We talked about what we sow Friday night. To my surprise, we shored a lot of common observations. Then, we steamed in the hottest tub. We walked out ofter\·ords, my bones felt heavy and my muscles suspended around my bones. On Saturday night, .the jam got together in a circle to discuss the moi•ement of the weekend. While people talked, someone tossed small coloriul ploybolls bock and forth in the circle. It looked like a game of marbles. You would toss a boll into the center and someone would try to knock yours out of the center and onto the periphery. Then, I forget who rolled herself into the center as a human marble. People giggled and rolled her around. Others joined her. That beautiful stock of 64 pillows by the \·all become the next marbles, and a huge and monstrous pillow fight ensued. Finale: a dive bombing affair. Pillow rumble, it was real good. A lot of heavy stuff. Straight, bold and big strides over obstacles into the pile of tossed pillows. The rest of the weekend was fun. I think we, as a group of disparate individuals, discoi·ered our challenge: a common ground. I think we also discovered a commitment: on organic message. To me, it was on unfurling of the foll, a movement outward and down across the floor. As I spoke with someone on Sunday afternoon on the trail bock from our lost dip in the pool, I felt a return. Andrew Clibanoff

Title: One of nine studios at the Theaterschool (TMDD) in Amsterdam.
Abstract: Aat Hougee discusses the shift from composition to improvisation in the curriculum of the Modern Dance Department of the Theaterschool (TMDD) in Amsterdam, highlighting the department's evolving vision of the creative process and the role of improvisation in fostering artistic development.
Text: translated by Leab Jacob It is roughly 5 years ago that in the curriculum of the Modern Dance Department of the Theaterschool (TMDD) in Amsterdam, Holland, the subject of composition was replaced, without too much discussion, with the concept of 'improvisation'. It was not just a matter of altering the name, but a conclusion brought about by the department's gradually changing vision of the function and content of the process of composition within dance education. In the department's eyes, the con. cept of 'composition' had become too static a hea:ding to apply to a subject that actually is at the core of its teaching-the search for new forms. As it had recently been taught in our school, 'composition' appeared to take for granted a correct and incorrect way, a belief that compositional truths already existed. Thus, for educators, it seemed artistically more interesting to busy oneself with the process that leads to a form than with the results of a process undergone by other people at other times. 'Improvisation' as a concept, it seemed, (though we were at that point unable to comprehend all the implications), had more to do with this ex· plorative organic approach. In fact, in the course of time, it came to embody a rich variety of aspects and possibilities, challenging the whole teaching field with its far-reaching influence. Mostly as a result of Pauline de Groot's work, the department takes as its starting point the view that developing into a dancer means developing into an artist. This creative development can in no way be set apart from the young dancer's growing physical capabilities. This premise means that in every movement class the student is being asked to arrive at a physical shape by tapping his/her own creative resources, even in those classes where the movement form is provided by the teacher. The idea of making use of the student's own potential is in fact a very obvious starting point, but it does demand a certain attitude from the student, a state of being that is open. Especially in this area of attaining a 'state of mind' enabling further physical and creative development, a variety of improvisational forms can play an important role in teaching. The department views as a cohesive whole the making of work, the training that leads to this, and the person's physical/creative development. It is a complex process of growth, with the achievement of form through essentiallly investigative methods of working as its continual starting point. It is also true, within the process of composition, that methods arising from moving are more efficient and achieve more logical results than most that stem from a more static and dogmatic view of composition. Improvisation represents an approach applicable to almost every aspect of teaching: it is investigative; allows, while practicing, an overview of what is possible; and teaches one to make choices. This weaving of improvisation methods through the whole of teaching-across a much wider area than simply compositional techniques-has, in a way, led to some confusion: which improvisation methods should be employed, when, and to what purpose? The TMDD has tried several times to plan more effectively by drawing up a list of approaches and goals. Title: 2nd EUROPEAN CONT ACT TEACHERS CONFERENCE
Abstract: A report on the 2nd European Contact Teachers Conference held in Amsterdam in November 1986. The conference included workshops, discussions, and networking events for contact improvisation teachers. Participants explored teaching methods, cultural differences, and the roles of teachers and students in contact improvisation.
Text: 2nd European Contact Teachers Conference November 18-21 , 1986 Theaters.chool, Modern Dance Department Amsterdam, Holland Participants: Meret Schlegel, Christine Goigg, Doniel Trenner, Lindo Forsman, Jacqueline de Vries, Wolfgang Grof, Mork Tompkins, Howard Sonenklor, Moniek van der Look, Doniel Lepkoff, Andrew Horwood, Pierre Riou, Bob Rease, Pauline de Groot, Pierre Serophin, Suzanne .Cotto, jean Bloch-Laroque, Stephen Crowford, Lucio Walker, Koren Nelson, Alita Alessi, Bruno Stefononi, Elinor Rodeff, Margot Rijven, Nancy Stork Smith, Kirstie Simson, Renate Muller, Wolter Weiler, Cathie Caraker, Gonne Kooy1 Nien Mari Chotz The first meeting on Tuesday evening was impressive. After introducing ourselves and talking about the schedule (prepared by Elinor, Renate and Cathie, who had organ· ized the conference), we came together for dancing. I was happy in the very plain meaning of the word. Happy, because I could dance with people without demonstrating anything in terms of teaching, without thinking about the next step in leading a class. There is this underlying structure I am dreaming of, there is this language spoken so well, that you can make poems. The room was filled with the atmosphere of light and easy dancing. We began the next morning with a warm· up led by Nancy, focusing on the questions: What do I need to get ready to dance with another person? How do I know what? Do I teach the other what I need? (The motivation for dancing: just a topic for teachers in their daily life.) The day got heavier, guided by a dense schedule we were not really able to fulfill. On the evening before, there had been at least ten people interested in teaching at this conference; now there was nobody. So, instead of co-teaching (which was set on the schedule), we gave brief personal reports of our work, one by one in the circle. Many issues were presented, but at that time we were not ready to pick them up for further discussions. (For example: falling as a need for giving up the image of yourself; realness of Contact; the help of aikido, tai-chi, meditation and body-work; to look what is beyond the form; relationship between ground and space.) The afternoon was spent with COTE ACHING: three people share the time (two hours) with or without connetting their material. It does not mean to find something new, but to give the chance to look at how other teachers teach. This time, Bruno worked with sounds leading to Contact. Pierre treated the left side of our bodies including our vision and ended up (surprisingly) with cart-wheels. Moniek then went from personal movement into group-improvisation, followed by open dance. People were kind of uneasy or ungrounded. Later we tried to find out why. Someone observed that we were "bad" students. We felt that we were confused by Pierre's sudden change of direction and by the different teachings. Moniek got nervous when she realized that her intentions did not work out. A small "accident" happened, but nobody was hurt, and the open dance was exciting to watch. {There was no "feedback" scheduled but we found time for it in the very last discussion on Friday, and got to some interesting points   One was the issue of how to deal with accidents in class: to pay attention to the hurt person, according to the situation;. to pay attention to the partner as well, because he might feel guilty; a teacher can get feedback for their teaching by remembering the energy in the room when an accident happened.) We left for dinner on the first day without a clear plan for the evening activitysomehow confused and very tired. Many people thought it was because of the talking (which was actually listening), or, because of the dense structure, or what? Some peo· pie began to already participate only parttime. Other people found this attitude disturbing. This evening almost nobody came. The second day began with co-teaching. Karen and Alito led the warm-up: first taking turns watching your partner's breath (who is lying on the floor), then doing a warm-up dance together and talking about it afterwards. Danny Trenner then led us through exercises where we sang contrapuntal jazz rhythms in two groups while doing contact, to learn to work with an external rhythm while improvising, without being disturbed by it. After tea-break, we started our first dis· cussion: the essence of teaching; different cultures; contact in performance; problems of teaching. The suggestion of splitting into smaller groups was made but not accepted: there was either no need to split at that moment, or, more likely, there was the fear of missing something being discussed else· where. We got into a constructive discussion about TEACHERS' AND STUDENTS' ROLES. Unlike the martial arts, where the master-role is very clear, the teacher-role in Contact Improvisation can be confusing. But, as a teacher, instead of being overwhelmed by a student's fantasies and projections, you can receive their energy and give it back. Also, if you don't take a student's aggression or resistance too personally, you can break the psychological cycle. On the other hand, you do have to find a way to work with difficult students. You cannot avoid conflicts. The whole psychological situation in a class can be like Contact Improvisation itself: give and receive weight and transform energy. The after-lunch co-teaching was done by Stephen, Mark, and Kirstie. In the begin· ning, Stephen worked with being absolutely dead and then responding to your partner's leading. Mark talked about one's habits {Do they work with this partner?) and how decisions are made in the dance. Kirstie had us centered and did some Ki-testing. At the end, they experimented with teaching their material simultaneously to the whole group, leaving us in a chaos. This evening, after having dinner together at the school, we went into the NETWORKING DISCUSSION, an important part of the conference. The discussion was dominated by finding a place and an organizer for the next conference. Will there be a next one? How do we prepare it? It was a hot discussion, at least for those who participated verbally. For many of us, the English was too fast and the statements were not related enough to each other. Some were interested in just a jam and others were not interested in open dancing at all. But to find out what was most important in a teachers conference for the whole group was just impossible. Some quarreling gathered around the question of how structured a conference should be in terms of prepared topics, etc. Looking back, I think that we somehow felt that the "teaching exchange" focus of this year's confe"rence didn't really work, the co-teaching was not convenient to everybody, there was not enough open dancing, and not enough time to meet people personally, all at the same time. And the conference will be over within the next day! But we could see clearly that a group-process is a group-process and cannot be compressed into one evening of talking about the schedule, but has to take place. By a vote we defined: all want another conference, three-quarters want more un· scheduled time. We agreed on two days of jam to get to know each other and to arrive, and three days of conference. We define ourselves as a support-group, but we can deal with a technical conference too. Also, the spirit of a conference is dependent on the organizer. Another conflict arose because of Euro· peans and Americans discussing European networking. One difficulty of this mix {in other aspects quite constructive) is the dif· ferent ways of communicating: the strong output of American participants vs. the European's preference for listening. Moreover, we Europeans have to stay in our cities to keep something going on, (and are not travelling around Europe giving workshops as much). We are still relying on each other; we have to. This is why the next day we made a gathering of European teachers (people who are settled in Europe and teach here) to talk about practical network. In that meeting, we agreed that it had been necessary for the first two conferences to invite somebody (i.e. Nancy) who is very well known and experienced. Her most valuable function has not been so much her attraction to get people to the conference, but her catalyzing presence. Yet, we will try to make it without special invitations next time and try to share the responsibility equally among everyone. On the practical level, we decided to meet next year not in a city but in a house in the countryside, which means meeting in the summertime. Three people volunteered to take responsibility, to ensure a gathering would happen. [See 'Notices' in this Newsletter for details about next conference.] The networking was understood as a real supportive one, not only in terms of teaching, but also as an exchange of performances and projects, ideas. This is the formal structure, the rest of it has to be developed in personal relationships. The European communication is still arranged through the NEWSLETTER, coordinated each time by a different person. We ended the conference with a final round robin and a party. We felt we have awakened potential connections all over Europe, seen that teaching problems get less dramatic when discussing them, and inspired each other through our dance~. See you next year.
