Title: DOLPHIN DANCE
Abstract: The author describes a dream-like experience of dancing with dolphins in a lagoon. She explores the similarities between contact improvisation and the freedom of movement experienced while swimming with these graceful creatures, highlighting the unique connection and playfulness that emerges.
Text: The first time I danced contact it was in a dream: filtered light, heaviness in my lungs, another's weight and breath rolling against my back, blood pulsing in my ears. Seven years later, my dream came true. Cold and shivering in the murky water of a small lagoon I dive and turn, hearing my breath in my ears, diaphragm constricted, straining to see a long grey form swimming lazpy below me. I come to the surface for air, my breath exploding in a burst. I breathe in deep and dive below again. After a few minutes of swimming I feel my skin beginning to warm. I stretch my limbs in the water, letting the physical movement calm me. The energy moves down out of my head and into my heart. I feel my heartbeat regulate and my breath softening. My attention turns to the sounds around me, mostly clicking and trilling. What I sense is that sound in the water has a great deal of movement. The noises bounce and vibrate below the surface. Suddenly I feel a nudge against the back of my knees, and turning I look into the eyes of a large smooth skinned dolphin. He opens his long mouth in a wide grin and the sound that comes from the blow hole on the top of his head is surprisingly like a human laugh. In turn I laugh back, amazed, and find myself with a mouthful of salty water. I surface again for air and quickly dive below again. Moving slowly towards him under the water I keep my arms at my sides to appear less threatening, and brush against his smooth back with my chest and belly. The dolphin gently grabs my arm in his.mouth. It is an odd sensation, having this huge mammal hold me between bis 88 teeth (same as a piano, but that's a different story). Knowing this is a sign of friendship I try and hold still until he releases me. His mouth feels like the grasp of a small child's fingers. Feeling like it is my turn to make a move I reach for the dorsal fin in the middle of his back and hold on tight to catch my first dolphin ride. The dorsal fin feels very firm. It is like a smooth, rubber covered, triangular shaped tree branch. It isn't slippery at all; on the contrary, my hand feels like it is touching a wet piece of solid rubber. We are side by side, under the surface, as the dolphin pulls me through the water. We both come up for air, dive again and then I notice on my other side a slightly smaller dolphin. I reach over with my free hand and grab the dorsal fin, arms extended, racing through the water I feel like I'm flying. Feeling the water's friction pulling against my skin I imitate the undulating motion of the dolphins. This second dolphin is a female, and she is happy to join us. We twist, dive, nudge and explore the similarities and differences ·in the way we move. When I first danced contact I dreamed about it often. At first I thought it was because I was learning something new and it was occupying my thoughts in my waking hours. As I remembered more of my dreams I realized dreaming contact was a way for me to dance contact without the usual limitations of a wakeful dance. I could move and dance in complete 3-dimensional space. In my contact dreams I had no horizon to limit or guide me. I feel this freedom in the water with these two lovely, graceful creatures. I am aware of a dream-like quality to our water dancing. We spin and chase, touqb and push, arching and tumbling, ignoring for once gravity and its constant demand. I feel an exhilarating freedom in this original and most basic liquid. They are home in it. I am just a visitor, very aware of my smaller lungs and lack of endurance, yet they welcome me and honor my limitations. I fill my lungs again and dive, following their shadowy forms swimming ahead of me. They turn and wait, and as I catch up they separate slightly so that I am in the middle between them. We all come up for air, and they stay, bobbing in the water next to me. My husband and daughter ca11 a greeting to me from the shore and I start to swim towards them. The male dolphin quickly moves in front of me, blocking my way, while his female friend nudges me back into deeper water. I am mostly surprised, a little frightened to find myself in a dolphin sandwich without a lot of movement possibilities. How do I convey Time-Out? Breathing deep I center my weight and push outwards with my arms as I duck below the surface and head out into the direction they were pushing me. They surface next to me, one in front and the other behind me. I tread water and laugh outloud. I'm incredulous and pleased that they want to keep me in the water. I feel like a dolphin play-thing. I reach out with my arms, twisting myself slightly, and grab bold of their dorsal fins. We all take a breath and we're off again, a dolphin on either side of me. We make a large circle of the lagoon and then they start towards shore. We are diving and surfacing, diving and surfacing, sunlight shining on the water, the salty breeze, my daughter laughing and clapping her little bands. Diving and surfacing, two dolphins and a woman making brief contact, making a dream-like dance. -ti rubber-stamp by Gottlieb-Clark

Title: • IS
Abstract: Steve Paxton discusses the relationship between the arts and the senses, particularly focusing on dance. He explores how dance, traditionally associated with the body, has become a spectator art primarily experienced through the eyes. He also delves into the interconnectedness of the senses and the role of trained kinetic systems in artistic creation.
Text: The arts can be related to the senses, roughly speaking-music for the ears, painting for the eyes, dance for the body. But dance suggests an exception, because in the West it has become a spectator art, and it is through the eyes that the audience begins a kinetic response, or a physical empathy with the dancer. The way the arts relate to the senses gets more and more complicated to describe when we consider the senses as interrelating. We notice that the muscles of the eyes move the visual apparatus to scan and focus. The neck and torso muscles move the head to expedite the eye movement. We move the whole body through space to look at sculpture. And we are able to dance on time to music by virtue of the fact that hearing, which is one of our fastest sensing systems, drives our kinetic response. In their creation or execution, the arts are deeply connected to specially trained kinetic systems which, in a painting for instance, produce not only images, but characteristic strokes and lines. The 'touch' of a musician is as characteristic. Title: THE SENSES
Abstract: This article explores the limitations of the traditional '5 senses' model and proposes a more nuanced understanding of sensory perception, drawing on various disciplines like yoga, acupuncture, and neuroscience. It discusses how our senses are deeply interconnected and how they influence our perception of time and reality. The author also examines the role of language in shaping our understanding of sensory experiences and the potential for 'mixed media' art to challenge conventional perceptions.
Text: s interrelating. We notice that the muscles of the eyes move the visual apparatus to scan and focus. The neck and torso muscles move the head to expedite the eye movement. We move the whole body through space to look at sculpture. And we are able to dance on time to music by virtue of the fact that hearing, which is one of our fastest sensing systems, drives our kinetic response. In their creation or execution, the arts are deeply connected to specially trained kinetic systems which, in a painting for instance, produce not only images, but characteristic strokes and lines. The 'touch' of a musician is as characteristic. These are ways of regarding the senses which are far from the '5 senses' model, which is the way children are taught about the senses and their perceptions of the world. And it seems that little is added to this initial picture in the adult popular mind. I have read newspaper articles about "the 5 senses and the mysterious 6th sense" just this year. I am not right up to date on the current material analyzing the senses into all their component bits, but they were up to about 25 separate senses (each with identifiable independent nerves) in the late 1970s, which is a much more interesting number. If you are interested in other models, read J. J. Gibson's The Senses Considered As Perceptual Systems, read Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen's work on Developmental Movement Systems (in past CQs), investigate the premises of yoga, acupuncture, or any of the Oriental physical systems which have been imported into the U.S., and read the provocative and heart-moving The Man Who Mistook His Wife For A Hat, by Oliver Sacks. I think we can't have too many models of the senses and their operation when considering a topic like improvisation. It is a bit self-referential to say that the model I'm working on in this essay is about the effect of models upon the mind, but I can't see any way around it. I should mention in this regard that Buddhist thinking includes the mind as one of the senses. I am fond of that thought for the questions which arise for the analysts (how fast do we sense our thought?). If this is an amusing poser to throw at the sensoral analysts, it is because most of their work on the senses relates to those of the surface, disregarding questions about our sense of gravity, our feeling of the muscles of the body when they are quiet, or the sense of 'being', if I may propose such a sense. Yet the analysts' labor to discover the special nerves for each sensoral aspect is of interest, if only to explain the mechanism which allows us to dance to music, a most popular form of improvisation. If we can bop at a party because our perception of sound is faster by 4 milliseconds than our perception of our limbs' relative positions, we may surmise something about how the brain interrelates the senses. We could also look at time itself as a thing modified by each of the senses, instead of being an objective measure of duration. In other words, in trying to describe the sensing of time, we must refer to the perception of times. These times then must be collated into how long we think an event took, which is a very complex computation involving which of the senses experienced the event. F9r instance, if we drop an object from a known height, we have the math to calculate how fast it will be moving when it hits the floor. This formula indicates that, barring air resistance, any object increases its rate of falling constantly. With this mathematical tool, we feel satisfied that we comprehend the event. It is objectively clear. However, if we drop a soapy dish and before it smashes on the floor, manage to catch it, we can appreciate the sensoral complexity and precision of another point of view-the subjective feeling of gravity's effect on the dish, which enables us to save it. We treasure this facility in sports-eye-hand-body coordination of time, space and posture getting you there to snag the pop fly. I was deeply impressed by seeing a blind woman drop and catch a plate she was washing. For once, the eyes didn't have it. It 'makes sense', as the phrase goes, that our bodies are completely attuned to the gravitic effectthat the rate a body falls is abundantly obvious to our own bodies; that any discussion of subjective time should mention the gravitic factor in tuning the human time senses. And we might as well put in right here yet another factor, the state of our endocrine system, which can speed up or retard our experience of these times-just to indicate how extraordinary a job the brain is doing and to get some glimpse of how quickly it does it. "Quickly," compared to what? Ah, "quickly" compared to how long it would take for the conscious mind to do the job. (This is my conscious mind writing, and I just wish you knew how long it's taking me to describe the little I can deduce about what my unconscious mind is doing.) a word Language, a medium in its own right, is deployed to analyze experiences. Language is either written or spoken. It is either for the eye or ear, but finally it is intended to be sensed by portions of the brain which decode sounds or symbols into meanings. We rely extensively upon it to communicate what we feel and think. We use it to qualify, quantify, and confirm and in general to hold our societies together. It is the major medium, I would estimate. Julian Jaynes has speculated (in The Origin of Consciousness in the Breakdown of the Bicameral Mind), that consciousness itself arose with the advent of the written word. The link of language to consciousness suggests many avenues for speculation. (It might explain the relative slowness of conscious thought, for instance.) I think it is well understood that there is much we experience which language cannot touch and should not be used for, but it is such an extraordinary medium that we keep applying it to all sorts of things, in hopes, perhaps, of contriving a successful new formulation; bringing the unconscious, un'knowable', or unspeakable into literate consciousness. I would bet that no dancer ever reviewed, however positively, has ever felt their dance captured in print. Yet language, used to describe other arts, forms a very important part of what we think about a work of art. It can certainly influence our point of view and may even suggest what can be thought about-that is, limit our perception or experience to the forum encompassed by language. It does seem to me that if we spend much time communicating with others via language about a painting, music, or a dance, we accustom our minds to the language version of the experience. There are sensible reasons for this. Human societies deeply appreciate evaluations which, like mining for gold, mean eliminating dirt and concentrating on what is considered valuable. Our actual experience of something can include much that is irrelevant to its evaluation. An apt evaluation of a work will likely be repeated by others to their friends. The further it goes from the source of the experience to a verbal or printed version, the less recourse we have to elaborations or answers to our questions. We put such a rendered experience into our own version of a context. It is an idea we flesh out with our own images. As such, it has become a fictionalized picture, it has become un-true, but we do it continually. Much of what we know about ourselves is described to us via language. The very idea of the 'imagination', for instance. How did you learn it existed? In many such respects, we 'imagine' ourselves according to categories, descriptions, and names of aspects of whatever we are told (or read) it means to be a hu;nan being. I have a soul, in other words, because the Bible tells me so. I have an ego and an id thanks largely to the writings of Freud, and an anima and animus courtesy of Jung. Not to belabor the point, we (think we) are conditioned to a considerable degree by our language. Not that the particular names, categories and descriptions we apply to ourselves have always been the same nor will they be used always. They reflect a consensus and will change or vanish as that consensus changes. Jaynes is fascinating as he tries to describe the state of the human mind prior to consciousness. But wc don't have to reach into the past to grasp some idea of how arbitrary our notions about ourselves are, we can examine ideas of cultures paralleling our own and feel the disconcerting void of (our own) recognizable terms of existence. Language is not only prominent, but it can be coercive. We may opt to disregard experiences which don't work in language. Tom Wolfe wrote a scathing article called "The Painted Word," wherein he suggests that painters in the NY School of abstract expressionism were in fact led by the writings of a few prominent critics to paint as they did. He seemed to feel that this was a degenerate situation which devalued the art produced. It could be said however that this was an exceptional case of painters and writers developing the ideas of a movement in concert-exceptional in that it was a very intimate scene with a mix of artists, musicians, dancers and critics in close communication, and with regular forums for discussion. Language could then be developed to account for the paintings at the moment of their creation. What Wolfe and the rest of us are accustomed to is a 5-to-10 year lag, to give time for critical language to be invented to describe the work. When this has been accomplished it has the effect Wolfe was describing: people learn to imagine in and with the new concepts, and artists and student artists elsewhere paint in the described manner. One medium may support another, rather like the sensoral model: one sense may support another. However, I have begun to think that one medium cannot accurately describe another. We are used to the attempt to make films of novels, and then read critiques in which, to no one's surprise, the film is found a more or (usually) less successful 'adaptation'. Films are now 'novelized' to similar effect. Critiques do not adequately portray the art, either: it all seems to boil down tCJ "you had to be there." There are nothing like the real things, whatever version of 'real' we happen to start with. Analysis of perceptions shows us the realms of 'reality' we are able to tap with the senses. Seeing, hearing, touching, smelling, imagining arc, to me, each so very different from each other, seen subjectively, that I am apt to think of them as sensoral dimensions. Again, we adapt one dimension to another; 'loud' colors, for instance, is an 'auralization' or a sight. But the point here is to notice how the sensoral dimensions are different, since we are so used to confirmations of events through their blending. Watch a carpenter drive nails at close range-eyes see and ears hear the hammer. Then, move into the distance-eyes see first   then ears hear. What we originally felt as one experience has been divided between the two senses. We are mildly bemused by the organic 'analysis' we experience. for somethiNG In the 1960s there arose an artistic movement called "mixed media" in which one saw dances, films, language, etc., used in the same work. Now that I understand the senses and the mind as 'mixed media', I am very surprised that the movement got this name. It seems to me that what was really going on was 'unmixed media', since the words usually did not relate to the dance or film which did not relate to each other in familiar ways. The audience was challenged with an event occurring in several sensoral dimensions, and the effect was similar to that of the lag between the visual and aural hammer-at-a-distance. The mind's habit of synthesizing perceptions was confounded. This was for me an agreeable aesthetic experience, because it illuminated ordinary perceptions a bit. It served to train the mind to examine different modes of sensing, and created in the midst of life a new game to play. As I recall, during that time no one mentioned that the theater, opera and dance were already 'mixed'. No one noticed that film had been mixed. Perhaps that was because people were excited over the possibilities for further mixes. Sounds emanated from sculptures. Words emanated from dancers. New mixes occurred even within the same media: for instance, Bach and Rock together within a dance performance. Paintings became 3-dimensional, sculptures were made with new materials such as cloth or compressed cars. Painters made happenings which were a kind of theater loaded with colors and shapes and textures and people and costumes and props; in fact, they were paintings moving freely into the 3rd and 4th dimensions, using 'in reality' what before would have been the models for 2-dimensionaf works. It was a period of radical interface. We were confronted with unaccustomed juxtapositions, and of course came to see things that way. It was rather different than our former way of seeing and from this contrast came little sparks of information. That is how I evaluate it anyway; or value it. When we have two things to contrast, it seems to cause one to notice, and to learn. It was difficult to appreciate exactly what we learned in the complex midst of a happening; I suppose it all got synthesized in the mind, and one began to notice things that had escaped notice previously. It led me to consider the process of learning, and I came to regard the overall experience as a rather powerful conceptual tool with which one could cause change in experienced reality. The question arises, why did we not notice media mixed before? That is what is so interesting. John Cage had been doing it for decades, and Duchamp's work suggested it decades before that. The surrealists seemed to be concocting mixed media images, and Picabia and Picasso began to collage-to contrast painted images and real objects, to sculpt images from found materials. that can't Perhaps the answer lies in language. Most folk couldn't 'get it' because they were still quite busy trying to 'get' what had happened in impressionism and pointilism. Cubism caused folk further consternation. And who could includemelting clocks or a urinal or a prepared piano or a bus ticket in the same conceptual frame? The critical thought and conceptual tools of the day were already busily employed elsewhere, and the media did not dispense images or rationales as quickly as they do now. The arts, in those days, had begun to change far more rapidly than our language could accomodate. During this century it became clear that changes were occurring on every level more rapidly than before. But this experience needed time to be finally understood, and those early examples, such as the more radical examples of Duchamp, were put aside to accumulate a kind of critical mass. By 1960, with enough hindsight, the times'-changing had provided us with the model for the mix, and many artists were at once ignited. By then the popular media and critical establishment were ready, and the mixed medium event was considered seriously and widely announced, after more than half a century gestation period. Apparently an object doesn't have a life of its own, an objective meaning, but is imbued with values by the way we, with our changing minds, evaluate it. For many people, an object such as Duchamp's birdcage filled with small white cubes of marble was not illuminating, but only absurd. The mix can appear quite empty and gratuitous unless the mind has some context in which to work with it. So during the 1960s when so many artists began to mix images, terms were arrived at to convey the impressions. Then the Duchamp objects were re-evaluated and it was possible to see them, not as obscure Dada jokes, but as objects with a particular luminosity, which operate in some other dimensions of the mind than the linguistic one. They resolutely resist meaning anything; and as it turned out, this quality became highly prized in that period of intense critical and artistic interchange. The laughter changed from dismissal to delight, and th<i last laugh was probably Duchamp's. The special gift of the mixed media was to provide a contrast to our conventional use of media and the senses. We had to admit that we did use conventions to convey our thoughts and feelings, and to run our society at large. The new mixes indicated that, once in place, conventions can dictate what the mind will allow itself to think. It seems to be the nature of the mind, the senses, the body, and of the society made up of these, to fall into habits, which are necessary for continuity, aids to individual survival and collective civilization. Individual habits and collective conventions prod us to adapt what we perceive into the most convenient shareable mental construct. From the music we are accustomed to hearing, we form an idea of the intervals between notes. As our ears become more educated, we can become quite accurate in reproducing these intervals. Confronted with music in a different scale than usual, however, this aural education works against accurate reproduction. The unfamiliar intervals will be 'adapted' to the nearest known intervals. This adjustment is so automatic and unconscious that the person attempting to reproduce the new intervals will probably not even realize their mistake. Given another level of training in the logic of different musical scales, reproduction becomes possible, if difficult. For those who don't have such training, being confronted with an unfamiliar system can lead to confusion. Indian music, for instance, may remain opaque and possibly even disturbing; the intervals will seem wrong compared to the scale we are familiar with. In addition, it will be very difficult for the person to say why it seems wrong. The result may be a kind of unease and possible retreat from the unfamiliar system, a sensation of being lost. Not just lost, but without knowledge of how we are lost, for there are many dimensions in music where it is possible to go astray. Under these conditions, a little information about the nature of the systems is very useful for re-orientation. However a very different sort of aid is an appreciation of the feeling of being lost. Getting lost is possibly the first step toward finding new systems. Finding parts of new systems can be one of the rewards for getting lost. With a few new systems, we discover we are oriented again, and can begin to use the cross pollination of one system with another to construct ways to move on. Getting lost is proceeding into the unknown. To reject the familiar, so rooted in our nervous system and minds, requires discipline. The difficulty is that we have to know so much to understand what it is we do and why we do it, in order to know what to avoid. We are not attempting to simply eliminate the known systems, but also to realize how we have adapted to those systems. It is the habits of adaptation which will keep us reproducing the system. The system itself is not the problem, but rather this human capacity to imprint unconsciously a new system upon our old system-or to embody the maps of our acquaintance, however tenuous. We are close to improvisation here. When lost, we will have to relate appropriately to unknown and changing conditions. The dictionary explains that improvisation means 'extemporare', or 'out of the time'. I suggest that we interpret "out of the time" in two contradictory ways. I suggest we discard all notions of clocks, and the half-life of cesium, or celestial mechanics, none of which are capable of improvisation, and equate time with human experience of duration, which is to say the experiences accumulated in life, so that "the time" will mean who we have become. "Out of the time" will mean that, out of experience (conscious or not) there is material for making something. Simultaneously, "out of" should be construed as 'aside from'. We have to use what we have become in such a way as to not be so controlled by it that it is automatically reproduced. Improvisation is a word for something which can't keep a name; if it does stick around long enough to acquire a name, it has begun to move toward fixity. Improvisation tends in that direction. Dance is the art of taking place. Improvisational dance finds the places. °"' -to be continually continued.

Title: by Christina Svane
Abstract: This article is a profile of Lisa Nelson, a dancer whose work explores the relationship between perception, thought, and movement. Svane describes Nelson's unique ability to manipulate focus and create unexpected gestures, challenging the audience's expectations and inviting them to engage with their own awareness.
Text: First thina you notice is her eyes. She can spin out her gaze like fine from a fly-fisher's reel. our focus the hook at its end. Even when she's hardh· mm·ing. there's so much going on that the onh· way t.o keep ~p with her is to let her remind you that seeing is nor a relationship with an external world. but with \'Ourself. There is no external world. What you see flyi~g across the room is thought. And when she moves. vou see the thought that moves this woman through the thought of space. It almost makes you squirm to feel your focus held so intimately within hers. How does she do it? With a tiny impulse she projects an enormous sweeping gesture that ne\·er happens. Because you thought it was going to happen. you see it; then \'OU see that she hasn't moved. With the skill of a Chapiin. she will prime ;·ou for pathos. and just as you begin pouring ir out. you notice she is cavorting in a rather awkward. obscene and brilliant dance. You want to laugh. but you're still carrying your last emotion. Your expectations are weighing you down. Unloading, you dive back in and find a major clue in the timing between the shifts in her focus and the movements of her bodv. You see her perception as thought, and a split second later see its impact through her body in movement, ideas being completed as feelings. (In her "blind" work, in which she has been exploring learning movement with eyes closed. we see her "seeing" through her ears, skin, nose and perhaps other senses. Here she makes it crvstal clear that every movement is determined h)· her p'erceptions, or designed to clarify th em.) At this point we are pulled inro the sparking space of awareness of .one's own awareness. in which. as Lisa says, "It's all you, right?" In fact, one of Lisa'~ trademarks is the nerve-synapse suddenness of her sequences. Although her movement invention is prolific, (and inimitable, though aspects of her style have cropped up in many new dancers'!. it is not the movements that we are asked to focus on. Ir.is in the moment before and after each impulse where we are intent on discovering how the synapse works and what the code is. Rarely will she follow momentum through to its natural resolution or decav. but allows each change in her perception caused by the movement to alter its course. As she drops her head toward t~e floor, she may suddenly reverse direction in response to the startling loss of her horizon, the wood grain flooding her screen. Like the tribesmen of the rainforest who, never having seen a large clearing, read distant animals as close range miniatures, she registers the surprises of an unconditioned perception. This makes her appear as a mind that has just dropped into a body and is finding out how it all works. For this she needs feedback through the consequences of her every move, and perhaps this is what also gives us the feeling that she is never dancing alone. She is dancii;ig a duet with the entire con ten ts of her consciousness. Within minutes we feel the spirit of her work, but it is as challenging to actually read her dancing as it is James Joyce's Ulysses. Both artists take consciousness as their content, and in order to anastomose across the many levels of its structure, they must work with a multi-faceted mind. But closer examination reveals distinct, unbroken threads of sensory perception, reactions, personal and cultural memory, imagery ranging from archetypal and hallucinogenic to geographical and anatomical, and the dialogue of selfquestioning and self-discovery. Lisa has the added challenge of weaving these elements into a multi-dimensional tapestry-with rhythm, cadence and echo-on the spot. Title: THE POLITICS OF IMPROVISATION
Abstract: This article discusses the political aspects of improvisation, particularly in dance, emphasizing its immediacy, decision-making, and collaborative nature. It presents the results of a survey on the use of improvisation in college and university dance programs, highlighting its benefits for students and the qualities of an ideal improvisation teacher.
Text: THE POLITICS OF IMPROVISATION Of all the dance forms, improvisation is probably the most political-because it contains the urgency of immediacy. Improvisation forces people to make decisions on their feet and to live with those decisions. It helps people to see how their decisions affect others. When done by groups of people, it has everything to do with learning to work with others-not competing but working with the idea of the total picture and the individual's small but significant place in that overall picture. When working in duet form, as in contact improvisation, one is forced to really listen to what the other body is saying. In contact, movement choices are based upon forces of nature such as gravity and the spiral plus a direct response to the movement of the partner's body. This ability means survival in the contact form. While improvising, we learn again and again that to listen to another's movement is to come to a shared meeting ground. This is the politics of improvisation. With this in mind, I conducted an informal survey in the fall of 1984 to see how improvisation was being used in colleges and universities throughout the United States. Because of financial constraints, I wrote only to dance programs which offered at least a masters degree in dance. There were 60 in all; 31 responded. Here follows the information gathered: 25 of the 31 schools who responded had improvisation courses. 5 schools offered it only as part of another course such as composition. 15 schools offered one level, 7 offered it at 2 levels, and 3 schools offered three levels. 10 schools awarded 1 credit, 9 schools awarded 2 credits, 4 awarded 3 credits and 2 awarded 4 credits. 27 of the 31 schools believed it should be a required course, 16 believed one semester was enough, 4 felt that 2 semesters sufficed, 2 thought 3 should be required and one believed 4 semesters should be required. 15 schools allowed it to be 132 CQ/Cl Sourcebook Volume 12 1987 repeated for credit. Accompaniment for class ranged from voice to sounds, to canned music, piano and percussion, the range generally found in technique classes. The music was primarily provided by the instructor with occasional visits by musicians. One college always had live accompaniment, but this was the exception. It was felt that a wide variety of movement experiences should be offered in improvisation classes. These should include experiences with an aural, visual and art emphasis. Students should be exposed to the elements of dance in their most fundamental forms: space, rhythm/time, dynamics, body articulation, effort qualities, line, emotional qualities, gesture, sound, texture, sensory awareness on all levels. Other important aspects to include were phrase development, chance [methods], environmental inspiration, examination of personal idioms, group dynamics, elements of contact work, awareness of inner/outer space. Through these experiences, students should show an improvement in performance skills, a greater ability to think on their feet, greater trust in themselves and in each other, have an improved ability to recall, and generally be able to view the total picture within the framework of the dance, and dance within the framework of the arts. Most of the schools had members of their full-time faculty teach the improvisation classes. The appropriate teacher just seemed to surface. Some of the notable improvisation teachers mentioned were Daniel Nagrin, Claudia Melrose, Kathryn Karipides, Irini Nadel [Rockwell] , Barbara Dilley, Shirley Ririe, Joan Woodbury, Loa Mangelson and Ann Riordan, among others. On only one occasion did a Teaching Assistant teach improvisation. Qualifications for the "ideal" improvisation teacher would also qualify a person for sainthood, things to which all dance teachers aspire. He or she should be experienced, sensitive, have an ability to work from a problem-solving base, be able to create an Volume 1 2 1987 environment safe for exploration, be constructive, kind, open, have a sense of humor, empathy, extensive experience in improvisation performance, be able to handle emotional blocks, have an ability to work with imagery, be able to create a group dynamic, be able to structure problems that lead to meaningful solutions and, probably most importantly, be able to change plans mid-stream. The effects of improvisation experience upon students were noticed in their ability to experiment, explore and develop bits of material. They had a wider movement vocabulary, improved creativity, were more in touch with their own movement sources, took greater risks, created more authentic, less stylistic work, had improved technique and became more sophisticated self-aware students. They were more comfortable dancing with others. Students often experienced an evolution from fear to delight and it was a turning point in many of their lives. It was felt that improvisation had value in and of itself. Besides the obvious benefit of helping students learn to choreograph, it is an aid in learning to see and understand dance movement as it relates to all the arts. It allows the uniqueness of the individual to be celebrated. It teaches students to consider the value of their own movements before setting judgments. Improvisation enhances creative thinking and problem-solving, heightens kinesthetic perception, creates an awareness of group dynamics, fosters a personal viewpoint about dance, deepens awareness of movement logic and helps students to live creatively. No one mentioned the importance of improvisation in preparing students to teach children or members of the "very special" population. Also, the use of improvisation in dance therapy was not mentioned. I was surprised by this omission as I feel that improvisation is the very basis for working with these groups, which many dancers will do at some point in their career. Improvisation is seen as an art form separate from more "conventional" dance. At one school, students have to perform a structured improvisation before they can receive their dance degree. It was felt that there are some who are brilliant at improvising and they should perform. There were mixed feelings about the way it should be presented. Many saw it as having an important place within conventional choreography or within structured choreographic works. Some felt that it shouldn't be mixed with traditional choreography. Some felt that it stood more strongly in an intimate setting. The University of Utah was one place that received recognition as a place to learn about improvisation. Naropa Institute was another. Some of the other schools mentioned were Ohio State University, UCLA, Arizona State University, University of Texas at Austin, Wesleyan University, University of Arizona at Tempe, Sarah Lawrence, NYU School of the Arts, and Southern Methodist University. I think it is obvious from this survey that improvisation plays an important role in the training of dancers. I know there is a place in dance for the highly competitive classes that train the super-tech dancers who are so popular today, but I feel this survey supports the belief that there is still more to being a dancer, and that it can be uncovered through · self-exploration. An improvisation class can become the laboratory for exploration of the form and of the self. It can be a forum for sharing, not competing. It can be a place to celebrate our differences while helping us to understand that we share the same roots. "Self-exploration," "nurturing," "sharing," "celebrating," "lifeenhancing"-to me, these words represent a very strong, positive politics. It's this approach that keeps dance vital and strong.~ CQICI Sourcebook 133

Title: SMALL DANCE POEM
Abstract: This is a poem about finding one's dance, embracing movement, and the journey of self-discovery through dance.
Text: SMALL DANCE POEM   with thanks to Chogyam Trungpa you start out to find your little dance first move, best move you don't even know you are beginning you think perhaps you are a vegetable of course, that is true you begin and begin you don't even know you are beginning you stand up you start this way many times to find this little dance you've heard so much about and this time you are standing on a patient turtle you start out to find your little dance this time you think you are the great ballplayer Sadahara Oh but you work hard to keep both feet on the ground you forget about slashing your mummy and race home for dinner without going anywhere you find more in your little dance than there was the time before and think about it less you are a little dance but you are not alone you are hanging in the closet in between a black sealskin cape with Betty Davis shoulders and a green striped bowling shirt that once belonged to someone named Marty you are not harassed by gravity this time and the next time you will not even care history proclaims to each a little dance bare! y a step is taken but the changes compound you start out a little dance you are called "de born born" fidgety rhythmic pulse you can travel anywhere you choose there is not a country you can not em brace and you never leave your little spot you start out to find your little dance first move, best move best way, only way only way, one way and music or no music or no music with music no way, wrong way first move, best move Terrie Yaffe [Text performed with Karen Nelson and Nancy Stark Smith at Breitenbush jam performance, 1986, Eugene, Oregon.] 134 CQ/CI Saurcebook

Title: Letter to CQ from Daniel Lepkof f
Abstract: This article presents a series of questions posed by Daniel Lepkoff regarding the state of Contact Improvisation, questioning its hierarchy, the allure of gymnastic skills, and the potential disconnect between technical skill and genuine feeling in performance.
Text: Letter to CQ from Daniel Lepkof f QUESTIONS NOT TO ASK: Why is the aerial lift a signature of an accomplished Contact dancer? W!ly are complete beginners so beautiful to watch, and experienced Contact lmprovisors often so boring? Why is there a hierarchy of Contact skills? Why were many of my advanced Contact students unconsciously resistant to learning? Why can someone become advanced in a form based on communication? Why do I expect to get "danced on" at Contact jams? Why are Contact-based performances so devoid of vision and self-examination? Why does the allure of gymnastic skills overshadow the exploration of making contact? Why do experienced Contact dancers get frustrated with beginners? Why does a form rooted in the senses give rise to a generic look, when life itself is so varied? Why did I overhear an audience member say during a C.I. performance, "How can adults do all of that and not seem to feel anything?" 1r DANIEL LEPKOFF has been instrumental in the development of the teaching and performance practice of Contact Improvisation since its inception in 1972. He is currently based in New York City.

Title: ANSWERS NOT TO BE QUESTIONED
Abstract: Karen Nelson responds to Daniel Lepkoff's questions about Contact Improvisation, offering her perspectives on the aerial lift, the appeal of beginners, the hierarchy of skills, and the challenges of conveying sensation in performance.
Text: ANSWERS NOT TO BE QUESTIONED Response to Danny Lepkoff's HQuestions Not To Ask " in "Still Moving," CQ Vol. 13:3, Fall 88 by Karen Nelson "Why is the aerial lift a signature of an accomplished Contact dancer?" [Lepkoff] A. It does take some physical skill and listening ability to communicate timing, impulse and subtlety of moving weight and support in order to accomplish the aerial lift. I'd say it's more like the ink than the signature. [Nelson] "Why are complete beginners so beautiful to watch, and experienced Contact Improvisors often so boring?"· Beginners' Luck-we are watching an exploration of totally new territory, the unknown. With experienced contact improvisors we see expanding knowledge of an infinite unknown. Yet often a stage of doing contact involves a kind of automatic response, everything seems predictable for the viewer and doer, even if it still feels great to do, it can be personally stagnating. Learning new senses of disorientation and new choices of improvisation is challenging to the imagination. "Why is there a hierarchy of Contact skills?" Safety; some semblance of order is useful. To engage the senses, gross and subtle, is an overwhelming field of discovery. A teacher's personal "hierarchy" of skills is probably something very alose to their own dancing of contact. P.S. What are yours? "Why are so many of my advanced Contact students unconsciously resistant to learning? "Why can someone become advanced in a form based on communication?" How do you as a teacher read a person's unconscious? Is this an advanced form of communication? "Why do I expect to get 'danced on 1 at Contact jams?" Personal history. "Why are Contact-based performances so devoid of vision and self-examination?" Because it is an unprecedented performance form and a study of performance values doesn't come along with basic learning of and therefore showing of the work. It's a style of its own, still evolving. "Why does the allure of gymnastics skills overshadow the exploration of making contact?" Could be because everyone loves and marvels at the ability of gymnasts-like when you watch the Olympics-and it's exciting to see these tricks performed live. Maybe it stimulates childhood memories. "Why do experienced Contact dancers get frustrated with beginners?" Because beginners are better at not knowing what could come next. "Why does a form rooted in the senses give rise to a generic look, when life itself is so varied?" Why do human beings look alike, distinguishable from kangaroos? "Why did I overhear an audience member say during a C.I. performance, 'How can adults do all of that and not seem to feel anything?'" How can we make this incredibly rich and varied inner world of sensation visible to outside eyes? * KAREN NELSON is co-director of Joint Forces Dance Company which produces the annual CI JAM at Breitenbush in Oregon where she lives. She has been practicing CJ since 1977, teaching and performing in North America and Europe.

Title: THE BERLIN JAM
Abstract: Keith Ormand discusses the challenges of establishing a Contact Improvisation jam in Berlin, exploring cultural differences and the potential for Contact Improvisation to bridge these gaps.
Text: THE BERLIN JAM by Keith Ormand Living in Berlin for the last seven months I have had ample time to ponder. As a foreigner I am often faced with a certain level of culture gap, and when this carried over into Contact Improv I found some issues which I would like to share and invite comment on. Can Contact Improv cross these gaps? Does Contact lmprov fit into the German society? And, more pertinent for me, into the Berlin Society? Contact Improv is not absent in Berlin, nor has it been for the last eight years. Every week at least five different classes are taught drawing more than 40 students. Workshops are sponsored throughout the year with fair success, and there are even a few performances, performance groups here which have utilized Contact Improv. Clearly Contact Improv has precedent here. And yet no jam has been established. Why not? 138 CQ;CI Sourcebook Previously I lived in Seattle where a jam has developed, especially over the last three years, from a small group into a large society, unhierarchical, and very supportive. The jam there draws from a community of about 100 people, and hosting between 15 and 30 people each Saturday. In the last year the Jam sponsored six

Title: THE BERLIN JAM II.
Abstract: Keith Ormand discusses the evolution of the Berlin Jam, a Contact Improvisation community, over a year. He addresses initial challenges, the support from local teachers, and the formation of the Berlin Contact Ballet. He also explores gender dynamics and the question of hierarchy within the community.
Text: The Berlin Jam has now been in existence for over a year, and is showing no signs of coming to an end. Many of the problems encoun tered a year ago have vanished, and the Jam is entering a new stage. As it grows, new problems come to the surface, and with time these also will be replaced. At least three of the four teachers offering contact courses regularly here support the Jam by informing their students of its existence. As a result, there is a regular attendance of 12-16 people, and usually one or two are there for the first time. In return, information is exchanged in the Jam regarding the classes and workshops which are available. Furthermore, The Berlin Contact Ballet has been formed by participants of the Jam, and has three performance dates in the upcoming months. On the other side, many of the people who have taken contact courses since before the Jam began have never been to the Jam. I hear that they do not have time since Saturday is the only day during the week to take a day off from dance. Those of us who enjoy dancing on Saturday respect this, and appreciate it. I have also heard that some of the more advanced dancers would come if more of the other advanced dancers were there. Contact Hierarchy? The Berlin Jam is predominately male, with a ratio of 2: 1. This is not surprising in a city where 75% of the contact teachers are male. Last February I had the opportunity to spend a weekend in Cologne, where a jam was also organized. It was a pleasant change to encounter a jam with 10 women and 4 men. I also participated in a workshop in Brussells, in which I was the only male for the first two days, and one of three by the last day. Last December I participated in the European Contact Jam in Angers, France, where the proportions were about equal, something like 18:17, and I am not sure which gender had the majority. Now, in Angers, there was one woman who was as fascinated by the gender question as myself. She asked questions such as "How does it feel, you men, to be dancers?" and made statements such as "I really like seeing two men dance together   It is such a different energy than when two women, or a man and a woman are dancing together." Being one of the men dancing at the time this last statement was uttered, I was brought abruptly to the realization that men and women are different. Well, of course I won't presume to say how we are different. I do not often have difficulties in telling men and women apart, and if there is any lingering doubt, I can always contrive to dance with the one in question and take a gender energy reading. But precisely what this difference is, eludes me. Have you ever been told by another dancer that he/she prefers dancing with men? Have you ever told another dancer that you prefer men? Have you ever told your parents that you prefer men? I hear this preference often these days, much more often than a decided preference for dancing with women. And generally, the assertion of a preference for women partners in Contact Improvisation is often accompanied with the assertion of a specific woman. I do not want to imply that this is a problem. It is not a problem, unless you are not one of the "preferred dancers." After all, there are men, too, that I do not want to dance with. Many dance forms have been dominated by men. In Kabuki, and Keith Ormand & Andi Lucas in the Berlin Jam. Peking Opera, women are traditionally excluded. Although not a dance form, Shakespeare's company had no women on the stage. Contact is much more lenient. Although even in ballet, men acquire recognition more easily than women, actually, ballet is not a good comparison, since, in Contact a very good female dancer may be regarded as outstanding, while a good male dancer may be regarded as standard. I believe it is rather the opposite in ballet. And of course, I do not want to use Contact Improvisation as a metaphor for society. That is up to you. Actually, I am interested in heirarchy. Who is good enough to dance with? Who should be allowed to participate in special jams and conferences? Who should be excluded? At one point someone at the Berlin Jam said that we should not tell anyone else about the jam, because there might not be enough room, and we might not like the newcomers. He conceded that anybody who had the energy to fit the jam into their schedule probably would not be so disagreeable, and probably could find enough room to dance in. In Angers, the question of who should be allowed to participate in the jam, and in turn, in the conference, was not easily solved. Well, I know that there is nothing I hate more than being forced to dance with bad dancers, or listen to th~ opinions of unqualified, nonfeachers. (Of course I know that space is often a problem here, but I prefer to deal with the problem of exclusion which occurs when there is enough space.) When is a dancer good enough to go to jams? Over here, many people start contact in classes. But how do they know that they are good enough to go to a jam? How do they know that they have reached the point that they can participate in workshops for experienced dancers? If they are not part of the dance crowd, they may never know. When they come to the jam and find that none of the dance crowd from the classes is there regularly, they have no standard to measure their own progress until they have established themselves either in the jam, or in the class. It is easy to think, as a newcomer, that the really good dancers do not come to the jam because they do not want to dance with the people there. It is easy to come to the conclusion that the dancers in the jam are not as good as the dancers not at the jam. This may be why it is so easy to dance in the jam; no challenge. Is it that the good dancers find the jam not challenging enough? or are they afraid of being hurt by dancing with someone who is unexperienced? I have heard these excuses. But how can the beginning dancer get enough experience to dance with a good dancer so that he/she won't hurt him/her? Are we going to support the beginning dancers? or is it a justifiable aim to keep contact among ourselves, now that there are so many of us. It would be safer, perhaps, to dance only with people we know. There may still be a little room here for taking risks. Or maybe you take risks by offering classes to beginners. Are your students good enough to go to a jam? Contact is in no danger of dying out, but is there any possibility for growth? In Berlin, the space problem is left alone, but we keep a careful eye on the quality problem. When a bad dancer shows up, we change the standard. In this way, we are sure that all the dancers participating in the Berlin Contact Jam are good. 'fr KEITH ORMAND established the Berlin Jam a few months after having moved there from Seattle where he had been active in the Contact community for many years.

Title: EGALITARIANISM AND HIERARCHY IN CONTACT IMPROVISATION
Abstract: Cynthia Novack explores the tension between egalitarian ideals and the emergence of hierarchies within the Contact Improvisation community. Drawing on Louis Dumont's theories, she argues that social roles and actions inevitably create hierarchies, even in movements that value equality. The article examines how distinctions between amateurs and professionals, skilled and less skilled dancers, and social dancers and performers challenged the initial egalitarian ethos of Contact Improvisation.
Text: The following piece is an excerpt from Cynthia Novack's doctoral dissertation, "SHARING THE DANCE, an ethnography of contact improvisation," written in 1986, soon to be published. For more information contact Cynthia at 46 Warren Street, NYC, NY 10007. EGALITARIANISM AND HIERARCHY IN CONTACT IMPROVISATION by Cynthia Novack Anthropologist Louis Dumont has suggested that: "The ideal of liberty and equality follows immediately f ram the conception of man as an individual. In effect, if the whole of humanity is deemed present in each man, then each man should be free and all men are equal . .. By contrast, as soon as a collective end is adopted by several men, their liberty is limited and their equality brought into question."' Dumont continues an analysis begun by Toqueville of conflicts in American society, arguing that "to adopt a value is to introduce hierarchy, and a certain consensus of values, a certain hierarchy of ideas, things, and people, is indispensable to social life" quite independently of "natural inequalities or the distribution of power." Consequently, the ideal of equality, "even if it is thought superior, is artificial."' Dumont is proposing that the concept of equality among individuals will inevitably be challenged by hierarchies arising from social roles and social action defined by the very concept of equality. His argument does not defend the use of power and control in hierarchy, but rather attempts to separate hierarchy from the automatic association with power and control which it has in Western culture. Contact improvisation embraced values of individualism, equality, and anti-hierarchical relationships, but, if Dumont is right, one would expect contradictions to appear between these values and the differences developing from social roles and social action, even if no one takes power. In the initial formation of contact improvisation, an egalitarian ethos maintained itself, with Steve Paxton as the teacher. As the contact improvisation movement developed, the looseness of organization within the movement contributed to an atmosphere of fluidity. As Steve Paxton notes, people were free to come and go; for those who chose to be involved in contact improvisation on only a casual basis, not much was at stake. So long as no one was concerned about the outcome of a performance other than to demonstrate the exciting new dance form of contact improvisation, and so long as the group of people participating in the dance form remained a small group of friends, everyone could be viewed on an equal basis. Contact improvisation could be practiced in both a social setting and a performance setting by the same people. However, for those people who became involved with the dance form on a professional basis, teaching and/or performing to earn their living, a great deal was often at stake. As the years went by, many of those who had been doing contact improvisation since the beginning became teachers, and some began to form performance groups. There was a spate of local group organization from 1977-79, as well as an increase in touring by individuals gnd by ad-hoc groups. Both teaching and performing established distinctions of roles within the movement. Differences between amateurs and professionals, between the less skilled and the very skilled, and between the social dancers and the performers developed. Lisa Nelson, after talking about the "folk" nature of early contact improvisation, commented, ''Eventually a lot of people became teachers and that started to change things   if you'd been performing, that kind of became a habit and you wanted to keep performing   after a while, it took you away from just being 'a folk' and spending time with 'the people."'  Inevitably, the ideqlogy of egalitarianism and spontaneity was challenged by the appearance of implicit hierarchy and overt planning. The demands of performing and operating within the professional dance worldpromoting one's work, applying for grants, seeking students-involved these dancers in somewhat different concerns from people who were participating in contact improvisation for social and recreational reasons. Dancers were often differentiated from each other on a more informal basis. Some emerging differences were simply based on the level of skill of individual participants: everyone began to know who the most able dancers were. Elizabeth Zimmer recalled her perceptions of the contact improvisation jams in Vancouver: "There was a hierarchy. People tried to pretend there wasn't, but people who could really move got to dance with the people who could really move . .. like if I would ask Andrew Harwood to dance, we would dance for a while and then he'd say he wanted to stop and then he'd go on to dance with somebody who could really dance. So I'd consider it a good day if I got a couple of minutes with Peter [Ryan] and a couple of minutes with Andrew. So there were people you didn't want to dance with because they couldn't, other people you were reluctant to ask because they were so good, and depending on how you were feeling about yourself on any given day, you took certain kinds of risks." Those who were very skilled or very involved in developing the dance form often found their interests diverging from the increasing numbers of new and relatively unskilled contact improvisers, as well as from those long-time improvisers who were primarily interested in socializing. For example, in 1979, two large gatherings of contact improvisers took place. "Current Exchange," a month-long meeting at the Western Front artists' cooperative in Vancouver, was organized by Steve Paxton for "serious students" of contact improvisation. Those wishing to attend had to submit letters to Paxton describing their activities and interests because Paxton did not want to teach or be in a position of responsibility for the group. The conference involved dancing, discussion, writing, and videomaking, a full-time endeavor for people with a strong involvement in the dance form. "Country Jam," an event held that same year on Vancouver Island, was, according to Peter Ryan, ''exactly the opposite of Current Exchange." Ryan, who attended and helped organize both events, laughingly described Country Jam as "dance for the proletariat   it was homespun, there was organic food and jamming every day." Ellen Elias, who attended Current Exchange, felt that it was "elitist" because of the requirement to write a letter, even though everyone who wrote was accepted. Among contact improvisers, she says, "there was a way of being elitist that was subtle   there was definitely a sense of in-group, out-group, but it was supposed to not be there." Like Zimmer, Elias noted the social convention of assumed equality which overlay the existence of hierarchies. What is particularly notable about the contact improvisation community is not that hierarchies existed but that many participants were so conscious of them and disturbed by them. As mentioned earlier, many contact improvisers actively promoted the idea that an experienced dancer should be able to dance with anyone and learn something from it, as well as vice versa. At the 1980 Dance Guild Conference ["Dance As Artsport," in Minneapolis], many of the remarks at a gathering to discuss "Politics and Contact Improvisation" were addressed to the problem of "elitism" and the "exclusivist attitudes" of the "contact heavies."' People felt strongly that the egalitarian aspects of contact improvisation needed to be maintained. As the years passed, cultivating a spirit of trust and caring between partners remained a central component of contact improvisation classes and jams, and extended to the social ethos of communal organizations like Dance New England. On a social basis, it was strongly felt that the participation of everyone in contact improvisation was not to be sacrificed to the special abilities of a few people. But this ethos was very difficult to maintain as a part of presenting the work publicly. * 'Louis Dumont, Homo Hierarchicus (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1966), p. 11. 'Ibid., p. 20. 'Jerry Zientara, unpublished notes, 1980. Patrick Scully & Ellen Schelly of Contactworks, Minneapolis, 1977.

Title: ''FALL AFTER NEWTON''
Abstract: "FALL AFTER NEWTON" is a videotape documenting the development of Contact Improvisation over 11 years, from Steve Paxton's Magnesium in 1972 to the Contact's 11th Anniversary Concert Series in 1983. The tape examines the evolution of the dance form through the performances of Nancy Stark Smith, with narration by Steve Paxton.
Text: ''FALL AFTER NEWTON'' "FALL AFTER NEWTON" is a videotape that traces 11 years of development of Contact Improvisation from Steve Paxton's seminal work Magnesium in 1972 through consecutive years of Contact performances including Contact's 11th Anniversary Concert Series at St. Mark's Church in NYC in 1983. Steve proposed the documentary concept for "F.A.N." after editing the videotape "Chute" with Steve Christiansen and Lisa Nelson in 1979 from performance tapes of the first Contact concerts in 1972. The great fortune of having video coverage of performances from the very beginning suggested the possibility of examining one dancer's development and looking for corresponding growth of the dance form itself. In 1980, the editing team plus Nancy Stark Smith, who was asked to be the focal dancer for the tape, began pouring through 9 years of video documents of performances (approx. 50 hours) and made a first 20 minute edit from the material. Seven years of sporadic editing sessions, script writing and revisions resulted in a 23 minute videotape in color and black and white with the following narration by Steve Paxton. Lisa Nelson ["Fall After Newton" received partial funding from the National Endowment for the Arts, the Judson Church Dance Project of Bennington College in Vermont, and Videoda, a project of Contact Collaborations, Inc. "F.A.N." and other Contact tapes are available through Videoda, Box 22, E. Charleston, VT 05833.] TRANSCRIPT by Steve Paxton When an apple fell on his head, Isaac Newton was inspired to describe his three laws of motion. These became the foundation of our ideas about physics. Being essentially objective, Newton ignored what it feels like to be the apple. When we get our mass in motion, we rise above the constant call of gravity toward the swinging, circling invitation of centrifugal force. Dancers ride and play these forces. Beyond Newton's third law, we discover that for every action several equal and opposite reactions are possible. Therein lies an opportunity for improvisation. We are looking at performance of Contact Improvisation, a duet movement form. This tape takes a sweeping look over 11 years of practice by Nancy Stark Smith, from her first exposure to the form I was working on when it was new in 1972, through moments chosen from consecutive years of performing with me, Steve Paxton, and with others. Nancy solos by testing her movement, playing with gravity and the floor, which are, in this work, not taken for granted, but are considered constant partners. She doesn't direct herself-she starts moving and then lets it happen, finding ways to cope with momentum and gravity. Here, in 1976, Nancy and her partner Curt Siddall move to follow the point of touch as it moves-a basic focus for their improvisation. In the play of moving and being moved, specific movements are unpredictable, but they occur within a knowable field-of gravity, centrifugal force, support and dependency. Human touch unites the forces which act upon the body, with the sensations they provoke within the body. This interaction makes it possible to keep all the parts of both their bodies harmonizing. They were not so adventurous 4 years earlier. In this first performance of Contact Improvisation, they were getting used to moving by touch. By feeling their way, they brought back clues about the form and about themselves and their perceptions. "O 0 E' < ·al s 0 ..c Cl. c 0 ';< "' 0  "' > B "' ~ E "' -t ;:! It investigated the reflexive quality of touch, with momentum, falling, rolling and colliding. . Magnesium ends with five minutes of standing, to draw a great distinction in the scale of movement.
