Title: STILL MOVING THE ECSTATIC POETRY -Searching for The Roots Of Contact or JALALUDDIN RUMI
Abstract: This article explores the connection between the ecstatic poetry of Jalaluddin Rumi and Contact Improvisation. It discusses Rumi's life, his encounter with Shams of Tabriz, and the themes of ecstasy, love, and longing in his poetry. The author suggests that Rumi's improvised poetry and his emphasis on spontaneity and the liminal align with the principles of Contact Improvisation.
Text: Today, like every other day, we wake up empty and frightened. Don't open the door to the study and begin reading. Take down the dulcimer. Let the beauty we love be what we do. There are hundreds of ways to kneel and kiss the ground. Jalaluddin Rumi We have a huge barrel of wine, but no cups. That's fine with us. Every morning we glow and in the evening we glow again. They say there's no future for us. They're right. Which is fine with us. When I am with you, we stay up all night. When you're not here, I can't go to sleep. Praise God for these two insomnias! And the difference between them. Sometimes I forget completely what companionship is. Unconscious and insane, I spill sad energy everywhere. My story gets told in various ways: A romance, a dirty joke, a war, a vacancy. Divide up my forgetfulness to any number, it will go around. These dark suggestions that I follow, are they part of some plan? Friends, be careful. Don't come near me out of curiosity, or sympathy. I would love to kiss you. The price of kissing is your life. Now my loving is running toward my life shouting, What a bargain, let's buy it. by Martin Keogh Imagining the whirling dervishes, brings alive blossoming robes, hats resembling beehives, beards like bees in pursuit, and arms floating weightlessly, the lone clouds in a clear summer sky. The twirling faces focus on nothing as they turn, peering into the betwixt and between, into the limenal world. The original whirling dervish was Jalaluddin Rumi. Born on September 30, 1207 in Balkh in what is now Afghanistan, Rumi's family settled in Konya, Turkey after being exiled by the Mongol invasions. During the thirteenth century this was a meeting place at the western end of the silk road for Christian, Islamic, Hindu, and Buddhist worlds. Here he succeeded his father as head of a medrese, the dervish learning community. This fairly conventional career ended when he met the wandering dervish, Shams of Tabriz. Shams took Rumi's books, the sum of his intellectual brilliance and tossed them down a well to show him that he needed to live what he had been reading and writing. With Shams, Rumi met the "inner friend," "the beloved." However the mystery is named, he found it with Shams and out of their parting came Rumi's poetry. The poetry is described in the introduction of Open Secret by John Moyne and Coleman Barks: "The essential power of Rumi's poetry is ecstasy, an ecstasy melting the confinement of the ego into a larger, elastic, cross pollinating dance of Selves. His is not the ecstasy of Union, not in the poetry. It is a love-ecstasy mixed with some brokenness and much longing. "Rumi's odes and quatrains are the personal, human records of a man's being given a sharp, clear consciousness of the divine, and enduring it." Rumi died in 1273 and his funeral was attended by members of all religious groups including the different Islamic sects. Rumi was a Sufi, poet, dancer, and 144 CQ/CI Source"book We don't need wine to get drunk, or instruments and singing to feel ecstatic. No poets, no leaders, no songs, yet we jump around totally wild. though it is immodest to claim, his acuity puts him in the geneology of Contact Improvisation. Though some of Rumi's poems were written, most were improvised and came out spontaneously metered and rhymed. It's difficult to find a comprehensive description of Contact Improvisation. There are adequate explanations of the physical and functional aspects of our dance, yet there is always that element which can't be embraced with language. Seven hundred years ago Rumi recited poetry that to this day speaks to the soul of Contact. Here is a sampling of Rumi's poetry. In the second group are poems that I feel have a connection to C.I. In the Sufi tradition, another name for the medrese is the night school, following the idea that we have a day mind and a night mind. The day mind does the laundry and pays the bills. The night mind is for poetry. These poems are ideally read aloud, at night. Think that you're gliding out from the face of a cliff like an eagle. Think you're walking like a tiger walks by himself in the forest. You're most handsome when you're after food. Spend less time with nightingales and peacocks. One is just a voice, the other just a color. The clear bead at the center changes everything. There are no edges to my loving now. I've heard it said there's a window that opens from one mind to another, but if there's no wall, there's no need for fitting the window, or the latch. D Contact Improvisation has always been sheltered under the aegis, the protection, of the founders' predilection for not creating certifications, degrees, professional associations and strict definitions of the form. From a broad variety of sources, imagery is created, related disciplines explored, points of view expressed, but absolutes are ultimately dismissed. How easy it would be to concretize into a set of exercises and rules this protean dance form which at its best is fluid. It is accepted but only whispered how Contact is a metaphor for our lives and that it has therapeutic value. Less talked about, and rightly so, are the spiritual elements, what we contact, or more likely what contacts us during those dances that are out of our constraint, where a third body is created. Contact Improvisation, like Rumi's poetry, is limenal, neither in balance nor over the edge. His poems express the dances that are not predetermined, those rare moments when the dancers disappear and there is only the dance. * Let the lover be disgraceful, crazy, absentminded. Someone sober will worry about events going badly. Let the lover be. Out beyond ideas of wrongdoing and rightdoing, there is a field. I'll meet you there. When the soul lies down in that grass, the world is too full to talk about. Ideas, language, even the phrase each other doesn't make any sense. [Special thanks to Coleman Barks for permission to use these translations. This is a partial bibliography of Rumi's poetry: Open Secret and Unseen Rain, John Mayne and Coleman Barks, Threshold Books; We Are Three, Coleman Barks, Maypop Books; Night and Sleep, Robert Bly and Coleman Barks, Yellow Moon Press. M.K.]

Title: STILL MOVING DANCE WITH DIFFERENT NEEDS a report by
Abstract: This article reports on a two-day workshop called "Dance With Different Needs," which brought together disabled and non-disabled individuals to explore contact improvisation. The workshop aimed to create an accessible space where people of all physical abilities could meet on equal ground and experience movement possibilities. Facilitated by a team of experienced instructors, the workshop incorporated various exercises and improvisational techniques to foster sensitivity, communication, and trust among participants.
Text: Alito Alessi, Alan Ptashek and Karen Nelson THE WORKSHOP DANCE WITH DIFFERENT NEEDS was a two day, JO hour workshop which brought together disabled and non-disabled people to learn and practice contact improvisation. The focus of the workshop was to explore contact as an accessible form for people of all physical abilities to meet on equal ground and experience the movement possibilities that exist between them. The workshop, which was attended by 60 people, was facilitated by Alita Alessi & Karen Nelson (Joint Forces), with special invited guests Kevin Finnan and Louise Richards of England, and Alan Ptashek and Bruce Curtis of the San Francisco Bay Area. Earlier in the year, Karen and Alita worked with Mobility International U.S.A. to develop an intercultural dance workshop with disabled and nondisabled people from Germany and Michael Goldhammer (left) said, "It has to be fun to interest me." Oregon. Alan, an able-bodied mover, and Bruce, a quadriplegic mover, are both from Berkeley and have been practicing contact improvisation together for the past two years. Kevin and Louise, from England, have been working with different populations including dancers, students, old, young, able-bodied and physically alter-a bled, and have found contact improvisation to be an accessible and engaging form to teach. The workshops (which were free) were wheelchair accessible, and sign interpreted. [Alito] As no two people are identical in their expression of Contact Improvisation, styles and approaches toward teaching Contact are equally diverse. Collaborative teaching is a challenging situation where the exchange of facilitation, structure and spontaneity is formed by the communication between the teachers. The six facilitators of the "Dance With Different Needs" workshop had all been previously working in their separate home areas with people of varying physical disabilities. With the exception of Bruce Curtis's relatively new practice of Contact Improvisation, we collectively had many years of experience in teaching Contact to a wide range of students. As this workshop was our first teaching collaboration with one another, we had questions, but more so, an excited curiosity about each other's ideas and approaches toward shaping the teaching material. Day One We began the first of the two day workshop with an extended period of personal entry and exploration of the very large gymnasium. Spatial and peripheral alertness was gradually developed. We encouraged individuals to improvise their personal warmup. Attention to breath and the forces of gravity upon the body were emphasized. There were a few people with previous experience in Contact Improvisation, disabled people in both manuallyoperated and motorized wheelchairs, a 146 CQ/CT Sourcebook Naomi and David find ways of support in the chair. blind woman, a deaf woman, and others with lesser physical limitations or injuryrelated conditions. Many others in the workshop of approximately sixty people were able-bodied and interested in Contact as well as in learning within this particular situation. There was a high level of enthusiasm and willingness to develop playfulness and physical contact. The speed was faster than we had anticipated. We began to slow the overall pace and look toward a deepening of the process through which we move into contact with greater sensitivity and awareness. Those of us who could fall and enter the floor did so, while others stayed in their chairs, relaxing into the "small dance" that can be felt in a sitting position. The forms of contact between able and disabled movers slowly revealed the ways in which a person in a wheelchair often must teach and become the initiator when their partner is feeling awkward and tentative. It seemed to be equally important to allow that partner time to get in touch with their awkwardness. As we moved with one another in an increasingly more mindful and physically alert manner, our specific strengths became more apparent. When Michael Goldhammer explained to me that his head and neck muscles were the most powerfully developed extension of his body, we both found much pleasure in feeling the exchange of one another's strength and support. "O :r 0 :::c " c. ~ (cont'd) 11-year old Jessica and Karen Nelson rolled and rolled and rolled together. (from floor up) Michael, Jessica, David, Roger, with Steve Christiansen videotaping. Gwenneth van Frank and Michael Goldhammer head dance. Roger Kerns about to join the log roll. Louise Richards guides us through "log rolling" across a sea of partners. all photos by Heidi Timm except where noted Later in the morning, we had people combine in small groups where each person was gently rocked and rolled along the floor. Particular focus was placed on the head-neck joint, inviting restful and fluid movement to be passed through the body. Counter-balancing with a partner was also explored in various positions, each person using whatever degree of movement and flexibility they had in their arms. A person in a wheelchair could lean their weight off the side of the chair so that they wouldn't be pulled too far forward or out from their chair by their partner's leverage. In the afternoon, Kevin and Louise introduced a different form of a gauntlet (two parallel lines of people facing each other) where one person slowly walked, wheelchaired, or crawled through the gauntlet from one end to the other while everyone in the lines gently blew upon their clothing and skin. Sensuality was a powerful and common feeling for us all. We held a round-robin toward the end of the day. There was little reluctance to enter the circle. We ended the day with a circle for feedback and discussion. Day Two Sunday included quite a few new people. We began the morning in a quiet and more reflective mode. Karen led an extended warm-up that brought us into light qualities of contact with one another, maintaining a feeling of warmup without further ambitions. Later, we covered one half of the space with mats and introduced "log-rolling." Everyone lies on their stomach, lined up next to each other with heads pointing in the same direction, arms extended overhead. The contact between the sides of bodies is tight but flexible. One by one, a person places him/herself in a perpendicular direction across the bodies. Before beginning to log-roll, the joined bodies gently nudge and articulate some small movements upward to the person they're supporting to give them a feeling of buoyancy. Then, the person atop is carried along by the rolling bodies until he or she reaches the other end. For those people who left their wheelchairs, this exercise was an exhilarating way to experience the supportive combination of body, ground, breath and momentum, essential ingredients of Contact Improvisation. Staying on mats, we moved into partner work, what we call "low table" positions. Here, one person is on hands and knees, while the other partner 148 CQ/CI Saurcebook drapes him/herself horizontally over the back of their partner. Gradually, either partner can initiate some movement, changing shape and position in whatever way they are able. Relaxed but alert, the bodies can feel the force of gravity through muscles and bones. Higher support positions were also introduced, allowing skills for falling and rolling to be expanded upon. The level of trust, communication and safety was becoming very apparent as we entered another round-robin. The dancing was accompanied by some friends who played acoustic and synthesized music along with vocal improvisations. The workshop closed with a deep appreciation for what we all created. The desire for this work to continue was echoed throughout the group. [Alan] IMPRESSIONS Through the workshop, I learned about a deeper level of being supported, and opening my body to trust the support more, in more directions. This came after working with Jessica, a girl whose arms and legs have sensation but cannot bear weight without additional bracing or support. Her spinal and torso movement is fluid like a fish and we had a great time cruising the space by rolling. We discovered a way she could wriggle her weight onto me while working close to the floor. Once I felt the center of her weight directly on top of me, I could play with rocking her and shifting the position of my support under her, raising the level of the support to hands and knees. For her it was slightly delightfully terrifying-"Don't! Don't! DO! DO! STOP! STOP! GO! GO!!" So I stayed within her limits of how much permission to take. Her fear was of falling on her head without any protection from her arms while hanging forward across the bench my body made for her. Then we played with shifting her weight towards her feet, just enough so she could feel the floor through her flat feet, with most of her weight still into me. From here I crawled and she had the sensation of walking, feeling the floor pass under her feet while she took steps. There was something in her courage to trust my support and to follow her interests that affected my dancing. Later, during a round robin, I had a dance with an able-bodied man I'd never danced with before, David, where I gave my center in situations that are usually slightly delightfully terrifying for me-up high on a shoulder, hanging upside down, the support moving with momentum, no hands-and I felt deeply relaxed. I just realized in rewriting this story that I was in the same situation with David that Jessica had been in with me. We truly do instruct each other through the dancing. [Karen] " In reflecting back on what I now prefer to call the "Dance with Different Abilities" workshop rather than "Dance with Different Needs," I experience an immense gratitude for the opportunity to not know, to not assume mobility habitually and to appreciate more deeply contact in still frames. Leading a class with physical assumptions or habitual statements like "Stand up," "See the whole space," or giving any verbal instructions for that matter, could at times isolate. A good sense of humor was quickly cultivated. Verbal interpreting for the blind, sign interpreting for the deaf, and a multitude of modifications allowed for a moment by moment experience. Along with everybody else, I seemed to learn a lot about replacing the use of one sensory perceptor with another. Seeing with your skin could not become cliche. My perceptions began to expand through the transmission of experience in this atmosphere of diverse abilities. Considering the weight of a partner with a nearly total absence of muscular resistance gave me a profound experience of the "small dance" and enlightened me about the sense of an abandoned body moving through space where my willingness and ability to support was essential to the pleasure and safety of the dance. I also did a solo dance with a wheelchair, lifting it, rolling it over my back, balancing it on my shoulders. This allowed me to experience not only the spirit of the chair but how it was an extension of its owner's body. The anatomy of a wheelchair, with or without a partner in it, was a great education in mechanics, motion and caring. The idea that contact improvisation is an accessible movement form continues to expand in all directions regardless of one's physical abilities. A sense of common ground pervaded the space. [Alito]

Title: CONTACT WITH SPECIAL NEEDS
Abstract: This article discusses the authors' experience teaching contact improvisation to individuals with severe physical and/or mental disabilities. They challenge the assumption that dance requires movement, highlighting the inherent movement in the body, such as breathing and the pull of gravity, even in those who are prostrate. The authors emphasize the potential for dance and connection regardless of physical limitations.

Title: CONTACT WITH SPECIAL NEEDS
Abstract: Louise Richards and Kevin Finnan discuss their experiences teaching contact improvisation to people with severe physical and/or mental disabilities. They describe their work with New Midlands Dance, focusing on youth and special needs groups, and share anecdotes from residencies at schools and adult residential centers. They emphasize the importance of allowing movement, no matter how small, and creating a shared responsibility in the dance.
Text: Whenever we tell people that we teach contact improvisation to people with severe physical and/ or mental disabilities they look at us like we're bonkers. A dance with somebody who is paralyzed would appear to be a contradiction. How can you dance if you can't "move"? The study of contact teaches that there is always movement in the body, the continual falling with gravity, and for somebody prostrate there is always the movement of the breath. Where there is movement, no matter how small, there is the possibility of a dance. It sounds easy to say, and obvious, but it took a while for us to prove it to ourselves. We are Kevin Finnan and Louise Richards and we are members of New Midlands Dance, a British community dance company with a commitment to new dance. In early 1985 Lesley Hutchison became Artistic Director of the Midlands Dance Company which was until then a traditional contemporary rep touring company receiving an annual revenue grant from the Arts Council. Lesley transformed the company into a community dance resource for the region. In order to reach the widest possible range of people within the region, there would have to be a change in the company's way of working. New forms, New methods, New audiences, New dance! In the summer of 1985 we joined Lesley in forming the New Midlands Dance Company. We decided to focus on youth and special needs groups, sectors of the community with little or no access to the arts. Our work involves both performances and workshops in a residency format. We have just completed a year long project with special needs groups and are about to embark on a similar project with prison/custody populations, men, women and children. Whoever we work with: dancers, students, old, young, able-bodied or paralyzed, we have found contact improvisation to be an accessible and engaging form to teach. Our first real experience with a physically handicapped group was during a week long residency at a school for children with disabilities in Nottinghamshire. We had expected to be working initially with mentally handicapped groups but to our horror our first residency of a year of touring was to be in this school. Residencies are usually one week long and we work with a core group plus staff; teaching intensively Volume 13 1988 CQ/CI Sourcebook 149 and performing once or twice during the week. We had done a lot of preparatory work, particularly with mentally handicapped groups but none of this really prepared us for the first session with fifteen wheelchair-bound children. The group was nervous because they didn't know what to expect. We were nervous for exactly the same reason. We started very timidly, introductions and other warm-ups in a game format to break the ice, introducing the notion of touch early on. The group was resistant. They were handicapped so what could dance possibly be for them? On top of that they had all the usual teenage hang-ups about looking stupid, touching each other and associating dance with pop records or ballet. Most of them had upper body movement, few of them could move legs or feet. We worked a lot with contact through fingertips and heads. In pairs they started to use their weight through counterbalance and easy pushing and pulling. At first there was a real feeling of them doing it to humour us, but gradually over the week the pairs moved into duets. They worked on shared "journey" dances. For example, two people in one chair supported through each other's laps or backs, using their weight to initiate movement in each other. Strong bonds developed within the group, with each other and with us. The school is in a beautiful wooded environment so there were countless invitations to accompany them on walks on the special wheelchair trails. It was hard not to form real attachments with two girls in the group who took me (Louise) for regular lunchtime strolls. Going up steep hills they (in their chairs) left me (on my legs) standing. I (Kevin) was invited to play soccer in the playground with pupils and staff. I was amazed at the speed and vigour of the game, wheelchairs and crutches flying past me. Receiving a great pass from a young lad in a wheelchair on the wing and filled with sudden enthusiasm I turned and volleyed the ball goalwards, only to see it ping off the head of a passing lad on crutchessending him flying. I was mortified, what had I done? I could see the headlines: "Dancer assaults crippled child." I began apologizing to everybody. To my surprise this promoted gales of laughter at my expense. I was learning another seminal lesson: Just because people are less able in some way it does not mean that they need to be wrapped in cotton wool and touched at arms length. The children were physically adventurous and were 150 CQ/CI Sourcebook prepared for physical risk. Over the week, through the dance sessions we became more confident and they became more adventurous, taking full weight, spinning their wheelchairs and supporting themselves through new body surfaces. We were successful in challenging their notions about what dance was and showed them they could create their own. During the project we have worked with a range of disabilities. With the chronically disabled we start from relaxation, rocking, listening to and working with the breath rather than imposing movement, allowing ourselves to be with another body, picking up breathing rhythms and amplifying them into shared movement. We don't do to people. Even the most handicapped person can move someone else-we lay our heads in the bowls of their abdomens and let their breath move us. A shared responsibility. We had a dance with a boy called David who has head movement but no other body movement. He was propped on a cushion, we put our heads together. We explained to him about listening to the moving point. Slowly it began to roll around our heads. Sometimes it would slide, we'd explain to him that we needed it to roll so that we were moving and being moved by each other. This developed into a twenty minute dance of amazing intensity. David had a huge grin which never left his face. We don't just work with children. Similar work at an adult residential centre developed much further due to our increased experience and confidence at that time. We began with everybody out of their chairs. Finger dances which rolled down arms and into torsos happened early in the residency. We taught about weight and momentum and they learned that their seemingly immobile weight could affect change in someone else. A man called Ian resented being moved and responded with "I'm not helpless, you know." We told him he should move us too and he could do this by letting his weight fall back, thus pulling us up. We really gave our weight in these counterbalances. By further using counterbalance and shared balances back to back or side to side, people could support themselves on unfamiliar levels. By using the natural ledges on our bodies, backs, hips and thighs, we would feed their weight through our bodies in the passage from up to down. We used a lot of "body surfing" and "log rolling" and developed ways of using table work both as supporter and supported. For example, people with upper body movement were able to use their arms as levers to get on and balance on our backs, and were often able to sit on their folded legs and use their arms as main supports to take our weight through their backs. With careful regard to the weight, this developed into a dance, transferring support between us, swapping roles and using flow and momentum to move. Early rocking developed into tumbling, throws and catches where people could experience spatial disorientation. It is impossible to explain people's joy in this work. For more nervous people we made physical structures to give movement experiences. For example, interlocked human "tables" became a mobile support structure. One woman lay on the backs looking at the ceiling and said "I've never been upside-down before." It is not always possible for people to communicate verbally as to whether or not we are achieving anything, particularly when mentally handicapped. However we believe the dance communicates on a very deep level. In one session a man got quite violent. He was working with one of our helpers and started to lash out with his fists. Intuitively I (Louise) grabbed his wrists but rather than blocking and restraining him I began to move with him. Gradually his energy changed from confrontation to flow. Sandra was a group member who gave no sign of recognition from one session to another. She didn't seem to understand any of the work we were doing. One of our warm-up exercises involves passing a touch point from finger to finger around the circle. On the very last day I (Kevin) made a point of saying goodbye to her. As we were leaving she came up, did a wonderful "finger dance" and touched her finger to the end of mine. I was speechless, shocked and deeply moved. There are many of these stories and we've chosen these few to try to convey at least a feeling of the work. What seems to be a daunting task is incredibly rewarding. We are not therapists but dancers who teach dance to people whatever their abilities because we believe that dance is for all. We haven't space here to discuss our performance work in this context, although it too is an integral part of the work. Maybe that will be another article. Certainly we plan to write another installment on our experiences teaching contact in custodial settings. tr

Title: BEGINNERS DANCE
Abstract: Marie Mannschatz recounts her first contact improvisation class after a seven-year break, led by Nancy Stark Smith in Spain. She describes a dance with a partner, focusing on head contact and shared movement, and reflects on the emotions and questions that arose from the experience. The dance heals something within her, replacing it with openness, curiosity, and a need for creative expression.
Text: It is my first contact class after a seven year break and the first dance at all after months of painful resistance against any engagement in the moving arts. A friend has convinced me to participate in this Contact Improvisation workshop taught by Nancy Stark Smith in Spain, north of Barcelona. Very slowly I settle back into the body, keeping my vital forces way down inside. The air around me stays empty and my heart aches in consequence of neglecting its basic needs. The teacher tells us to kneel down and connect with the crowns of our heads. A tall young dancer with sea-blue eyes slips towards me and offers his head. Our bodies hardly move while we sit quietly tuning to each other. Through my skull I feel the pulsation of his spinal liquid, the rhythm of his blood, feel my hesitant expansion towards him and decide carefully to open up a little bit more. "Let's roll across the floor, keeping in contact with the top of our heads." Gliding across the wooden surface we look for a synchronized movement. His nose reaches already up into the air, mine still sticks to the ground. "Now roll back to the other side of the hall. Allow yourself to go slow; when you feel stabilized in your connection you may want to develop a more open dance with each other, from time to time coming back to the head connection." We exchange no opinions about our way of working together. His attitude is serious and alert. We both focus on our task, intending to align our abilities. Like siamese twins we are rolling now, grown together at the crowns of our heads. My brother starts to guide me through the space, passing arms, feet, legs and torsos of other dancers. He calls me internally and waits for my answers. His touch is delicate and firm at the same time. I try to catch an expression of emotion in his face. His gaze is relaxed and empty, while he is diving deeper and deeper into the realms of my intuitive self. Reaching a rare level of trust I allow him to hold me, carry me and let go of me. For a tiny second I am as happy as a toddler. But as my mind is realizing the long lost feeling, it vanishes under the weight of memory. My partner keeps moving. Inhaling the fresh smell of his sweat I curl into his lap and want to stay there, losing my sense of self, ready to slip back into the liquid warmth and timeless security of a womb. He keeps moving. He is obviously an experienced dancer, unlimited in his gentle presence, clear in his direction, while my perception is flooded by images, feelings, rhythms and vibrations. Like a little boat I am rocking across his body waves, feeling his bones and soft Volume 13 1988 stILL G NfOVI CQICI Sourcebook 153 tissues communicating with mine. By now my lungs empty completely. Each exhalation goes further and is sometimes accompanied by an unconscious sound of agreement. Our breathing patterns overlap, we lose culture and age, but I stay always aware of being a woman. For the glimpse of a moment a silvery net is woven around us by dashes of sunlight, spread all over our bodies. The next minute we are blades of grass in the summer wind, intermingling with the group energy. The two of us are not alone in this space-we touch others flying through their territory, grateful: ly catching the arm that supports us the moment we lose our balance. A little laughter jumps out of my throat. Hey, babe, life can be fun! No reaction on his side. He always keeps moving. Finally we discover our spiral spheres and now I am expanding completely. Yes! Fun! Love! Spirals up and down and up again in different speeds and colours. Spirals towards a subtle completion. Our bodies agree to finish the dance. Gently we unwind the energy threads which carried the codes of body language. A few more touches and swirls and thanks to the floor. Then: Gravity and empty space. As soon as the dance is over, the communication system is fallen apart. Here I am with onehundredtwentyseven questions I never dare to ask: Is a dance like this daily life for him? Was the level of contact my own projection? Did he enjoy the fluidity of our movements as well? Which images arose for him? What did he learn? The class continues, other dancers come, but this first dance stays with me. My questions unfold into an investigation of relationship-patterns. Something has been healed inside of me, has been replaced by soft openness, curiosity and a need for creative expression. In the dew of the next morning I sit down to continue the dance with my type>,yriter. Across the printed letters my eyes are wandering towards the milky bluish mountains in the distance. Birds busy with being surround me and the heavy sneeze of a Spanish farmer echoes through the valley and is answered by angry barking dogs. *

Title: DEEPENING
Abstract: Tom Trenda describes "Deepening," a structured movement form combining elements of the Trager Approach, Authentic Movement, Re-Evaluation (CO-)Counseling, and Contact Improvisation. The form centers on one person giving undivided attention to another as they move, using touch to gain deeper kinesthetic and tactile information. Trenda explains the preparation, basic structure, and application of Deepening in a Contact Improvisation context, highlighting its benefits in fostering personal validation, movement exploration, and a new relationship to form.
Text: Deepening combines elements of work that I've been doing in The Tragertm Approach, Authentic Movement, Re-Evaluation (CO-)Counseling, and Contact Improvisation. This work was first presented in a class that I taught with Danny Mack and Susan Brokaw at the 1987 Breitenbush Jam. I listened to literally hours of personal testimony and feedback by highly experienced contactors after this class, which indicated to me that I was "on to something." This work is not about the advancing of Contact Improvisation skills exclusively, although from the feedback I've received, it seems to be very effective in that way. It can be applied in various movement contexts, from dance improvisation to dance therapy. It is a very specific structured form which demands a high amount of commitment, attention, and focus. What is Deepening? Listening to another while they move is at the heart of this experience. Like Authentic Movement, this form is about one person putting their undivided attention on another, without judgement, comment, or intentionally shaping their process. Simply being there with that person with total commitment to whatever they do, as "witness" to their process. Unlike Authentic Movement however, the "witness" uses not only their eyes to "pay attention to," but also their hands and (later) their bodies. Why touch? Because touch gives a kind of information that cannot be obtained through just observing. I am not only looking for the information that I can get simply from how I see your movement. This experience is deeply physical. This kind of connection, this kind of "being with," is not only through a visual mode, but includes the kinesthetic/tactile as well. It is the experience of seeing, touching, sensing, and moving with, on all levels of someone's body, from periphery to core. Feeling experiences which often arise out of this kind of deep, intimate sharing are those of profound personal validation and support. Preparation I first have people pair up and I teach basic Trager hands-on skills. With one person laying on their back, the other places their hands somewhere on their partner's body and "settles in." The focus is on deepening the level of contact with one's hands through the surface structures of their partner's body such as skin and body shape to the deeper structures such as skeleton and organ. Once this kind of contact is sensed, the active partner begins to lightly rock the body of their partner, sensing for the movement of the skeleton and the pathways this movement is traveling on. This works beautifully to drop people into their body's core, and to engage them in focusing deeply into another person's physical structure. Through the work of Milton Trager, I have learned that by developing sensitivity in the hands along with the focusing capacities of the mind, the surface of the body can be penetrated allowing core structures to be contacted and moved. This kind of "penetration" or depth of touch is necessary in the Deepening experience. The intent, once this is obtained, however, is not to "do" anyt~ing with those deeper structures, but simply to contact them, to listen and to follow what is happening in there while that person is moving. The basic Deepening structure The basic structure begins with one person in the pair moving on their own and the other person observing. Throughout this whole experience the person moving is focused on referencing everything to their own center, edge, flow, timing, weight, momentum, intention, etc. In other words, they are soloing. The person watching is following with their eyes, the whole or any part of this person's body moving-wherever their attention is drawn. Next, the person observing moves into the other's kinesphere and begins to follow the movement of any part, [touching it] with their hands. Here it is helpful for the person moving to work at a slow pace. This facilitates contact from hand to body. It is also important to note here that the person "soloing" is not initiating or "leading" the other, but simply moving while someone moves with them. They are paying attention to their own movement process. Their partner is also paying attention to the movement process of the person soloing, with their eyes and hands and whole being. This is an experience of "one-way attention." In other words, both partners are paying attention to one person's dance. It sometimes requires an active intention on the part of Volume 13 1988 the person following to not initiate, limit, or direct their partner's movement, especially if they have had a lot of Contact Improvisation experience. Noticing the subtle ways in which we do this in Contact Improvisation is one of the benefits of practicing the Deepening form. This means that when a movement is going outside of one's reach space, the follower must simply let it go. To pull the motion back towards oneself by changing the pressure would inhibit the full movement of one's partner. It is helpful for the kind of deep contact I spoke of earlier that the person Applying Deepening in a Contact lmprov context If I am working with a group of Contact Improvisors, I will have people focus on bringing the experience from the edge (hands) to the center (torso), and throughout the whole body. The person "paying attention to" their partner (while that person continues to "solo") begins to use the rest of their body to follow, track, and read their partner's movement in just the way that they were using their hands earlier. Here I make it clear that it is not about "going after contact," but is about allow0 0 _c 0. Tom Trenda & Bev Rackoff following does not ,jump around with their hands, but rather rests on one body part, "reading" as much information as is possible about the whole organism from that one moving part. There is everything to be learned about a whole from any of its parts. Of course, it is a lie to say that the person moving is "soloing." As soon as one is aware of being watched there is interaction. And when one is being listened to through touch, there is certainly a presence there to be reckoned with. But just as one can do a "solo" dance piece with many people watching, one can also solo while being touched if the person touching has a presence of respectful attention. ing any body part that is convenient to come into this role, as the movement flows through one's kinesphere. This prevents people from throwing their centers into contact. It is O.K. to be in the way of your partner's motion-you are a part of the environment in your partner's dance. Issues of weight support invariably come up at this point. Torsos weigh more than hands. If I am following a Volume 13 1988 movement with my hand I can be above or below it, without much change in weight. But if I follow someone's movement with my torso to a place where I am on top of them, they are supporting my weight, but I am supporting their movement. Similarly, if their movement takes them to a place on top of me, I focus on supporting the movement, not the weight. The focus is not on giving and taking body weight. This is often what makes Contact Improvisation so static: you give me your weight, I'll give you my weight, and [thus] the dance of all the signals and responses associated with this. Weight sharing is one byproduct, just something that happens to happen, in the process of reading someone's movement with certain parts of your body in the Deepening form. At this point, I might suggest the soloist begin playing with moving faster, changing levels, and jumping. Or the partners can allow the roles to dissolve, keep moving, and take from this structure anything they feel [like] integrating. I also structure sessions for specifically working on connecting in this Deepening way in running, falling, and jumping. This seems to be very challenging-to come into contact with a quickly moving body without shaping the course of that jump, run, or fall. The outcome Some of the benefits of doing Deepening are rooted in the fact that it is about taking turns. How often do we get to receive such undivided attention to such a major part of ourselves? To be supported in whatever we are doing? Receiving this kind of attention from someone enables one to go deeper into their own body/movement process. This form creates a high degree of safety for people to explore their own movement. As the person moving, you get very committed to your own movement without a lot of ego investment. This comes from someone else's commitment to your movement without ego. As the person following, focusing one someone else enables you to let go of any of your own stuff about your own movement. It takes the focus off yourself and how well you are dancing. Through practicing this work a new relationship to "form" can be discovered. It could be said that "form follows following." Awareness of form grows organically from the inside. Pathways begin to emerge through the skin and extend out of (and back into) the body. It comes unself-consciously from the mutual commitment to following each other's internal movement pathways. *

Title: EXPOSED TO GRAVITY
Abstract: This article introduces The Exposed to Gravity Project, a collaborative organization specializing in movement arts and education for physically disabled people. It includes an essay by Bruce Curtis, one of the initiators of the project, about his personal experiences and perspectives on dance.
