Title: EXPOSED TO GRAVITY II.
Abstract: Alan Ptashek discusses his collaboration with Bruce Curtis, a physically disabled man interested in Contact Improvisation. He reflects on the pre-conditioned responses able-bodied people have towards disabled individuals and how their practice challenged and expanded ideas about movement limits for those with spinal cord injuries.
Text: by Alan Ptashek In the SUllllller of 1986, Bruce Curtis called me and introduced himself as a physically disabled man who had become very interested in Contact Improvisation. He described his previous experiences with this movement form as well as his travels within and outside of the United States. Without having met him, I was already seeing Bruce in terms of the mobility and curiosity that had led him to explore Contact Improvisation, a dance form that I have been practicing, developing and teaching since 1974. I was also thinking of how I might interact with a person who has spent more than half of his life in a wheelchair. I knew that within myself and most able-bodied people, there exists a wide array of pre-conditioned responses and behavior that has limited and confused our interactions with disabled people. At the extremes of one's discomfort/ awkwardness with disabled people (and vice-versa), we may unconsciously be physically distancing ourselves, avoiding direct or sustained eye contact, or behaving in an overly protective manner. As I viewed tapes of Bruce's earlier dances, I felt excited by the possibilities for developing a physical vocabulary between us, one that could challenge and expand previously held ideas about the limits of movement for those with spinal cord injuries. Bruce and I acknowledged that there was much more ground to explore, and we began a regular practice of Contact Improvisation, a collaboration that held equal amounts of enthusiasm, caution and wonderment for both of us. Learning where and how one's Contact partner senses and carries their center of gravity is essential to the development of trust and physical rapport. Bruce's wheelchair was an immediate part of that learning for me. The man and his wheelchair are definitely not inseparable, and a constant awareness needs to be maintained for intuitive-ly and· reflexively determining the boundaries and shifts of balance between Bruce's body and the structure of his chair. In another sense, I often feel Bruce's chair as an extension of his total physicality, sensing the combined weight of body and chair as one moving mass. By placing my arm, hand or larger surface area of my body, such as my back or hips, in contact with any surface of Bruce's body, I gain immediate access to sensation, motion, breath and balance in Bruce's body as he moves in his chair. If my hand places a gradually increased amount of weight around the side of, or at the back of Bruce's head, I can use his responding movement and weight exchange as it enters my hand (which is spread and channeled throughout my entire body). I feel and image his entire spine moving downward through the chair's seat cushion, feeling his spine rooting into the floor. There is a corresponding upward movement through his spine and head into my hand, as contact and awareness of these multi-directional forces of gravity and momentum are established. As both of us maintain this bodily-felt relationship to weight exchange and shared movement and stay open to sudden impulses and influences upon either of our bodies, a playful, energetic and innovative dance is created. An essential quality of improvisation is an appreciation for what is taking place within the present moment of one's awareness. Following our instincts and trusting our inherent bodily wisdom will guide us toward our next perception, feeling and action. As our practice has continued during the past year, Bruce and I have become much less protective of one another, more open about our confusion, discomfort or expectations. We move together, with Bruce in and out of his chair, both on the ground and at higher levels from the floor, where Bruce can be supported around my hips or shoulders. Sudden lifts of Bruce's body from either his chair or the ground create momentum for spins and swift descents back to the ground. We've practiced basic skills for relaxing the body as we spill into the floor from higher support positions. As with many Contact Improvisation duets, the high velocity of movement and risk between Bruce and myself rriay suddenly be experienced as a heightened state of alertness and precision, our awareness of time and space relaxed and expanded, moving safely through our movement possibilities. Bruce's wheelchair is surprisingly light and responsive to subtle degrees of weight and momentum, although it is Bruce's receptivity to those subtleties that determines how my body and movement can shape itself with his chair. I have leaned and thrown my weight on Bruce and his chair from many angles and impulses. We have occ"asionally fallen onto one another's body and the floor, with the chair somehow cooperating for our safety and continued contact with each other. Neither of us have ever been injured in our dancing. Our warm-ups include taking weight across one another's back and hips, counter-balancing through the extension and grip of each other's arms and hands, slowly stretching and releasing tension from muscle and joints. We focus deeply on internal awareness of breathing and finely-tuned balance. Where certain areas of Bruce's spinal and muscular functioning is limited, I have developed an intuitive capacity to locate those parts of his limbs and torso where he can initiate movement, and direct the needed amount of pressure to sustain our surface of contact without slipping or losing our communication. Whether this limited physical functioning is within his fingers or around his pelvis, there is always enough time and attention for us to kinesthetically scan through our bodies for other areas of strength, support and balance. It is this "scanning" that creates the movement vocabulary which is shared between Bruce and myself. Our work together has been observed and commented on by movement and somatic educators, dance and physical therapists, performing artists and other people with physical disabilities, both less and more severe than Bruce's. We have performed before a variety of audiences within the San Francisco Bay Area, most recently through The John F. Kennedy Center's Special Arts International Program, at Grace Cathedral Church and at The New Performance Gallery. University and cable TV stations have produced and aired tapes of our work. Exposed to Gravity: Two Men Dancing, a video edit of our work, has been screened at various educational video festivals in the U.S., Mexico, Brazil, Nicaragua and China. Our practice sessions and video tapes have been viewed by individuals and groups who are interested in movement and body awareness for those with spinal cord injuries. Bruce and I do not look upon our dancing as a particular form of rehabilitative or therapeutic work, although those aspects and benefits are acknowledged and may be applicable in working with other disabled people and those who are inter

Title: Alan Ptashek and Bruce Curtis
Abstract: This article discusses the collaborative dance work of Alan Ptashek and Bruce Curtis, focusing on Contact Improvisation and the integration of physical differences between disabled and able-bodied dancers. They explore the kinesthetic and proprioceptive experiences, emphasizing the importance of attentive relationships and transcending physical limitations.
Text: an active and attentive relationship to all areas of Bruce's body throughout the time of our dancing. There are no "dead" or unfeeling parts of Bruce in my relationship to him as a moving human body who is as fully involved in the life of our dance as I am. Comparisons between our abilities are limiting and too predictable if based solely on physical skill and functioning. Our minds, hearts and creativity join us in deep and powerful ways, that integrate and often transcend the obvious physical differences in our bodies. In a Contact Improvisation dance, there are somatic activities taking place on many levels of consciousness and perception. The glandular and neuromuscular systems are being filled with sensation, becoming a direct source for the communication between still or moving partners. What is happening while we are rolling, falling and 162 CQ/CI Sourcebook guiding ourselves and partner via the feedback exchanged through skin, nervous system and internal organs? As our body spins and suddenly shifts from standing or sitting in a chair to balancing on arms or head, what accompanying changes are ignited through the body as cerebra-spinal fluid or adrenal gland activity pulses through the moving partners? To what extent does emotional excitement play upon the ability to feel movement and expand ourselves motionally? In my movement with Bruce, these questions and interests arise and provide direction for our future explorations. I'm reminded of a particular image described by Bruce after one of our practice sessions. He referred to parts of his pelvis and legs as having "black holes," whereby reaching through his senses he goes "fishing with the flashlight of my awareness" into those black holes, in a sense, providing the pathway for sensations to be felt. Movement can't be forced in any "O ::;,0 0 @ body. Desire and risk are called upon if there is to be a deepened and more fully conscious movement for any human being. As we continue our collaboration, Bruce and I are interested in moving with other disabled and able-bodied people, and in offering lecture-demonstrations and workshops. We want to work with other individuals, groups and organizations who support the development of movement arts/ education as a valuable and inspiring basis for play and communication for people of all levels of ability and disability. In these ways, Bruce and I hope to further explore and share with others a dance and dialogue that we have delighted in. 0

Title: Contact in an Alley
Abstract: Cheryl Pallant reflects on a Contact Improvisation performance in an alley in Richmond, Virginia. The article explores how the unique environment, filled with urban artifacts and outdoor elements, influenced the dancers' movements and the overall experience, contrasting it with the sterile environment of a museum.
Text: Yes, a group of us have been contacting regularly here in metropolitan RICHMOND, [VIRGINIA] and s!owly rousing the curiosity of others. "ls it a sport?" "Oh, it's choreographed." Anyway, recently DENNY SORENSON, ED CLAP, KEN MANHEIMER, SUZANNE NAY and I performed publicly and in my attempt to understand, at least translate my experience into words, I've written some reflections from the day: Contact in an Alley I had noticed the fluorescent flyers stapled to the walls of Fulton School. How could I miss them amid the otherwise drab chipped paint on the walls? I picked up an orange one from a table in one of the halls, studied the collage which incorporated the Richmond skyline atop a pile of rubbish, then read its only words, "Ram Cat Gallery," and wondered why I had never heard about this gallery before. Was this to be a new display space for art? Several weeks later, Suzanne Nay, one of the members of the group I'd been doing Contact lmprov with, asked me whether I'd be interested in participating in Ram Cat Gallery. To her I addressed a barrage of questions. Downtown Richmond is laced with a network of alleys. Usually you only know the one behind your apartment and the one behind your workplace. Although I'm familiar with many more (they're great for evening walks), I had never encountered the alley called Ram Cat. It's a typical cobblestone alley, out of the way, unknown but to a few, and like every alley, used regularly by sanitation engineers. This section of town like all of historic Richmond had its peculiar sites and stories. At one end of the alley stands a three story milk bottle, in 1913 the home of a dairy, and at the other end, the studio of Blab TV, a local cable show featuring philosophers er   um   publicly blabbing. Several artists, Suzanne one of them, had chosen Ram Cat as a site for visual artists, musicians and performing artists to showcase their wares. Did I want to partake in this event by doing Contact outdoors? I said yes and several days later, a few days before the show, investigated the space which I quickly found to be full of glass, parts of pipes, strips of wood and a hodgepodge of other items that would make dancing much more than a challenge. After envisioning myself rolling across the ground, rising with my face and limbs bloodied by what I had encountered en route, I considered renegging on my previous agreement. Art for art sake is fine but blood is blood. Despite promises of a cleanup, we who had agreed to perform continued to entertain the idea of merely playing spectators that day, a much safer role. Then the carpet was rolled in and once unfurled, five gleeful dancers pou need on it to begin to experience Contact in the wilds of a Richmond alley. Relatively new to Contact, I found alley dancing invigorating. How could I not respond to the fifty-year-old, keyless piano (used as accompaniment for another dance) found amid a pile of Coke bottles, men's Volume 13 1988 shoes, t-shirts, tires, used condoms and other artifacts of American culture? Beneath two trees growing out of brick walls, we tumbled, pushed, pulled, and leaped in response to each other but also in response to the sun, the fresh air and to the angles of the buildings unique to Ram Cat. Whether we were conscious of it or not at the time, our dance was influenced by the environment. We all later agreed how the quality of our moves differed from those performed in our usual wooden floor, high ceiling dance space. The cushion the carpet provided made our more pedestrian moves such as walking and crawling more springy and made falling less threatening. The slight incline of the ground sometimes contributed to the momentum and direction of a roll. Being outdoors, reminiscent of children on recess, allowed us to be more playful. Although we more or less stayed within the confines of the carpet, a space much smaller than what we were used to, the diminished size did not diminish the breadth of our expression. With the idea of performance in mind, we had earlier given ourselves a time limit, but while dancing it was obvious that we didn't want to stop. The rawness of the alley suits Contact. Contact is not sterile or refined, a manufactured product assuaging a public that wants art to be more or less predictable and beautiful, pleasant enough to be displayed like souvenirs from last summer's trip to Europe. Contact is more primitive, disregarding etiquette and incorporating a full range of human expression. Bodies intermingle intimately continually. Bodies graze and press against each other with the ease of a chat and the impassioned eloquence of discourse. The aim of Contact is not to create forms, to reach toward lofty ideals or vulgar ones, but to sustain a gestural communication with another. The product, then, is the result of dancers exchanging their weight and support with integrity, innocence and responsibility. The power of the form originates in its authenticity, in presenting the dance in its moment of becoming. This, it seems, is where the element of improvisation comes in. Improvisation stems from a source that is not solely intellectual but integral. Not only the mind but the body too generates the composition. The Cartesian problem of dualism disappears, neither mind nor body attributed with greater heirarchical importance. The composition is a fusion of the self as whole. Out of this concordance, spontaneous movements arise naturally and last as long as the dancers are able to sustain its many evolutions. More than any other dance form, Contact resembles life, at least my life with its constant flux and need to make decisions within a moment's notice. The improvisational movements are organic, not polished time after time in the studio, and are influenced constantly by whomever I come in contact with. The alley has contributed to the group's general knowledge of Contact. I know also that it affected some of the spectators. Several days after we had danced, a friend of mine mentioned how she had gone to a museum and left after ten minutes. Her reason: the controlled and lifeless environment contradicted the intention of art. She had been touched by the vitality of the alley. [Cheryl Pallant]

Title: WITH AWARENESS
Abstract: Darshana Ellis emphasizes the importance of self-awareness in Contact Improvisation, suggesting that a dancer's own conscious presence greatly enhances the quality of the dance. The article provides breathing techniques and exercises to cultivate this awareness, promoting a deeper connection with oneself and one's partner.
Text: WITH AWARENESS by Darshana Ellis I've played with dancing and teaching C.I. for about 8 years and something hits me continually-if your own awareness isn't with your self before you touch someone else, it won't feel half as nice and will appear "not to work." We all know the contrast of a dance that culminates in luxurious bliss versus one whose consequence is bruised body or soul. So now, how?: Bringing conscious presence into anything creates meditation (and some very nice dance material). Starting with the rudimentary (thin air), some breathing techniques that help remind us what we're doing: 1) On your own, lying on the back (or front), using the floor for resistant reference, explore the breath's travel into the lower belly, throughout the ribcage and high into the entire lung, chest cavity. This exercise is best verbally guided: anatomical reminders are great, e.g., open around the clavicle, deep into the armpit, ar.ound the sacrum, etc.) 2) In partners, one partner lying on their back, other lies over them perpendicularly, face down, belly to belly. Partner on top may have to take some weight on their elbows and knees for comfort's sake, to begin. Partner on bottom initiates a low, deep, slow belly breath, partner following. Try breathing in opposition, Jetting your partner push the breath out of you then Jetting gravity create space in the belly for the incoming breath. 3) Coming back to the breath. During any contact exercise or warm-up (anytime) if the dancer(s) get sidetracked, lost or sleepy-stop, to come back home, breathe first. 4) Running, one of the best reasons in the world to breathe. I will run 5 miles sometimes just to give my lungs an excuse to breathe. Running backward, downhill, relaxed and breathing softly, is meditation. Indoors, if your space allows, even short runs with the breath slow, deep and relaxed help the body become softer and more quiet in motion. Try sideward and backward relaxed runs, fast and slow, alone and with partners. Like the ultimate in love brings you back to yourself, the ultimate dance form takes you home to your body, heart and awareness. -tr DARSHANA ELLIS is a dancing foal and a teaching cantactar in San Diego, Calif

Title: A RESPONSE
Abstract: Susan Schell expresses excitement about the developments in Contact Improvisation between able-bodied and disabled dancers, noting its potential to address elitist tendencies within the form. She emphasizes the importance of commitment to the realities of exchange and attentiveness to oneself and others in creating challenging and growth-producing duets.
Text: A RESPONSE from Susan Schell I have recently become very excited by developments in Contact between ablebodied and disabled dancers. At A Cappella Motion workshop this past summer there was a v.ideo that Karen [Nelson] and Alito [Alessi] brought from the [Dance With Different Needs] workshop that took place in Oregon and then the report about it in the last issue as well as the articles by Bruce Curtis and Alan Ptashek. This new growth in the form seems to have the potential of shedding light on some of the questions that have surfaced through the years about elitist tendencies in Contact. I have never felt the limitations of the form to be carried by any one person in a dance; rather, it is determined by the willingness of those participating to commit to the realities of their exchange instead of what they wished it would or would not be. I think this kind of attending to oneself and each other can be exhausting or the assumption is that it would be, so an easier duet with ''somebody who can really dance" is often the option taken. As a result, some of the most potentially challenging and possibly growth producing duets are aborted or avoided altogether. Perhaps it has something to do with our perception of what it means to be challenged. Our skills can be even more limiting than another's lack of skill if we do not find ways to make our experience available to those we dance with. Otherwise, all our much sought after skills begin to isolate us and become the sign posts of exclusion rather than routes of access. This kind of attentiveness to one another and the dancing was palpable for me in both the video that I watched of the workshop and in the writings of Bruce, Alan, Karen and Alito in CQ. I will be very interested to see/ experience the effects of this work on all our dancing in the future. One parting question-what is a "bad dancer?" u SUSAN SCHELL has been teaching Contact Improvisation and performing since 1977. She has worked in Authentic Movement for the past six years and is currently co-directing a 9 month intensive program in the form.

Title: HIERVISIBILITY
Abstract: Steve Paxton discusses the concepts of egalitarianism and hierarchy in Contact Improvisation, responding to Cynthia Novack's columns. He argues that hierarchies are often perceived by those outside them and that criticizing those who organize classes or specialize in Contact Improvisation is to disparage grassroots community work.
Text: HIERVISIBILITY by Steve Paxton Let me see. I gather egalitarianism and hierarchy are opposed in the title of Cynthia Novack's columns in the last "Still Moving" section ["Egalitarianism and Hierarchy in Contact Improvisation,'' CQ Vol. XIII no. 3]. I fear a trip has been laid on us by some freeassociating dance critic who once described CI as more democratic than other dance forms. I sort of remember that line getting picked up by subsequent reporters-freecwheeling, dance for folk, etc., that kind of image arising uncensored, unexamined and perhaps unverified. In fact, until Novack questioned me recently, I don't recall any of the many dance writers asking about this point. Egalitarianism resulted in democracy, our 'form' of government. This was opposed to monarchy-Geo Washington was offered the monarchy for the states of America, I once learned. So that sort of hierarchy was avoided by democratic government. But a hierarchy, a tern~ porary one, is what we use to run the country. I believe I agree with Dumont's thesis. Agreeing on values creates constraints on individual directions. And humans are a communicating animal-we get jerked out of our path by far more subtle events than agreeing on values. Sometimes for good, sometimes for ill. A pause, a glance will do it. I have noticed that hierarchies are noticed by those outside them. This suggests that those who make them up are to some degree ignorant of that fact, or even that they are projected on a group, or faction, or gathering, or team, or committee by someone who perceives the association as hier-. Or rather, higher. Now no one in these stories is dead; Zimmer, Elias, Ryan, Harwqod or myself; it would be possible to ask some direct questions of all of us. For instance, who organized the situation Zimmer attended? I'll bet Ryan had a hand in it. Harwood and Ryan are both movers and shakers in the Canadian Contact Improv. scene and it seems to me no Contact scene could exist without deep bonds existing-I mean people must enjoy dancing together in order to have it survive for over a decade. Zimmer probably wasn't the only beginner who wanted to whet their skills on those two, and probably not the only one to emotionally defer to their skills. Elias says there was definitely a sense of in-group and out-group at the Current Exchange gathering [in Vancouver, B.C., summer 1979]. I can vouch that there was such a situation. The in-group photos: Natanja den Boeh consisted of any one who had a long association with the idea of CI and had toured and/or taught with the others. The out-group were in such a group for the first time. They were a bit at sea. They didn't know how to act and since there are no rules as such, no one told them. The nice things about rules, schedules, etc. is that they limit the number of choices one has to make. If one may act any old way, a bewildering situation may exist. Those who weren't bewildered were in. Those who were bewildered saw themselves as out. If Current Exchange was elitist, it was Volume 14 1989 only in the sense that the entire U.S. and Canada was not invited. In fact, living conditions restricted the size. Word was quietly put out to a few people who told a few other people. A letter of intent from participants was required to insure they had their own reason for using the facility (Western Front Lodge/ gallery I studio/ video) and that their reason resonated with the facility and harmonized in practical ways with the rest. Every one of us paid for the rent of Western Front and pitched in for food, cooking and cleaning up. I fear that the article, in using these two examples, will give elitism a bad name. Surely just being a small group or being buddies is not cause to bring out such a big gun. To be elite is to hold some plum and restrict its dispersal. To use this word to criticize those who go to the trouble of organizing classes or who attempt to specialize and concentrate is to disparage a kind of grass roots community work. Zimmer and Elias will be amused to learn that they have been placed in an elite, at the top of a hierarchy, recently. In Berlin at the 4th annual Contact Conference (they decided to drop the word 'improvisation', to my despair). A European delegate asked if all Europeans could do with Contact was repeat what the first generation had done. So it goes. Zimmer and Elias are, to Europe, first generation contactors. And this is an example of a hierarchy being perceived from without. Truth be told, CI is a dance form. It does have and, as far as I am concerned, teach certain values; mostly to do with physical safety. CI has always abounded in logical contradictions, foremost to do with improvisation. If improvisation springs out of each moment in each individual, then how to get people to improviseto discover their own initiative? And I point this out in classes-this cannot be taught, but it can be learned. I can help with the physical part. I can provide useful (to me, at least) images and meditations. I can point out glaring errors in partnering. I can't know how someone feels or protect them from their insecurity, fear, dislikes, associations, boredom, or their elation, warmth, sense of achievement, for that matter. Contact Improvisation deals with gravity, momentum, human bodies, etc. Humans form or perceive hierarchies. It is egalitarian. The folk who aren't in Contact Improvisation, either don't know about it or choose not to do it. To pick at words just a bit more, Contact Improvisation could not have "embraced values of individualism, equality, and anti-hierarchical relationships,'' because CI cannot do anything. It is something to be done. And in Dumont's remark some strange loose ends, which perhaps should be brought to the attention of the U.S. government and of course, its boss, the people: "If, in effect, the whole of humanity is deemed present in each man, then each man should be free and all men are equal. By contrast, as soon as a collective end is adopted by several men, their liberty is limited and their equality is brought into question." So apparently even a government formed on values such as freedom and equality will trample on freedom and equality. How embarassing. Yet even such an experiment in good intentions is of some interest, compared to the intentions of other governments, then and now. If liberty and equality are chosen, then at the moment of choice, they exist. What happens the next moment is something for all of us, anthropologists especially, to ponder. * STEVE PAXTON is an inveterate Contactor who is interested in improvisation.

Title: ''THEY CAME THEY SAW THEY DID A LITTLE SHOPPING"
Abstract: This article is a personal view of a contact improvisation conference in Berlin, focusing on the cultural and linguistic experiences.
Text: Berlin-A personal view by Kevin Finnan I digress, there had been fears that there might be a language problem, but luckily everyone spoke English and anyone who did not, did not speak. This compromise was working wonderfully until a frustrated German listener, unable to contain himself, spoke out somewhat testily at the first panel discussion. Luckily, he did so in German. Thus all the English speakers, completely unable to understand him, could continue on without noticing. "Vive la Difference," whatever that means! By now the conference was in full swing. The spartan life of eating, dancing, eating, dancing, eating talking, eating, eating was taking its toll. In the case of yours truly the old adage "free food makes Jack a fat boy" was not heeded-alas! Thus several unsuspecting partners were crushed to a fraction of their normal volume when dancing with moi, and several sackloads of health food. Allegations of a covert operation by German dance to elevate its European status by reducing the rest of us to bulging bean bags were hotly denied. At the second panel discussion, which was on the topic of performance, a furor broke out. Members of the panel were apparently attempting to perform during the discussion. Order was only restored when the panel was persuaded to return to the sedentary you-listen-we-talk format. It had taken a courageous lone voice to bring back sanity to the proceedings. It has long been known that performance is not a viable method of communication after all! I, mercifully, was spared the whole indignity as I had a pressing engagement with a dinner table in another part of town. A quote that rang clearly through my mind came on the last day. Someone, who shall remain nameless, (after all who am I to point the finger) but who definitely was not me, observed dryly that "the conference had been entitled 'Issues for the Nineties', but as far as anyone could see it was "Whatever happened to the Sixties."

Title: THE EUROPEAN CONTACT COMMUNITY
Abstract: This article discusses the European contact community's annual teachers conference in Berlin, highlighting the cultural exchange and discussions on the nature of contact improvisation.
Text: The European contact community came to Berlin for its annual teachers conference under the banner "Issues for the Nineties"-but more of that later. The merry folk of Europe had come together, oh joy! There was also in attendance an extremely large contingent of American gentlefolk, "our cup floweth over" was the thought on everyone's mind. Scurrilous accusations that certain visitors were treating the event as a trade fair were roundly dealt with-thank goodness! At the first gathering the eager and the faithful were presented with a handy information pack and a condom. The completely untrue rumour that this was in response to previous years' discussions was treated with disdain. Instead, the conference grasped its prophylactics and awaited "Deepening the Form." Days and days of dance and intercourse, the cut and thrust of a modern art movement, here, in the very crucible of 20th Century politics-Berlin. Rich, poor, east, west, Berlin-the divided city. This is extremely handy as any fellow tourist will tell you! What would be an insurmountable tourist problem, is divided into easily touristable sections. The East, ever mindful of its responsibilities has erected a handy wall and effiCient turnstiles, very similar to the Disneyland model. One always knows where one is. Everything appears to be produced by the same company and everything is so extremely cheap. So cheap in fact one has extreme difficulty cashing in all those cute little chips that allow you to go on any of the rides. Sadly however, the West does not show the same sort of responsibility. The American, British and French sectors are almost indistinguishable. No walls to keep out the non-paying. No efficient tour guides. I for instance, was completely unable to find the German sector. A sad fact of the times, I mused.

Title: BASIC CONTACT LIST--------------
Abstract: This article presents a random list of elements, concepts, exercises, skills, and attitudes that the authors believe should be included in a basic contact course.
Text: A random list of elements-concepts, exercises, skills and attitudes we thought should be included in a Basic Contact course. In no particular order, these include: Alignment Body-work, massage The Stand The spiritual or inner sense of the work Compassion Being rather than Doing Falling Play, playfulness Spatial Orientation Warm-down Neutral Condition Entering & leaving the Dance History of Contact Breathing Safety The Small Dance Back Stretch Counterbalances How to listen to the Body Ease of movement Positive feedback modes Uses of Imagery Contact Jargon Kinesiology, Anatomy Relaxation Following the Contact Point Connection Trust Posting Rolling Balance Stuffing Warm-up Arriving Ambiguous instructions * These notes were taken by Jerry Zientara at the After ArtSport Conference, Teaching Discussion, Minneapolis, MN, June 24, 1980. 0

Title: STILL MOVING (cont'd) HARBIN HOT SPRINGS NOTES-----
Abstract: This article discusses the author's experience at the Harbin Hot Springs California Contact Improvisation Jam, focusing on community building, nude dancing, and renewal ceremonies.
Text: California Contact Jmprov. Jam Harbin Hot Springs, Nov. 88 Home, I sit at the breakfast table, overwhelmed with grief. Leaving Harbin and the incredible sense of community that we gradually built was very sad for me. I didn't acknowledge it until Monday morning. I was listening to Whales Alive and the singing back and forth of the whales made me intensely aware that our gathering was over and the migration back to the working grounds, like whale feeding grounds, was a very lonely process. Fortunately, we have a contact community in San Diego now. Three of us went to Harbin: Darshana Ellis, Bruce Gardner and myself. So we have each other as a support group. Two others are regulars in our community: Annete Frei and Laurelia Barton. We will be processing the learning of this Harbin for quite awhile. Some ideas that come up follow. Mixer: The round robin is inefficient for giving everyone a chance to dance. It is common for many of us to have an inner dialogue that goes like this: "They look so good," "I don't want to interrupt," "I'm not good enough," "I'm tired, cold   , " "Neither of them like me," and "They haven't had a long enough turn." This kind of taped message goes through my mind over and over again. I have to contradict my mind to get into a round robin. This becomes less of an issue when I begin to know I'm accepted. Then again sometimes the inner messages are confirmed. In a mixer format, everyone is encouraged to dance with someone they have never danced with before for a fixed time interval, then everyone switches to another unfamiliar dancer. This happens in "class" settings regularly but I think it should be used to introduce an evening of dance. There are no "I'm interrupting" or "long enough turn" messages to deal with. And this process helps to overcome the "I'm not good enough" and "I'm cold and tired" excuses. A set time interval is very important so that everyone switches at the same time. Perhaps the use of a bell or music to cue people to the switch process is appropriate. 0

Title: STILL MOVING (cont'd)
Abstract: This article continues the discussion of the Harbin Hot Springs California Contact Improvisation Jam, focusing on structure in improvisation, nude dancing, and renewal ceremonies.
Text: There are those who rigidly oppose structure at all costs. I agree that improvisation in its purest form should dominate. But I have strong feelings of compassion for the newcomers to contact who are overwhelmed by the beauty of the more experienced dancer and the close bonding and subgrouping that is common in contact communities. Nude Dancing: For the first time at Harbin, we had a nude contact session that occurred spontaneously on Friday night. I was overwhelmed by inner dialogue, "How will my body react to even greater sensuality than the already incredibly sensuous contact dance form?" The beauty of this session finally overcame my inhibitions and I truly enjoyed the freedom. It was like the first skinny dipping at the beach. Although I'm thankful for this experience, I have mixed feelings: (1) what will outsiders think, (2) will the wrong kind of people be attracted to our community if nude dancing becomes commonplace, (3) many community members stopped dancing when the nude dancing began, (4) many people were subtly criticized for objecting. Some thoughts for future occurrences: (1) I will not encourage nude dancing at Harbin with any regularity, (2) if the community agrees to a nude dance, I will strongly encourage a non-prime time, contained setting that will not disrupt the community function, (3) this should never be advertised in any way because of the potential disruption from outsiders. Notes on my nude dance experience: It was like velcro and silk. Initially I felt glued to my partner like velcro. This permits some unusual perches and unexpected locks. Then the perspiration set in and I slide around like sliding the length of the high school shower on my butt. It wasn't that bad but I never knew when I would stick or slip. I perspire heavily so I became concerned over others slipping on my slicks so I stopped, but not before rocking back on my back for a long slide across the floor. My dances with men were shorter than usual and I had some inner reservations like those I went through when I first started dancing with my community brothers long ago. Renewal (Welcoming) Ceremony: Initially getting together for the first community meeting needs more grounding spiritually. We seem to get too cerebral with names. I would appreciate repeating some of the closing rituals from the last Harbin so that we can honor the continuity of the community and show newcomers some of the results of the last community gathering. When the Native Americans joined for the Sun Dance, they began with ceremonies that evolved in the course of centuries to honor the community and to ritually bond each tribe member. I don't think this needs to be anything elaborate but something like a line -

Title: THE BERLIN CONTACT CONFERENCE 1988
Abstract: A report on the Fourth European Contact Teachers Conference held in Berlin, W. Germany in June 1988. The conference focused on artistic exchange and included open jams, workshops, panel discussions, and performances.
Text: About eighty five people came from Europe and the U.S. to take part in the Fourth European Contact Teachers Conference in Berlin, W. Germany from June 8-13, 1988. About a year ago, the Tanzfabrik (literally, "Dance Factory") was asked to participate in "Werkstatt Tanz: Issues for the Nineties" as Berlin is the European City of Culture for 1988. DIETER HEITKAMP, BRUNO STEFANONI and BOB REASE collectively organized this conference with a theme of 'New Influences and Crossovers'. "Werkstatt Tanz: Issues for the Nineties" was organized around a theme of artistic exchange and some of the events of the conference were open to the public. June 8th and 9th were days for registration and open dancing as well as reunions with friends, and acquainting oneself with parts of Berlin. Most people had arrived by the evening of Thursday 9th for an official welcoming and introductions at the new studio at Tanzfabrik. One studio had been put aside as a 'Video Cafe' and quiet room where, throughout the conference, videos of contact-related work were being shown informally. Friday 10th June began with OPEN JAMS in three studios at the Tanzfabrik. On Friday afternoon, NANCY STARK SMITH and ROBIN FELD led two separate WORKSHOPS-"Developing the Form" and "Contact and Martial Dance." On Saturday afternoon, ISHMAEL HOUSTON-JONES led a workshop on the Politics of dancing, while PAULINE DE GROOT led one on improvised dance and music. On Friday and Saturday evening after dinner, there were two PANEL DISCUSSIONS. The topicfor Friday was 'Teaching' and Nancy Stark Smith moderated, assisted by Steve Paxton [see excerpts from this discussion in this Newsletter]. People on the panel included ROBIN FELD, BOB REASE, LOUISE RICHARDS, BRUNO STEFANONI, BERND KAMMERER, and GILA ROGERS. The discussion looked at questions in teaching such as the definition of a teacher, language and Contact, sexuality and aggression within sessions, and Contact in Therapy. Bernd spoke of his difficulties in the translation from English into German, of the concepts and practice of Contact. He had learnt Contact in English and was teaching it in German. Bernd was voicing an experience of teaching which must be common to all those teachers of Contact for whom English is not their first spoken language. It was added that it helps to use language which is part of the lives of the people being taught, to teach concepts of Contact in ways which will make it accessible for them. Steve Paxton said that his first concern when teaching Contact was how to teach it without people hurting themselves. Robin Feld described how she uses the breath to encourage the release· and flow of weight in her teaching. Using imagery such as melting, softening and folding at the joints all helps to encourage a safe physical environment for doing Contact. Louise, who teaches Contact with Kevin Finnan in high security prisons, said that changing from a dispersed to a focussed activity can also prevent injury in a session. The question "what are you teaching when you are teaching Contact?" was linked with finding a definition of a teacher. STEVE BATTS spoke of sharing an investigation with his students. He directs but may not know the outcome of the activity. He brought up the element of improvising in teaching, so that possibilities may be explored by teacher and learner together. "What about feeling and emotion in Contact?" This brought up some important issues. Steve Paxton talked about how emotion may or may not be acknowledged in dance. He spoke of how Contact arose in a dance context, within which people such as Martha Graham and Jose Limon were dealing with emotion, and making it into form. Paxton was drawn to Merce Cunningham, because Cunningham's dancing ethic was more abstract and he dealt with shape, form, space and time-the physics of dancing. This was more intellectual and there was less drama, less expression of emotions. In physics there is gravity, momentum, shape, angles and as physics is present in dancing, so are the emotions, "but we don't know how to deal with it, teach it, make it into a form." This was difficult for Kevin Finnan who explained that he taught Contact to criminals who have killed children and adults, including their relations, and these 'students' learn Contact and talk about it afterwards. I think there was some confusion here between finding forms for emotional expression in daily life, and finding emotional forms for dance, although the distinction can sometimes be difficult. Contact in therapy was an issue which was also discussed, and Gila Rogers, a dancer who is also a psychotherapist, explained how she combined Developmental work with Contact in her treatment of emotionally disturbed people and how effective Contact can be in her work generally. On the following evening, the topic for the panel discussion was 'Performing Contact-Working with Personal Material'. Steve Paxton moderated, assisted by Nancy Stark Smith. The discussion began with an infqrmal jam for the panel who were PAULINE DE GROOT, LAURIE BOOTH, BOB REASE, DIETER HEITKAMP, ISHMAEL HOUSTON-JONES, MARK TOMPKINS and JAAP KLEVERING. When the dancing had subsided, some people found seats to sit on, while others continued improvising while the discussion took place. After about an hour, there was a break and the panel rearranged their chairs closer to the audience and remained seated. Steve began by asking each person on the panel to say a little about themselves, and their work. He also asked them whether they had danced in a Broadway show or musical, which had run for more than three nights, or if they had danced on a boat, and whether they performed set material or improvised material. I was occupied with taping the discussion and taking photos so my notes are scarce. However, I have down that Laurie Booth was interested in aberrant behaviour as movement in performance, describing aberrant as marginalized or unusual activity. He recounted an incident which he was witness to at the zoo that morning, where a monkey had made history by imitating a film cameraman to the point where the monkey was making a film of everybody looking at him inside his cage. (I think this is what he meant, although the cameraman may have given the monkey the equipment to make a film). Ishmael had never danced any set material, and Steve was alone in danc~ng in a sh~w which repeated itself for many nights running. JORGEN TELLER asked whether improvisation can become a collection of anecdotes from learned forms. Steve replied, "Be careful of what you're taught, every step you've ever learned is stored in the body, and pieces will emerge when you're least exJ pecting it." There was a lot of discussion around defining the form of Contact Improvisation. A definitive statement of Steve's: "Forms exist to follow, but you're less than human if you don't try to break them." This panel discussion began at 8pm and was going strong at 11 :30pm when I left. There were tapes made of it which would hopefully be obtainable at the Tanzfabrik. The NETWORKING COMMUNITY MEETING began at lOam on Sunday morning, with sunshine streaming through the window of the studio. We decided that the next European Contact Teacher's Conference would take place from the 10th-17th August 1989 in Finland, and Jaap Klevering and Jaana Turunen would be organizing it. in Cyprus and Walter Weiler offered to organize one for Zurich, Switzerland. Dieter Heitkamp was interested in compiling a kind of journal to document responses to and feelings about the conference in Berlin. In the last part of the meeting we all shared something of this with the rest of the group. Here are some of the things that were said: How to begin dancing with strangers. Was this a conference or a symposium. The founders of Contact dance don't know the definition of it. The conference was part of Issues for the Nineties and we spent most of the time talking about the '60s and '70s. At no time did anyone say OK that's what Contact is. To make a group at this conference to talk about personal, social and political issues surrounding Contact dancing. That a large group of people should learn how to listen to each other. It is a political act to go and see how the Berliners live instead of attending the conference-this is as important as being 'in the stars'. There is no personal communication after such intimacy. To create more opportunities for personal work to develop. The psychology of the outsider-a celebration. To sustain a network between conferences. Wanting to have nothing to do with the 'hippy, pseudo cult' which Contact could become and to keep Contact available for all people. The "BERLIN JAM" on Sunday afternoon was an opportunity for open dancing among people outside of the conference and those in it, and new energy and faces meant revived dancing, for me anyway. It was a welcome change from the highly structured events of the conference, and reminded me of the two days open jamming before the conference began. I enjoyed the Sunday afternoon novelty of that jam and was glad of the opportunity to dance with new people. That night was the party, and Dieter transformed the biggest studio with some spotlights and a sound system into a disco. On Monday morning a group of us went to a cafe together. At the Contact Networking meeting Mark Tompkins suggested that people get together and talk about the personal, social and political issues that they experienced in dance and particularly Contact dance. It was a small group and there was the chance to talk quite personally which was a relief. The group was small enough for some close personal communication to take place and I feel that this is what the conference, by virtue of its size, failed to provide for, except in this group and outside of the structured ti me. The PERFORMANCE MARATHON was from 1 pm to 6pm that afternoon. This event was open to the public and everyone paid 15 marks toward it for the Berliner Aids Hilfe. In the first half there were solos, duets and one or two group pieces. This half was quite organized, in that there was a predetermined order to the pieces. There were improvisations and set pieces in this part of the marathon, including new collaborations. After the break, the space was basically open except there was a structure which Pauline ignored or forgotten as time w;nt by. When one of the musicians left, sound became the domain of the dancers who accompanied themselves from around the space or within it, talking and singing, or using tapes or playing the percussion instruments that were available. The space was nearly always pretty well full of activity and there were one or two solos and at one point there were about twenty people in the space. The marathon was the last organized event of the conference, although most people would be attending the PERFORMANCES of STEVE PAXTON and LISA NELSON, and LAURIE BOOTH that evening in another part of Berlin. But it was the end of the conference at the Tanzfabrik and so those of us who were there sat in a circle together for two minutes of silence to acknowledge an ending with Dieter, Bob and Bruno. I would like to finish with some quotes by KERIAC from an article called "Politics and Contact" in an old issue of CQ: . whv was this form named Contact Improvisation and not Steve Paxton Technique? In the entire modem dance world, every new approach except Contact is based on a cult of personality: Graham technique, Cunningham technique, Hawkins technique, etc . .. to me, that name is revolutionary-it reflects a whole new value system in dance. . I understand that Paxton was a teacher at Bennington at the time he began exploring Contact, and that his co-workers were mostly students. And yet, if two people try to do Contact while maintaining the typical student-teacher relationship, I think those two wouldn't end up doing much Contact at all. Both the name and the form itself assume that Contact is a collective creation that is bigger than individuals. There is a letting go of ego, and a letting go of traditional role expectations, that is unprecedented in dance. .. Contact began with the progressive, antielitist values of its inventors. But third and fourth generation contacters, who may have little or no contact with the originators, now outnumber the originators as teachers of the form. It's quite possible to teach someone 'Contact' in the physical dimension only, without any conscious reference to values, or even in relation to values that conflict with the form. To me, it's important for teachers of Contact to cultivate in themselves and in their students a heightened awareness of the political and spiritual richness of this form of dance. .. I think we in the Contact community have a unique opportunity to foster the revolutionary model that was generated by the Contact originators. We can validate the activities that do not conform to the traditional expectations, because our own experience in Contact has given us intimations of another type of 'good quality performance' . .. we can perceive performers as real people in real time, making choices that have physical results neither good nor bad, rather than applauding 'stars' whose image would be ruined by a 'mistake'." [from "Politics and Contact," interview with Keriac by Mark Pritchard, San Francisco 1979, CQ Vol. Vil no. 7. Fall 7987.] JULIET SHELLEY lives and works in Oxford, England and is a member of Jointwork Dance Group.

Title: DIALOGUES AND EXPLORATIONS
Abstract: This article features excerpts from "The Alphabet of Movement: Primitive Reflexes, Righting Reactions and Equilibrium Responses/Part I" by Bonnie Bainbridge Cohen, with interviews by Nancy Stark Smith. It explores the relationship between developmental movement patterns and dance.
