Title: a bottle of wine, a cane, a cloth
Abstract: Martin Keogh discusses the use of imagery in teaching Contact Improvisation, emphasizing its power to enhance the dance experience. He provides a list of evocative images that he has used in his own dancing and classes.
Text: In the ancient fairy tales there is often a character walking in the woods where he meets a man (often named Mercurius, one of the names of Hermes) who gives three gifts. These might include a bottle of wine that is never empty, or a cane that will open any door, or a cloth that will heal any illness. A gift that is often given is the cloak of invisibility. One of the images I often wear as I'm dancing is this cloak. I try not to interpret the image or figure out how it applies to my dance, I simply wear it, and the dance changes. In teaching Contact Improvisation, I have found images to be invaluable for getting at the soul of our dance. It is possible to give physical corrections and teach techniques but I have found that it is the imagery that brings down mountains and sets the oceans ablaze. The images are sometimes descriptive and sometimes prescriptive. I will often flesh them out with a story or other images but they don't come with an explanation. Here is a list of images, some that I have used in my own dancing and some that I have given in my classes: sleeping beauty after the kiss the sand in an hourglass sausages for bones an empty scale seeing through fish eyes -Atlas after putting down the world think of yourself as a timeless piece of literature -hunter after big game deep in the jungle and the lions have just come into view bread rising and overflowing the bowl resplendent robes, jewels and crown of a king at the bottom of the exhale is when the lights go on pancake batter spreading as it's poured patina cracking and peeling off greenhouse for winter blossoms in the chest head and shoulders like a mop -you have no forehead an old crone who has seen it all the reverence, standing in a grand cathedral with sunlight streaming in flowing skirt, longgggg hair, dangling earrings, dozen bracelets, emerald in bellybutton, tattoo of a rose on the thigh filled with cooking

Title: STILL MOVING, , . after all these years
Abstract: Jerry Zientara reflects on his long-term involvement with Contact Improvisation, highlighting its impact on his personal growth, artistic expression, and healing practices. He discusses how Contact has influenced his understanding of intimacy, trust, and the connection between physical and emotional well-being.
Text: In my life as an animal, Contact Improvisation has been one of the brightest illuminations, helping me in the search for wisdom, happiness and the meanings of life. Contact has been a catalyst in my relation to the world, opening my dancing and giving me a world to dance in. Since I was a small child I have surfed on the urge to create little worlds of my own. I have been producer and director, writer and performer, designer and clean-up crew over and over in order to dwell in the magic reality of an altered, imagined society. Contact, in its allabsorbing concentration of attention and array of options, gave me hope and an example of physical/metaphysical freedom. I hungered to expand the inward state of being in the flow of movement, turn it inside-out and make an arena of total involvement. In 1982 I began going to jack-off parties. Lessons about weight and ?u~render, momentum and timing, mt1macy and respect for the partner vital in Contact were also vital amidst hot, horny men eager to play together. In both Contact and the j/o scene, trust, good humor and sensitive touch invite the interpersonal rapport, and generate above and beyond the physical sharing an atmosphere of generous welcome. Unwilling to be merely a participant, I felt my dictatorial drives push me to become an organizer of the San Francisco JACKS in 1984 and the next year I was one of th~ circle of radical artists who aimed to conquer the epidemic of FADS (Fear, Anger, Doubt and Sorrow) by becoming the Healing Order of Kthar Sissies. The party animal within me emerged as Dogtor Woof! Semiremide and I began to administrate, mediate and realize clinics, parties, rituals and ceremonies dedicated to healing of the self and the planet. Dance had become movement, theatre had become paratheatre, my Contact group had become a support network and dining club; as the '80s rolled along, religion, money, art and sex twisted and turned into something almost coherent, something like a big jewel lighting my way. For the last four years, my endeavors have included mixed events for men and women, of gay, lesbian, bisexual, heterosexual, wild, shy, s/m and other persuasions widening my outlook and expa~ding my provincialism beyond the exclusively gay men's milieu. Recently I went to a Contact weekend where I discovered many folks deeply embroiled in anxieties about intimacy, attraction and other psychoerotic phenomena within the context of our movement form. At last, I thought, my studies might apply to the world of Contact, where I got so many good ideas in the first place. Currently I am looking for ways to offer some of the lore I have won to contactors who once again surround me. I am meditating on drills, exercises, articulations of some of the attraction/repulsions, curiosities, fears and delights movers· report that verge on and merge with the psychoerotic. In private practice as a planet therapist, I use breath, mas~age, movement and counseling, seekmg to heal psychic wounds, as many of us have been doing all along, directly and indirectly. The duet of the skeleton and the breath once my vision of the Contact dan~e, has another dimension, crisscrossed and united with the duet of the personality and the aura. Attractions to certain partners r~sistances that lead to challenge~, difficulties leading to triumphs, the darknesses required for stars to shine in: these are among my current considerations. How these notions apply to Contact, how Contact applies to me and others, how by dancing our best we can heal ourselves and the planet: these are among my favorite thinks. Found in a spin, loving the spin I'm in, I remain your admiring student and pal, relaying radiant blessings! Woof! * JERRY ZIENTARA was part of Frxx Movix a super-8 cinema corrmune, from 7 969-76 ' whose works include "Fur on Fire" and "Artsport," a 7 975 movie on contact improvisation. 7 980, Grup Txatr D Frxx · 7 984 Hea!ing Order of Kthar Sissies, pa/atheatric realizations and se/f-hea/ings. Currently dancing again. He lives in San Francisco where he massages bodies and rrinds.

Title: WHAT'S IN THE BAG? Issues that lie in the shadow of Contact Improvisation
Abstract: This article presents a transcript of a discussion at the 2nd California Contact Festival, facilitated and edited by Martin Keogh and Kirk Andrews, exploring the 'shadow' aspects of Contact Improvisation. Participants delve into uncomfortable and often repressed issues related to sexuality, power dynamics, community, and personal vulnerabilities within the form.
Text: transcript of a discussion at the 2nd California Contact Festival, 6/10/89, facilitated, edited and revised by Martin Keogh and Kirk Andrews In the issue that had "Questions Not to Ask" [by Danny Lepkoff, CQ Vol. 13:3], you put out the call for some "meaty discussion." I think this will provoke just that. Over the months of working on this, I have gone through feelings that range from elation to alarm. Looking at the form has reflected back on myself and a lot of my own issues that are crying out for attention. I hope that by putting this material out to the community at large, it will evoke the same for others. [M.K.] Keogh: A few months ago I had the idea of having a discussion on the shadow of Contact. I told Kirk, and he said he was thinking of doing a panel on sexuality and Contact. We agreed they were related, and decided to put them together. We spent a lot of time reaching into what we thought the shadow was for ourselves personally, and for the form as a whole. We came up with an image that poet Robert Bly uses to describe the shadow. He sees it as a big bag that we drag behind us. When something is too painful to deal with, or there is something we don't want to look at, we throw it in the bag. When we were children, we threw a lot of who we were into the bag from parental and teacher disapproval and their desire for us to be good little boys and girls. And as adults we continue to fill the bag. For some of us the bag is so long that they're all blocked up in the doorway. Kirk asked me, "Why do you want to delve into this shadow material?" I thought about this and realized that it's because I feel married to this form of dance. It would be easy to trance out or go on automatic and not confront the stuff that over the years of dancing I've put into the bag. Sometimes when I'm in a duet and a beautiful moment opens up, an opportunity for a spontaneous ride, I say, 'Wait a minute while I get my bag', and then the moment is lost. Hopefully, by mucking around in the muddled and uncomfortable aspects of the shadow, we can get some stuff out of the bag, so the dance can continue to open up. Andrews: The term 'shadow' has been used for thousands of years as a literary metaphor for the dark side, the underworld of life. Carl Jung, of Analytic Psychology fame, then picked it up and used it as a more poetic way to describe information that we repress and keep down. There are a lot of things that we have inside us that we don't show to the outside world. Jung said we have a "persona" character that we like to show, and then a bunch of "shadow" characters which are kept hidden. The shadow is full of these characters. A lot of them are quite creative and powerful (i.e., the thief, the witch, the tyrant) but we are taught that they are unacceptable. When we work on integrating the shadow characters, by talking about them, and bringing them into conscious awareness, we release a lot of energy that has been trapped there. The annoying thing is that just when we think we have the shadow uncovered and figured out, it changes into another form. Integrating the shadow therefore becomes a lifelong process of looking within ourselves. We hope this discussion today will help us to bring out some of these shadow issues that are very real but also very difficult to talk about. Keogh: One aspect is my pers~nal shadow in the dance: "What am I bnnging that I'm not wanting to look at?" Then there is the shadow that is inherent in the form itself. I've noticed as we have looked at some of this, that sometimes the material is offensive. The ones I take offense at, the ones I get defensive about, the ones where I say, "No, that's not what Contact is about,'' are the ones I need to look at most carefully. We want to start by shining a bright light at Contact so the shadow can become nice and long and clear. Take a moment to think of what you like best about Contact, what brings you to the form? Participants: • The incredible playfulness of everybody• Trust•. Connection • Release • Cooperation • Resonance• Total contact with someone • I feel like I get to be more fully me than in anything else I do • Because it helps bring out the shadow side of me • Confronting my fear and my sense of limitation • Physical and emotional risk • Surprise • Touch • Freedom to push • The accepted intimacy • I love the sensuality • The vitality • Inspiration to be creative in all of my life • Getting energy from non-energy• It's a metaphor for all my relationships • Spontaneity • Athleticism• Sportsmanship• Meditation • Recognition • Keogh: These statements demonstrate why we love this form. Because we. l?ve it we think it's healthy to turn a cntical e;e towards the form and our participation in it. One way that Kirk and I have been working on this is to look at what we like then delve into what's behind that. If.I like how playful everybody is, does that suggest we have a group of people who refuse to grow up? If this idea bothers you, you might be near the shadow. Today, let that be a guide. Here are five questions to work with in your small groups: • What do I deny or repress to do this form? • What do I like too much about this form? • What do I experience in this form that I don't like to acknowledge? •What's missing for me in this form? •What's missing in the Contact community? (The group splits into eight small groups who talk with different levels of animation. We get back together.) Keogh: We would like to hear a few statements from each group. The rest of us will try to hold back the impulse to make it all better, or say you're wrong, or you're ok, or that's not my experience. We will just try to hear it. Group one: We talked about two main categories. One was sexuality and the other, community. There is a blurred distinction between sensuality and eroticism, and the lines often blur in the dance. . . One person said that sometimes women he'd be dancing with spoke about feeling aggressive sexuality from their male partners, and they didn't know how to deal with it, and usually would excuse themselves to go get water. Participant: Uh oh, you blew thefr cover now. Group one: With community, the individual often judging what the community wanted from them. It came back to not knowing who you are yourself, changing how you act to fit the community. Group two: Honesty vs. niceness, how do you let someone know you dislike them and don't want to dance with them. Is it better to be honest and just tell them so, or be nice   Culture came up. A lot of us seem to be from the same background   Everyone in our group is involved in academic institutions, and really get into our heads, is this a haven for our bodies to express themselves? Group three: What do I experience that I don't like to acknowledge?: fear of physical danger, of rejection and vulnerability. How do I judge who I dance with or don't dance with and how do I tell them? Men holding back their weight from women   What's missing for me in this form?: The completeness of the intimacy. This sense that it is ok to be intimate within certain parameters but it doesn't extend even to sometimes saying goodbye to someone after class. One of the most frustrating parts of this form is describing it to people who don't know it. A definition!   What do I like too much about this form?: Again, intimacy, sensuality, letting go of the mind, just sort of checking out or o.d.ing on the experience, not knowing when to stop just because 'it's there'   What do I deny to do this form?: fear of physical danger. Sexuality: the fear of being exposed, fear of rejection, of not looking good, the judgement that I don't know how to do it. The judgement that I am not trained enough to do it. .. What's lacking in the community?: a lack of professionalism, in presentations and facilities. Group four: We talked about feeling vulnerable about approaching people and feeling insecurity around skill levels   Someone had discomfort dancing with the opposite sex, and had a desire to know them better to feel more trust before dancing with them   The difficulty of making eye contact while dancing, which seems paradoxical in such an intimate situation   Someone was disturbed by the lack of blacks and minority groups. Group five: Somebody asked does anybody feel grief or other strong emotions while doing Contact? We had all had some intense experience, either remembering something from our childhood, or something that made us want to cry. . . We talked about how difficult it is to do Contact and be in a relationship. Both with a partner who does Contact or one who doesn't. How do you communicate to your partner that this is only Contact, we're not having sex here   We also talked about how the community is very homogeneous. We are mostly white, well educated, and lacking ethnic cultures and people with handicaps. Group six: We talked about talking too much about emotions and the kind of philosophical baggage that comes with the form. Why do we have these kinds of discussions? Both perspectives of it being baggage and opportunity. . . We talked about fears of intimacy, liking parts of the form too much, so it goes into a dangerous area, such as liking being touched too much, and then becoming dependent on it. We talked about dreams. Group seven: We talked about snobbisms in the community. That fashion awareness is very repressed   and some liked too much the availability of attractive women. (lots of varied reactions) Group eight: Injuries; people feeling they are put aside and not talked about even though they very much affect the form   We also talked about the community as a whole not having a defined sense of what Contact is, and letting it develop and grow out of that, it's a "free for all" kind of deal. Participant: Contact also has a smugness about it, vis a vis the modern dance community. It's a mutual thing, we often say modern dance is very mechanical, and something is missing in it. And about Contact, their's is a thread about a lack of discipline, a lack of professionalism, focus, we take refuge in our own spontaneity and structurelessness and our unwillingness to work with crafting things. Andrews: Any time you put out that you are better than someone else, one has to wonder if the shadow part is saying, "We feel less than   " Keogh: Kirk and I have come up with some statements, or "judgements" about Contact that we hope will bring some of the shadow out into the light. Some are more serious than others. We would like to put these out, and then we can make the impossible jump of trying to at least resolve our talk today. After we came up with this list we split them into four categories: •Power • •The Form • Gender & Sexuality • Personal (a catchall for those that are hard to categorize) We decided not to put these down as questions but as statements. We will start with the Power category: •We are always in a supportive role with one another, seldom in a conflict role. There's very little conflict in this community. Participant:   little that gets expressed anyway. (laughter) Keogh: • We are all big fish in a little pond and there are no predators. Because the form is about support and flowing and acknowledging, the form attracts people who aren't very powerful. • We are people with a complete lack of boundaries. • There is no overt competition, there are no levels of attainment, no accolades to be reached. So you can do this form forever and never get any acknowledgement for it. • We are a group who tends to have a failure streak. (heated reaction) Participant: Is there any group that doesn't? Keogh: Remember, we don't have to defend the form right now. • No one in our community is outstanding or excels in their own field. (more heated reaction) Participant: What are these???? Keogh: These are statements. Participant: That someone else made, that you made, that you believe, that someone believes??? Keogh: These are possible shadow statements. Some of them we came up with looking at what is good about Contact, some are our own speculation, some we heard from others, and some are from people looking at the form from the outside. Participant: Ahhhhh! That explains it! (laughter) Andrews: These are generalizations. Participant: I have a difficult time with some. Andrews: That may be a sign that they are in your shadow, we usually don't like, and are critical of, what we hold in the shadow. Participant: I want you to take responsibility as the person who reads these statements. It's like someone else is trying to define who I am, and I resent that. I ask that the person reading these put them in an "I" form. Andrews: That's a good thing to say but our answer is no. I hear what you want and we talked a lot about how to do this. Keogh: We decided that because the form is so supportive and "I" based and nonconfrontive that we would simply put these out as statements. Andrews: They include us, but I can't take responsibility for them all because I don't believe them all. This is to fuel the discussion. We are not saying, this is how you are, or how the form is, but these are possibilities of our shadow in this form. If these statements don't apply to you, just let them go by with a laugh. If they draw a reaction from you,_ it is worth reflecting on your reaction. That is a part of our purpose. Keogh: Under the category of The Form: • There is no connection in this form between discipline and art. It makes no artistic statement. • There's a hierarchy based on who gets the highest rides, who shows off the best. • It is a form for latent gays and perverts. • We suffer from naive idealism, with ideas of egalitarianism and "organic process." Andrews: In the Gender and Sexuality category: • We're getting off on breaking the incest taboo. We get to have a kind of sexual experience with lots and lots of people who are more family than lovers. • Men are better at Contact than women. (oohs and laughter) • It fosters an androgynous sexuality. It turns men into women and women into men. Keogh: Look at our apparel. Andrews: • The emotional and the sexual get cut off to do this dance. Under the Personal category: • One thing I don't like to acknowledge is that I'm good at this form. My braggart has been kept in shadow. • Contacters are slaves to their sensations and feelings. If we gave as much weight to our ideas, we would be called fanatics. (whew/ no, no/ again!) • Contacters are slaves to their sensations and feelings. If we gave as much weight to our ideas, we would be called fanatics. And possibly would be much more powerful in the world with that force behind our convictions and beliefs rather than our physical bodies. • We are trying to fill the hole where we don't feel loved. • We are all leftovers from, or resent having missed, the '60s and the touchy/feely/group-gropes. (moan) • This issue of everyone being so playful and not wanting to grow up. The Peter Pan syndrome. Participants: Hallelujah! I Let's just change the definition of growing up I some of this stuff doesn't sound like shadow but conscious choices. Andrews: Like we said, there's a lot of creativity and pow:r in the shadow. Participant: Whenever we talk about sexuality /intimacy, getting into our bodies, we take on the morality we grew up with, rather than celebrating this thing that brings up our feelings of intimacy, that nurtures us, that fills the gaps, the holes where we feel unloved. I feel when we talk about this, it's as if we are getting off on something we shouldn't. I'd like to see more of a sense of celebration over these things. Andrews: That is true, and, for right now we are here to dig up the muck more than to celebrate. Participant: I like that. I'm not saying we shouldn't be digging. I just wanted to say that the terms sexuality and sensuality always get lumped into the muck. Participant: We have to dig them up to celebrate them. Participant: I see the focus on two forms of shadow. There's our own internal blockages, that may get in the way of the dance (or help the dance). And then there is this cultural stuff that we grew up with. IN essence, we are here to turn that stuff upside down and explore the side of it we never got to see the first 20 or 30 or 40 years of our lives. The culture is driven by fanaticism on a certain level, the fanaticism of dominating the world and repressing our feelings about that. Here we are turning it upside down: it's not our place to be powerful out in the world in a driving way. We can't challenge what's out there with the same behavior as that which we are challenging. So, it's very appropriate, at this stage in the evolution of the form and the community to be very introspective and visible. Keogh: I feel we're trying to elevate this material. I don't think we are ready to do that. We haven't been down in the shadow long enough yet. Participant: I noticed my emotional responses to some of these statements. Some went right by and others got stuck in me. Like hearing an old judgement I used to have about myself from the culture. Boy, there was a lot of reaction happening among us in response to many of these. I would encourage everybody to look at the ones you had the most inner discomfort with and ask what's happening here. Clearly there's a lack of resolution around a lot of these issues. I appreciate the statements being read the way they were because they were spoken the way my internal judge speaks them. Andrews: One of the benefits of looking at the shadow is you get a lot of energy back. If we are powerless, the power is in the shadow, if we are playful, the adult is in the shadow, if we are shy and afraid, the confident one is in the shadow. It makes it worthwhile to go there. Secondly, I think it's important for our community to look at the shadow and look at what's missing in order to be a real community and not a pseudo community that's superficial. Call it community maintenance. We can't say, "Oh, we talked about that last year," and then let it go. We have to keep working with it. One of the things that I want to acknowledge is that our community does a good job of talking about issues. That has been especially true at some of the Harbin jams. Hopefully today will have raised up some questions that we can continue to work with. This is an ongoing process, seek out a friend if you need to talk with someone. We need to close for now. Keogh: Before we get active, let's sit quietly for a moment and review what this discussion has evoked. * Special thanks to Dawn Weiss and Dan Matson for transcribing the tapes of this event.

Title: MY RISE & FALL IN CONTACT IMPROV
Abstract: Mark Pritchard reflects on his experiences with Contact Improvisation, particularly his feelings of being unappreciated and excluded due to his differing views on the form's relationship with New Age issues. The article traces his involvement in Contact Improvisation and explores the challenges he faced within the community.
Text: The following is an article about my career in contact improvisation. During the time I was doing Contact, I often felt unappreciated and shut out by other contacters because I wouldn't toe the line on Cl's relation to New Age issues. This article looks back on that period and traces my involvement in the form. [M.P.] MY RISE & FALL IN CONTACT IMPROV by Mark Pritchard -------------1. In 1974, after seeing a visiting dance company during my senior year in high school, I sign up for modern dance P.E. as a freshman in college. Astonished that I had made such an effeminate choice, my parents make me switch to basketball-which, since I'm only 5 '4", I hate. 2. Three years later, a fellow writer on the college newspaper invites me to a performance by Deborah Hay, who has just moved to Austin. "She's kind of a hippie, but you may like it anyway," my friend predicts. I hate the first half of the show, and then love the second. A few months later, I take the first dance classes of my life with Hay.
