Title: THE CALIFORNIA "HARBIN" JAM A Brief History
Abstract: This article provides a brief history of the California Contact Improvisation Jam at Harbin Hot Springs, from its inception in 1986 to the present. The author discusses the organizers, the inspiration behind the jam, its growth and evolution, and its impact on the regional Contact Community.
Text: The California Contact Improvisation Jam at Harbin Hot Springs continues to be an amazing, delightful, challenging, evolving phenomenon. The first one was held in the Fall of 1986. We're now working on the eighth Jam, which will be the end of May, 1990. The organizers are: Julie Oak, Penny Paulus, David Russell, Robin Trenda, and myself. On occasion, due to uncontrollable circumstances or by choice, an individual organizer has taken a Jam "off." For the past year, Robin has discontinued his role as an organizer, because of the vast commitment he has made to establishing and directing the new Wall Street Center for the Arts in Chico, CA. In the Spring of '86, the 5 of us, plus several other Bay Area Contactors were at the Breitenbush Jam [in Oregon]. Robin proposed a meeting for exploratory talks for anyone interested in starting a California jam. During the week we must have had 4 or 5 meetings and the groundwork I oz was laid. We went home, fresh from the excitement of Breitenbush, made phone calls, decided on Harbin as the site (mostly because of the spacious Conference Center, the mineral hot tubs and pools, and its 2Vi hour proximity to the Bay Area), found a caterer, chose a date and the ball was rolling. We had a solid example from Breitenbush to draw upon, and our own personal experiences there helped shape our ideas about how we wanted our jam to be. Thanks to Alito Alessi and Karen Nelson for creating the event that inspired us. We had the advantage of having a large regional Contact Community as a base, but still we decided to minimize our risk and start small. The first one was from Friday night ., to Sunday night, and was truly one §1 of the most joyous and exhilarating c3 weekends of my life. Everyone seemed to feel that way. It was like giving birth, except that the labor had seemed so easy! We decided not to wait a whole year to do it again. The 2nd Jam was about 6 months later, © 0 in May '87, and was expanded to 3 ] days and nights. c.. We've been doing them twice a year ever since, one in the Fall (late October, early November) and one in ~ the Spring (late April, early May). !:'-The 1990 schedule, however, has ·g, been changed drastically. The Con..: ference Center we use at Harbin c (where we have a beautiful large, iJ airy room, bathrooms, showers, a ~ small "guru" room, and hot & cool 15 pools all to ourselves) is in high de0' mand, and this year is not available tf at our usual dates. Also, for years ;; people have been wanting a longer E jam, and there is an ever-expanding ~ list of folks who want to come. We c. always have a waiting list, though ·5 we've increased our maximum from v B 40 to 55. So, we decided to try gf' something different. This year we're i having THREE Jams-all occurring over holiday weekends [see Notice in "CQ Newsletter"]. We will resume our "regular" Spring/Fall schedule Volume 15 1990 in '91. What has been the effect of all these Jams? Besides being a tremendous source of enjoyment and opportunity for exploration and development of our Contact, there has been much bonding and inspiration for other Contact activities. The "Community" I speak of has grown dramatically during these last four years. It is still diverse, and not everyone involved with Contact comes to the Jams. But a strong, vibrant and more organized group continues to spawn, expand, create and develop. The annual Contact Festival emerged from an initial vision and discussion at one Harbin Jam, spearheaded by Andrew Clibanoff, who now lives on the East Coast. The Contact Teachers Network has taken shape-we now cooperatively list all our classes, workshops, jams and performances together on one joint flyer. There was an energetic effort to create a Contact Community Center. Many people devoted much time and energy to this endeavor. Because of the lengthy process we were preempted in getting the studio we had hoped to rent. For now, the 8th Street Studio serves as our Berkeley hub. There have been various performance groups and series, as well as Contact camping trips and picnics. A 40-minute edited videotape titled "Thank You For This Dance," has been created by videographer/filmmaker Brandy Brawner and me. It contains footage shot at the '87 and '88 Harbin Jams. Copies are available from me for $25 [see 'Contacts' for address]. Although the majority of Harbin J ammers do come from the Bay Area, many have come from throughout the West Coast, notably Seattle, Portland and San Diego. We strive to set up an environment where everyone feels welcomed, included; and that each person's feelings, ideas and feedback are important. We have daily group "sits" and meetings (though we prefer to call them "gatherings"). We have a "dream pool" where people put out their dreams and fantasies for things they would like to have happen at that Jam. There are group scores and presentations. A memorable one, initiated by Darshana [Ellis] from San Diego, involved nude women and paint. After much heated debate about whether, where and when it was going to happen, it turned out to be an exquisite dance ritual performed outside shortly before the Sunday closing. Last Fall, Keriac and others constructed a thoughtful score which we all participated in, processing our many deep and mixed feelings following the Earthquake ("The Pretty Big One") which we had just survived 1 Vi weeks before. There is careful attention given to group process and how Jam policies and decisions are made. Participants' written feedback at the end of each Jam has proven invaluable. As organizers, we have developed our skills as facilitators-a role which has proven to be both challenging and rewarding. And of course there's lots of Contact. Dancing, jamming, classes, more jamming. But I think what makes the experience so rich is that rather than being an isolated 2-hour episode of Contact (like at a weekly jam) it goes on 24 hours a day for 3 or 4 days. We live it and breathe it together, as a group. We eat together, sleep together (accommodations are either camping or communal in the conference center), hot tub together, hike, dance, talk, play, drum, argue, sing, cry, laugh, hug, etc. It feels so natural. I always feel somehow more fully "me" at these Jams than at practically any other time. And I always feel so grateful for this form which has so immeasurably enriched my life; and for the opportunity to serve, grow with, and be part of this special Community, which I know extends beyond the Bay Area, beyond California, beyond the U.S., even beyond Europe and into at least parts of the rest of the world. * SHARON TOMSKY is a dancer, contacter, and bodyworker. She teaches, performs, & organizes contact events in the San Francisco Bay Area. CQICI Sourcebook 199

Title: DANCING WITH THE DIFFERENTLY-ABLED
Abstract: Tom Giebink reflects on his experiences dancing with differently-abled individuals at a DanceAbility workshop, exploring themes of empathy, balance, and the transcendence of physical limitations. He shares anecdotes about dancing with individuals with cerebral palsy, blindness, and spinal cord injuries, highlighting the unique perspectives and abilities they bring to movement and improvisation.
Text: Empathy, an elusive word, means   dancing in another person's skin? If empathy is the ultimate form of love, then dancing contact improvisation, too, is a form of love. This idea took on new meaning for me in Eugene, Oregon at the 1991 DanceAbility workshop. Disability is not monolithic. Cerebral Palsy is not the same as Multiple Sclerosis is not the same as Paralysis due to nerve damage is not the same as Blindness. Even within the "category" of cerebral palsy, one person can communicate by speech, another by pointing at picture symbols, yet another spells words by looking through a clear plastic plate covered with the alphabet while a "reader" speaks the words the "speaker's" eye movements have indicated. Each person is affected by their disability in a singular way, yet they are routinely lumped together as people "who can't get along without help" in our (able-bodied) world. Instead, each has struck a different balance with the physical world, making themselves differently-abled. Gerry Overington, who is totally blind, told me that I might close my eyes but would still not enter the world he lives in since my "mind's eye" would still see the scene. He does not live in a picture that's been temporarily obscured. For him the balance of his senses has shifted toward attention to touch, sound, smell, and memory. Bruce Curtis lost the use of his legs, and hands partially, to his spinal cord injury at 17. Since then, his wheelchair has become an extension of his body. (He's definitely not "confined" by it.) If I say, "Wheels have replaced his legs and feet," that seems obvious yet far too simple. 202 CQ/CJ Sourcebook Rather, his body has become differently shaped because it integrates his chair with his flesh and bones so that his movement is an ever-varying combination of the capabilities of both. In dancing with Bruce, I was the one learning to move. I couldn't respond in habitual ways-weight and balance were different. For instance, "taking weight" in an able-bodied duet often involves supporting the other's weight through spine, legs, and feet. However, in one duet with Bruce, I felt "taking weight" as a balancing in which our arms were like the spokes of a wheel transmitting weight back and forth between me as the hub, and him as the rim, our weights alternately stretched away then compressed towards each other. Bruce might lean/ extend into me in such a way that my weight, anchored through the floor, would provide a resistant center which he could alternately push off from or be pulled in by, creating a momentum and continuous change of direction that rolled his chair around me. Gravity seemed to act horizontally as he pivoted around me. No hands were required to turn the wheels of his chair, the spiraling thrust created was the almost effortless product of the lateral interplay of our weights. (The image of planets orbiting each other comes to mind.) Seen from the outside, one might think that the able-bodied person was always initiating, but Bruce said his partner's active weight supported him by providing a resistance he could work off of, amplifying his initial impulses so that his range of movement was extended. In fact, our dance was unrestrained by his chair whether he was moving in it or carrying the duet out of it to the floor. Emery Blackwell cannot walk or feed himself. When I helped him at the Breitenbush Jam my hands were momentarily his: when they fed him, while brushing his teeth, while cleaning up after being on the toilet. .. standing or sitting was a game of balance and support with me or some well-anchored object. Yet he bicycles 30-60 miles a day, alone. He talks of his dance of getting into and out of the bathtub, dancing his way out of bed, into the bathroom. He has a joy in moving that I realize I've long given up to the habitual shorthand of getting from here to there in the world. He also dances for audiences-solo, and in a remarkable partnership with Alito Alessi, continually dancing through what I'd imagined to be his limits. He bought ballet shoes for feet which, although they will not support his weight, have been poetically aligned by his cerebral palsy into a permanent en pointe position. He is a truly graceful, whole human. Dancing in EMPATHY, what does it mean? Bruce told me a story, saying, "Suppose I drop a coin on the ground. Now, it usually takes me longer to pick it up than an able-bodied person and it's curious to see if someone will pick it up before I do. There is a certain amount of time which society allots to a given task and if I take longer than that I am seen to be having a problem." He's not. Long ago he accepted his own frame of reference. Time has become very personal. He's not having any trouble but able-bodied people often don't see that. Their discomfort sets in when, "it takes him too long" and sympathetically, sometimes with pity, the coin is picked up so that he doesn't have to "work so hard at it." Bruce said he does appreciate help, but it almost always comes with that attendant insistence on the able-bodied frame of reference. Sometimes that means he's been judged, subconsciously or not, to be less than competent. Perhaps he's seen to be in physical pain? For a short while I was captive of those feelings, even when I knew they had no basis in fact. In my case, the pain and fear associated with old, and temporarily-very-disabling skiing injuries were being dredged up, leading to momentary irrationalities like, "He is in pain, and unhappy. It's temporary, he'll heal   " Or, sometimes emotions can link disabilities with aging and dying (I've had a close friend and parent die recently) and so sadness and grief, as well as fears around the loss of physical functioning, can inappropriately become attached to disabled people. It's awkward when Volume16 1991 photo: Rochus Schmuecker Gerry Overington getting a ride with Emery Blackwell in Eugene, Oregon. the experience of the differently-abled is felt through an able-bodied filter, but it's not surprising. We spend so much time and attention dancing around our own discomfort. So to dance in empathy is to dance in the frame of reference of one's differently-abled partner, moving on equal terms   which is true of contact improvisation in general but now one stretches into new territory (as Chinese or Arabic are a much greater stretch for our English ears and tongues than German or Spanish). Sometimes the contact of the improvisation is other than touch. Other times conflicting touch impulses are felt. Emery told me that an able-bodied person bends an arm by signalling muscles to contract while simultaneously suppressing those signals to muscles opposing that movement, but the area of his brain which controls the "suppression" function has been damaged by cerebral palsy so both bending and straightening muscles contract at the same time. It's a standoff that he can overcome by conscious thought but there's often a "lag time" of 30 seconds or more which, even then, is accompanied by the jerkiness of conflicting muscle messages. In dancing Volume 16 1991 with him, I found I had a tendency to arbitrarily choose to follow one impulse or, conversely, none. Either way, I was stuck in my own perspective, doing my own dance, drowning out Emery's initiatives. Waiting with Emery meant operating in his time, listening for his intention to sift through his nervous system, allowing my senses to shift into line with his without losing my own center. Dancing with that lack of knowing was differently-dancing, since for those dances I was living as if all muscle movements required conscious intervention. I felt the awkwardness like a never-ending struggle to juggle. Rarely have I been so conscious of the body as the container of the spirit. But then that's the content of these dances: the movement of the human spirit transcending the container it's been given by birth or chance. In contact improvisation, both movers are extending through limits, not the least of which are the limits of empathy   going into another world and allowing another into one's own. Enabling each other to dance with those risks. * TOM GIEBINK works as a sculptor, painter, performer, and video artist in Austin, Texas where he is currently organizing a DanceAbi/ity workshop with Mary Ganzon to take place hopefully this coming fall. He spent 6 years on the alpine ski race circuit until he moved to Austin where there's no snow, but there is Contact.

Title: A QUESTION OF PERFORMANCE
Abstract: John William Johnson questions the criteria for deciding to perform at the Breitenbush Jam, and whether performers have a responsibility to give their best to the audience. He reflects on the range of commitment to performing and the potential for deeper engagement with experienced performers.
Text: Some questions I brought to the performance portion [of the Breitenbush Jam experience in Oregon, specifically the post-Jam performances in Eugene] were never addressed and are still burning a groove in my brain. What is the criteria for deciding to perform, and do we have a responsibility to the audience to give our best? I was very happy to see that everyone who wanted to got to perform. There was no sense of elitism, or judging a person's worthiness to perform. But I think it would serve us all to help each other bring what is unique and special about us to the stage. At 44, I think of myself more as a mover than a dancer. 'Performance artist' is a convenient term nowadays. I think of a dancer as someone who spends a lot of time dancing, practicing, focussing on their body as an instrument of expression. As a performer, I try to focus on the areas in which I can offer something unique, something that makes a contribution. For people with limited dance training and limited contact experience to perform in either of these areas doesn't seem to make sense, for sure to the audience, and probably not for the performers. My wife, who has a strong ballet background, found it hard to relate to most of the performances. She was reminded of when she was a little girl, and the kids on the block would put skits together, and the parents would watch. I guess this is fine, if the audience feels related enough to the performer that they really don't care what they do; they just love seeing their friends on stage. What is the criteria for deciding to perform, and do we have a responsibility to the audience to give our best? Scheduling only one day [at the end of the Breitenbush Jam] for a Performance Conference seems an anomaly to me. I think it would make more sense to have the jam on the weekend, and have the conference last much longer. There was barely enough time to figure out what we wanted to do, and there was little if any time to take advantage of the people present who spend their lives as performers. The range of commitment to performing varied greatly. Should anyone be allowed to come to the Performance Conference? It was nice to feel like we were all kindred spirits, but the day seemed identical to me to many improvisational workshops that are offered to the general public. I missed being able to pick the brains of Steve [Paxton] and Nancy [Stark Smith] and Alito [Alessi] and Karen [Nelson]. It would be interesting to know why we all came to the Performance Conference. I have the sense that it's partially an ego thing. I get to go home and say I'm a performer, I get to make believe I'm of the same caliber as people who focus their lives on performing. I get to avoid all the deeper questions, all the demons that squelch my creative drive the other 51 weeks of the year. Namaste, John William Johnson Portland, Oregon

Title: BIRTH DANCE
Abstract: Lisa Gottlieb-Clark describes her home birth as a contact dance, emphasizing the intuitive connection between her and her baby. She contrasts it with high-tech births in sterile hospitals, celebrating the spiritual and natural aspects of her experience.
Text: Birthing my baby boy was the essence of a contact dance. For me, the key to a satisfying improvisational dance means abandoning my analytic mind and embracing the center of my intuitive self. This intuitive center grew in size and strength through my pregnancy, and bloomed as my labor began. I trusted my body in the dance of birthing, and my body freely opened. In this age of high-tech births, in cold, sterile hospitals, my home birth was instead a celebration of spirit and nature. I danced my baby out into this world, and he danced with me. Now, when we hold each other and move together through our days and nights I feel the continuation of our original improv on the day he was born. Lisa Gottlieb-Clark LISA GOTTLIEB-CLARK: "I live in Ann Arbor, Michigan with my husband Ed, my daughter Zoey and my new baby Nevon. I · am a visual artist, and also have a part-time body work practice."

Title: FIRST TOUCH
Abstract: Christina Svane reflects on the importance of physical contact, particularly between mother and child, and its connection to well-being and development. She discusses the therapeutic effect of Contact Improvisation and the need to restore the possibility of communicating through touch in childhood.
Text: It has been said that gravity is the expression of Mother Earth's love for her children. When I imagine that hug ending, I feel the horror of being lost in space, alone. When my baby had the hiccups inside me, I yearned to comfort her, but how could I hold in my arms what I already held in my womb? My blood in her veins, my body her world-yet I could not say to her, "I am here. You are not alone." That which loves us surrounds us yet cannot contact us; we must contact it. Perha~s I could say that culture is the collected effort of our species to ·;nake contact with the unseeable totality in which we are developing. It can not pick us up when we cry. But its blood runs in our veins. Sometimes, in dreams, we see what we later will call a face. I find it tragic that Contact Improvisation has so often a therapeutic effect on a person. That implies that everyone out there who isn't experiencing it is probably suffering. That doesn't sound quite logical. But surely it has spread because it answered a collective need, quenched a collective thirst. I have tasted my own milk and it is sweet. I cannot remember, but I imagine, that as a breast-sucking newborn, I enjoyed nursing not only Volume 16 1991 for the sweet sustenance it poured into me like sunshine, but equally for the contact improvisation. We could call it our first conversational partner, speaking and listening through the skin of mouth, hands, arms, face and chest, to a partner who is warm, responsive, fluid, round and featuring a special point of access. The circle with the point in the center. Symbol of the sun, the mother. (In Tibetan teachings, the solar principle is feminine-the power to ripen and sustain life-and the lunar principle is masculine. It was affirming to see this interpretation.) What effect has it had on us to live in a society in which our most important symbol has been deemed obscene? I am not advocating a "topless" society, though I see nothing wrong with that concept, so long as it is left up to each individual to decide. But I believe in doing the obvious, ·or at least recognizing it, and it is obvious that the human body is a long way yet from being liberated. Especially the body of the mother, once worshipped, now persecuted through taboos, harsh birth practices, a medical establishment that discourages nursing, and ignores the fact that skin-toskin contact with the baby is the key to its well-being and development. In accepting the Nobel Prize, and again in addressing the Italian Government this spring, His Holiness the Dalai Lama of Tibet reminded his audience that every member of photos by Janet L. Cox the human race is born free of religion or culture, but shares universally with all human babies the need for affection. Physical contact with the mother is the single most important factor in the well-being of the newborn for the first weeks of life, he said. It reaffirmed my feeling that this is the topic of the hour. If we allow the generation being born now to grow up with their need for contact satisfied instead of scorned, the problems of the world may be inherited by sane and compassionate people who have the natural ability to do the obvious. I wonder how the contact community can assist in the process of restoring to childhood the possibility of communicating with parents or others through touch-a language already functioning at birth, years before speech is perfected. Perhaps the goal of Contact Improvisation should be to render itself obsolete. My hope is to stimulate dialogue in "Still Moving" regarding the language of touch between parent and infant. I would like to hear accounts of what you've been doing privately and/ or publicly with this relationship. * CHRISTINA SV ANE was one of the founders of Movement Research, Inc. in NYC. She recently returned with her newborn girl to Vermont after 2 years teaching dance at the Theaterschool in Amsterdam, Holland. CQ/CI Sourcebook 205

Title: STILL MOVING (cont'd) On Watching "Continuing Contact" Oberlin College Dance Company Concert Spring, 1990
Abstract: This section presents audience reactions to a performance of "Continuing Contact" by the Oberlin College Dance Company. The responses vary, with some viewers appreciating the intimate movement and spontaneity, while others found the performance trivialized by the proscenium stage and costumes.
Text: Tumbling socks   That is what the performance of Continuing Contact brought to mind during the concert. The eight dancers appeared in loose white costumes and took turns bumping each other out of duets. Have you ever sat and watched your clean clothes rise and fall through the spin of the drying cycle? A pair of white socks thrown into a dark load will stand out vividly and will look like they are tumbling alone in the dark. I can easily unf ocus my eyes from the looping pattern and concentrate on the intimate movement of socks in contact with each other. The socks wrap, roll and slide across each other. Theirs is a continuous falling and rising. There is no "muscling it" in this duet, the socks rise in response to their incredible momentum. The dancers on stage also did a duet of wrapping, falling, sliding, rising. There was continuous motion; none of the moments of contact resulted in weight colliding and ending in dead stops. Nothing ever remains stationary in the dryer either. Kim Monis When the dancing began I was absorbed in the details; where the point of contact was, where it was traveling and how; placement of weight. Soon, I felt m)'self responding in, as they call it, a kinesthetic way, feeling physical empathy with the movement. Yet I, for the first time so removed from the dancers, was deeply moved by the spontaneity of their responses to each other; the infinite variety, and the incredible (and necessary) sensitivity of those responses. I had not been separated enough from it before to see the miraculousness of these movements in terms of just daily human interaction. SylviaChwe Watching Contact and doing Contact are experiences further apart than most audience/performer relationships. Contact is like Pop Rocks. If you just watch surface activity, it's difficult to understand what's going on. Get Close, pay attention; maybe you'll hear it crackle. But to really experience it, you've got to pop it in your mouth and feel the explosions. Betsy Cutler -0 Qj l c: ..c: ..2. @ 0 0 ..c: c. "Continuing Contact" was a performance Ann Cooper Albright directed with her students at Oberlin College, Spring 1990. Using contact improvisation, it was danced on a proscenium stage in front of a backdrop of enlarged 'hieroglyphs'. The performance frame in which contact improvisation was danced in the ODC concert trivialized this movement form. On a proscenium stage, the Continuing Contact dancers were formally separated from the audience, removing the personability and the three-dimensionality available at closer viewing. Unlike a regular jam, the dancers wore white costumes which made it difficult to distinguish between bodies and hence watch the particulars of what one body was doing, save dancing solo, at any particular time   The audience found the dancing amusing if not hilarious and I became increasingly more uncomfortable as the people around me laughed harder. What for me is a beautiful and moving dance form had become a comedy act. Chloe Stamas

Title: CONFESSIONS OF"A LAYMAN DANCER Dedicated to Anyone Who Ever Danced With Me
Abstract: Barry Kirsh reflects on his journey with Contact Improvisation, contrasting it with his father's bowling and exploring the spiritual and physical aspects of the dance form. He discusses his initial focus on technique, his shift towards listening to impulses, and the challenges of integrating his dance aspirations with his daily life.
Text: Would you pass up free tickets to an ice hockey game at the Forum in Montreal? Seats at ice level, with the Canadiens playing the defending Stanley Cup Champion Calgary Flames? I did. And my father was baffled when I declined his invitation. I'm sure he was shaking his head at the other end of the telephone line and wondering about me. Don't misunderstand. I love hockey. But, on Wednesday nights this autumn, I have been attending dance classes. In fact I have been dancing Contact Improvisation on a once weekly basis for the better part of 4 years now. My father, on the other hand, has been bowling every Tuesday night for the last 40 years. Yet, he would grab the hockey tickets at a moment's notice. Why didn't I? Could it be that 'the World of Dance' has occasioned more for me than bowling has for my father? Three and four years ago I remember that the dancers talked a lot about technique. Many of us in Contact courses and occasional weekerid workshops wanted to improve our skills. I felt that if I could stand on my hands and flip over someone else's back, then I would improve tremendously as a Contact Dancer. Or at least be in a position to register for a new course entitled, "Flying," an eventual step from Contaet Dance, I believed. Luckily Montreal is the home of several fine Contact Dance teachers. Andrew Harwood, the leader in three workshops I have attended, has helped me. My feeble attempts to walk on my hands were not ridiculed. Instead, my immediate needs were recognized. He suggested poetic polarities to frame my precarious perches. We pulled for the earth and pushed to the sky. We differentiated shadows amidst images of light/dark. With weight/lightness, we intimated the profundity of Being and Nothingness it seemed, as I grew into my body more fully. The poetry did assuage my fears of disorientation. Though I still had to accept the reality of lurching acrobatic postures and an instinctual begging for form. I kept on. Contact Dance became a paradox to me. It intrigued me as a mystical endeavour in the guise of physical movement. It was exciting that people around me seemed uninhibited about their bodies. So spiritual communication through bodily movement became the enigma I sought to express each time I danced. To hell with handstands! If I could listen to the impulse, the magic of Contact might glow in the intense corporeal kinship on the dance floor. It was better than erotic behavior because it drew from many more human emotions. And I took delight in it. My weekly course work with Gurney Bolster confirmed the notion that concentration was essential. The long warm-ups, from the slightest movement, gradually, into the sweeping gestures of the entire body, heating up and perspiring in solo dance focussed my energy and prepared me best to dance with others. I think I wanted to become a monk at one point. Cultivating the meditative poise of a monk would surely accrue the release of unfettered movement. Then I went home to my wife and kids to realize that deliberate action often meant compromise. No recluse could I be. Nevertheless, I wished to continue my labour of love, regardless of my certain limitations. But Gurney became pregnant, and Andrew, like most of the Contact teachers, taught exclusively during the day. Spiritual aspirations could not transcend the realities of my daily life. I was a layman whose feet coul

Title: IN RESPONSE STILL MOVING
Abstract: This section contains two letters responding to previous articles in Contact Quarterly. Mary Ganzon reports on her contact group's all-day jam and expresses appreciation for articles addressing issues within the contact improvisation community. Tica Lemos reflects on Diane Elliot's article about creating safe contact environments and shares her experiences teaching contact improvisation in Brazil.
Text: It was in April '86 when I first saw contact improvisation. Nancy Stark Smith and Lou Danielson Stewart were giving a demo [in Austin, Texas] on the Friday evening before a weekend workshop with Nancy. I had an immediate kinesthetic response and a sensation of calling. I knew that my body/mind was curious and longed to explored this form. It wasn't until the latter part of '87 that this practice was part of my life. I was truly in love with it and was a little incredulous when some would say, "I tried it, but it's not for me," or, "I have a really hard time watching it." I knew I hadn't been exposed to another side of how people have experienced contact. Then, in a group conversation at the dorm during the A Cappella workshop '89, someone brought up how people had left the form-for reasons other than family, other movement forms, or some seemingly natural reason. This piqued my curiosity. My attention at people's grievances during round robins, jams, or workshops heightened, not because I wanted to fix anything but I just wanted to know. So, I have really appreciated Martin Keogh's and Kirk Andrews' "What's in the Bag: Issues that lie in the shadow of contact improvisation,'' ("Still Moving," CQ Vol. 15:1, Winter 90) and Mark Pritchard's "My Rise and Fall in Contact Improv" (CQ Vol. 15:3, Fall 90). They have really broadened my vocabulary of perception, understanding, and allowance. I am realistic enough to know that uncriticized consensus is a sign of narrow vision and listening, not to mention impending blocks. Thank you everybody for the contributions to "Still Moving"-for the ones with continuing communities and for those building ones. There seems to be a common thread to bridge and breach a loneliness. I am happy to report on our own contact group. We had our first all-day jam this summer. [See "Newsletter" for report.] Mary Ganzon Austin, Texas I would like to comment about Diane Elliot's article in the "Still Moving" section-"Making Safe Contact" /CQ Vol. 15:2, Spring/Summer 90]. I was moved by her capacity to put down the ongoing difficulties, reflections, situations, conclusions, etc. of the work. That was great, because just recently in a workshop in May [in Sao Paulo, Brasil) I felt good about teaching, I mean in an ordering way, a kind of organizing in my mind together with people's time or timing how to introduce contact and all of its interaction with energy, physics, dance .. , but it's still so fragile that I'm not able to reflect clearly, or even get at any conclusion. It's like a necessary step of the work and I'm in a very good humour to at least recognize a subtle change and understanding of my teaching. Let's see: people here have never seen the work of contact; to feel better when putting together a small woman with a big man or to allow the men to be together at another time or to let them choose by themselves; to work only on the floor for a few minutes or few days, why?   It's more intuition than knowing. Well! Let's say it's not so complicated, but on the other hand, it is, otherwise I can't know where I am, and it's hard for students to get somewhere. I also feel that you have to teach & practice a few movement skills just like any language so you have a minimum to be able to work with and to allow the dance & principles to come out and to develop by themselves. I think Elliot's right when she says that the great thing is to create an atmosphere for the work, (but at the same time not to feel responsible or guilty if things work or not), but to create an atmosphere I need to be calm. It means that I can be lost, but if I'm not calm in my heart and mind it's not easy. It's about having love, to be in love and with love, but love is not enough if I'm not clear about what I want to do, to give, to receive, to look for or NOT. The way that she used to get her experiences down on paper helped me a lot. I've also appreciated her openness and courage to put out and share with people her fears and angers. Tica Lemos Brasilia, Brasil

Title: SHELF LIFE
Abstract: This is a book review of Cynthia J. Novack's "Sharing the Dance: Contact Improvisation and American Culture." The review highlights Novack's anthropological perspective on contact improvisation, examining its relationship to American culture from the 1960s onward, including its encoding of sexuality, spontaneity, and gender roles.
Text: Sharing the Dance: Contact Improvisation and American Culture. Cynthia J. Novack. Madison, Wisconsin: The University of Wisconsin Press, 1990. 114 North Murray Street, Madison, Wisconsin 53715. Sharing the Dance, by Cynthia J. Novack, is subtitled Contact Improvisation and American Culture. She has posed her deep investigation of contact improvisation as a lens through which she shapes her view of American culture from 1960 onward. She holds that we can have a perspective on what we do in contact improvisation by contrasting it with other political and dance phenomena from the period, and by measuring contact history with cycles of other cultural events which are familiar to usthe "demise" of the 1960s counterculture, the effect of an affluent economy turning meager, the flings of youth leading to more measured steps. Cynthia J. Novack is an anthropologist, dancer/choreographer and teacher. With striking intelligence and patience, she writes from all these perspectives in this book. To save you any inconvenience, I quote the blurb on the back cover of the book: "   The book examines the ways in which contact improvisers (and their surrounding communities) encoded sexuality, spontaneity, and gender roles, as well as concepts of the self and society in their dancing. While focusing on the changing pr_actice of contact improvisation through two decades of social transformation, Novack's work incorporates the history of rock dancing and disco, the modern and experimental dance movements of Merce Cunningham, Anna Halprin, and Judson Church, among others, and a variety of other physical activities, such as martial arts, aerobics, and ~rest ling. "Novack concludes her study with a discussion of contact improvisation both as an icon of the "end of the sixties" and as an ongoing dance practice which continues to demonstrate the subtle ways in which movement represents and creates culture." Steve Paxton

Title: Roll. Gerry Overington. by Steve Paxton
Abstract: This article explores rolling on the floor as a way to examine structural forms in the body, particularly the intertwining spirals found in walking. It describes different types of rolls, including spiral rolls and crescent rolls, and their effects on the spine and muscles.
Text: Rolling on the floor provides a way to examine structural forms in the body. An example of such a form lies in the intertwining spirals noticed in the play of left and right and forward and back basic to normal walking. photos by Kate Mount

Title: Right-left walk. Steve Paxton.
Abstract: This article describes the spiral movements in the body during walking and how these movements can be exaggerated to create spirals. It also discusses how these spirals can be translated to floor work, leading to different types of rolls.
Text: (cont'd) If you take a step and continue the oppositions in the body to an extreme, you can see two spirals circling around each other. And if the next step is taken to an extreme, the spirals reverse. Left-right walk. Steve Paxton. Right side moving around support of the left. Left side moving around support of the right.

Title: Helix legs. Gerry Overington.
Abstract: This article describes how the spiral form of walking can be taken to the floor to create a coil that can be rolled with little effort. It discusses the initiation of energy in spiral rolls and how weight changes within the body facilitate movement.
Text: When this form is taken to the floor the energy of the extreme twist of the body promotes a coil which can be rolled with no apparent effort. This is done with the spiral initiated either at the top with the hands and arms, or with the toes, feet, and legs at the bottom. In these spiral rolls, a single initiation of energy flows into the most extreme spiral the body can achieve and the roll continues as long as the shape is maintained. The movement stems from changes of weight inside the body as different surfaces of the spirals are rolled upon. The less extreme alternating helixes of walking also permit movement initiation from different places in the body, but in practice just a few such options are integrated into an habitual walk. The other options wither with disuse. Turning this basic form onto its side causes many parts of the body to extend and take responsibility for the roll.

Title: Helix arms. Steve Paxton.
Abstract: This article describes crescent rolls, a set of five rolls where the body maintains an arced shape while rolling on the floor. It details the different variations of crescent rolls and their effects on stretching and toning various parts of the body.
Text: (cont'd) Crescent roll: head lifted. Steve Paxton. Head and feet lifted. Middle lifted.

Title: Two moments in the 'Simone Forti' rolls.
Abstract: This article describes crescent rolls, a set of five rolls where the body maintains an arced shape while rolling on the floor. It details the different variations of crescent rolls and their effects on stretching and toning various parts of the body.
Text: Crescent rolls come in 5 varieties. The premise: a body shaped like a banana, arced from top to toe, and maintaining this exterior shape relative to gravity while rolling along the floor. In this form the left and right sides of the body stay closer to parallel than in the previous spiral form. The rolling choices are: head lifted, head and feet lifted, middle lifted. And two in which the whole body is stretched along the floor: rolling toward the points of the arc or toward the bend of it. These rolls are viewed as a set because of their external form; the coordinations for their execution are different as the relationship of the shape to gravity changes. The first roll provides a good stretching for the short muscles at the joining of the sides of the pelvis to the upper torso, and a good stretch for the abdominals. The arms are used on the floor, so great strength is not needed in the lower back. The second and third rolls are outstanding whole-body toners, and are fairly advanced work, muscularly. The last two were spotted in the dance works of Simone Forti, the American choreographer, and don't require as much strength, but provide one of the unusual coordination problems in the annals of human locomotion. If coming forward, the roll is toward the points. If moving backward, toward the bend.

Title: Exploring discs. Teaching by to11ch. Gerry Overington & Steve Paxton.
Abstract: This article discusses the benefits of exploring form through nine different rolls, emphasizing the unusual sensations and spinal workout they provide. It also highlights the importance of touch in teaching these rolls, particularly for blind individuals, and how they can guide sighted individuals through kinesthetic understanding.
Text: This article is excerpted from a forthcoming writing by Touchdown Dance, a project working for extended mobility for the blind, directed by Steve Paxton and Ann Kilcoyne, Devon, England. Exploring form in these nine rolls has several advantages. Fear of falling does not interfere with learning. The sensations found in the exercise are unusual: we rarely notice these singular forms in our daily movement, but in these rolls we can hardly miss the basic forms-the helix and the turning crescent. These forms give the spine itself a workout, as well as the muscles and attachments of the spine. The point is that there are sensations in the body of the spine itself, in the discs. This rather dull lot of feelings along the length of the spine can best be identified in the lumbar, where a vague pinching sensation may accompany the backbend. Once the quality of sensation in the spine is found, it can be noticed in the course of the rolls. It then begins to make new sense to speak of 'the spine'. A prerequisite to this discovery is relaxation, as tension masks sensation and maintaining it requires wasted effort. Once the feeling in the spine has been located, one can more accurately stretch the circling arms through the upper spine at the center of the back, or align points on the spine to discover new postures. Sighted people start to learn these rolls by seeing them. For those having difficulty in translating what they've seen into what to do, handson is most useful, with verbal aids. Blind people I work with learn the rolls by feeling with their hands and are further assisted by hands-on and verbal aids. When the blind then direct the efforts of the sighted, they tend to teach by hand. They convey the principles, and the sighted person can visualize what is meant. In teaching, one can transmit the basic spiral forms visually, verbally, and kinesthetically. Each of these transmissions is effective, but touch is the keystone of the work. *

Title: GIANT STEPS Contacting Children with Neuro-lntegrative Dysfunction
Abstract: Judy Stone describes her experience teaching contact improvisation at Giant Steps, a school for children with neuro-integrative dysfunction. She details the innovative approach of the school, the techniques used to establish rapport with students, and the positive learning experiences that resulted from introducing the children to contact improvisation.
Text: From September 1989 until June 1990, I taught contact improvisation at Giant Steps, the Canadian Institute for Neuro-lntegrative Development. This Montreal school is known throughout North America for its innovative approach. The director, Darlene Beringer, is open to many new ideas and was daring enough to include contact dance as part of the school curriculum. To this end, Ms. Beringer assembled a team of three experienced contact dancers: Ian Talbot, who had been working at the school for several years, Marie-Renee Tremblay, and myself, Judy Stone. In December, Ian was obligated to leave because of other commitments, and he was replaced by Fiona Meyer. Giant Steps services children between the ages of 4 and 13 with developmental delay, sensory and motor dysfunction, aphasia, autism, apraxia, genetic disorders and specific syndromes. Techniques of synchronization and neuro-integrative patterning used in music therapy and occupational therapy form the basis of the school's approach. Ms. Beringer recognized that contact improvisation uses both vestibular movement patterns and proprioception within an improvised context that is readily adaptable to individual needs and abilities. We began by establishing a rapport with our students using massage, manipulation and simple weight exchanges. For the first few weeks we paired each child with an adult As the months passed and comfort levels increased, the children worked with each other more and more. Our sessions were structured much like an adult's contact class with a warm-up followed by directed exercises around a theme (falling, rolling, supporting weight, following a point of contact), then dancing (duets, round robins, solos), and ending with a warm down. Sixty children came to us in groups numbering from three to nine. Each group had very different abilities and we adapted the classes accordingly. Two adults would demonstrate an exercise while the children watched. Some were aided by our simultaneous verbal descriptions while others could imitate our actions without necessarily understanding our words. Levels of verbal and physical prompting that were necessary also varied immensely. There were enthusiastic students who quickly took the exercises and made them into their own dances with intriguing variations. Even the children who needed to be guided through each step appeared to enjoy the new movement sensations. Many children responded to concrete imagery. We gave names and a little story to each exercise (see examples). When we began to have round robins, children would at times lose focus and we would use the names of exercises as anchors to recall their attention to the dance. "Look at Emilie, she's being a rock. How can you dance with that rock?" "It looks like Francois is being a house. Can you be a snake and slither through his house?" These movement suggestions helped to overcome the impasses of short attention spans, motivational lapses or perceptual disorganization. Everyone involved in our dance program was surprised and delighted by the progress which the students made. Children who were initially quite tactilephobic began to relish the physical contact that they received in our class. Passive or withdrawn children were soon initiating contact and by the end of the year joyous dances filled with mutual respect and recognition developed between children who had previously shown little interest in each other. I myself was amazed at the wide variety of positive learning experiences that came about through introducing the children to contact improvisation. This dance form has been an incredibly effective tool in reaching these sometimes unreachable children. A SAMPLE OF EXERCIS~ THE ROCK One child would be the support, or "rock," on hands and knees. Her partner would find various ways to give weight. We would offer suggestions such as: sitting or lying on the rock; sliding off the rock; being snow melting on the rock; finding various ways to be on or near the rock as it moved about the room; finding ways to be supported by two rocks; somersaulting from a rock then crawling underneath your partner to become the support for her. Exercises would usually be introduced with an adult partner, the adult in this case being first the rock, then the weight giver. When the children became comforta.ble giving and taking weight they would then work with each other. Judy Stone with students at Giant Steps. 218 CQ/CI Sourcebook Volume17 1992 FOOT DANCE BRIDGES WITH SNAKES We did dances with different body parts. Foot dances were a favorite that children at any level could do. Snakes would slither under a roomful of wavering bridges. THE RAIN MASSAGE Fingers and loose fists were gentle raindrops falling on the backs of children resting on the floor. The teachers in the school who gave so much to the children were pleasantly surprised to be receiving relaxing massages from their charges. The children also enjoyed massaging each other. THE CHAIR One child lies on their back, knees over chest, feet up, forming a chair which gently pushes into the air anyone daring enough to sit upon it. Variations: leaning against the chair with different body parts. This exercise brought smiles to the often impassive faces of severely autistic children. THE MONKEY IN THE TREE A monkey climbs a human tree in search of imaginary bananas. Many earthbound children were motivated to climb to unexpected heights. THE HOUSE Several children join together forming a multi-level structure. Others take tums entering, exiting and otherwise exploring the house.* If you have any questions or would like to share your work with us please write or call: Judy Stone, 4039 Des Erables, Montreal, PQ, H2K 3V7, Canada; (514) 524-0280.

Title: A CONTACT PROJECT WITH YOUNG CHILDREN
Abstract: Lauren Shapiro Raker discusses her experience using contact improvisation with young children to enhance their modes of expression. She describes the evolution of "Pretzel" dances with specific rules and the use of a basic notation method to guide the children's movements. The project culminates in the children creating their own music to accompany their dances.
Text: Improvisation is the most natural form of movement for the young child who is beginning to dance. They move freely through suggestions of various images   readily becoming the "butterfly," "cloud," or "tiger" that is suggested. Throughout my twenty years of teaching experience with young children, I have employed improvisation as a method to enhance the children's modes of expression. Although they occasionally made contact with another student (partner) during the course of an exercise, it often seemed uncomfortable, or took on the appearance of social dance styles. The movement then became more contrived and less free. Five years ago, I began to introduce contact improvisation to the children. We began gradually with very specific rules. What evolved were some very elaborate and interesting shapes, which we dubbed "Pretzel" dances. The children loved the procedure as well as the results. We have continued to evolve these dances over the years by adding and eliminating the rules of design. In the most basic form, a group of youngsters takes independent space on the floor. They must be close enough to the other students to touch them. Upon hearing certain musical cues, i.e., the beat of a drum, they must contact a neighbor with any one part of their body. Upon hearing the second cue, they make contact with another child or the original child using a differen' part of their body. This method continues until the children are entwined in an elaborate design. The design usually breaks apart with a final musical cue (i.e., the ping of a triangle), and then the group is ready to begin a new design. Very often when I watch their pieces evolve, it seems that I am viewing them through a giant kaleidoscope. Recently we attempted a new version of our contact "game." I decided to explore the use of a basic notation method. A pattern might be written like this: START: 1, 2, 3,   1, 4, 3,   2, 0, 2, END. These numbers indicated how many parts of their bodies should make contact with another dancer or dancers. By writing this series of numbers on the wall, the children viewed them as they moved. The contacts flowed more smoothly, and the transitions occurred at the individual pace of each child. They no longer only made contact at the specific beat of a drum. The results were less entangled and intertwined, but far more interesting and sophisticated. The final step of these contact projects at this point, has been to add our own music. Using simple percussion instruments, the children take turns being the musicians and the dancers. Although there seems to be a rigid formality to the method, it appears to have captured even the most reluctant and inhibited of the children to participate in the creation of joyful and creative design.* Students in Contact Project at Town School, NYC. CQ/CI Sourcebook 219

Title: A COMMON SENSE
Abstract: Anne Kilcoyne and Steve Paxton discuss their contact improvisation workshops for the visually challenged. They describe the physical and emotional challenges faced by blind individuals and how contact improvisation can help them overcome these challenges. The article includes a case study of a blind man named Peter who found a new level of experience through contact improvisation.
Text: Peter is big and burly and in his fifties. He has virtually no sight. having been badly injured in a traffic accident His sight loss was instantaneous and irreversible. He could no longer work at his trade; he no longer had an income and he felt very depressed He came to the contact improvisation workshop with some trepidation-he was not "artsy craftsy" and thought dancers were a peculiar and probably effeminate breed However, he thought he would give it a chance as a friend of his had spoken very warmly about the workshop. Having been athletic and interested in sports when he was sighted, he experienced no difficulty with the work. Over the five days, he began to enjoy himself, giving and receiving massage and learning to build up the skills that are basic to contact improvisation. Towards the end of the workshop Peter was asked to contribute to some video-based research. At the start of the workshop, blind participants had been recorded walking the length of a gymnasium, finding a chair, sitting on it. and rising from it They were asked to go through the same exercise at the end of the workshop; thus we are able to record objective changes in posture and gait Peter had in fact missed the initial session as he had joined the workshop late. He is a very humorous man, and realising the reasons behind the exercise he treated us to his version of a "bad walk" as he put it What he gave was a hilarious Chaplinesque performance of the exercise: holding his cane ahead of him, he stumbled his way forward through the vast dark territory of the unseen gym, the blind cane then became a fencing sword and he fought his way through a duel with an imaginary foe. Victorious, his stick transformed into a horse which he sat astride and whipped into a gallop to the far end of the gym. Turning, he lurched drunkenly back towards the chair which he could not see but sensed the position of. Having reached it. he failed to sit on it. somersaulting his way through falls; and ultimately, threading his cane through the Volume 17 1992 back of the chair and hoisting i~ aloft over his shoulders, he trudged off into the proverbial sunset. Peter had found improvisation and performance. When the workshop finished Peter broke down and wept with deep grief. It was the first time since his accident, several years before, that he had cried. His tears were not only for his loss of sight but also tears of appreciation at having found a new level of experience. This experience opened up the future for him. He has since entered the Royal National College, in Hereford, England and qualified to become a masseur. He has found direction and now expects to combine his new-found skills in massage with his old interests in sports and sports injuries. Peter is one of many blind people who have come to contact improvisation workshops that we have developed in England over the last five years. These workshops are designed to extend the movement vocabulary and creative experience of the visually challenged and the professionals that work with them. The blind who have danced with us come from all walks of life. Some have been blind from birth, others have lost their sight in adulthood through degenerative diseases, accidents and diabetes. The professionals include social workers, recreation officers, teachers and dancers who work to make dance accessible to disabled people; most of the professionals are sighted but a few of them are visually impaired. If you are born without sight there are profound implications for your physical development as well as your social and intellectual/cultural life. The blind person is inhibited from freely moving from one place to another by the fear of falling over or bumping into things and by a confusion in spatial orientation. Those who are congenitally blind spend much of their lives at home, sitting or lying down. The paucity of the everyday movements of walking, sitting down and getting up means that the muscles in their feet and legs do not develop their potential. Through lack of use, their muscles are underdeveloped, flaccid and poorly toned. These characteristics are also reflected in posture; the torso is often limp, the head hanging forward. The essential movement needs of the body are often met by a gently repetitive rocking motion in the seated Volume 17 1992 position. This rocking is generally discouraged by family and professionals as it is considered to be a 'blindism '-i.e., a movement or gesture which is not found in the sighted world and which is seen as a stigma. In those people who have seen for some years but lost their sight in adult life there is another set of bodily responses. These people do not generally exhibit blindisms. Their gestural vocabulary is consonant with that of the dominant sighted culture, but their loss of sight prohibits normal everyday movement. The trauma and anxiety which accompanies visual loss is reflected in a chronic level of muscular tension which is so habitual as to make muscular relaxation a forgotten experience. they, too, stand and wait for someone with sight to guide them to another seat in another room where they can safely 'park' their bodies. Although there are some programmes of physical education available to the blind these are mostly purely functional and often mechanised. For example, there is tandem cycling, or jogging a course that is marked out by a rope which the blind person can hold onto, or the treadmill or weight lifting machines that are available in a modern gym. Whilst a few of the visually impaired make great efforts to keep themselves in trim by going to the gym, they generally report a sense of boredom with the repetitive and socially isolated nature of many of the exercise regimes open to them. Contact improvisation seemed an ideal activity for the blind, based as it is in the ·natural physics of movement, in human communication, and focused on a touch-based learning path rather than a 'seeing and copying' mode endemic in so many dance classes. The inherently democratic nature of contact improvisation makes it a particularly good form for the so-called disabled who deal continuously with disabling social attitudes and relationships. For example, Janee, who is partially sighted, had left the workshop with Rose, a sighted arts worker. They were sitting in a car at a petrol station when Rose was approached by a lady who Anne traces the pathway on Peter, from sacrum, under shoulders, underneath arms to the little linger. Sitting allows one to feel the sitzbones. Carollne (l.), is · extending ring and small lingers, feeling the connection from center-of-weight (pelvis) along the same path. Title: Letter from a Touchdown Dance workshop participant
Abstract: A participant in a Touchdown Dance workshop describes the profound after-effects of the experience, including vivid dreams and a heightened sense of spatial awareness. The participant also discusses the challenges of responding to sighted imagery and the importance of verbal descriptions that refer to familiar tangible objects.
Text: Dear Anne, I will try to be articulate about my perceptions of the Contact Dance workshop I attended in the spring, though I don't consider putting thoughts into words to be my natural way of expressing myself. The workshop seems to have had quite a profound effect on me, and perhaps you will forgive me for starting by describing some of its after-effects. For a few days I felt quite out of tune with friends and acquaintances. I just wanted to withdraw and relive the experience, and one of the first things I did was to get out my sketch pad and draw a complete sequence of all the movements and partnerships I learned in the workshop; I found that I had remembered every single one vividly. When I got to bed, at peace and very relaxed, I had two strange experiences, which I suppose were sort of dreams. I was aware that I was lying inert in the dark. I began to feel as though my head was being gently drawn away from my body; as though some kind of magnetic force was attracting me, and the pull came first from one direction and then another. The sensation was similar to that which we did during the head massage exercise and I felt very elated, but was aware that the force controlling this sensation was not human. I wasn't afraid at this point, and the sensation then faded and the sequence changed. I was aware of standing in a bare room with white walls. I was only conscious of my body from the waist up. While standing in the same spot my body started to make a circular movement from the waist. As I did this I began to get the same feeling as before; that a magnetic force was drawing me upwards by the head. I felt myself rising upwards gaining speed and I could see the ceiling getting closer. I remember feeling slightly afraid at this point because I wasn't quite in control and I thought I might hit the ceiling, but I didn't, and just floated round and round the edges of the room as though on the end of a 222 CQ/CJ Sourcebook piece of elastic, til the intensity of the sensation woke me up. This experience was all the more unusual for me because I am not religious; haven't done any form of meditation; hadn't had any alcohol and wasn't high on anything. It's only happened on that one occasion so far and I would like to find out if other people who've done the workshops have had any kind of after-effects like this? There may be a connection between this experience and a discovery I made some years ago while undergoing some formal mobility training with the long cane, under blindfold. Much to my instructor's bewilderment, I found that I could sense objects from between 25 to 50 yards away without making contact with the long cane. I did this without sight or sound cues. I just felt a strong sense of claustrophobia when there were solid objects in front of me, and relief and elation when there were wide open spaces. Since my mobility instructor's objective was to teach me to detect obstacles with the cane, he was rather skeptical of this ability, and set me many challenges. He hadn't encountered this in other clients, but did reveal that a similar thing was referred to as a rare phenomenon in his profession, and was known as "Shadow Sound." I disagree with this description: I don't think it is a "rare phenomenon" ; nor has it got anything to do with "sound." I think it has more to do with a primitive instinct for self-preservation and dealing with the unknown, which is dormant in most people, and only comes into play when they are deprived of one of the other senses. Anyway, I return to my observations about the workshop. An element of the workshop that appealed to me was that the only "props" we needed were human partnerships. Through the variety of exercises and partnerships I was involved in during the workshop, I was able to initiate more ambitious shapes and movements, confident that I would get the support to carry them through as well as anticipating and supporting my partner's intentions. I think the basic structure of the workshop was sound, and there were only two instances where I experienced difficulty; though both of these were resolved during the five day period. The first was trying to respond, from the perspective of a person with visual impairment, to the mainly sighted imagery used to describe some of the shapes we were attempting to create, e.g., I didn't understand Steve's reference to "a double helix," which we were supposed to achieve when we were doing the rolling exercise. As I suggested at the time, verbal description is necessary, but could be more effective if it referred to familiar tangible objects. (I have since found that I have a sea shell which is eroded by the sand, and forms the exact shape I was trying to make.) I think this point is important as I don't want to be in positions where I have to rely too heavily on a sighted partner's interpretation. The second occasion I experienced difficulty occurred when one of my sighted partners matched me up with a visually impaired person for the next sequence in the workshop. I found that I couldn't get any rapport or positive contact going. Title: STILL MOVING BABY CONT~CT
Abstract: Sandra Jamrog discusses Baby Contact, a method for helping babies and parents bond through movement and stillness. She describes her experiences experimenting with Baby Contact since her daughter's birth, incorporating elements of Body-Mind Centering, Contact Improvisation, and Kestenberg work. The article highlights the benefits of this practice for both parents and babies, including enhanced attunement, sensory stimulation, and the development of movement skills.
Text: I am a Childbirth/Parent Educator and a Teacher of Body-Mind CenteringTM. One of the aspects of my work is helping babies and parents "bond." I feel Baby Contact is a perfect way to help parents attune with their babies. I have been experimenting with Baby Contact since my thirteen year old daughter Jenny was born. During the summer of '77 I was working at the School for Body-Mind Centering™ and was fortunate to have had some colleagues invite me to join in some Contact Improvisation. I was fascinated. I was pregnant for the third time and had danced and performed through all my pregnancies. Doing Contact Improvisation while I was pregnant felt like a trio (me, the fetus, and the other adult). In addition to exploring BMC and Contact Improvisation, I was also discovering the Kestenberg work, a method of observing movement and working with child/parent movement interactions. Influenced by these three bodies of work, I was experimenting with dialoguing with the fetus in all sorts of ways: moving in the same rhythms that the fetus within me was moving; initiating the movement; following the fetal movements; leading from the uterus; vibrating the amniotic fluid with sound and movement; letting the weight of the uterus or the fetus adjust my relationship with gravity; as well as anything else that happened as a result of the continually changing dialogue within my body. After Jenny was born, the natural continuation was to keep dancing, with her on my body, using the same dialogue-sometimes following, sometimes leading; two energies creating one ever-changing form, contacting each other through movement and stillness. My Baby/Parent group began experimenting with Baby Contact, first the parent lying and breathing with their baby, just listening to their baby; then feeling their baby initiate movement, then responding in micro-movements to their baby's movement initiation. We began very gently and very carefully, combining initiating movement and responding to movement, moving and receiving, being motor and sensory. Eventually we built the micromovements into larger movements that moved through space. With Contact one needs to be constantly feeling and re-evaluating, ready to instantaneously respond as well as instantaneously act; one needs to be open to receiving as well as giving; responding as well as initiating. That balance of give and take, in and out, is an important attribute for parents as well as babies. In addition, in Baby Contact, babies have the power to move the environment, of initiating movement through space, of being responded to physically, of initiating change. They also have the experience of incorporating another person's rhythm, of internalizing another person's movement and perhaps even developing it. They also have the opportunity to see the world from many spacial perspectives, stimulating their vestibular system. My students and I have enjoyed Baby Contact and have learned things we could have learned in no other way. We have had.the opportunity to blend our adult bodies with our babies' bodies into one movement.* Baby Contact. photo: Sandra Jamrog

Title: DANCES WITH WHEELS
Abstract: This article describes a weekend movement workshop called "Dances With Wheels" held in Seattle, Washington. The workshop, organized by Charlene Curtiss, brought together people of varying abilities to learn and practice contact improvisation under the guidance of Alan Ptashek and Bruce Curtis. The event culminated in performances and a "jam" session for the participants.
