Title: EMERY
Abstract: This article profiles Emery Blackwell, a disabled dancer who uses Contact Improvisation to explore movement, freedom, and acceptance. It discusses his experiences with DanceAbility workshops, the challenges and rewards of dancing with both able-bodied and disabled individuals, and the power of dance as a teaching tool.
Text: n he was growing up, he'd get around by crawling on his knees everywhere. The floor, the lawn, the gravel, it didn't matter. Then he got a manual wheelchair. He'd propel himself around by pushing himself backwards, looking over his right shoulder to see where he was going. As a result, the skin on his knees went soft, no longer calloused, making him unable to crawl over the ground without pain. Now, that was a disability. At the age of 18, Emery got a power wheelchair and suddenly had to change his body habits and look forward in order to avoid crashing into walls and running over people. For the first time in his life~ he felt disabled. It was a change from old habits. He had to adjust to it. Feeling disabled was not an always kind of thing; it would occasionally pop into Emery's head, but mostly, he was thinking about bike riding. After he was introduced to the bike, he spent some time struggling, barely able to get around the block. With practice and time, he now tours around the state, on weeklong treks, zooming downhill at 35 miles an hour. What Emery loves about bike riding is the same thing he's learning to love about dance. Freedom, acceptance and being in control independently. Contact Improvisation has made some changes in Emery's life. Physically, he has learned to move more smoothly with better balance. On bike rides, Emery used to push hard and with jerky movements to propel his bike on the 40 or more mile treks. Now, his pacing is softer, smoother and more powerful A clear demonstration of his capability at better balancing happened in the bathtub. He fell and his body used the new dance techniques of rolling he had learned. A safe landing. He learned to have more fun. Actually, that's not true. Emery always has fun. He learned a new way to have fun when he began dancing. One of the major commitments Alito and Emery have in their dance work is to have fun as they are dancing. If they are having fun, this will telegraph to the audience who will be able to relax more and have fun with them. Emery discovered the power of the unspoken word-the speech of dance and movement that tells stories and feelings more completely than the spoken word. Although the main reason Emery dances is for the fun and for the personal experience and satisfaction, he can't avoid the educational aspects of his dancing. Simply because he is disabled, everything he does teaches. Dance, Emery has learned, is a marvelous, positive teaching tool. He will be volunteering his time giving performances in the schools and Alito is working on grant proposals to create a weeklong DanceAbility workshop next year. At the DanceAbility workshops, people have more time to interact with him, Emery notes-to experience him long enough to break through their own mental barriers. Often people start out hesitant or outright reluctant "It is the difficulty understanding my speech, I think, that distresses them the most After they realize I am an intelligent human being, they feel relieved," Emery says. An interesting thing happens for Emery at these workshops. There are people at the workshop that are "more disabled" than he is. And Emery finds that he tends to relate more with the able-bodied participants than with the more disabled. Having to slow his movements down to dance with people with more severe disabilities than he has (and less dance experience), Emery began to understand and have more empathy for able-bodied people who have to slow down their movements to dance with him. Emery forgets he's disabled. At the same time, dancing with ablebodied people makes him realize he is disabled. Makes him aware of the differences. Is that good or bad? Maybe both. It depends on how he's feeling at that moment about himself. If he's in a good mood and feeling good about himself, it's good. If he's tired or feeling less sure of himself, it feels uncomfortable. It is all a part of the learning process. At one jam, Emery danced with Gerry Overington of England. Gerry is blind. Emery had never danced with someone who couldn't take visual cues as to what the next move might be. Now Emery was experiencing what ablebodied people experience when they dance with him: assuming they need to take more responsibility for leading, initiating the movement. This was a somewhat new experience for Emery. His dances have evolved from a passive responding to a more active pursuit and exploration of movement in contact with others in space. But, isn't that what Contact Improvisation is all about? Emery also has gained the personal freedom of acceptance. Among dancers, he is accepted as a dancer. His own normal body movements and speeds are fine just the way they are. You know, it's funny that society has decided to label someone who walks differently or not at all as disabled. Often, it's the so-called "able-bodied" person with fine motor skills, that has disabilities-like not being able to get along well with others, or express their emotions, or feeling unhappy and depressed. When people who are struggling with their own pain see someone physically disabled, they often project their initer feelings of inadequacy and pain onto the disabled person. They latch onto the disabled person, wanting to help them, soothe their supposed pain and make everything all better. The trouble is, it doesn't work. It backfires. Because it's not the disabled person's pain. It's theirs. People often say how it hurts them to hear Emery's knees thump on the floor during his dance, thinking it hurts him. Emery says, "Sure, sometimes it hurts. Mostly, it doesn't. But everything in life costs a little pain. If you want to really help, let me experience my own pain my own way." People at dance workshops are often worried they will hurt Emery, but he's as tough as hickory wood. By being afraid to roll on him or put weight on him, they lessen the dance experience for both of them. Emery tries to tell them it's OK; after they get over their original resistance, Emery gets bounced off the walls and loves it In the workshops, it also happens that people often talk to somebody else when they are talking to Emery, as though they think he is deaf as well as has speech problems. But these are minor annoyances, ones Emery meets with every day of his life. What Emery gains from dance is well worth the difficulties. Dance has widened his circle of friends. Like bike riding, it has given him an opportunity to meet people on an equal basis. Dance speaks for him, breaking down barriers and walls like so many tinker toys.* This article is 'based on conversations between Emery Blackwell, Alita Alessi and the author in March, 1991.

Title: THE MOVING BODY an integrated movement course
Abstract: Alan Ptashek discusses "The Moving Body," an integrated movement course at UC Berkeley that he co-taught with Bruce Curtis. The course used Contact Improvisation to explore personal, social, and political issues related to disability, and aimed to create a supportive environment where students of all abilities could move and interact with one another.
Text: Exposed to Gravity workshop, Berkeley. by Alan Ptashek In the Fall of 1990, with Bruce Curtis, co-founder of The Exposed To Gravity Project, I began teaching a course at The University of California at Berkeley called The Moving Body. Having facilitated movement workshops for disabled and non-disabled adults, adolescents and children for five years, Bruce and I were interested in bringing our work into the university setting where movement exploration could be sustained throughout a semester-length period of time. The city of Berkeley bas one of the most visible and active disabled communities in this country. At the university, several organizations are centered around the creation of programs and services for both the public and student disabled populations. Despite the efforts of independent recreational sports programs on campus, disabled students lacked support and inclusion from the Physical Education or Dance Departments. While issues such as liability and accessibility were often heard, there clearly were no university instructors who had the orientation and skills with which to develop a viable course where people of different abilities could move and interact with one another. The Exposed To Gravity Project was given county and campus organizational support and we designed and implemented a course through the Department of Dance and Dramatic Arts. Undergraduate and graduatelevel students would receive academic credit and provisions were made for allowing public participation as well. Few administrators nor faculty fully understood the history or scope of our work and they had no precedent for a course of this nature from any other college or university in the country. With a class of twenty five students, we had an even ratio of those with and without physical disabilities. Students were majoring in and doing graduate studies in dance, theatre, psychology, anthropology, social welfare and public health. Disabilities included multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy, spina bifida, polio, arthritis and spinal-cord related injuries resulting in paraplegia and quadriplegia. Discussing disabilities as limitations and differences that are not always apparent, several people in the class considered themselves as having "hidden disabilities," such as chronic fatigue syndrome. As in all of our past workshops, there were mixed feelings of excitement, caution, confusion and an appreciation for new possibilities. As a movement practice, Contact Improvisation has been at the center of our work, providing a coherent physical language for all participants. The focus on physicality and sensation established a ground for the stimulation and discussion of personal, social and political issues that became immediately relevant and integral to The Moving Body. This course is one that feeds into areas that are societal, clinical, bio-medical, theoretical, educative, psychological, artistic, performanceoriented and, largely, improvisational. Steven E. Brown, in his article, "Creating a Disability Mythology," adds what may be another component area of the course, or an entire container holding all of the before-mentioned areas. He says: "Language, humor, music, stereotypes, history, heroes. Each of these shared experiences comprise elements of a culture. People with disabilities are beginning to recognize that we, as a group, have been developing each of the aforementioned topics into our own culture-a disability culture. I am convinced that every community harbors many heroes with disabilities. I believe it is time to work on the development of a disability mythology. Myth is more accessible than a documented history of events; myth permits us to be creative and expand our tale into a story to be repeated and retold for generations, a form understood by every other culture." We live in a culture that holds strict definitions and value judgements about what it sees as moving and not moving. With so much of daily motion and perception dictated by task, function and particular examples of productivity, movement at deeper levels than external appearances are less valued, ignored, and, at worst, unperceived. How we are being seen by others influences our self-image, presence and movements in the world. In our classes, I feel that we were creating new layers of a collective story, a body politic or body mythology. Myths take shape in a ritualized space. Several guest teachers (Dance and Drama Therapist, Bronwyn Warren; Feldenkrais teacher, Lawrence Goldfarb; and Dance Therapist, Neala Haze) were invited to present their work during the semester. Neala facilitated a session in Authentic Movement. Having each student move with eyes closed, "witnessed" by the group, was a beautiful and evocative ritual space. We were able to appreciate the most subtly articulated movements of each person, sensing and referring to our own bodies for the depth of response we gave one another. The experiential practice of the course was augmented with readings on dance, performance history, body systems, developmental movement, perception, sensory awareness, somatic therapies, communication theories and the use of touch in human experience. Students kept journals and papers were part of the requirements for academic credit. Many of the early classes brought forth the awkwardness and anxiety around physical touch between disabled and non-disabled partnering. It is very common for non-disabled people to feel hesitant and fearful of having physical contact with a person in a wheelchair or one whose physical form is shaped and moves differently than their own. Often it is assumed that the disabled person is brittle, in pain or umesponsive to being touched. In the class, students were strongly encouraged to express their needs, physical functioning and capabilities to one another. This exchange of personal information helped to relax them and elicit trust of an improvised and collaborative spirit. When encouraged to leave their wheelchair or crutches through their own movement or with assistance, the initial experiences of many disabled students (and of the non-disabled assistant) ranged from extreme disorientation and vulnerability, to pleasure and intense joy. A contained and safe environment in which to express feelings is very important in this context. The process of dialoguing after dancing allowed for us to speak from changes in self-image and self-organization with increased awareness, sensitivity and a mutual regard for one another as moving, embodied beings in the world Our learning environment carried as much influence as any of the specific skills for falling and supporting weight. Deane Juhan, in his book Job's Body (Station Hill Press, 1987), conveys a layer of this learning environment from a physiological understanding: "The process is anything but random or trial and error. It is highly specific, and it is the periphery which helps to organize the connections in the central nervous system, not an organized central nervous system which reaches out to innervate the periphery. It suggests that the use of touch and sensation to modify our experience of peripheral conditions exerts an active influence upon the organization of reflexes and body image deep within the central nervous system." Clearly, not all of the class participants came with the same intentions and interests. Most students, both disabled and non-disabled, loved the freedom to play and seek new physical forms, to feel themselves buoyant and resilient, fearless and beautiful in their dance. In the past year, I've been facilitating groups and workshops for professionals who work with or wish to extend their practice to physically disabled men and women. While working with movement and somatic practitioners, the focus is on how we make contact with ourselves while touching, supporting and moving with someone who has a physical disability. We look at ways to establish more of a peer relationship. This process is a risky one. Conventional and traditional techniques are challenged, while mutual dependency and the unknown are brought into the relationship. This is a process that medical science has little familiarity with. The impact of this course as expressed through responses from the students and faculty of The Moving Body strongly indicate a need and desire for the continuance of this work in university, clinical, community and artistic settings. * The Moving Body was videotaped and is available to the public (see Dance Map in this issue).

Title: PATHS OF CHANGE notes on contact improvisation in an institutional setting
Abstract: Aat Hougee's lecture, delivered with an improvised performance by Karen Nelson and KJ Holmes, explores the relationship between improvisation, education, and institutional settings. Hougee reflects on his experiences in dance education, the challenges of using language to discuss non-verbal art forms, and the importance of sharing risks and valuing both successes and struggles in improvised performance.
Text: a lecture by Aat Hougee delivered along with an improvised performance by Karen Nelson and KJ Holmes at the 7th European Contact Teachers Conference Geneva, Switzerland October 28, 1991 First introduction There must be a deeper reason for me standing here and for Karen and KJ being here, with me on stage, at the same time. An important reason is that it will certainly be less boring this way. Probably the best reason. Many of the decisions I have taken in my professional life during the last 17 years seem to have come out of nowhere. I don't dance, I am not an artist. but in my work as an organizer of art. I do try to follow my intuition. This is about the sixth lecture I am giving in collaboration with performers. So it might be time to find out why I have been making that choice. [Karen reading Aat's notes]: ''To learn about dance, I had to fall in love with a dancer, and another one and anoth· er one. I know, it just comes out in words and figures, but I've gone as far as I could. Much too far, but which dancer doesn't ••• " Aat Hougee was co-director of the Modem Dance Department of the State Theaterschool in Amsterdam, Holland (now called the School/or New Dance Development, SNDD),from 1975 to 1989. He currently directs the Center for New Dance Development (CNDO), a department of the College of Arts in Arnhem, The Netherlands, which he co-founded in 1989. These institutions are conservatories, in effect, specializing in new forms of training dancers that have been developing in the U.S. and Europe over the last twenty years. Putting myself in the position of a lecturer means that I will have to use words to communicate my ideas. By using words and using a language that most of us will understand. we tend to create a situation that is quite characteristic for most educational systems: it is based on the presence of those who know, or pretend to know, and those who don't know, or pretend not to know. It is a clear division of roles in which most of our ideas about learning find their roots, but somehow I am strongly under the impression that it is exactly this division of roles that keeps both the person in the role of the knowing as well as those who opt for the not-knowing role, from real learning. [Kl reading]: "As a kid in school I used to know everything better than everybody else. One day the teacher made clear to me that I didn't know anything. That load has stayed with me through the years and it's only whlle watching tv or reading my mys· teries, that I feel secure. Standing here, somebody will come up with a pin, and the balloon will be gone." When I started preparing my appearance here, some thoughts came to mind that seem to be quite closely related to the work that all of the people here are involved in. It has to do with the sharing mode of Contact Improvisation and about the challenging aspect of improvisation in general. It seems to be a philosophical problem as well: by using language to enter and clarify aspects of a field that goes beyond language, one immediately seems to reduce the level of thinking and perception. What we want to do here is to create a simple situation which might give us some more insight than just words. I prepared a text including several subjects that deal with the relation between and the development of improvisation, education and an institution. At the same time I would like to offer you a second line of thought-personal, emotional, non-rational. Actually it is that line of thought, some flashes coming from my personal life, my motivation and most of all my fears, that might have been crucial for many of the decisions I have made in my career and for most of the thinking I have developed At this point in my life I think it's possible and certainly more objective, if that's what we are going for, to include these aspects; maybe what I'm trying to say is: once we were convinced that we were on our way, finding the truth, but as we struggled along we started realizing that there is no other truth than the one we are creating ourselves. This personal material I handed out to Karen and KJ and they will work with it, confronting themselves, each other and me with material that is probably closer to not knowing and sharing than what I have to say. We agreed on one thing: we won't talk at the same time. Language as a means of communication tends to be quite vulnerable. And then: your role as an audience, you can take it passively if you like, but there will certainly be one slot where you will be openly invited to come in, but if you feel the need to enter before that, or after, go ahead ----.. A second introduction About watching improvisation. When we go to see a set performance we can expect that the choreographer has developed or has tried to develop work in which he/she knows what will happen from beginning to end We, as an audience, know that the choreographer and the performers know, and with that knowledge we will watch the performance. With improvised work, it's different. The improvising performer enters into a process of discovery and although certain parameters might be known, the performer will confront himself with unknown material and will force himself to take decisions through which new, unknown territories will be entered. Sometimes these decisions will lead to clear solutions, but just as often there will be emptiness, a search for solutions. An audience watching this kind of work needs to be in a different state of mind than an audience witnessing set work. When we buy a ticket at the box-office for a set performance, it's almost like buying a product in a store: whether we like the product or not, one thing will be clear-it's supposed to be a complete product, meant to be consumed like it is and we don't have to add something unless the instructions say we have to, but in general, the product is ready for use. An improvised performance will confront us with a very different situation: the ticket we buy at the box-office does not stand for a finished product. Those tickets I would like to call "shares." By buying one, the spectator becomes a share-holder: sharing the risk that the performer is taking, being present at the performance in a state of mind which will equally value brilliant solutions as well as struggle and despair, exciting moments as well as emptiness. (cont'd) Some history [Kl & Karen reading together]: "When I got this job, now 17 years ago, I was nobody, but nobody knew. It was 1975 and having some fantasy would. open doors. I had never seen any dance and after some weeks this Dutch choreographer told me that if I wanted to do something for the dance in Holland, I should quit my job. I had to cry, since what else could I do without a real profession.'' It was 1975 when I entered the field of dance education. I was 29 years old, had no history in dance, but Amsterdam was still a playful city where fantasy was valued as a valid motivation for getting a job. It would be quite an interesting story to lead you thr_ough the development of the Modem Dance Department's program and staff, especially since in that development, in the organization as well as in the curriculum, the anarchistic force and strength of improvisation has been quite striking. But what I think is more interesting here is to look at the development of the students during those years and how that development relates to the material the school has been offering and is offering now: what were the abilities and needs of the students at that time and what has changed since. In 1975 the main educational objective seemed to be: to teach students how to move, how to use their bodies in a more complete way, to change their thinking about movement and dance--that dance is about movement, that it is a creative act, and that copying historical form, suffering and sweating, are not the right ingredients to train a dancer. At that time we would get two types of students. There were those who saw being a dancer as meeting with accepted standards, to be reached through intensive daily training, strongly dominated by imitation of existing form. Most of those students, however, were lacking the discipline to work in such a way, partly due to the times we were living in. Also, those students often had interesting ideas, where the traditional training wouldn't give them the right skill to realize those ideas. There were other students who came without these kinds of traditional expectations about their training. In many cases disappointed with previous theoretical university studies, they were ready to dive into this new world of explorative physical and mental work. Title: C.I. AS PART OF AN INSTITUTIONAL CURRICULUM
Abstract: This article discusses the challenges and possibilities of incorporating Contact Improvisation (CI) into a dance school curriculum, reflecting on the author's experiences at a school in Amsterdam. It explores the initial enthusiasm for CI, the difficulties in establishing it as a regular part of the program, and the eventual integration of its principles into a broader approach to dance training.
Text: It was 1985. The first Contact Teachers Conference took place at the school in Amsterdam. Steve Paxton was there, not attending the conference, but teaching at the school, working with improvisational scores. One afternoon we were standing in the ball and through the window in the door we could see the meeting of the Contact teachers. At that moment, Steve said: "Somehow I would like to open the door and say 'no'." This is an anecdote, maybe I made it up myself, maybe it was really said, but even if I made it up myself, I experienced this as one of these moments that became crucial for the development of my thinking since. When Contact Improvisation entered the school, which happened through an introduction by Pauline de Groot [around 1980] and a little later through workshops taught by David Woodberry, Steve Paxton, Lisa Nelson, Nancy Stark Smith, Christie Svane, Danny Lepkoff and Mark Tompkins, it did add many new elements to our thinking about dance, improvisation and especially about dance-training. Although strongly related to other forms we were using at that time-release-work, alignment and several improvisational approaches-Contact seemed to work as an integrative force as well as offering a very physical alternative approach to training. For us it felt new in terms of vocabulary, and also in the teacher/student relation it offered new exciting forms. It seemed to be open, explorative, daring. I remember that around that time the Trisha Brown Company came to the school for a lecture/demonstration, and several of the more traditional Dutch choreographers were there as well. One of them asked about the training of the dancers, suggesting that they certainly would have a strong traditional background. It was Randy Warshaw who answered the question saying: "No, my only training was Contact Improvisation." It felt like a true moment of Victory! After this first intensive introduction to Contact Improvisation, we considered giving it a more permanent place in the program, not just in the form of intensive workhsops, but on a regular basis. At that moment, looking at the content and format of the work, we were certainly convinced that C.L could offer a creative and realistic alternative to replace at least part of the more traditional technique classes. But the problem was that unfortunately there were no teachers available who would be willing to teach on a regular basis. We did try to organize a regular jam, but that initiative, which came from the students, only lasted for a few weeks. In the years after, we kept bringing guest-teachers to teach C.L workshops. It always would stimulate the enthusiasm in the school, and time after time we tried regular scheduling, using local teachers as well as long-term guests, but it never really succeeded. Contact never took the place that we thought it deserved. An important reason for why this happened can probably be found within C.L itself. C.L has mainly been developed (outside of institutions) in short workshops with students who made a free choice to do this work and who were not overloaded with all the other approaches a school program offers. In those workshops, methods of teaching were developed in relation to the specific demands of short and ()pen worksllop ~ituatic:ms. Cl:>ntact Improvisation was and is not about· a historically defmed form, like most of the other approaches to dance used in education, but about exploration in a democratic and social environment. Students who study within an institutional situation seem to develop a tendency to pass responsibilities on to their teachers: "You tell me what I have to do, I might protest, but if you don't tell me I will protest as well." Work that is taught through this principle will normally fit in easily. Contact Improvisation worked in the school program as long as it was set up as a very special event. The lack of authority within the work made it impossible to use on a regular basis as a replacement for more defined dance forms. All this was quite a while ago. A lot has changed since, especially when we look at the expectations and mentality of the students who join the school. I think by now C.L could have become part of the regular curriculum. But again it didn't. Why? During the first fifteen years of development of the school we collected a whole range of alternative methods to train dancers. Finding out about these methods, bow they can be used in a school situation, how they are relating to each other, etc. took a lot of time and energy. Through regular workshops, C.I. played an important role in this process. Although we managed to learn more and more about these methods, and especially about how to use them in a more efficient way, we realized at a certain point that studying these methods should never become a goal in itself. And so we made the choice to use elements of them in the program in an integrated way, but not to use any of the methods in a pure form as a specialist option. During these years in Amsterdam,. people unconnected to the school would often make remarks about the work being too introverted, not outgoing enough. At that time we would become quite defensive when remarks like that were made. Understandable. New approaches are hardly ever clearly recognized and we were also in the middle of a process of discovering the applications of new methods that certainly did require a reflective attitude. Combining this process-oriented work with more form-oriented traditional methods was something many of the students were asking for: but in our opinion at that point in time, we saw these as being conflicting approaches. I don't think we ever lost our belief in the importance of form, but how to get to that non-historical form, how to develop a way of working that would allow an ongoing process of change in form, that was a new path we had to find first, through exploring all those different methods that connect physical development with the use of imagination. During my last years as a director of the school in Amsterdam, a model was developed where the different alternative "techniques" were having a clear position in the program, through regular classes or through carefully planned intensive workshops. Although it felt as if we had finally reached the point where we were able to give full value to the new work, there were doubts coming up as well. At a certain point, one of the teachers, who had been teaching t'ai chi for many years, retired. Students and staff were asking: "Who will be teaching t'ai chi next year?". My first reaction was-we'll have to find a replacement. My answer was, however: "Nobody. We won't have t'ai chi next year." At that moment I realized that making a program based on subjects would, through time, inevitably lead to a static situation, comparable with the situation most traditional modem dance schools are in, working with methoc:ls and ideas of people who (artistically) died long ago. In our opinion, a school for dance should have one main objective: to train students to be artists who will be able to develop new forms through the use of physical means. An objective like this does not allow any limitations. Methods to develop creative and physical skills are just methods to reach a goal that lies beyond these methods. Contact Improvisation is one of them and any artist using improvisation as a way to discover new form, will not accept the limitations that are part of this method, or of any method, but will in fact include anything that will support this process. Does that mean, since many elements of Contact Improvisation have been defined, that that's the end of C.L? Certainly not. C.L has added several innovative aspects to the training of dancers that cannot be found in other approaches. Part of teaching C.I. is teaching students to find improvisational solutions within a certain frame of thought. At the same time, artistically, we want students to break through existing frames of thought and we want teachers in their teaching to be clear about that. Because that is exactly the lesson we learned from our battle with previous approaches to dance education: the importance of teaching the creative process instead of already-defined form, teaching physical skill through the use of physical and creative imagery, instead of forcing students to go through forms that are no longer connected with this time. Teaching C.I. in these terms means teaching the knowledge that has been developed tl:lrougfi tfils · work, but it means at the same time teaching a mentality that will stimulate a next generation to go beyond the results of that: to fmd new solutions, even if that would mean the disappearance of C.L as it is known to us at this moment. I realize that I am able to say much of what I say because I have been able to work from a relatively comfortable position. Comfortable in the sense that we did get the space and the funding to go through this development. When I look around me in Europe, I see many studios offering workshops. It is great that that happens, but most of the workshops are quite short and they are often not able to offer sufficient continuity for students, nor for teachers. Students are not able to receive government support for their studies and because of fmancial reasons most of the studios are not able to select their students. In an institution there is continuity, for students as well as for staff, and we are able to develop material over a longer period of time. We do have problems as well. Motivation can be one of them, sometimes things can be too easy. It is inevitable that, slowly, alternative approaches to dance will enter most of the existing dance institutions. The question is, however: in what form will that happen and what status will they get. Most institutions work through a simple model in which the teaching is based on a clear image of what a student who has gone through the program should look like. This is not just a matter of style, it is a very specific idea about education. But even institutions like that will, as time goes by, start including new approaches. Not the process-aspect of the new work, but probably the form of it. And since those forms are certainly more interesting and connected with this time than forms they have been using until now, it will be experienced as quite a revolution. However, when it's about improvisational work, it could be like a trap. Improvisation, I think, including C.1, basically is an anarchistic phenomenon. It is about finding new solutions. Changing existing structures and allowing it into a static educational system would mean, if we are not just teaching a form, the beginning of the destruction of that system, unless one would adjust the work itself to make it fit into the system. Within 20 years from now the Dutch National Ballet will include Contact duet forms in their grand gala performances and every ballet school will have their weekly Contact hour. In the year 2010, C.I. will have taken over the place that Graham Technique occupies now. But also in the year 2010 there will be some people struggling somewhere in a small studio, maybe in a few institutions, trying to develop work that goes beyond Contact. And ·if there happens to be a conference that year, I am sure Steve Paxton will appear, look through that window, and whisper "no" again. * One of the reasons why we have been able to develop two schools in The Netherlands has been the fact that we were able, and made the conscious choice, to enter the institutions on a formal level. We gained power, not through the work itself. The work that was done in the studios, the performances we made, hardly ever received any positive recognition. It was on the level of management, educational organization and strategy that we gained respect and established our role. By doing this we managed to create a comparatively safe environment in which the seeds that were planted by many artists in this field could develop. Within this framework there was no need for compromise and especially no need to let the work establish itself in a too recognizable and static form.

Title: JUMPING PARADIGMS
Abstract: This article is a response to Aat Hougee's remarks on truth and tradition in dance, particularly concerning Contact Improvisation. Paxton critiques Hougee's dismissal of traditional dance forms and argues for an inclusive approach that recognizes the value of past techniques in informing and enriching contemporary practices like Contact Improvisation.
Text: JUMPING PARADIGMS a response to Aat Hougee "Once we were convinced that we were on our way finding the truth, but as we struggled along we started realizing that there is no other truth than the one we are creating ourselves." -Aat Hougee Dear Aat, There may be wisdom in this remark. If it were shouted in a crowd I would feel it deeply. But it comes from you in your brown brick ivory tower. I read it through again: .. . no other truth than the one we are creating ourselves," and see that it has a selfserving logic. Also, who are "we," here: The staff and teachers at your school? Them, plus the students? The whole human race? Whomever it may be, suppose someone is off creating a truth of their own; do we then have two equal but different truths? What about those who found truth for themselves in times gone by? What will happen to your truth as future generations create their own? None of these seem durable, singular truths. They seem to be temporary, subjective truths. They seem to be all in our minds. This is not good enough. We know it's all in our minds. The problem is, as it always has been, what to do about it If we are going to be fair about it, one thing we must do about it is not trash the truths of others. Your chilly remarks about traditional forms created by (artistically) dead people through which students must be forced, toss aside the truths of many people, alive and (really) dead. Why? They are not perfect truths, of course, but you are speaking of the dance tradition in the West which every teacher at your institute knows, and which I also studied and which gave me a lot of the basis for Contact Improvisation. Did you imagine that Contact Improvisation dropped out of the sky? You use it in your institute as if it were unconnected from past techniques. But so intertwined is it with modem dance (and modern to ballet) that to dismiss any of the past dance work is to orphan it It eliminates a lot of the training which I assumed would be part of the studies of people who use it Have you noticed that there are no exercises for the feet or legs in the typical contact class? I assumed that the feet, legs, circulatory systems and joints from the past were quite substantial truths and there was no immediate need to replace or erase them. Furthermore, I assumed that these people would also be studying Tai Chi Chuan and Aikido, so I made CI a sort of bridge for Western (traditional) dance students into the unfamiliar Eastern forms. It is an inclusive approach, based perhaps on advice I heard from Pauline Koner, a famous modem dancer: to study as many techniques as I could with integrity. I found this excellent guidance because the real study is the human body, and in the various technical materials from different times and cultures a larger range of information was available to help with perennial problems: awareness, efficiency, longevity. 'To study' meant to get it into the body, not only the mind, which I think requires at least 2 years of regular class in the specific technique to embody the essentials. Is there some way to use 'truth' which is not so subjective? To follow Pauline Koner's advice creates the hope that one's subjective understanding will continue to grow, and more parts of one's body will come under conscious training. It takes one from the narrow confines of preliminary understanding to a broader attitude which can see other truths than one's own (yet continue to see one's own). In the aims you mention, "   to get to that non-historical form, to develop a way of working that allows an ongoing process of change in form," you have a very clear description of the aims of modern dance, founded at the end of the last century. (Happy Centenary, Modem Dance.) Ballet training of foot and leg have been retained, however. You are a pure modem dancer and a bit of a redneck, but these appalling qualities will not be punished. The past doesn't care, and you are surrounded and supported by its gifts, even though you don't seem to realize it Contact Improvisation is not anarchistic, because it is a formal cooperation. It is difficult in academic programs because it has no standard which can be graded, which may be as difficult for the students to understand as for the staff to cope with. It is to be experienced rather than judged, and our modem dance research above suggests that the experience begins to deepen after two years of regular classes and goes on deepening, widening, furthering, whatever. You don't 'get there'. Steve Paxton Vermont

Title: THE FOUNTAIN AT I.D.E.A.
Abstract: This article describes "The Fountain," a method for collective watching and sharing experiences of watching dance or other art forms. It involves watching, writing individual reflections, reading them aloud, and collecting the writings, all without discussion, to foster direct communication between audience and performer.
Text: THE FOUNTAIN AT I.D.E.A. The Fountain is a form for collective watching and reporting one's experience of watching. It is a direct way of sharing with a dancer some evidence of what happened in each of us as we watched her dance. It can be used for listening to music, poetry, looking at a painting, etc., just as well. !rs most important feature is that discussion is not allowed: It has four parts: 1. Watching 2. Writing-immediately, for 3 minutes, in silence 3. Reading-out loud, in a circle, only what you wrote 4. Collecting and printing what was written by Christina Svane In August 1991, feeling a collective need for feedback and support in the new dance and performance community, I conceived of I.D.E.A. (International Dance Exchange, Amsterdam). In October, I collaborated with Dutch choreographer Pauline de Groot to create a platform for such an exchange-monthly I.D.E.A. meetings at Pauline's studio "DE KOE." On the Saturday closest to the middle of the month, I.D.E.A. sponsors an open showing of work and performance/audience interaction structures, followed by informal exchange. At these meetings, I have been developing a form called The Fountain, in which spontaneous reflections are written during a three-minute pause between dances/performances. These spontaneous writings are read, without discussion, at the end of the entire showing. The writings are then gathered and published in the now-bimonthly I.D.E.A LOG, nee I.D.E.A. Newsletter. The Fountain form and its resultant writings constitute the beginning of an on-going experiment central to the purpose of I.D.E.A.: To further the exploration of dance as a collective experience in present time and space, and to create forms through which glimpses of that experience can be passed. Over the course of the first I.D.E.A. meetings, I found that by restricting formal performance feedback to only reading what was written during the three minutes between seeing pieces kept the exchange vital, surprising and full of imagination. To be in communication with, rather than about, what was seen opened up a more direct and creative transference between audience and performer, an exchange in the dimension dance comes from: the imagination. The model is conversation: taking each dance as a statement and responding likewise. The realness of the moment and our mutual share in creating that moment is not conditioned or tamed in any way by calling a dance a "work-in-progress." The moment is still absolute; the future we envision may never arrive; the improvements we seek are secondary. In conversation, someone says to you, "I love you!" You don't respond by telling them they should focus more on their pronunciation. You say, "I love you, too." Or you say something else. So this experiment is a challenge to us to be in the moment with the performer. Although my dream is to have a gathering of all kinds of artists, all kinds of people, the truth remains that we as an audience for each other are primarily dancers. And this is, we are, a gold mine of attention -'-highly developed attention-for each other. As dancers we are skilled as listeners-listening to our sensations, to the moment we are in, to the transformation of energy through the moment, to the level of statement that moves you when you see it. It is this wonderful degree of listening that we bring with us to each Open Showing. The dances are the tips of the icebergs of our experience. They are the part we can show. For complete i

Title: DRAFTING TECHNIQUES
Abstract: Steve Paxton reflects on the challenges of defining Contact Improvisation (CI) and explores techniques for training the senses and consciousness in relation to movement. He discusses the importance of fall consciousness, the role of images in initiating movement, and the need to address gaps in awareness during reflexive actions. Paxton also touches on the cultural influences on physical behavior and the potential for reclaiming suppressed physical possibilities through CI.
Text: by Steve Paxton How awkwardly we are damned if we don't or if we do, I thought to myself after the European Contact Conference in Berlin in 1988. During a lecture event I had been asked, "Just what is Contact Improvisation?" and I had muffed the answer. I was being asked by a woman with an attitude, in the presence of a number of veteran contactors, general public, and students, and I hesitated in order to think how the question should be answered for the whole group. The discussion up to that point had been full of historical revisions, elisions, pointed remarks about Americentric heavy-footedness. In short, the European contactors considered themselves second generation users of this form and wanted to know if they had to go through every step the Americans had gone through; and a few people who had come to the conference without prior experience ju~t wanted an explanation of what this whole thing was and how it was run and how did one improve and get recognition-things like that, which would be reasonable questions in a normal organization. The journal you are now reading had, among other things, been working for 15 years to elaborate on the basic answer to "what is CI?" And as time has gone on, the answer has shifted: away from an experimental dance phenomenon and toward a physical practice allied with a number of complex new body and mind studies. I have come to think of contact improvisation as a physical event best described negativelynot art, not sport, not most of the things which characterize dancing in this century. But I hate to describe things in the negative. It is accurate, but the mystics used it first and I don't like using their devices, which were used to try to inform students in conversations about the ineffable. We, on the other hand, are trying to describe the corporeal. But it is no longer easy to do so. It is, in fact, getting more difficult We now know too much, or think we do; the corporeal seems to be a complexity of social, physical, geometric, glandular, political, intimate, and personal information which is not easily renderable. Once things were relatively simple. I thought I knew how this then-nameless work should not be described. It was to be an improvisation without any ambiguous appeals to the imagination, because I did not know precisely what "the imagination" was (in fact I thought doing this work might educate me to the meanings of imagination, improvisation etc.). For the same reason there should be no mention of sexuality, psychology, spirituality. I would leave these in the hands of the experts and proceed with what seemed more immediate-the senses and the physical body. It did seem that before I could begin to train the senses of students, something had to happen in their brains. In recognizing that we do not begin to move from zero, that first we have a desire or image to launch the system into action, I decided that I had to work in the area of images, though cautiously. The images were to be, well, "real." That is, they were not to be obviously umeal. The effect of obviously unreal images upon the body is fascinating. For example, if you are told to imagine (that word!) your head is filled with a gas that's lighter than air, it is difficult not to respond with neck extension and postural straightening. Why should this be so? It may be related to the sort of mobilization which happens when we are searching for a lost object-first, the thought of the object, then the eye movements, the head turning, standing up, facing in different directions, a tentative walk to a new viewpoint or a possible site of the object All this prompted by the mental image of the desired object The responsiveness of the body to the image is innate, apparently, and with this innate connection the body may be responsive to any image the mind holds. But this is speculation about things which should be the subject of investigations. Without a theory of imagination to support our investigations, it seemed to me, we would have to improvise without fictitious gasses in the head-if that were possible. At any rate, I had only about a week to come to convey the central idea before we, a group of apt students and myself, would be doing it in public at the John Weber Gallery in NYC each afternoon. This time pressure meant that this effect of images on the body would be an essential tool for quickly transmitting the initial states which would let this physical duet/improvisation manifest as directly as possible. The first job was to point out this image-action connection. Then, exercises which demonstrate it in various parts of the body had to be produced. For instance, a mental exercise I gave while people were standing, in which they were to "imagine, but don'tdo it, imagine that you are about to take a step forward with your left foot What is the difference? As you were. Imagine   (repeat). Imagine that you are about to take a step with your right foot Your le~ Right Left. Standing." At this point, small smiles sometimes appeared on people's faces and I suspected they felt the effect They had gone on an imaginary walk and had felt their weight responding subtly (but really) to the image; so when "Standing" was said, the smiles revealed that they got the small joke. They realized that I knew about the effect We had arrived at an invisible (but real) place together. The stand was useful. The basic event was standing and observing the body. This was an exercise in itself, though a very reductive one. What gets exercised in there, inside the standing body, is the habit of observation; a noticeable movement of consciousness through the body. Within this exercise there are encounters with parts of the body which tick along or breathe along as we watch. It clearly seems to be one sub-system, consciousness, examining others. The other sub-systems are not obviously connected to the wandering consciousness, except that the encounter happens in what one calls "my body." The consciousness-as-observer regards the other sub-systems as separate from itself. The consciousness can travel inside the body. It is analogous to focusing the eyes in the external world. There is also an analogue for peripheral vision, which is the awareness of the whole body with senses open. Knowing these things and practicing them are different things, of course. We know far more than we can practice. We had to decide what to practice. One choice was the tiny movements the body makes while standing. I felt they were examples of reflex actions. They were not directed by the observing consciousness. Observing them might train the consciousness to understand reflex speed without going through an emergency experience which is when we're most often aware of our reflexes. We would be provided with many examples of reflex action when we began improvising in contact, but they might be of little use to us, because the consciousness can easily turn off to the experience of these reflexive moments. In other words, we can do something without "knowing" it. This successfully preserves the integrity of the body but does not train the consciousness; it leaves a hole in the knowing of the experience. Could the consciousness learn to see these gaps of awareness? Or, if not, could it at least learn to observe reflexive action calmly during the highly adrenalized moments? Why is fall consciousness so important to me? Because consciousness can be felt to change according to what it experiences. If a gap of consciousness occurs at a critical moment, we lose an opportunity to learn from the moment. A black-out lasting fractions of a second during a roll is not acceptable as full consciousness of the roll, and the gap will remain embedded in the movement as part of the over-all feeling of the movement. If consciousness stays open during these critical moments, it will have an experience of them, and will enlarge its concept to match the new experience. This expanded picture becomes the new ground for moving. _My s_pecuh!tion is that _ the gaps are mo01~n!S_ Vlh~n consciousness goes away. I don't know where. But I think I know why. Something is happening which is too fast for thought. For instance, the navigation of space is normally done with bead erect and visual impressions comfortably constant, with the horizon's horizontality remaining an important reference for our orientation. When this visual reference changes too rapidly for our (rather slow) consciousness to comprehend, as in spinning, rolling, and other "disorienting" movement, something reflexive and much faster than consciousness takes over. We play with this dual aspect of ourselves on carnival rides, or when learning to turn in dance. Dizziness and nausea are, I think, signals that we have reached the borderland between these two aspects of physical control-conscious and reflexive. When we linger in the borderland on purpose, we become our own experiment. We are subjecting the reflexes to stimuli so our consciousness can watch them jump. Normally, consciousness easily slips out, reflexes step in, and then step aside again, as in the blink of an eye where most of the time we are unaware of any gap in our visual continuity. Visual continuity is one of many ways we know "where we are," and not knowing where we are is experienced as an emergency situation. How many times a day, or an hour, do we re-orient, I wonder. At any rate, contact improvisation constantly challenges one's orientation: visual, directional, balance, and where in the body the consciousness is positioned. The challenge to orientation is not just in the more acrobatic aspects of the movement. Students were sometimes made nauseous by noticing their internal space while standing still. This, oddly enough, is probably a form of motionsickness, which bas been described as having a moving deck under one's feet but a steady horizon. In the stand, one experiences still feet and moving consciousness inside the body. In rolling or turning, the room seems (from the point of view of the eyes) to move, while the floor remains stable to the touch. What I bad to do was resolve the problem of orientation so that the consciousness could stay aware of the movement. A chicken and egg problem. Everyone in this group was athletic and many of them were dancers, so presumably their consciousness bad already been informed by body movement. But they weren't being asked to do what they knew bow do to. They were being asked to improvise; to do (or allow themselves to do) what they didn't expect to do. Under these circumstances previously learned movement techniqq.es often hamper rather than help the desired sort of manifestation. Movement techniques are useful for other reasons, of course, but not for examining gaps of consciousness during unexpected movement. Consciousness, supported by a collection of images and internal ob'servations which reinforced each other, had a job. It should not press the body, nor engage in time travel out of the body into memories or schedules because these bring images which will also affect the body, distracting from the improvisation at band. In this improvisation the consciousness was to hang in with the body, during real time, and stay alert. It should be a witness. This sort of consciousness-awareness of the present physical reality-is familiar to all of us. In fact the reason it is useful is that it is commonly understood, though employing it requires choices. Without a process of sorting we are confronted with such a variety of current physical images that we are inundated rather than guided into a practice. As the right kind of images were found, a working model began to emerge in my mind. The working model was based on aspects of an experience that I'd had while working with another person, in which an interesting event occurred and was confirmed by both of us. Moments of the duet, typically manifesting as "accidental" and flowing streams of movement, were for both of us pleasant, highly stimulating, and elemental. With other partners, more confirmations. It was worth pursuing. The working model was predicated on this experience and a desire to articulate the experience so others could find it. If others did find it, we were perhaps examining a basic mode of communication between the reflexes of people in physical contact as they moved. It was an idea which took two people to have. It wasn't wrestling, embracing, sex, social dancing, though it was an element of all of those. It needed a name, so we could refer to it without unwanted connotations. Contact Improvisation   ? To envision the exercises, I took the working model to be a simple imaginary person with no physical, sensorial, or social inhibitions. It was a generic person with positive elements I had observed in many students, dancers, martial artists, and children. I had met such a being in my partners when we were doing "it," the duet phenomenon. I had been such a being to them, apparently,. when they too confirmed the moment. It had to be a fairly simple model, because the users (the students and I) were actually functioning human beings with more possible neuronal connections than there are particles in the universe. I could not cope with that of course, nor other evident human complexities. In terms of the safety of the body in active interaction with another body, though, I saw I could ask the student to concentrate on movement and how it feels, and then suggest concentrating on the sensations of their weight, momentum, friction, the touch of their partner, the sensation of the floor under their body, and to learn to maintain their peripheral vision of the space. The working model had these characteristics and others equally easy to understand These were aimed at security, not at improvising. I recall saying that improvising could not be taught, though it could be learned. But I did think that safety could be taught "Keep your knees over your toes," for instance, is taught to students of dance. With the characteristics of the working model developed and understood by the students, I hoped they would be safe even if they were ass-over-teakettle. I pressed on. I made assumptions. I assumed I could explain things directly to the body ("notice gravity"). I assumed the body knew what I was talking about (gravity, usually ignored, moves into focus as a sensation of weight). I assumed that the body, having evolved for millions of years on this planet, was tuned first by planetary things which create our potentials, and second by cultural things which develop select parts of the potential. This is in line with some current theories about how we acquire language; we are born with potential to make the variety of human sounds and language connections, but are guided into the specific language of our culture, and the unused potential withers with disuse. For the working model, the basic question was-potential for what? What had the culture physically suppressed or selected out which we might reclaim? We may, with a bit of experience of sub-cultures of our own, and other cultures, understand something of what our culture requires of us for inclusion: certain gestures, modes of posture and behavior-body language, as they say-which constitute proper social activities and communications, as well as the accompanying mental attitudes we acquire or aspire to for proper presentation of our 'selves'. Indeed, the very idea of a 'self is probably a cultural construction. In sports and dance the rules of physical behavior are altered from the basic social behaviors to encompass activities understood to be outside the social norm but allowable in a controlled way. These activities require different sensing modes than does the usual body language we must learn for eating in company or attending school. The working model and its characteristics were like sports and dance in that they were altered. However, they depart from one another in how they are learned. Contact Improvisation behavior evolves from sensing movement; dance and sports, from attempting movement and then letting the senses fall into line, or not. "517t+£<~\t;.i'ri..,  'S ? A<..€. As to how we are educated  Not to become too embroiled in this, we may simply note that most of us learn to sit still and focus our attention for hours each day. The missing potential here is obvious movement of the body and varieties of peripheral sensing. Our alterations involved the investigation of space, time, and mass with senses in peripheral sensing mode: space becomes spherical, time is the present, mass is a changeable orientation to gravity. In devising an approach to this working model of the body, I skipped blithely by constraints and taboos of touching, because people are accustomed to ignoring them on the subway, during sports, or in the doctor's office. And I did not emphasize the unpredictable nature of the improvisation, akin to dancing on constantly shifting ground, but suggested instead a steady state of watching the reflexes. Let the reflexes figure out how to deal with the unpredictable. This method aimed to reclaim physical possibilities which may have become dormant, senses we have been trained to disregard. What would this lead to, really? It sounds very nice, this reclaiming and opening, but where would these changes take us? Who would we be? When we began, in 1972, I went boldly into all this. The people in the group were young, healthy, and alert I assumed that if we didn't consciously focus on problems we wouldn't create them, and at least such difficulties as surfaced would not have been projected. As I said earlier, things seemed simpler then. It was to be assumed that some of these students would eventually teach something of what they were doing to others, and I felt the need to develop this material in such a way that the students were aware of the teaching mechanisms. It boiled down to making the principles-physical, mental, and cultural-known to them as they learned them. We had the services of Steve Christiansen and his video camera and spent hours, when we were not working on the mat, examining the movement and ourselves, the movers. · This was very useful. Video was, in those days, a new tool for witnessing the body/mind, and let us see points in action when we were operative but not conscious. Such moments, noticed with the help of the videotape or close observation by a partner, could later be examined in action. Clues about the nature of the gap might be noticed. We began to notice where the gaps appeared, at any rate, and something of their frequency. We also noticed high unfettered moments (and recalled the accompanying feelings). And we observed fettered duets where reflexive movement was not to be seen. Sometimes people seemed wary, unable to let go of conscious control. Disorientation, fear, or fixed habitual responses would be noticed. In the working model, events of the emotions and disorientations which were felt in conjunction with a gap in awareness were considered to be symptomatic that the senses wer~ not ~uite ready to--report what was happening to the consciousness, that instead they were reporting to the reflexive part of the mind and body. I couldn't understand the wary duets. Obviously trust was missing. With some other partner or on some other day, this tended to change. All I could do to cope with this mode was to have partners change regularly. Eventually everyone found a duet which led them to their reflexes. When I proposed movement techniques they sometimes contravened ingrained movement habits: for instance, the aikido roll, which is a diagonally forward roll that arrived on our shores from the Orient. At the very attempt at this roll, students translated it into a somersault, the symmetrical forward roll we learn in Western movement. This misunderstanding could persist through any number of repetitions of examples and attempts and was seriously frustrating to both the students and me. If they couldn't put their finger on what was going wrong, I decided, it was perhaps because nothing in previous movement experience had prepared them for the movement principles which were developed in the Eastern martial arts. These repeated attempts at the aikido roll provided the first gap I noticed. The act of propelling the body into the roll is slightly scary, and many people have open eyes before and after the roll, but in the moment when they are taking weight on their neck and shoulders, they have their eyes squeezed shut, and they are not aware that this is so. I did not solve this two-part problem in time for the first performance, nor for many years after, though the students did perfect their somersaults. I learned that before the body could find the new rolling pattern it was useful for it to learn the sensations which an aikido roll creates. The new sensations, and the parts of the arm, shoulder, and back where the sensations arise in the roll, could be explored without committing the whole body to the roll. This changed the position of the consciousness relative to the exercise. Instead of an unknown action vs. an habitual known action which is so similar that it subverts the attempt, the student has two knowable actions. One is new, tentative, but understood through the sensorial model. The other is habitual. Having remedied the first difficulty by establishing the difference between the two concepts of rolling, the gaps of consciousness in either could be ferreted out. These explorations evolved into new technical approaches. It was noticeable that the approaches require that the student workwith helpfolmental attitudes as-wellas-directly with the physical body. In the aikido roll example above, it was less helpful to know the pattern mentally and try willfully to do it than it was to become an observer of the sensations and to work calmly on each emotional, orientational, or habitual block as it arose. The quality of consciousness was coming into focus. It. wasn't all of consciousness and all possible interactions, of course. A working model for consciousness in this case is Swiss cheese. We buy it as a lump, and don't attend to the holes because we don't use them. I was trying to point to the holes, assuming that if a Swiss cheese could be aware of itself, then the cheesy part was one sort of consciousness and the holes were another sort, integral to the shape, the nature of the whole cheese. We can't take this model much further, I realize; which may be to the advantage of getting on with the movement and its interaction with the consciousness. As we began work on opening up the senses to their larger potential, it became clear that each of the senses has images of differing natures. The Swiss cheese above, mostly a visual image in that I am concentrating on how the cheese looks, occurred in my brain and was transferred to another person by my voice, so it was a verbal transmission of a visual image. What was most needed in our work was kinetic imagery which was both appropriate to the movement mode and true (unlike the speculation about the consciousness of the cheese). The small movements of standing "still," which formed the basis of this sort of investigation, are true; they are really there. But are they images or sensations? Title: for John Cage
Abstract: This short piece is dedicated to John Cage, likely reflecting on his influence on improvisation and performance.

As we began work on opening up the senses to their larger potential, it became clear that each of the senses has images of differing natures. The Swiss cheese above, mostly a visual image in that I am concentrating on how the cheese looks, occurred in my brain and was transferred to another person by my voice, so it was a verbal transmission of a visual image. What was most needed in our work was kinetic imagery which was both appropriate to the movement mode and true (unlike the speculation about the consciousness of the cheese). The small movements of standing "still," which formed the basis of this sort of investigation, are true; they are really there. But are they images or sensations? If we observed them, would they filter through the observing mind and affect CQ/CI Sourcebook 259 the body as images do? Does the nervous system and its mediation of posture relative to gravity have the possibility of teaching the consciousness, and does the consciousness have the property of amplifying or strengthening that mediation? I assumed this reciprocity did exist I decided that sensations are what we feel to be happening at the moment, and they can become images when we take notice that we are observing them. This suggests that the consciousness can be aware of itself-a defining characteristic-and that there is a positive use for this ability to split into self-regard. However, consciousness doesn't work very well with the unknown, as was revealed in the aikido roll. It seems to need to know or to be noticing in order to direct itself and the body. The attitude of "witnessing" may change this internal control issue. The search for internal sensations reveals that "I can feel the small movements." Then our attitude begins to shift toward, "The body is kept upright by constant reflexive muscular actions around the skeleton." First we feel the movements, then we can objectify the feelings into images. The moment between these perceptions can be as short as a hyphen. All the above suggests that there is an important difference between knowing-noticing and noticing-knowing. These are the sorts of thoughts which came to mind during the working period from January to June, 1972. Or to say it in terms of the work: from Magnesium at Oberlin College through the spring term at Bennington College where we further identified the premise, the phenomenon, to the presentation of the work in NYC I called "contact improvisations." Students from those two institutions (plus members of the downtown dance community in NYC who "sat in") were joined by students from the classes of Mary Fulkerson at the U. or' Rochester. The Rochester group was least familiar with the proposed movement, and as Fulkerson was teaching them Release Technique via intensive image work, it was in order to reach these students quickly that the approach outlined above was developed beyond what had been necessary at Bennington College. At Bennington, I had begun by introducing these students of Western dance to Aikido techniques. However, I soon abandoned teaching Aikido and started work on specific tools for the interior techniques. Although physical techniques could be found for specific movement training, what those students required was a vision of Eastern martial arts philosophy underlying the techniques (or a viable replacement for that). This laid the ground for introducing an improvisation which requires a state of personal involvement and physical responsibility with/for another person. 260 CQ/CI Saurcebook It must be pointed out that many of the ideas about moving which I used existed before this study. The teachings of Release Technique, Aikido, and several other physical and mental disciplines were influential, and were adjusted according to my understanding at the time in order to convey the movement principles of the area of improvisation described by the words contact improvisation. Beyond that, to enable the movement to be accomplished safely, came physical exercises designed to introduce sensations that arise during "flying," lifting, and being lifted. and to physically strengthen the body for these energetic extremes of the form. Physical strength was seen as the result of finding the right, i.e., easiest, most efficient inner "pathways." Stress was discouraged. We were starting to work on the technical method, a work which continues today, in an effort to describe what Contact Improvisation is on its own terms as a phenomenon of duet movement as well as in the personal terms of a student, who may for instance have physical strength but spatial weakness, or improvisational skills but does not trust their weight to another person. To summarize: images were used to focus the mind and then give the mind foci within the sensations of the body. The words had to be unambiguous, unthreatening, informative and generally understood. The statements had to be true, obvious, relevant. To speak was a.lso to ~ettheton(!. I trieci to simplify the issues of the body for transmission to another body. I moved the mind of my mouth into my body, located issues, and reported the issues speaking (I assumed) directly to another body. The student's consciousness was enlisted to manage attitudes and observe the effect of image on the body, and to derive from these effects, and others observed within their bodies, images which could be named and otherwise objectified and discussed, and fitted into the improvisational structure. I made a number of assumptions. To study something like improvisation, which is defined as you go, everything you assume is going to affect the result I tried to be aware of what the assumptions were and to let the phenomenon we explored, the narrower field of improvisation when communicating via touch with another person, guide the definitive imagery into appropriate areas. This guidance caused us to consider all sorts of things, such as communication, emotion, psychology, sex, education, childhood development, culture, taboos, space, time, and the self. It is all very well to say that one takes responsibility for one's self in improvisation, but it is indeed a staggering job in its details. An improvisor's job is never done. All this to explore the ability of the consciousness to cleave to the body's moment and remain there as the moment changes.*
